title: Plant species list
abstract: "Sammelarten" sind durch   agg= Aggregate oder total gekennzeichnet. Sie umfassen jene Taxa, die teilweise bis zur Kleinart, Subspecies oder Varietas bestimmt wurden, teilweise aber auch nur auf Gattungs- (... spec. (indet.)) oder Artebene. Diese sind deshalb nochmals, inclusive der unsicher Bestimmten (cf.-data), für sämtliche Aufnahmen zusammengefasst. Phanerogamen, die in verschiedenen Schichten vorkamen (juv. = juvenil, .B = Baumschicht [> 5 m], .S = Strauchschicht [verholzt bis 5 m]) sind ebenfalls nocheinmal zusammengefasst.  Die zusammengefassten Sippen aus den Einzelaufnahmen sind noch in der Tabelle enthalten und unter der "Sammelart" mit einem * markiert.

title: Vegetation Cover of Understory Plants, Structure 2008
abstract: These data show the variation of vascular understory plant species within forest EPs based on their cover values in seven subplots per EP. The idea behind sampling randomly spread subplots is that plant diversity of the understory is strongly affected by the canopy properties and gaps vertically above the subplots. Hence by sampling seven subplots we intend to find most of the plant species being present within a 1 ha EP because we account for a whole gradient in typical light conditions for each EP. Consequently, we can assess the response of vegetation to the fine-scale conditions in available light or micro-topography but additionally we also increase the likelihood of sampling all understory species occurring in an EP.

title: Pollen analysis (2007)
abstract: Christiane Weiner has collected data on pollen quality of different flower species in 2007 as a pilot study for further analysis on pollen quality, e.g. in dependence of fertilisation and land use types. Pollen is the primary source of protein in the larval diet of bees and also very important in the diet of some other flower visiting insects. While some insects are restricted to visiting only one or few plant species, others collect or feed on pollen and nectar from a broad spectrum of plants. We are interested in the following questions: Do oligolectic and oligophagous insects choose certain plants because these plants contain more essential amino acids or provide pollen with a higher homogeneity of those components?Do polylectic and polyphagous insects combine different plant species in a way they are able to gain a complemented and balanced diet?Do different land use types offer a significantly different resource quality?In future the resource quality of a plot shall be assessable by its actual flower composition and the amino acid quality connected to it. For most flowering plant species we will be able to determine the pollen amino acid composition per flower/flowering unit (e.g. in Asteraceae). By counting all flowering units per plant species on a plot, we can extrapolate its resource quality (=qualitative and quantitative amino acid composition).

title: Butterflies 2008
abstract: Specialisation, abundance and diversity of flower visitors is compared across grasslands along a gradient of land use intensity. We focus on resource-based mechanisms that may determine flower visiting insect communities in different habitats. We will analyze flower visitor rates of pollinators in order to measure possible variation between differently used sites. Moreover, we will characterize the degree of specialisation on species and community level (pollinator networks; Blüthgen et al. 2007)

title: Vegetation complexity around Plantago lanceolata and host plant structure: plant level, 2008, 1st round
abstract: In grasslands, intensive mowing, heavy grazing, and fertilization represent major negative impacts for plant species richness. However, little is known about how intensification in land use influences the performance of species at higher trophic levels, apart from simply reducing species numbers. Here we investigate the impact of land use on all levels of a tritrophic system, and on the surrounding vegetation. The targeted plant, Plantago lanceolata L. (Plantaginaceae), was chosen because it is widespread throughout Germany, and occurs under different land use intensities.

title: Vegetation structure around Plantago lanceolata and host plant structure: plant level, 2008, 2nd round
abstract: In grasslands, intensive mowing, heavy grazing, and fertilization represent major negative impacts for plant species richness. However, little is known about how intensification in land use influences the performance of species at higher trophic levels, apart from simply reducing species numbers. Here we investigate the impact of land use on all levels of a tritrophic system, and on the surrounding vegetation. The targeted plant, Plantago lanceolata L. We focus on resource-based mechanisms that may determine flower visiting insect communities in different habitats. We analyze flower diversity and abundance as well as pollinator diversity and abundance and flower visiting rates of pollinators in order to measure possible variation between differently used sites. Moreover, we will characterize the degree of specialisation on species and community level (pollinator networks; Blüthgen et al. 2007).

title: Plotchart generation example script
abstract:
The code shows how to render a plotcart with R.
Plotcharts are the central source for the management of the plots. They depict the research locations of any sub-project on all experimental plots, comprising the VIPs. There are templates by landusetype and EP/VIP. These are then individually enhanced online by researchers who adjust their sub-plot locations in order to reflect reality. Please note that only a restricted number of LMT members are allowed to edit plotchart online. R is used as the rendering machine. BExIS employs a service with RServe as a backbone; but the underlying code is based on the supplied R-codes.

title: Core model for stage-structured matrix population models of grassland plants
abstract: A series of matrix population models with increasing realism and model complexity is built in order to investigate the impact of functional traits on plant demography in fragmented landscapes: 1) non-spatial and deterministic models, 2) non-spatial and stochastic models, 3) spatially-explicit and deterministic models, 4) spatially-explicit and stochastic models, 5) spatially-explicit and stochastic community models. All these models are built using this core model as basis. The core model includes:a)Classes for annual, biennial and perennial species and a function which creates a species pool of given functional diversityb)Classes for landscapes and landscape-creating functions.c)Classes for transition matrizes and building blocks and functions providing the set-up.

title: Stochastic model for local, stage-structured populations of grassland plants
abstract: In order to cope with environmental stochasticity plants developed different bet-hedging strategies. As land-use impacts on local environmental stochasticity, preadaptation of species can be used to predict species´ vulnerability to increasing land-use intensity.

title: Galls on Beech Trees in Hainich, 2008
abstract:
Hypersensitive reactions (HR) are regarded as one of the most important induced defense mechanisms and most effective bottom-up effects in multitrophic food-webs (Cornelissen and Fernandes, 2001; Fernandes, 1998; Fernandes and Negreiros, 2001). Plant genetics and physiological properties are generally considered to constitute the main factors influencing degree and frequency of HR against galling insects (Fernandes et al., 2003; Fernandes and Negreiros, 2001). Physiological plant properties are probably influenced by abiotic site conditions (soil, climate) (Fernandes et al., 2003), but also by other abiotic and biotic habitat characteristics as canopy openings or occurrence of other tree species, which depend on forest management intensity (Collet et al., 2001; Dittmar et al., 2003; Lof et al., 2005; Marusak and Barna, 2002). 
The frequency, diversity and community structure of herbivores and parasitoids is expected to differ in dependence of several habitat characteristics induced by forest management as well (Gossner et al., 2006) and may influence the frequency and efficiency of HR of the host plant, bur are otherwise dependent from the host plant quality (Fonseca et al., 2006).  
To reveal possible effects of forest use intensity on three-trophic-level interactions, the frequency and density of the most abundant galling insects on Fagus sylvatica (Mikiola fagi and Hartigiola annulipes, Cecidomyiidae) will be recorded on approximately 60 selected trees on plots characterized by clearly different forest management intensities in the exploratory Hainich/Dün. Recording of hypersensitive reactions to gall induction (Fernandes et al., 2003) and predators and parasitoids of M. fagi and H. annulipes (Dziurznski, 1961) will enable the analysis of the interplay of bottom-up  and top-down effects in this system in dependence from the forest use intensity. The relation of hypersensitive reactions (bottom-up effect) to living gall-inducers leads to an estimation of the relevance of forest use management for the susceptibility of European beech to galling insects. These investigations lead to an estimation of the possible indicative value of easily recordable plant structures as galls and HP sites for beech susceptibility or restistance.

title: forest landscape metrics, ALB forest plots, 2009
abstract:
Regional digital forest management maps ("Forsteinrichtungsdaten") provide detailed information on tree composition, stand age, and management type on the stand level readily available to forest managers. 
The "Forsteinrichtungsdaten" of the Schwäbische Alb with information was obtained from regional authorities (Regierungspräsidium Tübingen, Fogis 2006). The digital maps accurately described at least 90 % of forest stands, based on our experience with field inventories (Biodiversity Exploratories project, unpublished).
We categorized forest stand compositions based on the dominant overstory trees beech and spruce with a threshold level of 70 % of dominant trees into six deciduous and conifer stand compositions: beech, beech-mixed, mixed-deciduous spruce, spruce-mixed and mixed-coniferous. Stand age was considered for the oldest tree layer within stands.
For forest landscape metrics around experimental plots, we primarily extracted the number of patches as given by the distinct forest stands, mean stand sizes, mean perimeter/area ratios, the number of different stand compositions (patch richness with/and without distinguishing stand age) at 20 radial spatial extents (buffers) between 100 and 2,000 meters centred at each experimental plot using ArcView 3.2 and ArcGIS 9.1 (ESRI, Redlands, California). We further calculated  three Shannon-Indices (base = exp(1)) based on a) the number of different forest stand types, b) number of different forest stand types considering forest age and c) the aerial extent of different forest stand types for describing forest landscape compositional heterogeneity.
Note that the spatial extent (buffer sizes ranging from 100-2000m) is included in the title of variables (e.g, "CAP.Forest.100buff" is a variable at a spatial extent of 100 m radii around experimental plots, whereas "CAP.Forest.2000buff" refers to a buffer width of 2000 m for the same variable). Note further that variables are not yet scaled/ standardized which is recommendable for most kind of analysis.

For a reference of data usage see the following paper: Wells, K., Böhm, S.M., Boch, S., Fischer, M. & Kalko, E.K.V. (2011) Local and landscape-scale forest attributes differ in their impact on bird assemblages across years in forest production landscapes. Basic and Applied Ecology, 12, 97-106

title: Plant diversity (SCH, 2008)(2nd round)
abstract: In grasslands, intensive mowing, heavy grazing, and fertilization represent major negative impacts for plant species richness. However, little is known about how intensification in land use influences the performance of species at higher trophic levels, apart from simply reducing species numbers. Here we investigate the impact of land use on all levels of a tritrophic system, and on the surrounding vegetation. The targeted plant, Plantago lanceolata L. (Plantaginaceae), was chosen because it is widespread throughout Germany, and occurs under different land use intensities. In this dataset you will find the data for forb species abundance in the surrounding of P. lanceolata in late summer.

title: Litter removal in forests (2008-2009)
abstract: Bryophyte species number is dependent on micro sites and diversity of micro sites.Unmanaged forests show a low level of soil disturbances caused by tree harvesting and tree logging. Therefore, characteristic species for such open soil patches are absent on these forests.We investigate the effect of small scale disturbance by removing of the litter layer and the succession of bryophytes in different forest types in 3 different landscapes.

title: Aphid-endophytic fungi interaction experiment (2009)
abstract: 40 plots selected in two region of intensive and extensive landuse intensity. Two intensively used grasslands lost in the Swabian Alb due to vandalism. On each plot, we installed four pots with the  host grass Lolium perenne. Two grass pots on each plot were infected with endophyte fungi Neotyphodium lolii and two were uninfected. On each pot we put 50 aphids and counted the number of aphids every second week. On two pots (one infected, one unnfected) predators were excluded and had free access on the remaining two pots. We also counted the predators on the pots.

title: Flower-visiting insect intercations in grasslands, 2008
abstract: Specialisation of flower visitors is compared across grasslands along a gradient of land use intensity. We focus on resource-based mechanisms that may determine flower visiting insect communities in different habitats. We analyze flower visiting rates of pollinators in order to measure possible variation between differently used sites. Moreover, we characterize the degree of specialisation on species and community level (pollinator networks; Blüthgen et al. 2007).

title: Disturbance experiment on plant biodiversity and productivity (2009, all grassland plots)
abstract: The aim of this experiment is to test the influence of disturbance on plant biodiversity and productivity. For that purpose a split plot design was made up, which defines 8 subplots of different treatments within each of the 150 grass land plots in all three exploratories. As the disturbance tool a soil auger was used according to simulate the soil overthrow of a mole. The 8 subplots were treated differently in intensity (4 or 8 disturbances) and differently in frequency (spring, autumn or both). Two subplots remained untreated and were used as controls. The first disturbance treatment was done in May 2008, the second in September/October in the same year. In March/April 2009 a third treatment was examined shortly before the first vegetation relevè.

title: BioComp plant biomass nutrients in grasslands (wet chemistry)(2009)
abstract: The assessment of biomass production, chemical constituents and functional composition of grassland canopies is of crucial importance for the disentangling of biodiversity patterns. Generally, such essential data are rarely available for a high number of spatial and temporal replications. We will provide such data in a very efficient and cost effective way using near infrared spectroscopy (NIRS). Based on laboratory standard analyses of biomass samples, calibration models will be developed for the quick and cheap measurement of plant tissue constituents. For calibration, biomass samples of the 150 experimental plots of the three exploratories will be used. Initially, calibration models for the carbon content and the main plant nutrients (N, P, K) will be developed. Furthermore, the NIRS technique will be applied to assess the functional composition of grassland vegetation as well as to quantify various fractions of fibre such as cellulose and lignin.

abstract:
We tested the hypotheses that:
1. Land use intensity (LUI) and vegetation composition (plant species richness and P. lanceolata density) affect N and IG (aucubin and catalpol) leaf contents of P. lanceolata.
2. Plant chemistry changes impact the abundances of the herbivores Mecinus pascuorum and Mecinus labilis, and of the parasitoid Mesopolobus incultus.

title: Bryophytes, fungi and lichens on dead wood (2008)
abstract:
Decaying dead wood is among the most important factors for forest biodiversity. It supports habitats for animals, fungi and plants.  
Our questions are: 
1. How affect the forest management cryptogam communities on dead wood?
2. How are diversities of fungi and bryophytes related?
3. Which preferences have these species groups, considering dead wood decay stages?

title: InsectScale - Land Use Mapping (2009)
abstract: The aim of this sub-project is to quantify regional land use types  within the Biodiversity Exploratories, so that the effects of landscape composition and configuration and scale-dependency of biodiversity patterns, biotic interactions and ecosystem functioning can be analysed.

title: Disturbance experiment on plant biodiversity and productivity - Bryophytes in disturbance plots (2009, grassland)
abstract: This experiment is a subproject of the disturbance experiment (see data set 10204) The aim of this experiment is to test the relationships between additional soil disturbances and plant diversity and productivity. For this we designed a split plot design, which defines subplots of different treatments within each of the grassland experimental plots in the exploratories. For the disturbances we used a hand operated post hole auger, that we drilled randomly in soil 4 or 8 times per sub plot and at different seasons (spring or fall or both). Control plots remained untreated. The continuously marked subplots had a size of 1.5 m x 2m. We started the experiment in spring 2008.

title: Historical land cover (1820) GP Alb
abstract: Historical cadastral maps serve as an invaluable source of geospatial information on land use change and history. While first cartographic work and land surveys were sporadically conducted in SW Germany in the 17th and 18th century, a major development in land survey were the state-wide land survey and mapping conducted between 1820 and 1840. This land survey comprised the first detailed survey of field parcels and mapping of land use at the scale of 1: 2,500 based on trigonometric measurements. Cadastral maps serve as a basis for topographical land survey and planning till this day, and comprise spatial units at which land use and management take place in historical and recent time layers in a cultural landscape. They thus provide a historical background on present-day patterns of land cover and, presumably, also biodiversity.

title: Fertilization experiment - vegetation complexity around Plantago lanceolata: plant level (2009,2010, ALB, HAI, SCH)
abstract: Fertilization experiment. Fertilization may affect herbivore abundance directly via altered host plant quality and availability and indirectly via increased structural complexity and plant species diversity. Interacting effects of features of the vegetation with host–parasitoid systems could further alter more complex interactions in a multi- trophic context of bottom–up and top–down effects. Here data are given of the effect of fertilization on vegetation complexity (vegetation structure and diversity) around a host plant (here: Plantago lanceolata)

title: Vegetation complexity around Plantago lanceolata, host plant structure and insect abundance: Plot matrix, 2008, 1st round
abstract: In grasslands, intensive mowing, heavy grazing, and fertilization represent major negative impacts for plant species richness. However, little is known about how intensification in land use influences the performance of species at higher trophic levels, apart from simply reducing species numbers. Here we investigate the impact of land use on all levels of a tritrophic system, and on the surrounding vegetation. The targeted plant, Plantago lanceolata L. (Plantaginaceae), was chosen because it is widespread throughout Germany, and occurs under different land use intensities.

title: Abundance of deadwood beetles (order level) on different forest plots, 2009
abstract:
Canopy research is a topic that has long been neglected in temperate latitudes - in contrast to the tropical rainforests, where work in this area is already more advanced.  The reason for this, apart from the generally difficult accessibility of treetops, is the general view that all arthropod species occurring there can also be caught with traps close to the ground. Nevertheless, for some years now, research into arthropod communities living in treetops has also been intensified in temperate forests. 
Deadwood harbours a diverse community of saproxylic beetles but has become rare as a result of intensive forest management. The lack of this key-resource has yet largely unmeasured consequences for the distribution of saproxylic species, their overall abundance and guild composition. 
In order to investigate these effects we established a large field experiment by enriching freshly cut beech and spruce deadwood of different size in the canopy and on the ground beneath beech and spruce trees in age-class and extensively managed forests on 23 forest plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. Flight Interception Traps (FITs) were used to collect attracted arthropods. Sampling was performed monthly from May to October 2009.

title: Soil physical and chemical properties of grassland VIPs in ALB, SCALEMIC 2008
abstract:
This study will clarify the spatial distribution of soil bacteria, genetic structure of bacterial
populations and their functions at grassland plots with different land-use intensity (low, intermediate and high). The focus will be on C- and N-cycling as key processes in terrestrial ecosystems. All samples are taken in April 2008 from the top horizon (0-10 cm) of the nine grassland VIP (AEG 1 – AEG 9) of the exploratory “Schwäbische Alb”.

title: Abundance of deadwood beetles on different forest plots in the Schwäbische Alb, 2009
abstract:
Canopy research is a topic that has long been neglected in temperate latitudes - in contrast to the tropical rainforests, where work in this area is already more advanced.  The reason for this, apart from the generally difficult accessibility of treetops, is the general view that all arthropod species occurring there can also be caught with traps close to the ground. Nevertheless, for some years now, research into arthropod communities living in treetops has also been intensified in temperate forests. 
Deadwood harbours a diverse community of saproxylic beetles but has become rare as a result of intensive forest management. The lack of this key-resource has yet largely unmeasured consequences for the distribution of saproxylic species, their overall abundance and guild composition. 
In order to investigate these effects we established a large field experiment by enriching freshly cut beech and spruce deadwood of different size in the canopy and on the ground beneath beech and spruce trees in age-class and extensively managed forests on 12 forest plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. Flight Interception Traps (FITs) were used to collect attracted arthropods. Sampling was performed monthly from April to September 2009.

title: Ectomycorrhiza species on HEW10 and HEW6
abstract: Ein Ziel dieser Studie war es die Verteilung der Wurzeln einzelner Baumindividuen in einem Buchenreinbestand zu untersuchen. Außerdem sollte untersucht werden, ob der Genotyp der verschiedenen Buchenindividuen Einfluss auf die Zusammensetzung der  Mykorrhizagesellschaft hat, bzw. ob bestimmte Pilzarten bestimmte Individuen als Wirt bevorzugen. Dafür wurden Bodenproben in einem Naturwald (HEW10) und in einem Wirtschaftswald (HEW6) genommen.

title: Ectomycorrhiza species in a soil exchange experiment
abstract: Die Zusammensetzung der Ektomykorrhizagesellschaft in Buchenreinbeständen kann sehr unterschiedlich sein. Die vorkommende Baumarten spielen eine wichtige Rolle, aber sie können nicht der einzige Faktor sein, sont wurde i allen Buchenreinbeständen die gleiche Ektmykorrhizagesellschaft vorkommen. Andere Faktoren wie Bodentyp, Nährstoffe, pH, Bodenfeuchte spielen wahrscheinlich auch eine große Rolle.

title: BioComp plant biomass nutrients in grasslands (2010)
abstract: The assessment of biomass production, chemical constituents and functional composition of grassland canopies is of crucial importance for the disentangling of biodiversity patterns. Generally, such essential data are rarely available for a high number of spatial and temporal replications. We will provide such data in a very efficient and cost effective way using near infrared spectroscopy (NIRS). Based on laboratory standard analyses of biomass samples, calibration models will be developed for the quick and cheap measurement of plant tissue constituents. For calibration, biomass samples of the 150 experimental plots of the three exploratories will be used. Initially, calibration models for the carbon content and the main plant nutrients (N, P, K) will be developed. Furthermore, the NIRS technique will be applied to assess the functional composition of grassland vegetation as well as to quantify various fractions of fibre such as cellulose and lignin.

title: Simpson´s diversity of Coleoptera and Heteroptera
abstract: It has frequently been shown that grassland management practices such as mowing or grazing alter vegetation structure, microclimate and nutrient content of both plants and soils. If plant species richness is hypothesized to decline under intensive management, then this may have profound  consequences also for primary consumers and higher trophic levels.

title: Study on the background colour on flowers - observed colour
abstract: In our study we investigate the influence of background colour on the flower choice of insects. Floral colouration is known to be central in plant-pollinator interactions. The surrounding floral display can influence the flower choice of insect visitors and thereby affect pollination of a flower via competition or facilitation effects. Because we found a shift from yellow to white flower colours with increasing land use intensity in previous studies (Binkenstein et al. submitted), we focused this study on white and yellow flowering plants.

title: Soil living insect larvae in grasslands (2009 & 2010)
abstract: Differences in plant diversity and soil nutrient levels brought by gradients in land use intensity are likely to influence the abundance and diversity of soil living insect larvae. Insect larvae, especially root feeders, on the other hand can feed back, either directly or in interaction with other soil organisms, on the productivity and diversity of grasslands. Therefore, knowledge on their abundance, distribution and diversity is crucial for a general understanding of their impact on plant communities and for developing management tools for grasslands.

title: Removel and consumption of seed by different animal groups in forest plots, 2009
abstract: We assessed the contribution of different animal groups to the removal and elaiosome consumption of experimentally exposed seeds of two forest myrmecochores, the wood anemone (Anemone nemorosa) and European wild ginger (Asarum europaeum) by differentially excluding rodents, gastropods, and insects in forests dominated by European beech (Fagus sylvatica) under different management. The seed removal experiment was carried out in three regions (1) the UNESCO Biosphere Reserve Schorfheide-Chorin in northeastern Germany (NE region) (13°76’ E/ 53°00’ N), (2) the National Park Hainich and its surrounding areas (Hainich-Dün) in central Germany (Central region) (10°47’ E/ 51°15’ N), and (3) the UNESCO Biosphere Area Schwäbische Alb (Swabian Jura) in southwestern Germany (SW region) (9°39’ E/ 48°43’ N) and in 47 plots representing different forest management types in each region.

title: Myrmecochores, ants and gastropods in European beech forest (2009, all exploratories)
abstract: In Central Europe a diverse community of myrmecochores can be found in forests dominated by European beech (Fagus sylvatica L.), whereas ants can be rare and of low species diversity compared with other forest habitats. This suggests that seed dispersal of myrmecochores in European beech forests may well be ant-limited. In a recent study, however, slugs were identified as seed dispersers of myrmecochores in a Central European beech forest. We tested the hypothesis that myrmecochore abundance is positively related to the abundance of gastropods rather than to the abundance of ants in beech forest sites of varying management types.

title: Evaluation of arthropods exclusion methods with video recording in field, 2010
abstract:
We applied four treatments for allowing only certain animal groups access to experimental seed depots as described by Türke et al. (2010): (1) all animals had access (control); (2) only rodents and insects had access; (3) only gastropods and insects had access; and (4) only insects had access. 
Differential effectiveness of the animal exclusion techniques were confirmed in preliminary experiments (Appendixes S5–S8 in Türke et al. 2010 Oecologia 163:681-693). We used video recordings to further evaluate the influence of exclusion methods on arthropods in the field (8 day observations in an unmanaged beech forest (Hainich National Park) in July/August 2010).

title: Evaluation of ant exclusion methods with video recording in laboratory, 2010
abstract:
We applied four treatments for allowing only certain animal groups access to experimental seed depots as described by Türke et al. (2010): (1) all animals had access (control); (2) only rodents and insects had access; (3) only gastropods and insects had access; and (4) only insects had access. 
Differential effectiveness of the animal exclusion techniques were confirmed in preliminary experiments (Appendixes S5–S8 in Türke et al. 2010 Oecologia 163:681-693). We used video recordings to further evaluate the influence of depots with access to rodents and insects (gastropod exclusion) on ants in the laboratory (48 h in August 2010).

title: Ectomycorrhiza Trenches Experiment  (2011 - 2012)
abstract: Forest utilization by removal of trees leaves fine roots behind that may have spread far away from the location of the stem. We suppose that the degrading roots release nutrients such as amino acids or other compounds which in turn may be used by EMF, thereby generating additional niches. To investigate this idea, we conducted a soil trenching experiment.

title: Plot selection (BERICH, 2012 - 2013)
abstract: The overarching objective of this project is to understand assembly rules of the grassland communities in the Biodiversity Exploratories. Our principal experimental approach is enrichment planting, using different species additions to test for community saturation, to evaluate predictions based on the co-occurrence information in the GVRD, to analyse whether the community is characterized by trait similarity or dissimilarity and whether the latter reflects prevailing environmental filters or niche complementarity. Our study will include the three main different land use types (meadow, pasture, mown pasture) in all three Exploratories.

title: Soil carbon and nitrogen concentrations - soil sampling campaign 2011, all experimental plots (EPs), 0-10 cm
abstract:
The core project Soil provides essential information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all 301 Experimental Plots (EPs) of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the organic carbon (OC), inorganic carbon (IC) and nitrogen (TN) concentrations and carbon to nitrogen ratios (CN ratio) in 0-10 cm depth from all EPs in 2021. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil organic carbon and nitrogen concentrations are master variables in soil science. Soil organic carbon and nitrogen are the measureable components of soil organic matter (SOM). SOM exerts positive effects on numerous physical, chemical and biological soil properties. An increase in SOM generally results in an improved soil structure, soil moisture retention, soil buffering capacity, retention of pollutants, cycling and storage of plant nutrients and biodiversity. SOM also acts as a sink and source for atmospheric carbon dioxide.

The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-1, TR 1054/4-1, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Soil pH - soil sampling campaign 2011, all experimental plots (EPs), 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the soil pH values in 0-10 cm depth from all experimental plots (EPs) in 2011. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil pH is considered a master variable in soil science as it affects many chemical processes in soils. Most importantly, the plant nutrient availability is greatly affected by the soil pH as it controls the chemical forms of the different nutrients and influences the chemical reactions they undergo. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-1, TR 1054/4-1, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Quantitative genetic traits of Bromus hordeaceus at 49 grassland EPs, 2009/2010
abstract: The aim of our study was to test how differences in land use generate genetic differences among populations across multiple regions and grassland species, and thus to assess how common and how consistent evolutionary responses to land use are in grassland plants, which land-use factors contribute most to genetic differentiation, and which plant traits are most responsive.

abstract: This study will clarify the spatial distribution of soil bacteria, genetic structure of bacterial populations and their functions at grassland plots with different land-use intensity (low, intermediate and high). All samples are taken in April 2008 from the top horizon (0-10 cm) of the nine grassland VIP (HEG 1 – HEG 9) of the exploratory “Hainich-Dün”.

title: Study on the background colour of flowers - number of flowers
abstract: In our study we investigate the visual signal diversity in flowering plant communities. Floral colouration is known to be central in plant-pollinator interactions. To date, it is still unknown whether land use affects the colouration of flowering plant communities. To assess whether different land-use practices generate different flower colour diversity in plant communities, we collected data on flower numbers and flower colours of all flowering plant species on the study plots.

title: Flower visitor interactions 2008 - only pollinators
abstract: Specialisation of flower visitors is compared across grasslands along a gradient of land use intensity. We focus on resource-based mechanisms that may determine flower visiting insect communities in different habitats. We analyze flower visiting rates of pollinators in order to measure possible variation between differently used sites. Moreover, we characterize the degree of specialisation on species and community level (pollinator networks; Blüthgen et al. 2007).

title: Land Use Intensity on Nitrate Reducer Diversity (PROLINKS)
abstract:
Soils under contrasting land-use harbor phylogenetically similar biomes of methylotrophic and denitrifying prokaryotes. These exhibit differential abundances and activities due to the in situ conditions. To test this hypothesis we investigate
a) the impact of land-use on denitrification and methylotrophy
b) the impact of land-use on abundance and diversity of methylotrophs and denitrifiers

title: Olfactometer data of Mecinus pascuorum, laboratory experiment, 2009
abstract: The olfactory orientation of an herbivore to its host plant may be changed when plant diversity is enhanced in the surrounding of the host plant. Research on the effects of plant diversity on insects has focused primarily on crop plants and the orientation behaviour of insect pest species. However, agricultural systems do not function like natural ecosystems where members of a food web may adapt to each other in the course of evolution. So far, only a few studies have focused on odour-mediated interactions between non- crop plant species and members of higher trophic levels.

title: Olfactometer assays of Mesopolobus incultus, laboratory experiments, 2010
abstract:
The olfactory orientation of parasitoids to its host may be changed when plant diversity is enhanced in the surrounding of the host plant. Research on the effects of plant diversity on insects has focused primarily on crop plants and the orientation behaviour of insect pest species. However, agricultural systems do not function like natural ecosystems where members of a food web may adapt to each other in the course of evolution. So far, only a few studies have focused on odour-mediated interactions between non- crop plant species and members of higher trophic levels. 
We tested (i) whether the parasitoid Mesopolobus incultus is attracted by odours from the host complex (host plant Plantago lanceolata plus weevil Mecinus pascuorum) and (ii) how olfactory orientation of the parasitoid is affected by the presence of odour from non-host plants.

title: Assembled taxonomic information with focus on species based on several project datasets
abstract:
This dataset contains assembled data from several datasets from several Biodiversity Exploratories (BE) projects. In BExIS data is uploaded in quite different formats and syntaxes. Therefore taxonomic information is available in different ways. The data management team of the BE compiles these information in a single datasets with a standardized data structure. To achieve this, the data management team identifies datasets with taxonomic information, extracts the data, and stores it in a table in the database. Furthermore the taxonomic names used by the several scientists in their datasets were adapted to a standardized naming by using taxonomic information systems. The overall result is a species-plot-dataset relation.

At the moment access to this assembled data is given to the land management teams to support their work, especially regarding stakeholders. Furthermore the data is used to fulfill the requirement of reporting taxonomic information to local conversation authorities.

The objective of the project is to relate plant community structure and plant trait distributions to the abundance of root herbivores, which was sampled following the recording of vegetation.

title: AMFroot: Presence-absence of AMF virtual taxae in plant roots: PRELIMINARY data
abstract: Effects of land use and plant traits on phylogenetic clustering in AM fungal communities

title: Small scale distribution of insect larvae in 28 grassland EPs, 2011
abstract: The currently observed general decline in biodiversity is closely related to local and global changes in land use. Land use intensity influences site heterogeneity which is a major driver of niche differentiation, species coexistence, and biodiversity. Insect root herbivores can have pronounced impacts on plant productivity and diversity. We assume that by affecting soil heterogeneity and plant diversity, land use intensity influences the spatial distribution of insect root herbivores with feedback on the structure and diversity of grassland plant communities.

title: Nitrification-denitrification dynamics at high and low water contents upon nitrate addition
abstract: This study investigates the dynamics of nitrification and denitrification processes influenced by different oxygen levels (adjusted via different water contents: 50% and 80% of WHKmax). Plots of different land-use intensites were chosen to investigate the influence of land-use intensities and fertilization on denitrification and nitrification. The dynamics were investigated at different timepoints (T0, T1 after 24h, T2 after 48h, T3 after 144h) to monitor changes in the investigated processes over time upon nitrate addition.

title: Nitrification-denitrification dynamics at high and low water contents upon ammonium addition
abstract: This study investigates the dynamics of nitrification and denitrification processes influenced by different oxygen levels (adjusted via different water contents: 50% and 80% of WHKmax). Plots of different land-use intensites were chosen to investigate the influence of land-use intensities and fertilization on denitrification and nitrification. The dynamics were investigated at different timepoints (T0, T1 after 24h, T2 after 48h, T3 after 144h) to monitor changes in the investigated processes over time upon ammonium addition.

title: Influence of pH on abundance and diversity of ammonia-oxidizing archaea in forest soils
abstract: This study investigates the influence of pH on abundance and diversity of ammonia-oxidizing archaea in forest soils under different land-use intensities. Ammonia-oxidizing archaea will be detected in mineral horizons of different forest soils and microbial community structure will be determined.

abstract: concentration (mg/kg) of microbial phosphorus in soil

title: Grassland plant species under root herbivore attack by Agriotes larvae, experiment, 2010
abstract: Insect root herbivores can alter plant community structure by affecting the competitive ability of single plants. Our study aims at increasing knowledge on the impact of click beetle larvae (Elateridae, genus Agriotes) on grassland plant communities, by determining biomass responses as well as responses of the arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (AMF) symbiosis to this widespread generalist root herbivore for eight common grassland plant species (Festuca rubra, Holcus lanatus, Poa pratensis, Achillea millefolium, Plantago lanceolata, Veronica arvensis, Medicago lupulina, Trifolium repens), belonging to three functional groups (grasses, herbs, legumes).

title: Root herbivore history effects on grassland plants
abstract: Insect root herbivores can alter plant community structure by affecting the competitive ability of single plants. However, their effects can be modified by the soil environment. Root herbivory itself may induce changes in the soil biota community, and it has recently been show that these changes can affect plant growth in a subsequent season or plant generation. The study aims at determining whether these root herbivore history effects (i) are detectable at the plant community level and/or (ii) also determine plant species and plant community responses to new root herbivore attack.

title: terrestrial-laser-scanner-data (tree characteristics)
abstract: Understanding the nature of aboveground competition amomg forest trees, because it has been shown that differences in crown morphology, crown efficiency and space occupation modify the competitive strength and require a consideration of neighborhood identity. In comparison to the processes that take effect in monocultures, interspecific competition will be stronger or weaker what may result in a misjudgment of competitive interactions.

title: Translocation experiment - height and number of leaves seedlings (2001 - 2012)
abstract:
Hypotheses: EMF species richness is affected by beech family structures.
This subtask will be initiated in the current project phase; however analyses will take place only beyond the time frame of the current application. The plan is to construct low (closely related) to high diversity mixtures (unrelated) of beech nuts. For this purpose, the nuts will be collected under distinct trees (= full-sib family members) by our group. With help of the site managers, further collections of beech nuts will be obtained from the different Exploratories. 
Seedlings will be per-grown in a common garden in Göttingen and will be planted in a replicated design in the managed and unmanaged beech forests.

title: ClassII-peroxidase-sequences from pure cultures (HAI, 2008)
abstract: Leaf litter and other forms of plant litter are beside wood the ubiquitous results of terrestrial plant life. Based on a rough estimate, circa 260 billion tons of plant biomass are annually produced by green plants, which makes about 90 billion tons of cellulose, 50 billion tons of lignin and 50 billion tons of hemicellulose. It has been shown that fungi play an essential role in the carbon cycle of their habitats. They are involved in formation of soil humic matter and soil fine structure. Moreover, fungi (especially agaric) are most likely involved in the breakdown of the most recalcitrant moieties of the plant biomass (lignins and phenolic compounds). Identification of fungal genes and enzymes involved in the decay processes will be crucial for understanding this important ecophysiological process in forests and other ecosystems.

title: Prey DNA screening in centipede predators (Hainich, Fall 2009 and Spring 2010)
abstract:
PCR based gut content analysis can unravel predator-prey interactions where conventional methods fail. Centipedes are supposed to be generalist predators feeding on a wide spectrum of possible prey. This project addresses feeding ecology of litter-dwelling centipede predators by screening field-caught specimens for prey DNA in specific PCR assays.

title: Flower visitation honeybee and bumblebee
abstract: Domesticated honeybees (Apis mellifera) are suspected to have negative impacts on native pollinators, particularly wild bees, due to their large numbers, generalist resource use, and competitive strength. However, evidence for such effects is scant since competition for resources is difficult to demonstrate in mobile and long-lived organisms. We will exploit the unique advantages of the biodiversity exploratories to probe for competitive interactions between honeybees and their wild eusocial relatives, bumblebees (Bombus spp.). First, we will “read” hydrocarbon deposits (“footprints”) of honeybees and bumblebees on flowers to assess floral resource overlap between them. The novel technique will provide visitation data for sufficient replicate plant species across all grassland experimental plots so as to allow the detection of bumblebee displacement from preferred flowers in areas with high honeybee abundance. Second, we will measure fitness-related traits in bumblebees and analyze whether variation in these traits is explained by competition with honeybees, by land use or by a combined effect of these two factors. Third, we will conduct a field experiment with bumblebees in artificial hives to test directly for honeybee effects on bumblebee foraging and reproduction. The combination of multi-replicate correlative approaches with field experiments will allow general conclusions on the competitive impact of honeybees on wild pollinators in Central Europe and interactions with land use.

abstract: It is generally thought that soil animals face specific foraging conditions because movement through soil is highly energy consuming.Here we test the hypothesis that root feeding click beetle larvae (Coleoptera: Elateridae, genus Agriotes), to minimize energy loss, only migrate horizontally through soil when located in food depleted surroundings.

title: Particle density of mineral soil an all grassland EPs, 2011
abstract: The BIOSTRUC project aims at understanding the relationship between land use intensity, soil biodiversity and soil structure and its consequences for C-N dynamics in grassland soils. The project provides data on soil physical properties across all 150 Grassland Experimental Plots (EPs) of the Biodiversity Exploratories. Partical density is an important soil physical parameter to estimate the pore volume and it is influenced by e.g. parent material, soil texture and carbon content of soil.

title: Microtomography anaylsis of soil structure and roots HEG grassland EPs , 2011
abstract: The BIOSTRUC project aims at understanding the relationship between land use intensity, soil biodiversity and soil structure and its consequences for C-N dynamics in grassland soils. In soils, the relationship between soil structure and plant roots—which influences water dynamics in soil—deserves special interest. With X-ray computed microtomography (micro-CT), soil structure and roots may be visualized and quantified simultaneously. We analysed undisturbed soil samples from 49 HEG grassland sites.

title: Tick monitoring (Alb 2008 to 2010)
abstract:
Ticks are effective vectors of many infectious agents including viral, bacterial, rickettsial and protozoal pathogens. Ticks, feed on the blood of a large variety of vertebrates and are distributed in various habitats including forests. The presence and density of ticks determines the transmission level of tick-borne diseases and is, in turn, linked to various factors such as climate, habitat and density of the vertebrate hosts.In order to identify environmental factors which are likely to govern differences in tick abundances, we sampled ticks on forest experimental plots. The preliminary inventory in 2008 was restricted to the Exploratory Swabian Alb.
Read more in:  Lauterbach R, Wells K, O'Hara RB, Kalko EKV, Renner SC (2013) Variable Strength of Forest Stand Attributes and Weather Conditions on the Questing Activity of Ixodes ricinus Ticks over Years in Managed Forests. PLoS ONE 8(1): e55365. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0055365

title: Soil living insect larvae in grasslands, 2011
abstract: Differences in plant diversity and soil nutrient levels brought by gradients in land use intensity are likely to influence the abundance and diversity of soil living insect larvae. Insect larvae, especially root feeders, on the other hand can feed back, either directly or in interaction with other soil organisms, on the productivity and diversity of grasslands. Therefore, knowledge on their abundance, distribution and diversity is crucial for a general understanding of their impact on plant communities and for developing management tools for grasslands.

title: Small scale distribution of insect larvae on 28l grassland EPs, 2011
abstract: The currently observed general decline in biodiversity is closely related to local and global changes in land use. Land use intensity influences site heterogeneity which is a major driver of niche differentiation, species coexistence, and biodiversity. Insect root herbivores can have pronounced impacts on plant productivity and diversity. We assume that by affecting soil heterogeneity and plant diversity, land use intensity influences the spatial distribution of insect root herbivores with feedback on the structure and diversity of grassland plant communities.

title: Soil bulk density and organic carbon and total nitrogen stocks - soil sampling campaign 2011, all experimental plots (EP), 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the soil bulk density and the soil organic carbon (OC), total nitrogen (TN) and total sulfur (TS) stocks in 0-10 cm depth from all experimental plots (EP) in 2017. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soils are important reservoirs for carbon, nitrogen and sulfur. The storage of organic carbon and nutrients is not only important for climate regulation and plant growth but also affects other soil functions. A multitude of natural factors (e.g. climate, parent material, landscape position) but also human-induced factors (e.g. land use type, management intensity) influence the potential of soils to store carbon and nutrients. Bulk density is used to calculate elemental stocks but at same time it is also an important indicator of the degree of soil compaction. It therefore greatly affects the water and solute movement in soils and the soil aeration.The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-1, TR 1054/4-1, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: BELongDead fungi sporocarp overview inventory 2012 (760 logs)
abstract: Wood decomposition is the outcome of multiple interactions between decomposer communities and the substrate. These interactions largely depend on top–down control from abiotic and biotic factors whose interactions determine the local environment. Many wood-inhabiting fungi appear, based on fruit bodies, to have a preference for certain tree species. In some cases substrate preferences relate to interspecific differences.

title: Nitrification-denitrification dynamics upon ammonium addition ALB
abstract: This study investigates the dynamics of nitrification and denitrification processes influenced by different oxygen levels (adjusted via different water contents: 50% and 80% of WHKmax). Plots of different land-use intensites were chosen to investigate the influence of land-use intensities and fertilization on denitrification and nitrification. The dynamics were investigated at different timepoints (T0, T1 after 24h, T2 after 48h, T3 after 144h) to monitor changes in the investigated processes over time upon ammonium addition.

title: Decomposition activity of forest soil communities in a litter bag (HAI, SCH 2011 - 2013)
abstract: We tested decomposition activity of forest soil communities in a litter bag study with two mesh-sizes (Micro-,Macromesh) across all 4 major forest types (no "Plenterwälder") in Hainich-Dün and Schorfheide-Chorin. The experiment was embedded in a root-exclosure installation ("trenching"). We used leaf litter from two tree species, i.e. Fagus sylvatica and Acer platanoides. Thus the litterbag study had a 3x3 design: 2 litter types, 2 mesh-sizes, 2 treatments (trenched and non-trenched control). Trenching was established in autumn 2011. Study time for litter decomposition was from February 2012 (initialization of litter bags) across 3 sampling dates to October 2013.

title: Nitrification-denitrification dynamics upon nitrate addition ALB
abstract: This study investigates the dynamics of nitrification and denitrification processes influenced by different oxygen levels (adjusted via different water contents: 50% and 80% of WHKmax). Plots of different land-use intensites were chosen to investigate the influence of land-use intensities and fertilization on denitrification and nitrification. The dynamics were investigated at different timepoints (T0, T1 after 24h, T2 after 48h, T3 after 144h) to monitor changes in the investigated processes over time upon nitrate addition.

title: Influence of LUI on nitrogen-cycling microbes - 13C labeling experiment

Plots of different land-use intensites from ALB were chosen to investigate the influence of land-use intensities on plant and soil parameters as well as on nitrogen-cycling community. Dactylis glomerata was used as a model plant.

title: BEDry - Growth conductance - Phytometer  (9 forest sites, 2011-2013)
abstract: Climate change is predicted to severely affect precipitation patterns across central Europe. The forest understorey  has  not  been  subject  to  an  extensive  investigation  with  respect  to  climate  change,  yet,  even though it is playing an important role in natural regeneration and forest succession. We propose here to establish roof systems in forest plots in all three Exploratories and to study biogeochemical and hydropedological processes in response to reduced precipitation, and their interaction with forest land use type and the diversity of the forest understorey and of soil biota. Our research is focused on the direct and indirect effects of drought on different parts of the forest understorey system and the consequences for plant growth. We will address the effects of soil hydrological structures and functions and precipitation regime on the water and carbon balance of plant species and the resulting community effects in the manipulation experiments across land-use and biodiversity gradients. We will also take into account direct drought plus plant diversity effects on the microbial community structure and function and address the biotic feedback on soil structure and thus hydrological functions.

title: BEDry - Evapotranspiration (2012)
abstract: The main hypotheses concern the direct and indirect effects of drought on different parts of the forest understorey system and the consequences for plant growth.We addressed the effects of soil hydrological structures and functions and precipitation regime on the water and carbon balance of plant species and the resulting community effects in the manipulation experiments across land-use and biodiversity gradients. We also took into account direct drought plus plant diversity effects on the microbial community structure and function and address the biotic feedback on soil structure and thus hydrological functions.

title: BEDry - Basic soil profile description (9 forest sites, 2012)
abstract: Basic soil profile description

title: Leaf traits self measured (BERICH, 2011)
abstract: The overarching objective of this project is to understand assembly rules of the grassland communities in the Biodiversity Exploratories. Our principal experimental approach is enrichment planting, using different species additions to test for community saturation, to evaluate predictions based on the co-occurrence information in the GVRD, to analyse whether the community is characterized by trait similarity or dissimilarity and whether the latter reflects prevailing environmental filters or niche complementarity. Our study will include the three main different land use types (meadow, pasture, mown pasture) in all three Exploratories.

title: Dendrometer data of trees, Neighbor, 1 MIP, 2012-2013
abstract: By analyzing the growth response of trees as a function of local neighborhood diversity, the main objectives of the project are 1) to explain the growth response of selected trees on different time scales (day to year) as a function of their neighborhood 2) to reveal the impact of neighborhood density and species composition on individual tree growth and 3) to explain the revealed growth pattern by using growth related plant traits.

title: Colony growth of bumblebees
abstract: Domesticated honeybees (Apis mellifera) are suspected to have negative impacts on native pollinators, particularly wild bees, due to their large numbers, generalist resource use, and competitive strength. However, evidence for such effects is scant since competition for resources is difficult to demonstrate in mobile and long-lived organisms. We will exploit the unique advantages of the biodiversity exploratories to probe for competitive interactions between honeybees and their wild eusocial relatives, bumblebees (Bombus spp.). Therefore, we placed 40 commerically producted bumblebee colonies on 30 EPs of the Swäbische Alb. Additionally, we placed 10 colonies right next to bee hives of beekeepers that are also located in the Biosphere Reserve Schwäbische Alb. Documented are the weight gains of these colonies after a months outside. After one month we had freeye the colonies because we wanted to avoid the spread of commerically produced bumblebee drones and gynes.

title: Phosphate release kinetics at stable pH in calcareous grassland soils of ALB
abstract: Phosphate release kinetics in soils are of global interest because sustainable plant nutrition with phosphate will be a major concern in the future. Dissolution of phosphate-containing minerals induced by a changing rhizosphere equilibrium through proton input is one important mechanism that releases phosphate into bioavailable forms. Our objectives were (i) to determine phosphate release kinetics during H+ addition in calcareous soils of the Schwäbische Alb, Germany, and to assess the influence of (ii) land-use type (grassland vs. forest) and (iii) management intensity on reactive phosphate pools and phosphate release rate constants during H+ addition. Phosphate release kinetics were characterized by a large fast-reacting phosphatepool, which could be attributed to poorly-crystalline calcium phosphates, and a small slow-reacting phosphate pool probably originating from carbonate-bearing hydroxylapatite. Both reactive phosphate pools—as well as total phosphate concentrations (TP) in soil—were greater in grassland than in forest soils. In organically fertilized grassland soils, concentrations of released phosphate were higher than in unfertilized soils, likely because organic fertilizers contain poorly-crystalline phosphate compounds which are further converted into sparingly soluble phosphate forms. Because of an enriched slow-reacting phosphate pool, mown pastures were characterized by a more continuous slow phosphate release reaction in contrast to clear biphasic phosphate release patterns in meadows. Consequently, managing phosphate release kinetics via management measures is a valuable tool to evaluate longer-term P availability in soil in the context of finite rock phosphate reserves on earth.

title: Phosphate release kinetics at stable pH in calcareous forest soils of ALB
abstract: Phosphate release kinetics in soils are of global interest because sustainable plant nutrition with phosphate will be a major concern in the future. Dissolution of phosphate-containing minerals induced by a changing rhizosphere equilibrium through proton input is one important mechanism that releases phosphate into bioavailable forms. Our objectives were (i) to determine phosphate release kinetics during H+ addition in calcareous soils of the Schwäbische Alb, Germany, and to assess the influence of (ii) land-use type (grassland vs. forest) and (iii) management intensity on reactive phosphate pools and phosphate release rate constants during H+ addition. Phosphate release kinetics were characterized by a large fast-reacting phosphatepool, which could be attributed to poorly-crystalline calcium phosphates, and a small slow-reacting phosphate pool probably originating from carbonate-bearing hydroxylapatite. Both reactive phosphate pools—as well as total phosphate concentrations (TP) in soil—were greater in grassland than in forest soils. In organically fertilized grassland soils, concentrations of released phosphate were higher than in unfertilized soils, likely because organic fertilizers contain poorly-crystalline phosphate compounds which are further converted into sparingly soluble phosphate forms. Because of an enriched slow-reacting phosphate pool, mown pastures were characterized by a more continuous slow phosphate release reaction in contrast to clear biphasic phosphate release patterns in meadows. Consequently, managing phosphate release kinetics via management measures is a valuable tool to evaluate longer-term P availability in soil in the context of finite rock phosphate reserves on earth.

title: forest soil food web metaweb of 48 plots
abstract: We assembled 48 forest soil food webs. We used stable isotope analyses, fatty acid analyses, mollecular gut contend analyses, body mass ranges and literature data to establish the feeding interactions. Binary food web structures can be used to calculate food web properties to describe the species interactions. The food web properties can be used to compare the soil food webs to other ecosystems. These are the first soil food webs, which were assembled using a combination of molecular methods to asses the feeding interactions. Samples were taken in 2008 and 2011.

title: Carbohydrates in fine roots May 2011 all Forest EPs
abstract: Differences in stand structure of managed and unmanaged forests influence belowground carbon allocation, thereby, affecting EMF (ectomycorrhizal fungi) diversity.Preceding experimental studies of our group established causal relationships between EMF diversity and root carbohydrate concentrations, in particular fructose and glucose (Druebert et al. 2009, Pena et al. 2010). Since management or growth conditions can affect tree carbohydrate production and, thereby, constitute the physiological link between this ecosystem service and EMFs diversity, we will determine root carbohydrate concentrations across the EPs of the Exploratories and test if they were correlated with EMF diversity and test for relationships with inventory parameters

title: Gravimetric soil water content - Soil sampling campaign 2014, all experimental plots (EP), 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides essential information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all 301 experimental plots (EPs) of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the gravimetric soil water contents and dry matter contents in 0-10 cm depth from all EPs in 2014. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil water content has a dominant influence on plant growth, soil temperature, transport of chemical compounds, ground water recharge and soil aeration. The gravimetric soil water content is the mass of water in the soil, measured as the weight difference between the moist and the oven-dry soil. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-2, TR 1054/4-2, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Multirich R package metadata
abstract:
multirich is an R package for calculating unscaled and scaled multivariate richness (uMVR and sMVR respectively). These are two new approaches to calculating (e.g., functional) richness in a multivariate context.

The package can also calculate beta-diversity for trait richness and can partition this into nestedness-related and turnover components.
  The package will also calculate several measures of overlap

title: BELongDead fungi sporocarp inventory 2012 (1140 logs)
abstract: Wood decomposition is the outcome of multiple interactions between decomposer communities and the substrate. These interactions largely depend on top–down control from abiotic and biotic factors whose interactions determine the local environment. Many wood-inhabiting fungi appear, based on fruit bodies, to have a preference for certain tree species. In some cases substrate preferences relate to interspecific differences.

title: Herbivory grassland 2013
abstract:
Land use is a major driver of biodiversity loss in many taxa including species-rich invertebrate assemblages, but consequences
for invertebrate-mediated processes are still little studied.
Aim of study:
To assess invertebrate herbivory in 146 managed temperate grasslands
across a broad range of land-use intensities in three regions of Germany

title: Root herbivory impact on arbuscular mycorrizal fungi colonization and shoot herbivory in Plantago lanceolata, 2012/2013
abstract: Root herbivory can influence plant interactions with other organisms by systemically affecting plant morphology and chemistry. In managed systems the root hebivory impact may depend on land use intensity, as land use has been shown to affect plants as well as their potential interactions partners, thus setting the stage for root herbivory effects on plant interactions. Besides affecting plant interaction partners, land use may affect the morphology and chemistry of single plants, either directly or due to altered subjection to interaction partners, with consequences for root herbivore attack and plant interactions. We established local plants with and without root herbivores in their root system in grasslands of different management intensity to determine root herbivore impacts on plant attack by invertebrate shoot herbivores and on colonization by root fungi, as examples for plant interactions with above- and belowground organisms, respectively.

title: Phylogenetic diversity indices of grassland plant communities of all grassland EPs, 2011
abstract:
Changes in phylogentic diversity of plants can alter the functional space of a community and thus change ecosystem related processes and functions. Land-use intensification, as one of the major threats to biodiversity, can select for species with traits that enable them to cope with high land-use intensities. If those traits are conserved, land-use intensification can lead to phylogenetically clustered communities that contain of clsoely related species.
We test for the effect of land-use intensity on phylogenetic diversity of grassland plant communities in 150 grassland plots in the three regions.

title: Soil carbon and nitrogen concentrations - soil sampling campaign 2014, all experimental plots (EPs), 0-10 cm
abstract:
The core project Soil provides essential information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all 300 Experimental Plots (EPs) of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the organic carbon (OC), inorganic carbon (IC) and nitrogen (TN) concentrations and carbon to nitrogen ratios (CN ratio) in 0-10 cm depth from all EPs in 2014. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil organic carbon and nitrogen concentrations are master variables in soil science. Soil organic carbon and nitrogen are the measureable components of soil organic matter (SOM). SOM exerts positive effects on numerous physical, chemical and biological soil properties. An increase in SOM generally results in an improved soil structure, soil moisture retention, soil buffering capacity, retention of pollutants, cycling and storage of plant nutrients and biodiversity. SOM also acts as a sink and source for atmospheric carbon dioxide.

The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-2, TR 1054/4-2, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Influence of pH on abundance and diversity of ammonia-oxidizing archaea in forest soils
abstract: This study investigates the influence of pH on abundance and diversity of ammonia-oxidizing archaea in forest soils under different land-use intensities. Ammonia-oxidizing archaea will be detected in mineral horizons of different forest soils and microbial community structure will be determined.

title: BioComp plant biomass nutrients in grasslands 2009-2013 (NIRS)
abstract: The assessment of biomass production, chemical constituents and functional composition of grassland canopies is of crucial importance for the disentangling of biodiversity patterns. Generally, such essential data are rarely available for a high number of spatial and temporal replications. We will provide such data in a very efficient and cost effective way using near infrared spectroscopy (NIRS). Based on laboratory standard analyses of biomass samples, calibration models will be developed for the quick and cheap measurement of plant tissue constituents. For calibration, biomass samples of the 150 experimental plots of the three exploratories will be used. Initially, calibration models for the carbon content and the main plant nutrients (N, P, K) will be developed. Furthermore, the NIRS technique is applied to quantify various fractions of fibre such as cellulose and lignin.

title: Diversity analysis of nitrogen fixing organisms
abstract: Using the nifH gene as functional marker, we established a Terminal Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism (T-RFLP) analysis method in order to assess the influence of land-use intensity and seasonal effects on the diversity of nitrogen-fixing microorganisms in grassland soils.

title: Water loss of 67 pollinator species on grassland, 2013 and 2014
abstract: In the view of ongoing climate change, variation of climatic responses across species such as water loss is getting particularly relevant to compare the vulnerability of communities. Whereas previous work often focused on one or a few species, we examined water loss across different taxa representing the same ecosystem function: 67 species of pollinators. We tested whether differences between species correspond to taxonomic groups, body mass, surface area to volume ratio (SA/V ratio) and water content. Whereas body mass has received a lot of attention in the literature, surfaces have not been measured explicitly in this context.

title: Soil pH - soil sampling campaign 2014, all experimental plots (EPs), 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the soil pH values in 0-10 cm depth from all experimental plots (EPs) in 2014. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil pH is considered a master variable in soil science as it affects many chemical processes in soils. Most importantly, the plant nutrient availability is greatly affected by the soil pH as it controls the chemical forms of the different nutrients and influences the chemical reactions they undergo. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-2, TR 1054/4-2, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Phytometer data of an experiment with transplanted species of contrasting geographic range types under manipulated biotic interactions (herbivory and competition) and different land-use regimes in Germany, 2009 - 2010
abstract:
Geographic plant distribution is often assumed to be predominantly limited directly by the climatic tolerances of species. However, the role of climate is nowadays known to be mainly an indirect one by mostly mediating dispersal and establishment, species interactions or habitat characteristics, which all are often modified by human land use. In these complex systems, negative biotic interactions are predicted to increase in relative importance towards benign climate conditions. We tested this hypothesis experimentally by exposing plant species with different geographic distribution ranges to different climates, biotic interactions and land use. 

The dataset is the basis of the publication: Welk, A., Baudis, M., Böckelmann, J., Welk, E & Bruelheide, H. (2019): Plant species´ range type determines local responses to biotic interactions and land use. Ecology. doi:10.1002/ecy.2890
