title: Root Trenching Experiment in Hainich beech plots - succession of Ectomycorrhiza
abstract: In temperate forests the most important tree symbionts are ectomycorrhizal fungi (EM). In general, 90% of all plants form mycorrhizas (Cairney 2000). Morphologically this symbiosis is formed by a fungal mantle ensheathing the root tip and a Hartig net, which consists of fungal hyphae between cortical and epidermal cells of the host plant root. Agerer (1987-2006) has described EM fungal species by their morphology and anatomy on different host plants. Ectomycorrhizas can be distinguished by color, branching and surface texture of the mantle and emanating mycelia (Figure 1). According to their emanating hyphae, EM fungi have been classified according to exploration types: contact type with few emanating hyphae, short-distance type with a lot of emanating hyphae, medium-distance type forming rhizomorphs and long-distance type with few highly differentiated rhizomorphs (Agerer 2001). Those morphological differences may also result in functional differences. Petchey & Gaston (2006). Anthropogenic impacts also play a role; forest management, which aims to optimize several ecosystem services like soil and water protection, climate regulation and wood production. Those impacts via forest management may also influence soil microbial communities (Nacke et al. 2011; Hartmann et al. 2012; Felsmann et al. 2015). It was investigated whether stimulated local disturbance affects EM communities, and the duration until disturbed EM communities returned to a climax state. Furthermore differences in functionality, represented by exploration types of the EMs during recolonization, were identified. An experiment was installed within beech forests in the Hainich Exploratory by cutting roots within the forest soil. When a tree is harvested, the belowground parts remain within the forest soil and degrade, thereby serving as supplementary nutrient sources. The increased production of root litter as a consequence of forest utilization may create new niches. Additionally, Peay et al. (2011) hypothesized soil disturbances to maintain community diversity at a high level by creating additional habitats for EM species. Within our experiment a disturbance was simulated which resulted in patches free from living roots and the disturbed patches were monitored to study recolonization. Those patches are assumed to be recolonized by roots of surrounding trees, seeking to utilise the newly available space and nutrients. The EM fungal community within ingrowth and within undisturbed control cores were observed by morphotyping and Sanger sequencing over 18 months. This experiment was expected to obtain information about functional differences of the EM community using exploration types as markers.

title: Root Trenching Experiment in Hainich beech plots - succession of Ectomycorrhiza - Exploration types, 2011
abstract: In temperate forests the most important tree symbionts are ectomycorrhizal fungi (EM). In general, 90% of all plants form mycorrhizas (Cairney 2000). Morphologically this symbiosis is formed by a fungal mantle ensheathing the root tip and a Hartig net, which consists of fungal hyphae between cortical and epidermal cells of the host plant root. Agerer (1987-2006) has described EM fungal species by their morphology and anatomy on different host plants. Ectomycorrhizas can be distinguished by color, branching and surface texture of the mantle and emanating mycelia (Figure 1). According to their emanating hyphae, EM fungi have been classified according to exploration types: contact type with few emanating hyphae, short-distance type with a lot of emanating hyphae, medium-distance type forming rhizomorphs and long-distance type with few highly differentiated rhizomorphs (Agerer 2001). Those morphological differences may also result in functional differences. Petchey & Gaston (2006). Anthropogenic impacts also play a role; forest management, which aims to optimize several ecosystem services like soil and water protection, climate regulation and wood production. Those impacts via forest management may also influence soil microbial communities (Nacke et al. 2011; Hartmann et al. 2012; Felsmann et al. 2015). It was investigated whether stimulated local disturbance affects EM communities, and the duration until disturbed EM communities returned to a climax state. Furthermore differences in functionality, represented by exploration types of the EMs during recolonization, were identified. An experiment was installed within beech forests in the Hainich Exploratory by cutting roots within the forest soil. When a tree is harvested, the belowground parts remain within the forest soil and degrade, thereby serving as supplementary nutrient sources. The increased production of root litter as a consequence of forest utilization may create new niches. Additionally, Peay et al. (2011) hypothesized soil disturbances to maintain community diversity at a high level by creating additional habitats for EM species. Within our experiment a disturbance was simulated which resulted in patches free from living roots and the disturbed patches were monitored to study recolonization. Those patches are assumed to be recolonized by roots of surrounding trees, seeking to utilise the newly available space and nutrients. The EM fungal community within ingrowth and within undisturbed control cores were observed by morphotyping and Sanger sequencing over 18 months. This experiment was expected to obtain information about functional differences of the EM community using exploration types as markers.

title: ICP concentration of elements in fine roots, soil sampling, May 2011
abstract:
In the temperate forests, tree root tips are living in symbiosis with ectomycorrhizal fungi. We assume that root chemical elemental composition influence ectomycorrhizal fungal community composition and structure.
Root material, used for element anaylsis, was collected during the Soil sampling campaign in May 2011. Since the organic layer varied in depth among the sites and was not present in all forest ecosystems, the top mineral soil, comprising mainly the A horizon, was collected. In each plot, soil cores with a diameter of 0.05 m and depth of 0.10 m were collected along two transects of a 40 m length from north to south and from west to east at distances of 2.5, 8.5, 14.5, 20.5, 26.5, 32.5 and 38.5 m each, resulting in 14samples. All samples of a plot were mixed and homogenized, resulting in one composite sample per plot. Subsequently, fine roots (<2 mm in diameter) were collected, stored at 4°C and transported to the laboratory.

title: C and N concentrations of tree fine roots from soil sampling, May 2011
abstract:
Differences in stand structure of managed and unmanaged forests influence belowground carbon allocation, thereby, affecting EMF (ectomycorrhizal fungi) diversity. Is there an influence of C and N concentrations in the roots on EMF communities?
Root material, used for C and N measurements, was collected during the Soil sampling campaign in May 2011. Since the organic layer varied in depth among the sites and was not present in all forest ecosystems, the top mineral soil, comprising mainly the A horizon, was collected. In each plot, soil cores with a diameter of 0.05 m and depth of 0.10 m were collected along two transects of a 40 m length from north to south and from west to east at distances of 2.5, 8.5, 14.5, 20.5, 26.5, 32.5 and 38.5 m each, resulting in 14samples. All samples of a plot were mixed and homogenized, resulting in one composite sample per plot. Subsequently, fine roots (<2 mm in diameter) were collected, stored at 4°C and transported to the laboratory.

abstract:
Our objectives are:

    to predict the performance of species introduced to a community from above- and belowground traits and to compare these predictions to those obtained from co-occurrence information
    to analyse root traits in addition to leaf traits of the grassland species in the Exploratories and to analyse how leaf and root traits are related to each other and how they respond to different local neighbourhoods
    to characterize species-specific root exudation patterns, including the full spectrum of low molecular organic compounds exuded by different plant species
    to analyse how root exudation patterns and trait values change with residence time in a community and respond to land use

title: Throughfall, rainfall, soil solution, stem flow - K, Na, Mg, Ca analysis in water samples (2009 - 2016, ALB VIPs)
abstract:
The aims of this study are to determine cycling of water, nutrient, and carbon for the VIPs of the biodiversity-exploratories and relate soil acidification, nutrient loss and greenhouse gas emissions to land-use and biodiversity. Nutrient balance studies help to determine the sustainability of type and intensity of management. Nutrient-input via precipitation is one of the main external sources in natural ecosystems and is also an additional nutrient source in managed ecosystems. Furthermore, precipitation of water is of high relevance for water supply of plants and plays a key role in soil processes like mineralization.

Concentrations of K, Na, Mg, Ca in water samples from Schwäbische Alb. Used to calculate waterbound fluxes of these elements.

title: Vegetation releves header data on plot level (54) (BERICH 2011)
abstract:
BERICH
Project description
The overarching objective of this project is to understand assembly rules of the grassland communities in the Biodiversity Exploratories. Our principal experimental approach is enrichment planting, using different species additions to test for community saturation, to evaluate predictions based on the co-occurrence information in the GVRD, to analyse whether the community is characterized by trait similarity or dissimilarity and whether the latter reflects prevailing environmental filters or niche complementarity. Our study will include the three main different land use types (meadow, pasture, mown pasture) in all three Exploratories.

title: Decomposition (dung removal in g on 300 EPs, season 2014), Taxon: dung beetles (Invertebrates, Scarabaeoidea) - Dungwebs
abstract: Dung beetles (Scarabaeidae) are common detritivores, and especially the tunnelling genera Geotrupes, Anoplotrupes and Onthophagus enhance soil quality and support nutrient cycles by rapid burial of mammalian dung. Whereas dung beetles are known to provide important ecosystem services in forests and grassland, little is known in which ways land use affects dung beetles.

title: Nutrient concentrations in plant biomass at 73 grassland MIPs, 2015, SADE
abstract: The assessment of biomass production, chemical constituents and functional composition of grassland canopies is of crucial importance for the disentangling of biodiversity patterns. Generally, such essential data are rarely available for a high number of spatial and temporal replications. We will provide such data in a very efficient and cost effective way using near infrared spectroscopy (NIRS). Based on laboratory standard analyses of biomass samples, calibration models will be developed for the quick and cheap measurement of plant tissue constituents. For calibration, biomass samples of the 150 experimental plots of the three exploratories will be used. Initially, calibration models for the carbon content and the main plant nutrients (N, P, K) will be developed. Furthermore, the NIRS technique is applied to quantify various fractions of fibre such as cellulose and lignin.

title: LPJ-GUESS R package
abstract:
It is theoretically possible to experimentally and observationally test for potential mechanisms that determine community diversity and ecosystem functioning by manipulating or observing functional compositions and measuring ecological and physiological responses in detail. In practice, however, experimental limitations and environmental noise allow only a detection of the strongest functional mechanisms. In this situation, process-based models provide an alternative route of analyzing the available data for a wider range and combinations of different ecological mechanisms. The Biodiversity Exploratories provide detailed data from grassland and forests plots across communities that cover a wide range of (functional) diversity and land use types. Thus, they allow examining effects of land use and diversity on ecosystem functioning.
The objective of this project is to use a process-based vegetation model to compare the support and relative strength of different mechanisms that are hypothesized to affect interactions between diversity, land use and ecosystem functions. Mechanisms of particular interest are: 

1. Niche differentiation through growth strategies/competition for light. 
2. Niche differentiation through rooting strategy and differential water use. 
3. Niche differentiation through complementary nutrient / soil requirements. 
4. Intraspecific variability of traits, which could create the same effects through functional diversity, despite no apparent species diversity.

title: Three-dimensional trees, Hainich 2014, using terrestrial laser scanning, SHAPE
abstract: The intensity of silvicultural interventions such as thinnings or final harvests as well as the choice  of the tree species to be  cultivated are two basic silvicultural management decisions. However, our knowledge on the effects of silvicultural management intensity or different neighborhood diversities on distinct changes in tree architecture is still small, especially if the focus is laid on single tree attributes, e.g. branching pattern or crown deformations.

title: Performance of two year old beech progenies from six forest VIP plots from the three Exploratories under greenhouse conditions in 2014
abstract: A greenhouse experiment was conducted to investigate performance of beech progenies from the three Exploratoties in a common environment. Beech nuts were collected from Schorfheide (SEW5, SEW9), Hainich (HEW6, HEW10) and Schwäbische Alb (AEW5, AEW8) in between 28th September to 20th October 2011. They were sown in plastic pots in early April 2012. We sow beech nuts in two soil treatments: original Hainich forest soil (O soil) and the Hainich soil that was sterilized by ɣ-radiation and reinoculated with soil bacteria (S soil). The experiment was taken care and watered weekly with tap water until harvest under greenhouse conditions.

title: Ammonium and nitrate uptake of beech seedlings from three forest VIPs in the three Exploratories under greenhouse conditions in 2014
abstract: A greenhouse experiment was conducted to investigate nitrogen uptake of beech progenies from the three Exploratoties in a common environment. Beech nuts were collected from Schorfheide (SEW5, SEW9), Hainich (HEW6, HEW10) and Schwäbische Alb (AEW5, AEW8) in between 28th September to 20th October 2011. They were sown in plastic pots in early April 2012. We sowed beech nuts in two soil treatments: original Hainich forest soil (O soil) and the Hainich soil that was sterilized by ɣ-radiation and reinoculated with soil bacteria (S soil). The experiment was taken care and watered weekly with tap water until harvest under greenhouse conditions. To study N uptake of beech progenies, during three days before harvest, 15N (1.8 mg) was used to label beech progenies using either K15NO3 or 15NH4Cl. Only 15N data of beech progenies SEW5, HEW10 and AEW8 were analyzed and shown in this dataset.

abstract: We performed a mesocosm experiment with grass sods which were taken from 15 grassland plots at the Schwäbische Alb and brought to Münster (glasshouse). Four sods were taken from each grassland and treated differently: Control: no fertilizer, normal watering. Fertilization: three times addition of 100 ml pig slurry. Drought: No watering four six weeks in April and May. Many plant and ecosystem properties have been measured. Pleas ask data manager for detailed information on parameters and the experimental setup.

title: Climate Change Manipulation Effects on Biomass, Species Richness, Above- and Below-Ground C- and N-Pools in 15 Grassland Sites in 2008-2010
abstract: Experimental manipulations took place in 2008/2009 and 2009/2010, from the middle of June until the end of July in 2008 and 2009 for the simulated drought treatment and from end of February till end of March in 2009 and 2010 for simulation of increased spring temperat­ures. Our manipulations thus implicitly include carry-over effects of drought on the spring treatment the following year. Treatments are representing projected qualitative changes in summer drought duration and concurrent changes of the length of the vegetation period. Their length is based on interannual variability of the onset of spring (approximately 4 weeks after begin of snow melt in late February) and length of drought in summer (maximally 6 weeks). We left the rain shelter in place until there were cumulatively three weeks of rainfall withheld from the treatment (monitoring the closest German weather service stations for guidance). Thus, all treatments are within the variability witnessed in the region, but aim at representing earlier season and prolonged drought. Constructions were removed when no treatment was applied, but the plot was fenced off for the entire vegetation period. The entire plot was mown in summer after biomass harvest (see below).

title: Microbial and physico-chemical soil properties, Alb grassland, 2015, cooperation SADE-SCALEMIC
abstract:
Cooperation SADE-Scalemic:
SADE = seed addition and disturbance experiment.
One 7m x 7m control plot, one 7m x 7m plot with seed addition, one 7m x 7m with disturbanc (rotary cultivation), one 7m x 7m with seed addition and disturbance. The experiment addresses ecosystem resilience by assessing how fast grassland ecosystems including all their functions and processes recover after drastic disturbance and return to the initial conditions, in dependency on pre-disturbance diversity and land-use intensity. On the other hand, we will determine to what degree seeding of non-resident species can increase the local plant diversity and how such an increase may benefit ecosystem services such as yield, forage quality, pollination or carbon fixation. The seeding also allows one to estimate to what degree the current diversity of grassland is limited by a restricted dispersal capacity of plant species. Finally, the experiment tests the adaptive potential of grasslands to future climatic changes and extreme weather events, because a higher diversity of the vegetation could be associated with a higher resilience of the system. (Source: http://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/en/projects/current-projects/plants/sade/)

title: Soil enzyme activities of all grassland EPs, soil sampling campaign (SSC) 2011, SCALEMIC
abstract: The study focussed on regional biogeography of soil microorganisms, i.e. how below ground microbial communities are organised and differentiated along geographic, climatic and environmental gradients. To address this question we characterised soil microbial communities at three levels of resolution (gene abundance, enzyme activity, and community level). The three exploratories will allow us to up-scale the biogeography of soil microorganisms from plot to regional scale.

title: Soil bulk density and organic carbon and total nitrogen stocks - soil sampling campaign 2014, all experimental plots (EP), 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the soil bulk density and the soil organic carbon (OC), and total nitrogen (TN) stocks in 0-10 cm depth from all experimental plots (EP) in 2014. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soils are important reservoirs for carbon, nitrogen and sulfur. The storage of organic carbon and nutrients is not only important for climate regulation and plant growth but also affects other soil functions. A multitude of natural factors (e.g. climate, parent material, landscape position) but also human-induced factors (e.g. land use type, management intensity) influence the potential of soils to store carbon and nutrients. Bulk density is used to calculate elemental stocks but at same time it is also an important indicator of the degree of soil compaction. It therefore greatly affects the water and solute movement in soils and the soil aeration.The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-2, TR 1054/4-2, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Bacterial functional profile (predicted metagenome), 300 EPs
abstract:
The influence of edaphic parameters, land use, management, fertilization and tree species on the bacterial community composition was analyzed. Bacterial community composition was based on the phylogenetic classification of partial (V3-V5 region) 16S rRNA gene amplicons obtained by 454 pyrosequencing and based on the SILVA SSURef NR 123 Database.

Based on the taxonomy, a functional profile (predictive metagenome) was calculated.

abstract: Browsing of tree seedlings and saplings by animals (mostly ungulates) can change density and quality of natural regeneration of forests. In case of selective browsing the composition of the regeneration may be altered directionally.

title: SNP, SSR and phenotypic data of the translocation experiment used for an association study
abstract: Climate change may lead to an increased late frost-risk in European beech. Despite the ecologic and economic importance of beech, little is known about the molecular basis of bud burst in this species. Therefore, we conducted an association analysis to identify SNPs that are significantly associated with bud burst timing.

title: Leaf and root traits, monitoring, richness 2015 - BELOW
abstract:
Our objectives are:

to predict the performance of species introduced to a community from above- and belowground traits and to compare these predictions to those obtained from co-occurrence information
to analyse root traits in addition to leaf traits of the grassland species in the Exploratories and to analyse how leaf and root traits are related to each other and how they respond to different local neighbourhoods
to characterize species-specific root exudation patterns, including the full spectrum of low molecular organic compounds exuded by different plant species
to analyse how root exudation patterns and trait values change with residence time in a community and respond to land use

title: Sebacinales VIP single root fragment
abstract: Sebacinales are a group of endophytic fungi with rather enigmatic features in the phylum Basidiomycota. Despite their widespread occurrence as mycorrhizal fungi, they also form geographically wide spread associations as root endophytes of many different plant species, which possess the potential to support plant growth. Current literature views endophytic Sebacinales as forming rather species poor communities of one to four taxa in roots, however deep sequencing methods have not been applied until now. These properties warranted a comparison of classical and next-generation sequencing methods in analyzing Sebacinales communities from grasslands of the Biodiversity Exploratories project in Germany in order to judge the reasons behind the cryptic contradiction of high presence and low abundance and diversity. Results indicate that classical sequencing methods do miss rare species and that the diversity overall captured is clearly increased by in-depth Illumina MiSeq sequencing. This more in depth sequencing also has clear implications on correlations between community composition and land use, since the clear negative correlation detected in the Sanger sequencing data was absent in the same comparison to the MiSeq data.

abstract: The index quantifies stand structural complexity based on the fractal dimension of cross-sectional polygons. As the fractal dimension itself is scale-independent, the effective number of layers (dataset 19986), a measure of vertical structure, is used the scale fractal dimension values. Detailed information on index construction can be found in Ehbrecht et al. (2017), Quantifying stand structural complexity and its relationship with forest management, tree species diversity and microclimate, Agricultural & Forest Meteorology 242, 1–9. doi: 10.1016/j.agrformet.2017.04.012

title: Crustfunction Richness of Green Algae in Biological Soil Crusts at Schorfheide, 2014
abstract:
Hypothese: Biodiversity in biological soil crust is related to its function in the biogeochemical turnover. 
We visited all plots and  searched for biological soil crusts (BSC). Not every plot inherit BSCs. If we found more than one type of crust in one plot, we sampled up to three crusts per plot (labeled with odd numbers). We took the biological soil crust with a thickness of 5mm. Besides the crusts also crust-free soil nearby with similar characterisitcs was sampled as a control for soil analyses (labeled with even numbers, not used for biodiversity analyses).

title: BeLongDead CO2 flux of deadwood & additional environmental data incl. fungal div. in 2012
abstract:
Respirational C loss (referred to as CO2 emissions) is
the main process of dead wood decomposition. CO2 emissions from dead wood can be used as a
proxy for actual decomposition rates. We applied a closed
chamber measurement technique to 360 dead wood logs of 13 important tree species in
three regions in Germany.

title: BELongDead merging fungi sporocarp inventory 2012 & 2014 & 2015 by top 100 fungal selection
abstract: Multifunctional forestry increasingly aims at both optimizing timber production and the maintenance of species diversity. Wood-inhabiting fungi, crucial for the functioning of forest ecosystems (carbon and nutrient cycle), are among those taxa most threatened by commercial forestry.

title: Microbial community of forest leaf litter and soils in Schorfheide, Hainich and Alb using PLFA analysis
abstract: Microorganisms form the basis of soil food webs and represent key control points of carbon cycling and sequestration. Virtually all central European forests are managed and land-use regimes likely impact microbial abundance and community composition. Consequently, knowledge on how land-use intensity and abiotic variables, such as pH, C-to-N ratios, moisture regimes and concomitantly different stress levels, affect microbial communities is needed. We investigated phospholipid fatty acid (PLFA) profiles of leaf litter and soil from four forest types differing in foliage, age and management intensity, replicated in three regions across Germany. To account for temporal variation, samples were taken twice in the same season, but with an interval of three years.

title: BELongDead fungi sporocarp inventory 2014
abstract: The BELongDead experiment was conceived in 2008 under the direction of Prof. E. D. Schulze (MPI Biogeochemistry Jena) with the intention to monitor the impact of habitats on the dead wood decomposition processes and to observe colonization patterns of various saproxylic organisms over long time. Its central questions are I) how does the surrounding ecosystem influence wood decomposition, II) how does succession of the substrates proceed and III) how do microorganisms mediate wood decay and subsequently impact ecosystem processes like element turnover and storage. This enables us now to investigate the direct influence of different forest management regimes on a sizeable set of 12 (+1 less frequent) different dead wood tree species each homogenous in their initial wood properties (decay stage, volume, water content) and evenly distributed in replicates across plots, landscapes and management types.

abstract: Despite the importance of fungi in decomposition and nutrient cycling in forest ecosystems, no study to date has investigated the effects of forest management on fungal communities. Here we aimed to compare the fungal  community composition of leaf litter-inhabiting fungi from different forest management types across 4 time points (89 - 473 days).

title: Fungal communities pyrosequencing in deadwood Nitrogen Experiment HEW 2011 and 2013
abstract: Nitrogen deposition can strongly affect biodiversity, but its specific effects on terrestrial microbial communities and their roles for ecosystem functions and processes are still unclear. Here, we used deadwood and wood-inhabiting fungi (WIF) as a model system to investigate the impacts of N deposition on a highly N-limited habitat.

title: Tea decomposition after 3 month grassland MIPs, 2016
abstract:
Changes in the balance between soil carbon storage and release can significantly amplify or attenuate global
warming and are also driven by land-use intensity. Our study is part of a global initiative using this standardized and rather easy approach (Djukic, I. 2016: Global litter decomposition study; Umweltbundesamt Austria).

title: Epichloe endophyte infection and alkaloid concentrations of Lolium perenne, grassland EPs, 2014-15
abstract: The common forage grass Lolium perenne has evolved with the systemic fungal endophyte Epichloë festucae var. lolii. The endophyte provides herbivore resistance to the grass due to defensive alkaloids, some of which are toxic to grazing livestock. The endophyte produces three groups of herbivore toxic metabolites; lolitremes, ergot alkaloids, and peramine. Concentrations above 2 µg/g of lolitrem B and 0.3 µg/g of ergovaline (ergot alkaloid) are vertebrate toxic and concentrations above 3 µg/g of peramine are invertebrate deterring/toxic. We determine whether effects of the endophyte-grass association increase along a land-use intensity gradient.

title: Aboveground plant biomass nutrient contents in grasslands 2014 - 2016 (NIRS) - STOICHIO
abstract: The increase in agricultural management intensity has influenced vegetation patterns, composition and dynamics through increased vegetation disturbance (mowing, grazing) and altered soil fertility (fertilization). The chemical composition of the aboveground plant biomass- used as an indicator for plant nutrition and productivity- and fibre fractions of grassland biomass- used as measure of the quality and nutritive value of herbage fodder- both integrate spatial and temporal variation on soil resources during the growing season (Klaus et al, 2011).

title: Aboveground plant biomass nutrient contents in grasslands 2014 (XRF) -STOICHIO
abstract: The increase in agricultural management intensity has influenced vegetation patterns, composition and dynamics through increased vegetation disturbance (mowing, grazing) and altered soil fertility (fertilization). The chemical composition of the aboveground plant biomass, used as an indicator for plant nutrition and productivity and may also allow the detection of heavy metals or the accumulation of plant defense structures, integrates spatial and temporal variation on soil resources available to plant species during the growing season.

title: Decomposition (dung removal in g on 300 EPs, season 2014/2015), Taxon: dung beetles (Invertebrates, Scarabaeoidea) - Dungwebs
abstract: Dung beetles (Scarabaeidae) are common detritivores, and especially the tunnelling genera Geotrupes, Anoplotrupes and Onthophagus enhance soil quality and support nutrient cycles by rapid burial of mammalian dung. Whereas dung beetles are known to provide important ecosystem services in forests and grassland, little is known in which ways land use affects dung beetles.

title: Moth species on grassland VIPs (2014)
abstract: We want to know how biodiversity and abundance of grassland moth species is affected by land-use intensity a find any relationship between the occurrence of the species and their live-history traits.

title: Life history traits of moths
abstract:
To analyse how land-use intensification may represent an environmental filter for moth species with particular life-history traits, we categorized the larval feeding niche, wingspan (as a representation of body size), reproductive cycle (expressed through voltinism and hibernation stage), geographic distribution in Europe, and national conservation status of each species based on the literature and supplemented with own data. Our data are not plot related. 
For detailed information on scoring of the traits see Supplementary Literature S1.1. of Managels et. al (2017): Diversity and trait composition of moths respond to land-use intensification in grasslands: generalists replace specialists.

title: Additional plot information of moth sampling (ID21227)
abstract: We want to know how biodiversity and abundance of grassland moth species is affected by land-use intensity a find any relationship between the occurrence of the species and their live-history traits. This dataset provides additional sampling event information

title: Morphological traits of moths
abstract: We analysed the intraspecific variation of morphological traits associated with dispersal ability (body mass, wing area and wing loading) of 67 species of moths (Lepidoptera).

title: Development and pupae weight of caterpillar in different climate treatments, 2014/15
abstract: Across 30 species of moths, growth rate and pupal mass increased with temperature at conditions 4°C and 8°C above average summer days, but effects varied across species.

title: Survival rate of caterpillar in different climate treatments, 2014/15
abstract: Across 30 species of moths, survival rate decreased with temperature at conditions 4°C and 8°C above average summer days, but effects varied across species.

title: ATR-FTIR spectral data of Achillea millefolium leaves in 22 grassland plots, 2014,  BELOW
abstract:
Attenuated total reflection Fourier transform infrared (ATR-FTIR) spectroscopy reveal the characteristic molecular vibrational transitions of specific functional groups of chemical compounds, providing a comprehensive biochemical fingerprint of the analyzed sample.
 
Achillea millefolium L. (Asteraceae), Dactylis glomerata L., and Poa pratensis L. (Poaceae) were introduced as phytometer plants in grassland plots in the three regions. The plants were raised from seeds previously collected in those plots or purchased (for P. pratense, by Rieger-Hofmann GmbH, Blaufelden, Germany), in the greenhouse of the Botanical Garden Halle (Germany) from December 2013 to April 2014. Phytometers were planted in the field in May to June 2014 (for details see Herz et al., 2017). Each phytometer species was planted in 22 plots, spanning a full range of LUI values (0.5 – 2.6) across the three regions.   
Plants were harvested in autumn 2014. The leaf material was immediately frozen in liquid nitrogen and deposited at -80°C until further analysis.

title: Fungal communities assessed by Illumina MiSeq in beech leaves and leaf litter samples 2014-2015
abstract: The ecological significance of endophytic fungi, which occur asymptomatically inside living plants, is poorly understood. After leaf-fall, former endophytic fungi are supposed to quickly sporulate and re-infect living leaves. We hypothesized that former endophytic fungi persist in decaying litter for a prolonged period of time (i.e. at least for one year).

title: 2nd forest inventory, single tree data, V.2 on all forest EPs, 2014 - 2018
abstract:
The “2nd Forest inventory at the EP level” was conducted 5 to 6 years after the 1st inventory. It serves to quantify forest productivity, forest dynamcis, forest management interventions, and changes in forest structure and LUI. 
This dataset comprises original data on species, diameter at breast height, tree heigth, wood volume and geographical location (caliper limit: dbh >= 7 cm).

title: Fungal communities pyrosequencing in deadwood BELongDead 2012 all exploratories
abstract: Diversity and distribution patterns of microbial community and their drivers are central issues in microbial ecology as this information is crucial to understand and predict the role played by microbes  in maintaining ecosystem functions and stability (Kubartová et al., 2012) and  can help to make decisions on land management. Recently conservation of microorganisms became an issue, especially for WIF (Seibold et al., 2015). However, our knowledge about WIF is only fragmentary and controversial due to limitations in detection methods of fungal communities and a lack of well-designed field experiments with enough replicates (Hoppe et al., 2016; Kubartová et al., 2012; Seibold et al., 2015). Even the most fundamental questions about diversity and tree species preference of WIF have never been tackled using suitable approaches and experiments (Seibold et al., 2015). This study aimed to address two specific questions: (i) are there differences in the diversity of WIF that colonize deadwood of different tree species?, and (ii) do WIF taxa display tree species preference?

title: Comparison of composition of wood-inhabiting fungi (age-class timber exaction / unmanaged European beech-dominated forests)(Nov. 2011)
abstract: Despite the importance of fungi in decomposition and nutrient cycling in forest ecosystems, no study to date has investigated the effects of forest management types on fungal communities. Here we aimed to compare the richness and community composition of wood-inhabiting fungi from age-class (with high and low) timber exaction, and unmanaged European beech-dominated forests.

title: Assembled species and forest management information from Hainich forest EPs (2008-2011), used for syntheses project #8
abstract:
This is the compiled dataset of the synthesis project #8. It comprises the data used in:

Schall, Peter; Gossner, Martin; Heinrichs, Steffi; Fischer, Markus; Boch, Steffen; Prati, Daniel; Jung, Kirsten; Baumgartner, Vanessa; Blaser, Stefan; Böhm, Stefan; Buscot, Francois; Daniel, Rolf; Goldmann, Kezia; Kaiser, Kirstin; Kahl, Tiemo; Lange, Markus; Müller, Jörg; Overmann, Jörg; Renner, Swen; Schulze, Ernst-Detlef; Sikorski, Johannes; Tschapka, Marco; Türke, Manfred; Weisser, Wolfgang; Wemheuer, Bernd; Wubet, Tesfaye; Ammer, Christian (2017) The impact of even-aged and uneven-aged forest management on regional biodiversity of multiple taxa in European beech forests. Journal of Applied Ecology, DOI: 10.1111/1365-2664.12950


Please note!
The dataset provided was compiled from molten community matrices. Only species that are present at a site are listed. Hence, in some cases a site is not listed for taxonomic groups or subgroups as no species from these groups were observed. These cases are!
Lichens: HEW43
Forest specialist bats: HEW28
Non-forest specialist bats: HEW08, HEW43, HEW49, HEW50
Non-forest specialist spiders: HEW29, HEW37
Non-forest specialist vascular plants: HEW18 

You need populate these cases (with zeros) before performing analyses. For instance, the lichens site x species matrix needs to be complemented by inserting a row for HEW43.


Vertebrate species name coding!
In order to protect localities of vertebrates we coded species names. Bat species (sonotypes) observed were Barbastella barbastellus, Eptesicus nilsonii, Myotis myotis, Myotis nattereri, Myotis spec., Nyctaloid high-Group, Nyctaloid low-Group, Nyctalus leiserli, Nyctalus noctula, Pipistrellus nathusii, Pipistrellus pipistrellus, Pipistrellus pygmaeus, Plecotus auritus/austriacus. Birds species observed were Aegithalos caudatus, Buteo buteo, Carduelis carduelis, Carduelis spinus, Certhia brachydactyla, Certhia familiaris, Coccothraustes coccothraustes, Columba oenas, Columba palumbus, Corvus corax, Cyanistes caeruleus, Dendrocopos major, Dendrocopos medius, Dendrocopos minor, Dryocopus martius, Erithacus rubecula, Ficedula hypoleuca, Fringilla coelebs, Fringilla montifringilla, Garrulus glandarius, Muscicapa striata, Parus major, Parus palustris, Periparus ater, Phylloscopus collybita, Phylloscopus sibilatrix, Phylloscopus trochilus, Picus canus, Prunella modularis, Pyrrhula pyrrhula, Regulus ignicapillus, Sitta europaea, Strix aluco, Sylvia atricapilla, Sylvia borin, Troglodytes troglodytes, Turdus merula, Turdus philomelos, Turdus viscivorus.

title: Leaf and root traits of species in BELOW-subplots
abstract:
Our objectives are:

to predict the performance of species introduced to a community from above- and belowground traits and to compare these predictions to those obtained from co-occurrence information
to analyse root traits in addition to leaf traits of the grassland species in the Exploratories and to analyse how leaf and root traits are related to each other and how they respond to different local neighbourhoods
to characterize species-specific root exudation patterns, including the full spectrum of low molecular organic compounds exuded by different plant species
to analyse how root exudation patterns and trait values change with residence time in a community and respond to land use

title: Assembled ecosystem measures from grassland EPs (2008-2011) for multifunctionality synthesis
abstract:
A dataset of ecosystem function/service proxy measures from grassland EPs. The original variables are included alongside measures of multifunctionality. Multifunctionality was compiled according to different management scenarios (labelled scenarios 1 to 5 here) in order to test whether effects of land use and diversity differ depending on the set of functions desired, see Allan et al. 2015 Ecology Letters 18 834–843 for details on the scenarios and the weighting of functions in them. 

For details on the original measurements, see Allan et al. 2015 or the original datasets. Note that some of the original variables are indices compiled from several other variables (phosphorus retention index, forage quality). 

Multifunctionality was calculated using a threshold based approach, for each scenario and the metrics shown here are the main ones used in the analysis, i.e. multifunctionality calculated using a 50% threshold. 

A number of other measures were also calculated for sensitivity analyses. For each scenario, multifunctionality was also calculated using different thresholds to define adequate functioning (e.g. >50% of the maximum). Multifunctionality was also calculated without using a threshold, as a mean of scaled or z-transformed values. And for the equal weight scenario (number 4) multifunctionality was also calculated dropping each function one by one, to test the sensitivity of the metric to the inclusion of particular functions.

If you would like to use any of these other metrics, please see dataset 21706 with the code to calculate them.

title: Assembled species information from grassland EPs (2010-2016) for multidiversity synthesis
abstract:
A dataset including information on each species found in the in grassland EPs. It provides information on broad taxonomic classification, trophic level and functional role of each species.

This is an updated and more complete version of the data used in Allan et al. 2014 and Gossner et al 2016.

This dataset is connected to dataset 21766 (raw abundance) by the "Species" column. 

We also provide an R script (ID 22046) to help merging this dataset with dataset 21766 and calculate various metrics (richness, abundance, diversity and multidiversity).

title: FunWood - experimental nitrogen deposition on CWD (2011 - 2017)
abstract: Anthropogenic nitrogen (N) deposition alters forest N cycles and influences various ecosystem processes. Consequently, forest C cycles are also altered, and understanding interaction between these cycles is crucial in determining how forests will respond under projected climate change scenarios. European temperate forests are some of the most severely affected ecosystems, and coarse woody debris (CWD) is an important component of these ecosystems for accurate C budgeting and modeling. However, a substantial gap exists in our understanding of how anthropogenic N deposition influences the decomposition of CWD. This study addresses this important gap, based on the experimental research framework of the BELongDead project, housed within the larger German Biodiversity Exploratories network for long-term functional biodiversity research.

title: Collembola abundances on forests plots (2008, 2011)
abstract: To investigate major determinants of Collembola community composition, we sampled and identified Collembola species from four different forest types (coniferous, young and old managed beech, and unmanaged beech) across three regions in Germany, the Swabian Alb in the southwest, the Hainich in the center, and the Schorfheide in the northeast. The regions were chosen because they span a broad geographic range within Germany and differ in geology, altitude, and climate, with the Schorfheide featuring the harshest conditions in terms of climate (continental) and geology (Fischer et al., 2010). To account for temporal variation, samples were taken twice, in the same season (spring), but with an interval of 3 years. To determine the relative importance of drivers impacting total abundance and reproductive mode,we applied structural equation modeling.

title: BELongDead: C & N concentration of dead wood logs in 2012 & 2015
abstract:
The dataset is connected to the BELongDead (Biodiversity Exploratories Long term Dead wood) Experiment established on a total of 30 plots in 2009.  
On each plot dead wood logs of 13 tree genera were exposed in three replicates (subplots) (n = 1140 logs). Tree species include nine Angiosperms: Acer spp., Betula pendula, Carpinus betulus, Fagus sylvatica, Fraxinus excelsior, Populus spp., Prunus avium, and Quercus spp., Tilia spp. and four Gymnosperms: Larix decidua, Picea abies, Pinus sylvestris, and Pseudotsuga menziesii).

title: BELongDead chemical wood properties, decomposer activity and diversity of deadwood of 13 tree species in 2012
abstract:
The dataset is connected to the BELongDead (Biodiversity Exploratories Long term Dead wood) Experiment established on a total of 30 plots in 2009.
On each plot dead wood logs of 13 tree genera were exposed in three replicates (subplots) (n = 1140 logs). Tree species include nine Angiosperms: Acer spp., Betula pendula, Carpinus betulus, Fagus sylvatica, Fraxinus excelsior, Populus spp., Prunus avium, and Quercus spp., Tilia spp. and four Gymnosperms: Larix decidua, Picea abies, Pinus sylvestris, and Pseudotsuga menziesii).
Here, we intend to investigate the change in dead wood fungal diversity along a forest management intensity gradient and its influence on wood decay and ecosystem processes such as gaseous emissions and organic carbon leaching.

title: The soil macrofauna orderlevel from all forest EPs sampled in spring 2011
abstract: Soil animals are important drivers of decomposition processes, nutrient cycling and plant growth (Cragg and Bardgett 2001, Wardle 2002, Hättenschwiler et al. 2005). Belowground food webs acquire a major fraction of their energy from detritus (Moore and DeRuiter 1991) and therefore are viewed as decomposer or brown food webs. In forests most species either directly consume dead organic matter, in particular leaf litter, feed on microbial decomposers or prey on primary and secondary decomposer animals thereby forming part of the decomposer food web.

title: Environmental sound recordings from BeSound (all EPs, 20015 / 2016)
abstract:
Indices of acoustic diversity have been shown to correlate with vegetation structure, species richness of various taxa and landscape composition. Further acoustic monitoring is applicable across large spatial and temporal scales. It thus has a high potential for large scale ecosystem monitoring. Nonetheless the drivers of acoustic diversity in relation to land-use and landscape composition are yet not well understood. The acoustic niche hypothesis postulates that a higher organismic diversity should result in a higher acoustic richness and complexity. Land-use intensity affects biodiversity in various ways and therefore could have an indirect effect on acoustic diversity. This relationship is hypothesized to be modified by abiotic factors such as temperature and rain as well as noise from nearby roads and machinery mediated by altered calling behavior of vocalizing animals.
To test this conceptual framework we set up autonomous recording systems to record 1 minute every ten in grassland and forest plots established as long term research plots along a land-use and biodiversity gradient in three regions in Germany. We calculated two acoustic diversity indices - ADI and NDSI - to test these relationships.

title: Metacommunity analysis of seasonal and spatial variation of Cercozoa in a grassland soil
abstract: We investigated small-scale temporal and spatial distribution of the Cercozoa (Rhizaria, Harosa), a very common group of amoebae and flagellate protists, in an 10x10 m in the unfertilized grassland AEG31 plot.

title: Foliar fungal assemblages of perennial rygrass in dependence of Epichloe endophyte infection, grassland EPs, 2015: Summary
abstract: It was analysed, if season, region, land use and the presence of Epichloe endophytes can modify foliar fungal assemblages in L. perenne leaves.

title: MinSoil 2014 Mineral Soil C Priming
abstract: pH measurement in the mineral soil (0-10 cm); samples taken during the coordinated sampling compaign in May 2014

title: Soil pH - soil sampling campaign 2017, all experimental plots (EPs), 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the soil pH values in 0-10 cm depth from all experimental plots (EPs) in 2017. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil pH is considered a master variable in soil science as it affects many chemical processes in soils. Most importantly, the plant nutrient availability is greatly affected by the soil pH as it controls the chemical forms of the different nutrients and influences the chemical reactions they undergo. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-3, TR 1054/4-3, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: 16S rRNA gene (V3 region) DNA-based analysis of bacterial community composition (Species level) on nine pig carcasses, 9 forest plots, SCH, 2014
abstract:
Sequence read counts of bacterial taxa at species level, as determined by high-throughput sequencing of the 16S rRNA gene V3 region. Data are based on DNA extracted from carcass sample.
In brief, nine piglet cadavers from a local farmer in Gögglingen (Baden-Württemberg, Germany) were obtained directly after still birth and kept frozen at -20 ºC until 24 hours before the start of incubation experiments. Piglets were exposed on nine different experimental plots (EPs). Piglet cadavers were placed in black wire cages in order to exclude large vertebrate scavengers while allowing smaller scavengers like arthropods and other small animals to access the carrion. The carcasses were monitored at times 0 h, 48 h and 96 h, since microbial activity is highest during the first days after death. Stages of decomposition were defined based on established visual criteria. From each piglet and at each sampling event, a piece of tissue (≈ 125 mm3) from the snout was cut out with a sterile scalpel, inserted into a sterile tube filled with 3 ml of Allprotect Tissue Reagent preservation solution, transported to the laboratory at 4ºC and then preserved at -20ºC until analysis. The piglet cadavers remained on the plot and were monitored for further non-microbial parameter until complete decomposition. For further details, see Pascual et al (2017).

title: Epichloe infection rates and alkaloid concentrations of Festuca pratensis, grassland EPs, 2015
abstract: The common forage grass Festuca pratensis has evolved with the systemic fungal endophyte Epichloë uncinata. The endophyte provides herbivore resistance to the grass due to the invertebrate deterring/toxic loline alkaloids. We determine whether effects of the endophyte-grass association increase along a land-use intensity gradient and change with season.

title: Fine root traits of 141 common Central European grassland species, greenhouse experiment, 2012
abstract: Root traits are often thought to be analogues of leaf traits along the plant economics spectrum. But evolutionary pressures have most likely shaped above- and belowground patterns differentially. We aimed to find interspecific patterns in root traits over a large set of species and check if they can be predicted by aboveground traits.

title: Nutrient concentrations in plant biomass at 73 grassland MIPs, 2016, SADE
abstract: The assessment of biomass production, chemical constituents and functional composition of grassland canopies is of crucial importance for the disentangling of biodiversity patterns. Generally, such essential data are rarely available for a high number of spatial and temporal replications. We will provide such data in a very efficient and cost effective way using near infrared spectroscopy (NIRS). Based on laboratory standard analyses of biomass samples, calibration models will be developed for the quick and cheap measurement of plant tissue constituents. For calibration, biomass samples of the 150 experimental plots of the three exploratories will be used. Initially, calibration models for the carbon content and the main plant nutrients (N, P, K) will be developed. Furthermore, the NIRS technique is applied to quantify various fractions of fibre such as cellulose and lignin.

title: Interpolated climate data of BELOW subplots, 2014 - 2015
abstract: This dataset is not direclty related to the BELOW project. To analyse our data, we used the climate data provided by BEXIS. However, as the data set is not complete for all plots, we created our own climate data set, which might also be of interest for others.

title: Nitrogen content of bumblebees and plants, grassland, 2013, Footprints
abstract: It is unclear to what extent the nitrogen content of bees is a reflection of the nitrogen content of forage plants on a landscape scale or more to the point in the present context, to what extent bees can and will regulate the changes in nitrogen content of their diet.

title: SCALEMIC - Acidobacterial rRNA sampled from top soil at six dates in 2011 on one ALB grassland plot
abstract: SCALEMIC-Acidobacterial Activity extracts acidobacterial rRNA from 60 top soils collected at six sampling dates. All data in this dataset are obtained from one 10m x 10m low intensity land use grassland plot (AEG31).

title: Distance from every EP center to the next route based on OSM data
abstract: This dataset provides the distance from every EP to the next way for different categories of ways. The classification of ways is according to the Open Street Map classification scheme as described here https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/Key:highway

title: 16S rRNA gene (V3 region) RNA-based analysis of bacterial rhizosphere community composition (Species level) of Ranunculus acris, 2015
abstract:
Sequence read counts of bacterial taxa at species level, as determined by high-throughput sequencing of the 16S rRNA gene V3 region. 
Data are based on RNA extracted from either rhizosphere samples or accompanying soil sampled during the BeLoW sampling campaign in June-July 2015
(15.06.2015-21.07.2015).
Plant phytometers were grown axenically in a greenhouse and were transplanted to the grassland study sites in May to early June 2014 (by BELOW 
project).
Rhizosphere sample material was obtained as following. 
The target plants were identified in the field and excavated. Soil was removed from the roots manually until only adherent soil particles were present (few millimetres around the root). The roots were thoroughly washed in a sterile 0.5% NaCl solution, with vigorous shaking. The root washings were decanted, and the bigger particles recovered; the supernatant was then filtered through 47mm 0,2μm polycarbonate filters. All material was flash frozen in the field and stored in liquid nitrogen.
From Dactylis glomerata and Plantago lanceolata, also the rhizosphere of naturally grown plant specimen were sampled.

title: Annual water fluxes (Grassland, VIPs, 2010-2015)
abstract: We investigated how evapotranspiration (ETa), downward water flux (DF), and upward water flux (UF) in two soil layers over 6 years (2010-2015) are related with land use and plant diversity in agriculturally managed grassland.

title: Light measurements in MIP forest plots, 2017
abstract:
The objective of this project is to use a process-based vegetation model to compare the support and relative strength of different mechanisms that are hypothesized to affect interactions between diversity, land use and ecosystem functions. Mechanisms of particular interest are:
1. Niche differentiation through growth strategies/competition for light.
2. Niche differentiation through rooting strategy and differential water use.
3. Niche differentiation through complementary nutrient / soil requirements.
4. Intraspecific variability of traits, which could create the same effects through functional diversity, despite no apparent species diversity.

title: Soil pH and carbonate concentration on 25 grassland MIPs, Swabian Alb, 2016, SADE
abstract: Soil pH and carbonate content in the mineral soil (0-10 cm) of SADE Plots in the Alb Exploratory. Soil pH was measured for all treatments (S1: control; S2: seed addition; S3: seed addition + disturbance; S4: disturbance), carbonate content only for the control treatment (S1).

title: Bacterial communities in sapwood and heartwood of logs of the BELongDead experiment (selection cutting, Hainich NP, 2014)
abstract:
Sapwood and heartwood bacterial communities of deadwood logs of 13 different tree species using an amplicon based deep-sequencing analysis.
Here we provide the relative abundances of observed bacterial OTUs.

title: Abundance of arbuscular mycorrhiza fungi sampled from top soil at six dates in 2011 on one ALB grassland plot (SCALEMIC Experiment)
abstract: Abundant arbuscular mycorrhiza fungi (AMF) of the SCALEMIC 10x10 m plot on AEG31, from each of 360 sampling points (30 subplots x 2 replicates x 6 time points)

abstract:
Information about the land use on the EPs in 2018, based on information given by the farmers or on observations by members of the exploratories.
This file will be updated continuously.
It should be used only for fieldwork planning, NOT FOR ANALYSIS!.

title: Lotus corniculatus bumblebee footprints, grassland, 2014, Footprints
abstract:
To assess footprint-derived UHCs of bumblebees on Lotus corniculatus, we visited 35 grassland sites in 2014. During each visit, we assessed the local abundance of L. corniculatus by counting open flowers along a 100 6 m transect or, if highly abundant, estimated local abundance by extrapolation from a small area. 
To assess bumblebee visitation and the effect of patch density, we collected two pooled samples containing 15 L. corniculatus flowers on each site, respectively. For one sample, flowers were collected from L. corniculatus plants in low-density patches with on average 1.34 0.67 L. corniculatus flowers per 1 m2. For the second sample, flowers were collected in high-density patches with on average 28.41 17.04 L. corniculatus flowers per 1 m2. For compar- ison, because some plant species produce alkenes in their epicuticular wax layer (Cseke et al., 2006), we also sampled unvisited flowers. For this we covered a patch of L. corniculatus with mosquito mesh, removed open flowers, waited for fresh flowers to open, and took two samples of 15 flowers, both from the ‘Schwäbische Alb’. 
We extracted each pooled flower sample in 2 ml of n-hexane. Extracts were analysed with coupled gas chromatography and mass spectrometry.

title: Early cut aboveground plant biomass nutrient contents in selected species in grasslands 2014 (NIRS) - STOICHIO
abstract: The increase in agricultural management intensity has influenced vegetation patterns, composition and dynamics through increased vegetation disturbance (mowing, grazing) and altered soil fertility (fertilization). The chemical composition of the aboveground plant biomass- used as an indicator for plant nutrition and productivity- and fibre fractions of grassland biomass- used as measure of the quality and nutritive value of herbage fodder- both integrate spatial and temporal variation on soil resources during the growing season (Klaus et al, 2011).

title: 18S rDNA data for Protistan microbiome of grassland soils, NanoFaun, 2011
abstract:
The Protistan Microbiome of Grassland
Soil: Diversity in the Mesoscale

DNA isolation, PCR amplification and NGS: Whole genomic DNA was extracted from 1 g of each composite soil sample using the PowerSoil® DNA isolation kit (Mo Bio Laboratories, Inc., Carlsbad, CA) and quantified using a Nanodrop 100 spectrophotometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Germany). DNA quality was assessed by 2% Agarose gel electrophoresis. Overall DNA concentration was adjusted to 100 ng/µl using DEPC deionized water (ddH2O). The highly variable V4 region of the 18S rRNA gene was directly amplified from the samples using the eukaryotic specific primers 590F (5’-3’:CGGTAATTCCAGCTCCAATAGC) and 1300R (5’-3’:CACCAACTAAGAACGGCCATGC). To separate the sequences, the Titanium primer design and the recommended multiplex identifier (MID) adaptor complex design (Roche, Germany) method was used. The pre-454 sequencing PCR reaction contained: 2µl (100 ng/µl) DNA, 2 µl 10x DNA polymerase buffer with 20 mM MgSO4, 2µl (1 μM) 590F primer [590F + Key + MID + Adaptor A] and 2µl (1 μM) 1300R primer, 2µl (2 mM) dNTP each and 0.4 µl (2.5 U/µl) Pfu (Pyrococcus furiosus) DNA polymerase (Fermentas, Germany) and filled up to a total volume of 25 µl with ddH2O. Pfu polymerase was used because of its high fidelity (2.6x10-6 error rate) through 5' to 3' exonuclease activity. Cycling conditions were: initial denaturation at 95°C for 3 min; 30 cycles at 95°C for 30 s, 55°C for 30 s, 72°C for 2 min; and a final extension at 72°C for 10 min. PCR product quality was evaluated by agarose gel electrophoresis (2%) and its quantity was determined by spectrophotometry on a Nanodrop 100 (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Germany). The pre-454 sequencing PCR reaction was amplified in triplicate and pooled to a final concentration of 20 ng/µl to eliminate possible PCR bias. NGS using the GS-FLX sequencer with Titanium sequencing kit XLR70 (Roche, Germany) was performed by GATC Biotech AG, Germany. Sequencing was done as from the forward primer (adaptor A).

title: Insect visitation rate on Lotus corniculatus observed on some grassland plots from 2010-2011, Footprints
abstract: To estimate visitation rates conventionally, we used previously collected data from the same region (Martina Tospann, unpub- lished data). In total, 17 grassland sites were visited in the ‘Schwäbische Alb’ from 5-Aug-2010 to 2-Sep-2010 and 16 grassland sites in the ‘National Park Hainich’ from 28-Jun-2011 to 25-Aug-2011. Each grassland site was visited once, with observations conducted between 9:29 and 18:10. On 8 subplots (50   50 cm) per grassland site all visits to L. corniculatus were recorded for 15 min each. We also counted all open flowers on each subplot at the time of observation. For each subplot, we calculated the number of visits per flower per hour. We then used the average per grassland site for subsequent analyses.

title: Fungal ITS bulk soil and rhizosphere community composition at 13 grassland plots, Hainich, 2014, BELOW
abstract:
Data are based on total DNA extracted from either rhizosphere samples from plant phytometers or bulk soil sampled during the BELOW sampling campaign in autumn 2014 (September-October) in the Hainich-Dün Exploratory. Here, 13 plots and 4 phytometer plants (two forbs: Plantago lanceolata and Achillea millefolium and two grasses: Arrhenatherum elatius and Dactylis glomerata) were chosen.
Plant phytometers were grown axenically in a greenhouse and were transplanted to the grassland study sites by BELOW project from 28.04. to 04.06.2014. 
Sequence read counts of fungi, as determined by high-throughput sequencing of the ITS2 rDNA region.

title: Bacterial 16S bulk soil and rhizosphere community composition at 13 grassland plots, Hainich, 2014, BELOW
abstract:

title: Plant species-specific land-use niches; based on the years 2009-2014 land use and vegetation records - STOICHIO
abstract:
Intensification of grassland management (amount of fertilization, mowing, grazing) especially mowing and grazing,   has been shown to affect vegetation dynamics and structure and potentially causing overall biodiversity loss. The assembly, coexistence and persistence of plant species along environmental gradients and the occupation of available ecological niches are based on the species' responses to disturbance and stress.
A detailed assessment of plant species-specific performance in response to current agricultural grassland use in Central Europe is widely missing. However this knowledge, in combination with i.e. plant functional traits or ecological strategies, may provide useful information for predicting species responses to land-use (change).

abstract: Measure genetic and epigenetic diversity, their stability over one generation, relate them to land use and other environmental descriptors.

abstract:

The BELongDead Experiment was initiated to study effects of tree species identity and forest stand attributes on saproxylic communities and wood decomposition. Freshly cut logs of 13 different tree species were placed on 30 forest plots in 2009/2010. Sampling started in 2010 is still continued

title: Annual water fluxes grassland EPs 2010-2016
abstract:
According to Leimer et al. (2018) for the 29 grassland VIPs (dataset 22486), the water
balance of the 150 grassland EPs was calculated with a simplified method. The caclulated water fluxes comprise actual evapotranspiration (ETa), downward water flux (DF), and upward water flux (UF) in one soil layer (0-0.15 m) over 7 years (2010-2016).

abstract: Set of stand structural attributes (SSA) that characterize the structure of forest EPs in the years 2015 and 2016, and may contribute to explain local biodiversity.

title: Stand structural attributes based on revised 1st forest inventory, all forest EPs, 2008 – 2014
abstract: Set of stand structural attributes (SSA) that characterize the structure of forest EPs in the years 2008 to 2011, and may contribute to explain local biodiversity. The dataset is based on the revised 1st forest inventory data.

title: Formating Matrix Data into Long Table Format: R Script and Excel Macro
abstract:
It has a lot of sharing benefits to to stores wide matrix data, such as OTU occurrence, in a long table format. With the underlying R Script and the Excel add-in you can trnsform such a matrix data (wide) into the tabular (long) format. Matrix data can also have multiple header rows or columns.
In ID 20766 an R Script is stored that formats data back into matrix format. 
Information about usage are provided with the file as comments or in a etra file.

title: Growth, harvests, deadwood and mortality from forest inventories on all forest EPs, 2008 – 2018
abstract: Forest growth, harvests, dead wood input and mortality based on the 1st (2008 - 2011) and 2nd forest inventory (2015 - 2016).

title: InsectScale / LANDSCAPES - Landscape heterogeneity metrics (grassland EPs, radii 500m-2000m, 2009)
abstract: The aim of this sub-project is to quantify regional land use types within the Biodiversity Exploratories, so that the effects of landscape composition and configuration and scale-dependency of biodiversity patterns, biotic interactions and ecosystem functioning can be analysed.

title: Saproxylic beetles on different tree species, all forest VIPs, intensive subplots, 2011 to 2014, BELongDead
abstract: The BELongDead Experiment was initiated to study effects of tree species identity and forest stand attributes on saproxylic communities and wood decomposition. Freshly cut logs of 13 different tree species were placed on 30 forest plots in 2009/2010.

title: Timber production on all forest EPs, 2008 – 2016
abstract: Timber production is an important ecosystem service. We quantified timber production as mean annual increment MAI for even-aged forests and as periodic annual increment for uneven-aged and unmanaged forests.

title: Fungal assemblage from top soil at six dates in 2011 on one ALB grassland plot (SCALEMIC Experiment): OTU abundances
abstract: General fungi of the SCALEMIC 10x10 m plot on AEG31, from each of 360 sampling points (30 subplots x 2 replicates x 6 time points)

title: Stand composition based on 2nd forest inventory (abundance, basal area, crown projection area and volume) on all forest EPs, 2014 – 2018
abstract: This dataset describes the composition of the forest EPs in terms of tree species abundance, basal area, crown projection area and timber volume based on the 2nd forest inventory.

title: Horizontal heterogeneity and canopy cover from airborne LIDAR on all forest EPs, 2008 – 2010
abstract: Based on high resolution airborne Lidar this dataset quantifies the horizontal heterogeneity and canopy cover of forest EPs.

title: Chemical traits of fine roots collected in 2014 from 150 forest plots
abstract: The objective was to investigate the relationship between fine root chemical traits and diversity of the root-associated fungal community in temperate forests

title: Fungal communities from fine roots collected from 150 forest plots in 2014 by Illumina sequencing  - normalized to 8400 reads per plot
abstract: The objective was to investigate the root-associated fungal community and their relationships with root chemical traits and soil properties in temperate forests

title: Fungal communities from fine roots collected from 150 forest plots in 2014 by Illumina sequencing
abstract: The objective was to investigate the root-associated fungal community and their relationships with root chemical traits and soil properties in temperate forests

title: RemSens Landsat time series of all forest EPs, 1985 - 2015
abstract: Time series of Landsat images from 1985 to 2015, covering Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische-Alb.

title: High turgor loss point promotes drought survival of temperate grassland species, experiment, 2015 - 2016.
abstract: Understanding the mechanisms underlying differential drought resistance of temperate grassland species is crucial to predict consequences of global climate change. Turgor loss point(πtlp) has been suggested to be a key drought resistance trait in woody species. In herbaceous species its role has not yet been tested

title: Biomass experimental plants of 9 grassland plots,  LandUseFeedback, Hainich 2017
abstract: Under natural conditions, aboveground herbivory and plant-soil feedbacks (PSFs) are omnipresent interactions strongly affecting individual plant performance and community composition. Although recent research suggests that the outcome of these PSFs can be influenced by aboveground herbivorous insects, it is unclear to what extent the intensity of herbivory affects the outcome and hence the importance of PSFs under natural conditions. Therefore, we performed a standardized comparative PSF experiment in nine grasslands that differed in land-use related intensity of aboveground herbivory.

title: Plant soil feedback values of 4 grass species at 9 grassland plots, LandUseFeedback, Hainich 2017
abstract: Under natural conditions, aboveground herbivory and plant-soil feedbacks (PSFs) are omnipresent interactions strongly affecting individual plant performance and community composition. Although recent research suggests that the outcome of these PSFs can be influenced by aboveground herbivorous insects, it is unclear to what extent the intensity of herbivory affects the outcome and hence the importance of PSFs under natural conditions. Therefore, we performed a standardized comparative PSF experiment in nine grasslands that differed in land-use related intensity of aboveground herbivory.

title: Carbon and nitrogen content of experimental plants at 3 grassland plots, LandUseFeedback, Hainich 2017
abstract:
In 2017 we performed a herbivore-exclusion experiment in nine grasslands in the Hainich. Within this experiment we grew plants on different soils (to test plant-soil feedback effects) in the presence and absence of herbivores.
We wanted to investigate whether soils affect plant quality and thus herbivory by aboveground herbivores.
Therefore, we measured nitrogen and carbon content in shoots and roots of experimental plants.

title: Comparison of biomass, leaf number and height of beeches (Fagus sylvatica) from different origins in the Biodiversity Exploratory Schorfheide, 2017
abstract: In 2011, beechnuts were collected from four plots of each exploratorium, grown in the greenhouse before planted out to all exploratories. In total: 40 trees for each origin and 120 trees per plot. In 2018, trees of different origins and exploratories were harvested. Biomass, number of leaves and height were determined.

title: Comparison of biomass and height of beeches (Fagus sylvatica) from different origins in the Biodiversity Exploratory Schwäbische Alb, 2017
abstract: In 2011, beechnuts were collected from four plots of each exploratorium, grown in the greenhouse before planted out to all exploratories. In total: 40 trees for each origin and 120 trees per plot. In 2018, trees of different origins and exploratories were harvested. Biomass, number of leaves and height were determined.

title: Extracellular enzyme activities on 6 grassland EPs in Hainich, 2016
abstract: Rhizosphere soil of five plant species (Agrimonia eupatoria, Dactylis glomerata, Lotus corniculatus, Taraxacum sect. Ruderalia, Trifolium repens) was sampled along a land-use intensity gradient ranging from low to high intensities in the Hainich grassland exploratories in May 2016. At each plot, up to three individuals of each plant species were randomly selected and excavated to a depth of 10 cm. The soil adhering to the roots was operationally defined as rhizosphere soil.

title: Untargeted Metabolome Analysis of Root Exudates GCMS (Harvest Campaign 2014, BELOW)  - processed data
abstract: Primary and secondary metabolites exuded by plant roots have mainly been studied under laboratory conditions, while knowledge of root exudate patterns of plants growing in natural communities is very limited. Focusing on ten common European grassland plant species, we asked to which degree exuded metabolite compositions are specific to species or growth forms (forbs and grasses), depend on environments and local neighbourhoods, and reflect traditional plant functional traits. Root exudates were collected under field conditions and analysed using a non-targeted gas chromatography coupled mass spectrometry (GC-MS) approach.

title: Biomass, specific leaf area and leaf dry matter content of different plant species (54 grassland plots, BERICH) 2013
abstract:
BERICH
Project description
The overarching objective of this project is to understand assembly rules of the grassland communities in the Biodiversity Exploratories. Our principal experimental approach is enrichment planting, using different species additions to test for community saturation, to evaluate predictions based on the co-occurrence information in the GVRD, to analyse whether the community is characterized by trait similarity or dissimilarity and whether the latter reflects prevailing environmental filters or niche complementarity. Our study will include the three main different land use types (meadow, pasture, mown pasture) in all three Exploratories.

title: Box-dimension of stem base maps of 125 forest EPS, 2014-2016
abstract: We calculated the box-dimension (a measure of structural complexity) of the stem base maps (maps showing the position and size of the tree stems in 125 forest EPs) in order to test whether this measure is able to assess tree number, density and distribution at the same time.

title: Fungal ITS root endophyte community composition at 13 grassland plots, Hainich, 2014, BELOW
abstract:
Data are based on total DNA extracted from the root endosphere of the plant phytometers sampled during the BELOW sampling campaign in autumn 2014 (September-October) in the Hainich-Dün Exploratory. DNA extraction was done after root surface sterilization. Here, 13 plots and 4 phytometer plants (two forbs: Plantago lanceolata and Achillea millefolium and two grasses: Arrhenatherum elatius and Dactylis glomerata) were chosen.
Plant phytometers were grown axenically in a greenhouse and were transplanted to the grassland study sites by the BELOW project from 28.04. to 04.06.2014. 
Sequence read counts of fungi, as determined by high-throughput sequencing of the ITS2 rDNA region.

title: Infection Experiment with Pseudodidymella fagi on beech 2017
abstract: Plants can be severely affected by insect herbivores and phytopathogenic fungi, but the role of insect-fungus interactions is thereby poorly understood. We analysed the impact of mechanical damage (immitating feeding damage by adults of the herbivore Orchestes fagi) on infection rates of beech (Fagus sylvatica) leaves in the shade and sun canopy with Pseudodidymella fagi, an invasive plant pathogenic fungus.

title: Foliar fungal assemblages of perennial rygrass in dependence of Epichloe endophyte infection, grassland EPs, 2015: OTU abundances
abstract: It was analysed, if season, region, land use and the presence of Epichloe endophytes can modify foliar fungal assemblages in L. perenne leaves.

title: Annual mean nitrate concentrations (simulated and measured) in soil solution, all grassland EPs, 2010 - 2012
abstract:
We investigated the effect of land use and biodiversity on nitrate (NO3-N) and ammonium (NH4-N) concentrations in soil solution during 2010 and 2012. The Bayesian model is developed using soil solution data from the
29 grassland VIPs as well as plot specific data from
the 150 EPs and allows the extrapolation of the results to all 150 grassland plots.

title: Crustfunction Richness of Green Algae in Biological Soil Crusts at 22 forest plots, 2015
abstract:
Hypothese: Biodiversity in biological soil crust is related to its function in the biogeochemical turnover. 
We visited all plots and  searched for biological soil crusts (BSC). Not every plot inherit BSCs. We took the biological soil crust with a thickness of 5mm. Besides the crusts also crust-free soil nearby with similar characterisitcs was sampled as a control for soil analyses (labeled with even numbers, not used for biodiversity analyses).
