title: R script for paper Gossner et al. 2016 Nature 540:266-269
abstract:
An R-script to reproduce the analyses from the paper:
Gossner, M.M., Lewinsohn, T.M., Kahl, T., et al. (2016) Land-use intensification causes multitrophic homogenization of grassland communities. Nature, 540, 266–269. https://doi.org/10.1038/nature20575

The script contains the code to:
- Assemble datasets from BExIS to produce the dataset used in the paper
- Calculate beta-diversity                                                                            - Perform the statistical analyses                                                                                    - Produce the figures

It requires the following datasets:
- 21766 version 1.7.8 (diversity)
- 21726 version 1.6.24 (species information)
- 20907 version 1.9.2 (plot coordinates) 
- 20826 version 1.11.9 (plot names)
- 14446 version 1.5.8 (soil information)
- 17086 version 1.1.6 (soil information)
- 14447 version 1.10.13 (pH)
- 18148 version 1.2.5 (landscape)
- LUI_glob_sep_24.08.2017+165913 (from LUI tool) 
- 21707 version 1.0.0 (multidiversity function), also available at https://github.com/eric-allan/multidiversity

title: The soil macrofauna orderlevel from 48 forest plots sampled in spring 2014
abstract: Soil animals are important drivers of decomposition processes, nutrient cycling and plant growth (Cragg and Bardgett 2001, Wardle 2002, Hättenschwiler et al. 2005). Belowground food webs acquire a major fraction of their energy from detritus (Moore and DeRuiter 1991) and therefore are viewed as decomposer or brown food webs. In forests most species either directly consume dead organic matter, in particular leaf litter, feed on microbial decomposers or prey on primary and secondary decomposer animals thereby forming part of the decomposer food web.

title: The soil mesofauna orderlevel from 48 forest plots sampled in spring 2014
abstract: Soil animals are important drivers of decomposition processes, nutrient cycling and plant growth (Cragg and Bardgett 2001, Wardle 2002, Hättenschwiler et al. 2005). Belowground food webs acquire a major fraction of their energy from detritus (Moore and DeRuiter 1991) and therefore are viewed as decomposer or brown food webs. title: The abundance of forest soil living invertebrates from emergence traps in 16 HEW plots from April to November 2016
abstract: Larvae of Diptera are an abundant taxa in soil animal communities but information on the trophic position are lacking. By using emergence traps with a diameter of 1.15 m covering an area of 1 m² we are able to investigate soil living Diptera larvae which reached adulthood. The Diptera community will be investigated within one growing season from March until November 2016 along a land-use gradient by using emergence traps which will be sampled all 2-4 weeks. Species identity, abundance, biomass and emergence time will be analyzed. To identify the trophic position stable isotopes (15N and 13C) of Diptera will be measured.

title: The earthworm species from 48 forest plots sampled in spring 2014
abstract: Soil animals are important drivers of decomposition processes, nutrient cycling and plant growth (Cragg and Bardgett 2001, Wardle 2002, Hättenschwiler et al. 2005). title: Red Clover phenotypic data, experimental data, 2015
abstract:
-	Regrowth of fodder plants after grazing and mowing drives the profitability of their cultivation and is therefore an important target trait for plant breeding and agricultural engineering. However, for some fodder plants little is known about their regrowth dynamics in response to grazing or mowing.
-	We analyzed the native response of plant architecture, leaf morphology and growth performance to experimental cutting in wild Trifolium pratense L. (red clover) plants. One hundred fifty potted clover plants were established under controlled field conditions, and half of the plants were cut to 5 cm 3 months after sowing. Each plant was measured every week for 5 months. 
-	The cut and subsequently regrown plants carried fewer main branches (-20%), as well as fewer (-13%) and smaller (-32%) leaves than the control plants. However, the cut plants produced an average of 17% more cumulated leaf area (cut plus regrown leaf area) than the control plants. This discrepancy was explained by variation in the growth strategy of the plants, where the cut plants invariably expressed a second growth phase, while almost half of the untreated plants did not. 
-	Our results suggest that cutting acted as an artificial trigger initiating a second growth phase in the cut plants and thereby contributed to yield increase. Exploiting this mechanism may set new goals for breeding and optimization of the mowing regime.

title: EST-SSR data for European beech (Fagus sylvatica L.) from 3 forest plots, 2018
abstract: The genetic variation of a species can be analyzed with molecular markers. Despite growing genomic and genetic resources for European beech (Fagus sylvatica L.), the number of molecular markers for population genetic analyses is still limited. Therefore, we tested 15 new EST-SSR (expressed sequence tag - short sequence repeat) markers for this species. The performance of the markers was tested in progeny from beech populations growing in the forest plots AEW5, HEW10, and SEW5. The successfully tested markers can be used in future population genetic studies.

title: Vegetation Records for 150 Grassland EPs in 2017, Header Data without Species Identities (incl. biomass) - Updated Version available (Dataset 31466)
abstract:
Biomass was clipped in two subplots. In each subplot we clipped all plants of eight 50cm x 50cm plots at the height of 2cm.
The height was measured as well.

title: Vegetation records SADE on 73 Grassland EPs; 2017, Header data without species identity (incl. biomass)
abstract: A major challenge in ecological restoration is to effectively restore plant diversity in permanent grasslands. As species richness is often limited by seed dispersal, introducing locally absent species by seed addition is often crucial. We established a full-factorial experiment with high-diversity seeding and topsoil disturbance in 73 grasslands along land-use intensity and productivity gradients and evaluated the restoration success over 5 year (SADE is an abbreviation for "seed addition and disturbance experiment"). We found that plant diversity increased considerably when seeding and disturbance were combined while seeding alone only slightly increased species richness. Along land-use gradients, we found no direct effects of grazing or mowing on the establishment of sown species, but fertilization indirectly limited establishment in the combined treatment via a negative effect of productivity. Our results highlight the potential of using diverse seed mixtures for biodiversity restoration in a wide range of permanent grasslands, especially when combined with topsoil disturbance.

title: Crustfunction 16S rRNA gene (V3 region) DNA-based analysis of bacterial community composition (Phylum level) on 28 forest plots in 2014/2015
abstract:
Hypothese: Biodiversity of bacteria in biological soil crust is related to algal biodiversity. 
We visited all plots and  searched for biological soil crusts (BSC). We vistied Schorfheide in june 2014, Alb and Hainich in June 2015. Not every plot inherit BSCs. We took the biological soil crust with a thickness of 5mm and freeze the samples in field. DNA was subsequentially extracted using the MoBio PowerSoil Kit.

title: Relative space filling of  34 Forest EPs, 2014-2015
abstract: In this project we  applied terrestrial laser to quantify comprehensive spatial structures in forests with reasonable effort.

title: Vegetation Records for 73 Grassland EPs in the SADE project, 2015 - 2017
abstract:
SADE is an abbreviation for "seed addition and disturbance experiment".
In each of 73 grasslands we set-up a full-factorial experiment consisting of disturbance and seed addition treatments. This resulted in four 7 m × 7 m subplots per grassland, which contained one of four combinations: control, disturbed, seeds added and both disturbed and seeds added. In most cases the four subplots were grouped together with a 2 m margin between the subplots. In few cases, subplots were more scattered because of site heterogeneity or requirements by farmers owning the grasslands. For the disturbance treatment, the top 10cm of the grassland sward was destroyed using rotovation tilling (Schorfheide) or a rotary harrow (Alb and Hainich). Thereby, the sward was broken up and turned over, creating open patches with bare soil while fragments of the former sward, were left on the disturbed subplots. Disturbance was applied once in October 2014. The seed addition treatment consisted of adding a highly diverse, region-specific seed mixture of plant species to each subplot. While the same seed mixture was added to each plot within a region, different species pools were used for different regions. Seeds were purchased from commercial seed suppliers which guaranteed regional origin from geographically defined zones. In the Schorfheide the mixture consisted of 47 species, in the Hainich of 52 species and in the Schwäbische Alb of 66 species. The number of seeds added depended on seed mass and was targeted to 100 seeds × m−2 (for seeds < 1mg), 34 (for seeds 1mg − 10mg) and 17 (for seeds > 10mg). In few cases, the final number was slightly lower due to limited seed availability. Seeds were added twice, with two thirds of the mixtures added in November 2014 and one third in March 2015. For an even distribution of the seeds, they were mixed with sand or crushed soybean, which was also added to the control plots.

title: Vegetation Records for 150 Grassland EPs, 2008 - 2017
abstract: To create a dataset of a large-scale long-term time series of vegetation composition we conduct an annual monitoring of plant species richness and community composition. In spring of the years 2008-2017, we sampled all species in an area of 4m x 4m and estimated the percentage cover of each species.

title: Fertilization experiment - vegetation complexity around Plantago lanceolata (2009,2010, ALB, HAI, SCH)
abstract: Fertilization experiment. Fertilization may affect herbivore abundance directly via altered host plant quality and availability and indirectly via increased structural complexity and plant species diversity. Interacting effects of features of the vegetation with host–parasitoid systems could further alter more complex interactions in a multi- trophic context of bottom–up and top–down effects. Here data are given of the effect of fertilization on vegetation complexity (vegetation structure and diversity) around a host plant (here: Plantago lanceolata)

title: Tree microhabitat abundance of all forest EPs, 2017 - 2018
abstract: Tree related microhabitats may contribute to the preservation of biodiversity in forests.

title: Crustfunction 16S rRNA gene (V3 region) DNA-based analysis of bacterial community composition (biom file) on 28 forest plots in 2014/2015
abstract:
Hypothese: Biodiversity of bacteria in biological soil crust is related to algal biodiversity.

title: Vegetation Records for 151 Forest EPs, 2009 - 2017
abstract: To create a dataset of a large-scale long-term time series of vegetation composition we conduct an annual monitoring of plant diversity in an area of 20 m x 20 m in all 151 forest EPs.

title: SADE Experiment: Germination test of sown seeds, 2014-2015
abstract: For the SADE (seed addition and disturbance) experiment we wanted to have an estimate on how well the seeds we used for the seed addition treatment germinated in standardized conditions. This was important as we used region-specific seed mixtures for which we we purchased seeds from commercial seed suppliers, which guaranteed regional origin from geographically defined zones. With this germination test we could identify if species germinated in comparable quantities for the different regions.

title: Soil seed bank of 73 MIPs, 2015
abstract:
Seed bank composition was determined during set-up of SADE experiment in all four subplots before treatments were carried out.
The SADE experiment (seed addition and disturbance experiment) consisted of four treatment plots (control, seed addition, disturbance, seed addition & disturbance) on 73 grassland EPs/MIPs. The size of each treatment plot (SADE subplots), on which we collected the samples for the soil seed bank, was 7 m x 7 m each.

title: Fertilization experiment - Host plant parameters of Plantago lanceolata (2009,2010, ALB, HAI, SCH)
abstract: Fertilization experiment. Fertilization may affect herbivore abundance directly via altered host plant quality and availability and indirectly via increased structural complexity and plant species diversity. Interacting effects of features of the vegetation with host–parasitoid systems could further alter more complex interactions in a multi- trophic context of bottom–up and top–down effects. Here data are given of the effect of fertilization on host plant parameters (here: Plantago lanceolata).

title: Phospholipid Lipid Fatty Acids (PLFA), 27 grassland VIPs, May 2017
abstract: The dataset describes bulk PLFA concentrations in mol per g of soil from the 27 VIP grassland plant. These were measured at James Hutton Institute.

One hundred fifty potted clover plants were established under controlled field conditions, and half of the plants were cut to 5 cm 3 months after sowing. Each plant was measured every week for 5 months. 
-	The cut and subsequently regrown plants carried fewer main branches (-20%), as well as fewer (-13%) and smaller (-32%) leaves than the control plants. However, the cut plants produced an average of 17% more cumulated leaf area (cut plus regrown leaf area) than the control plants. This discrepancy was explained by variation in the growth strategy of the plants, where the cut plants invariably expressed a second growth phase, while almost half of the untreated plants did not. 
-	Our results suggest that cutting acted as an artificial trigger initiating a second growth phase in the cut plants and thereby contributed to yield increase. Exploiting this mechanism may set new goals for breeding and optimization of the mowing regime.

title: Fertilization experiment - weevils and parasitoid of Plantago lanceolata (2009,2010, ALB, HAI, SCH)
abstract: Fertilization experiment. Fertilization may affect herbivore abundance directly via altered host plant quality and availability and indirectly via increased structural complexity and plant species diversity. Interacting effects of features of the vegetation with host–parasitoid systems could further alter more complex interactions in a multitrophic context of bottom–up and top–down effects. Here data are given of the effect of fertilization on the abundance and incidence (presence/absence) of the weevils Mecinus labilis and Mecinus pascuorum as well as the parasitoid Mesopolobus incultus inhabiting Plantago lanceolata.

title: Root biomass per soil volume of 111 Forest EPs, Soil sampling campaign, May 2011
abstract: Root biomass per soil volume was determined in a composite sample, representative for each forest plot

title: Soil carbon and nitrogen concentrations - soil sampling campaign 2017, all experimental plots (EPs), 0-10 cm
abstract:
The core project Soil provides essential information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all 301 Experimental Plots (EPs) of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the organic carbon (OC), inorganic carbon (IC) and nitrogen (TN) concentrations and carbon to nitrogen ratios (CN ratio) in 0-10 cm depth from all EPs in 2017. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil organic carbon and nitrogen concentrations are master variables in soil science. Soil organic carbon and nitrogen are the measureable components of soil organic matter (SOM). SOM exerts positive effects on numerous physical, chemical and biological soil properties. An increase in SOM generally results in an improved soil structure, soil moisture retention, soil buffering capacity, retention of pollutants, cycling and storage of plant nutrients and biodiversity. SOM also acts as a sink and source for atmospheric carbon dioxide. 

The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-3, TR 1054/4-3, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Vegetation Records on 147 Forest EPs; Forest - Regeneration; 2016
abstract: Browsing of plant species by animals (mostly ungulates) can change density and quality of natural regeneration of forests. In case of selective browsing the composition of the regeneration may be altered directional. Additionally we assume that herbs and shrubs might be affected in different ways by browsing.

title: Vegetation Records on 147 Forest EPs; Forest - Regeneration; autumn 2015/spring 2016, header data without species identity
abstract: Browsing of plant species by animals (mostly ungulates) can change density and quality of natural regeneration of forests. In case of selective browsing the composition of the regeneration may be altered directional. We assume that herbs and shrubs might be affected in different ways by browsing, while shrubs suffer, herbs could profit through seed dispersal and higher light availability by removal of shrubs.

title: Field data - soil sampling campaign 2017, all experimental plots (EPs), organic layer + 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides essential information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. In 2017 the 4th coordinated soil sampling in the biodiversity exploratories took place. This dataset contains all field data from all experimental plots (EPs) in 2017. The sampling included the organic layer in forest plots and the 0-10 cm depth increment at all EPs. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-3, TR 1054/4-3, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de)

title: Soil enzyme activities - soil sampling campaign 2014, all forest experimental plots (EPs), 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides essential information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all 300 experimental plots (EPs) of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the soil enzyme activities  in 0-10 cm depth from all forest EPs in 2014. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil enzymes play an important role in nutrient turnover in forest ecosystems as they are responsible for the conversion of organic matter into plant-available nutrients. We measured the activities of key enzymes involved in N, C, P, and S cycling. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-2, TR 1054/4-2, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Morphological traits of moths (Standardized)
abstract: We analysed the intraspecific variation of morphological traits associated with dispersal ability (body mass, wing area and wing loading) of 67 species of moths (Lepidoptera)

title: Root associated fungal community of 111 Forest EPs, forest-rarefaction to 466 OTUs, 2011: OTU abundances (related to ID 19186)
abstract: The objective was to investigate the root associated fungal community.

title: Bacterial diversity as assessed by Shannon index in top soil collected at six dates in 2011 with respect to AEG31 (SCALEMIC Experiment)
abstract: Understanding spatial and temporal patterns in species diversity is one of the fundamental goals of biodiversity research. The SCALEMIC Experiment offers an ideal basis for studying such spatio-temporal changes. Soil bacterial diversity as assessed by the Shannon index was analyzed with respect to the SCALEMIC 10x10 m plot within AEG31. Diversity measurements were performed with respect to each of the 360 sampling points (30 subplots x 2 replicates x 6 time points).

title: Novel antibiotic resistance genes in VIP soils, 2008
abstract: In contrast to clinical pathogens, bacterial communities inhabiting complex environments such as soil have been rarely considered within studies focusing on antibiotic resistance. To assess risks of environmental resistomes and develop strategies to tackle antibiotic resistance, an improved knowledge on the ecology of resistance determinants including their origins, diversity and underlying resistance mechanisms is urgently required. Antibiotic resistance genes were identified in soil samples derived from the VIP plots. For this purpose, function-based screening of soil metagenomic libraries was performed.

title: Ant species diversity and occurence of root aphids in ant nests on 110 grassland EPs, 2014/2015, AntAphid
abstract: Ants are an important functional group of temperate grassland ecosystems. Land-use intensification has been shown to have a negative influence on ant diversity. However the mechanisms leading to these effects are not well understood and may affect different ant species differently, as ant species may differ in trophic niche.

title: Genetic diversity indices based on EST-SSR data for European beech (Fagus sylvatica L.) from 3 forest plots, 2018
abstract: The genetic variation of a species can be analyzed with molecular markers. Despite growing genomic and genetic resources for European beech (Fagus sylvatica L.), the number of molecular markers for population genetic analyses is still limited. Therefore, we tested 15 new EST-SSR (expressed sequence tag - short sequence repeat) markers for this species. The performance of the markers was tested in progeny from beech populations growing in the forest plots AEW5, HEW10, and SEW5. The successfully tested markers can be used in future population genetic studies.

title: Vegetation records for grassland SADE on 73 EPs, 2015 - 2018
abstract: SADE is an abbreviation for "seed addition and disturbance experiment". The goal of this project is to study the effect of disturbance and/or seed addition in grasslands. In spring of the years 2015-2018, we sampled all species in area of 2m by 2m and estimated the percentage cover of each species for each treatment separately.

title: Abundance of mobile genetic elements and 16s genes in all EPs, 2017
abstract: The absolute abundance or threshold cycles from the quantification of incp-1 plasmids and intI1 integrons, along with the absolute abundance of 16s genes, was determined via quantitative real time PCR  in the soil of all Experimental Plots. This was done to identify land use techniques that have an influence on the abundance of mobile genetic elements, kown to spread resistance genes throughout bacterial communities.

title: InsectScale / LANDSCAPES - Landscape heterogeneity metrics (grassland EPs, radii 500m-2000m, 2009) - shape files
abstract: The aim of this sub-project is to quantify regional land use types within the Biodiversity Exploratories, so that the effects of landscape composition and configuration and scale-dependency of biodiversity patterns, biotic interactions and ecosystem functioning can be analysed.

title: Vegetation records SADE on 73 Grassland EPs; 2018, Header data without species identity (incl. biomass)
abstract: A major challenge in ecological restoration is to effectively restore plant diversity in permanent grasslands. As species richness is often limited by seed dispersal, introducing locally absent species by seed addition is often crucial. We established a full-factorial experiment with high-diversity seeding and topsoil disturbance in 73 grasslands along land-use intensity and productivity gradients and evaluated the restoration success over 5 year (SADE is an abbreviation for "seed addition and disturbance experiment"). We found that plant diversity increased considerably when seeding and disturbance were combined while seeding alone only slightly increased species richness. Along land-use gradients, we found no direct effects of grazing or mowing on the establishment of sown species, but fertilization indirectly limited establishment in the combined treatment via a negative effect of productivity. Our results highlight the potential of using diverse seed mixtures for biodiversity restoration in a wide range of permanent grasslands, especially when combined with topsoil disturbance.

title: Community-level insect herbivory rates assembled from plant-species specific herbivory assessment on all EPs, 2017/2018
abstract: Insect herbivory is an important process in terrestrial ecosystems, which can be affected by land-use intensification.

title: Ambrosia beetles and antagonists sampled by Pheromone traps on all EPs in 2010 and on a subset in 2011
abstract:
The aim of the study was to investigate the relationship between forest management intensity, the abundance and attack rate of ambrosia beetles, i.e. native T. domesticum,  native Xyleborus spp.and the invasive pest Xylosandrus germanus, and their control by its natural antagonists. 
This is a data compilation for the manuscript " Effects of management on ambrosia beetles and their antagonists in European beech forests". The species data is available from the data sets  20031 und 20034.

title: Microcosm experiment, seedling abundances (1. count 2015), HEDGE I
abstract:
THE EXPERIMENTS WERE NOT CONDUCTED WITHIN THE EXPLORATORIES! THEY WERE CONDUCTED IN A COMMON GARDEN!
Intro: The focus of this project is to understand how (compositional and configurational) habitat heterogeneity influences species composition and biodiversity of grassland communities. Traditionally, it is believed that an increase in habitat heterogeneity has a positive effect on biodiversity (Hutchinson's niche concept); however, empirical data suggest that the effect of heterogeneity on biodiversity might as well be negative, neutral or unimodal Allouche et al. (2012). According to the Area-heterogeneity trade-off proposed by Kadmon and Allouche (2007) environmental heterogeneity has two opposite effects on species richness. On the one hand it increases opportunities for niche partitioning, at the other hand it reduces the amount of suitable area available for each species, thereby increasing the probability of stochastic extinction. To test the predictions of the AHTO model we set up a long term microcosm experiment simulating different combinations of habitat types and land use, resulting in different levels of habitat heterogeneity within a given area.
Experimental design: The experiment was conducted at a common garden site in Tübingen and comprised 248 Planting tubs (Polyethylene (PE)-boxes; 80 × 80 cm width, 40 cm depth) that were embedded into the ground and filled with a seedless sand/soil mixture. A grid of 4 × 4 subplots (20 x 20 cm each) was established within each planting tub. In a subset of plots subplots were separated by PE-walls, in all other plots subplots were not physically separated from each other. Each subplot received a species mix consisting of 40 species common to Germany (8 seeds per species). Four treatments (mowing, fertilization, trampling by livestock, soil depth) were applied to create different land management regimes on the subplot-level and in combination different levels of habitat heterogeneity on the plot level.

References
Allouche, O., Kalyuzhny, M., Moreno-Rueda, G., Pizarro, M., & Kadmon, R. (2012). Area–heterogeneity tradeoff and the diversity of ecological communities. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 109(43), 17495-17500.

Kadmon, R., & Allouche, O. (2007). Integrating the effects of area, isolation, and habitat heterogeneity on species diversity: a unification of island biogeography and niche theory. The American Naturalist, 170(3), 443-454.

title: Tree hole sampling at 52 forest plots: gerneral information, 2014
abstract: We investigated how different aspects of forest management, i.e. the amount of biomass harvested and the proportion of non-native tree species, directly and indirectly via a change in habitat and resource availability at forest stand and tree-hole scales affect the communities of arthropods (abundance, richness, species composition, trait diversity and composition) in water-filled tree holes.

title: Tree hole sampling at 52 forest plots: water analysis, 2014
abstract: We investigated how different aspects of forest management, i.e. the amount of biomass harvested and the proportion of non-native tree species, directly and indirectly via a change in habitat and resource availability at forest stand and tree-hole scales affect the communities of arthropods (abundance, richness, species composition, trait diversity and composition) in water-filled tree holes.

title: Tree hole sampling at 52 forest plots: species abundance, 2014
abstract: We investigated how different aspects of forest management, i.e. the amount of biomass harvested and the proportion of non-native tree species, directly and indirectly via a change in habitat and resource availability at forest stand and tree-hole scales affect the communities of arthropods (abundance, richness, species composition, trait diversity and composition) in water-filled tree holes.

title: Vegetation Records for 150 Grassland EPs in 2018, Header Data without Species Identities (incl. biomass)
abstract:
To create a dataset of a large-scale long-term time series of vegetation composition we conduct an annual monitoring of plant species richness and community composition. In spring of the years 2008-2018, we sampled all species in an area of 4m x 4m and estimated the percentage cover of each species. This area is not disturb by other experiment and is called core area ("Heilige Fläche (HF)" in German).  

Biomass was clipped in two subplots. In each subplot we clipped all plants of eight 50cm x 50cm plots at the height of 2cm.
The height was measured as well.

title: Infection rates of different grass species with grass endopyhtes of the genus Epichloe on grassland plots, June-August 2017
abstract: Symbiotic Epichloë endophytes in cool-season grass species are able to produce different alkaloids, which can be toxic for vertebrates and/or invertebrates. Hence it is important to monitor the infections of grasses in Germany with Epichloë fungi, to be able to estimate possible intoxication risks.

title: Extracellular enzymes and wood physico-chemical parameters  in logs of the BELongDead experiment (plenter forest, Hainich NP, year 2014)
abstract: The BELongDead experiment was conceived in 2008 under the direction of Prof. E. D. Schulze (MPI Biogeochemistry Jena) with the intention to monitor the impact of habitats on the dead wood decomposition processes and to observe colonization patterns of various saproxylic organisms over long time. Its central questions are I) how does the surrounding ecosystem influence wood decomposition, II) how does succession of the substrates proceed and III) how do microorganisms mediate wood decay and subsequently impact ecosystem processes like element turnover and storage. In total >1,000 logs comprising 13 tree species were placed in all VIPs of the Biodiversity Exploratories. In this study, a subset in Hainich were analyzed with special emphasis on the differences between sapwood and heartwood.

title: Fungal composition and species richness in logs of the BELongDead experiment (plenter forest, Hainich NP, year 2014) - related to DS 24209
abstract: The BELongDead experiment was conceived in 2008 under the direction of Prof. E. D. Schulze (MPI Biogeochemistry Jena) with the intention to monitor the impact of habitats on the dead wood decomposition processes and to observe colonization patterns of various saproxylic organisms over long time. Its central questions are I) how does the surrounding ecosystem influence wood decomposition, II) how does succession of the substrates proceed and III) how do microorganisms mediate wood decay and subsequently impact ecosystem processes like element turnover and storage. In total >1,000 logs comprising 13 tree species were placed in all VIPs of the Biodiversity Exploratories. In this study, a subset in Hainich were analyzed with special emphasis on the differences between sapwood and heartwood.

title: Abundance of predatory arthropods and ant activity in grasslands, 2015
abstract: Land use is a major driver of biodiversity loss in many taxa including the mega-diverse arthropods, but con-sequences for arthropod-mediated processes are still little understood. Using a rapid ecosystem function assessment (REFA), we approximated predation by quantifying predation attempts on artiﬁcial sentinel prey. Dummies were placed on the soil surface of 83 managed temperate grasslands across a broad range of land-useintensities (grazing intensity, mowing frequency, and the amount of applied fertiliser) in two regions of Germany. Additionally, we assessed the abundance of ground-dwelling arthropods using pitfall traps as well as ant activity.

title: Predation measured as predation marks by arthropods, birds, rodents and slugs on dummy caterpillars in grasslands, 2015
abstract: Land use is a major driver of biodiversity loss in many taxa including the mega-diverse arthropods, but con-sequences for arthropod-mediated processes are still little understood. title: Morphometric Traits of Herbivorous Insects (Hemiptera: Auchenorrhyncha, Heteroptera; Orthoptera)
abstract: A functional trait approach helps to evaluate the consequences of land use on community assembly and consequently ecosystem functions. Morphometric traits of insects, which are related to functions such as microhabitat use or dispersal, overcome some of the caveats of literature-based traits.

title: Abundant fungi on all EPs (from Soil Sampling Campain 2011) - merged grassland and forest data: relative abundance
abstract:
Monitoring of the general soil fungi from grassland and forest soil of the coordinated sampling campain in May 2011.
Here we give the total abundance of found fungal OTU excluding rare taxa (Singletons, Doubletons, Tripletons).

title: Abundant fungi on all EPs (from Soil Sampling Campain 2011) - merged grassland and forest data: taxonomic look-up table
abstract:
Monitoring of the general soil fungi from grassland and forest soil of the coordinated sampling campain in May 2011.
Here we give the total abundance of found fungal OTU excluding rare taxa (Singletons, Doubletons, Tripletons).

title: Summarised abundance of predatory arthropods and ant activity per plot in grasslands, 2015
abstract: Land use is a major driver of biodiversity loss in many taxa including the mega-diverse arthropods, but con-sequences for arthropod-mediated processes are still little understood. title: MinSoil 2017 Organic Horizons CNS
abstract: Determination of C, N, S concentrations of the organic layers in the forest experimental plots (Oa, Oe, Oi). Samples taken during the coordinated sampling campaign in May 2017.

title: R code to reproduce the analyses used in Felipe-Lucia et al. 2018. Nature Communications. "Multiple forest attributes underpin the supply of multiple ecosystem services"
abstract: R code to reproduce the analyses used in Felipe-Lucia et al. 2018 Nature Communications. "Multiple forest attributes underpin the supply of multiple ecosystem services"

title: Draft genome sequence of the ascomycete Chlorociboria aeruginascens DSM 107184
abstract: In the BLD-FFD-HZG projects, we identify the microbial community during decomposition processes, i.e. mainly fungi. For selected candidates of interest we provide in the next step the whole genome sequence, to find important enzyme involved in the decomposition of lignocellulosic material. Moreover, these resources are also important for metatranscriptomic and metaproteomic approaches.

title: Raw data of forest attributes of forest EPs of the Exploratories project used in "Multiple forest attributes underpin the supply of multiple ecosystem services"
abstract:
Assembled RAW data used in the analyses of the paper Felipe-Lucia et al. 2018. Nature Communications. "Multiple forest attributes underpin the supply of multiple ecosystem services". It contains data on ecosystem services, forest attributes and environmental variables.
Please, check associated dataset ID 24348 for data manipulation and analyses.

title: Impact of belowground herbivory on plant community resilience—SIMULATION DATA
abstract: This is a data set simulated by the IBC-grass plant competition model. By introducing a submodel of belowground herbivory, we test its impact on the recovery of our model plant communities after a disturbance killing a predetermined number of plants.

title: Multiplex PCR results of alkaloid genes of different grass species, grassland plots, June-August 2017
abstract: Symbiotic Epichloë endophytes in cool-season grass species are able to produce different alkaloids, which can be toxic for vertebrates and/or invertebrates. Hence it is important to monitor the infections of grasses in Germany with Epichloë fungi, to be able to estimate possible intoxication risks.

Hence it is important to monitor the infections of grasses in Germany with Epichloë fungi, to be able to estimate possible intoxication risks.

title: Determination of different ecotypes of Epichloe uncinata in Festuca pratensis via SSR primers, grassland plots June-August 2017
abstract: Symbiotic Epichloë endophytes in cool-season grass species are able to produce different alkaloids, which can be toxic for vertebrates and/or invertebrates. Hence it is important to monitor the infections of grasses in Germany with Epichloë fungi, to be able to estimate possible intoxication risks.

title: Indole-diterpen alkaloids from Epichloe festucae in Festuca ovina, grassland plots, June-August 2017
abstract: Symbiotic Epichloë endophytes in cool-season grass species are able to produce different alkaloids, which can be toxic for vertebrates and/or invertebrates. Hence it is important to monitor the infections of grasses in Germany with Epichloë fungi, to be able to estimate possible intoxication risks.

title: Fungal ITS rhizosphere community composition (filter technique) at 46 grassland plots, Schorfheide, Hainich and Schwäbische Alb, 2015, BELOW – OTU abundance table
abstract:
Data are based on total DNA extracted from rhizosphere samples from plant phytometers sampled during the BELOW sampling campaign from June to July 2015 in the Schorfheide Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb Exploratories. Here, 46 plots (SCH 11, HAI 17 plots and ALB 18 plots) with similar land-use intensity index and 2 phytometer plants (a forb: Plantago lanceolata and a grass: Dactylis glomerata) were chosen.
Plant phytometers were grown axenically in a greenhouse and were transplanted to the grassland study sites by the BELOW project from 28.04. to 04.06.2014. 
Sequence read counts of fungi (ITS2 rRNA region) were determined by using Illumina MiSeq sequencing.

title: Fungal ITS rhizosphere community composition (filter technique) in phytometer and resident plants at 13 grassland plots, Schwäbische Alb, 2015, BELOW – OTU abundance table
abstract:
Data are based on total DNA extracted from rhizosphere samples from phytometer and resident plants sampled during the BELOW sampling campaign in July 2015 in the Schwäbische Alb Exploratories. Here, 13 plots and 2 phytometer plants (a forb: Plantago lanceolata and a grass: Dactylis glomerata) were chosen.
Plant phytometers were grown axenically in a greenhouse and were transplanted to the grassland study sites by the BELOW project from 28.04. to 04.06.2014. 
Sequence read counts of fungi (ITS2 rRNA region) were determined by using Illumina MiSeq sequencing.

title: Fungal communities in sapwood and heartwood of logs of the BELongDead experiment (selection cutting, Hainich NP, 2014)
abstract:
In late 2008 an experimental platform for researching deadwood decomposition was established, and named the BELongDead (Biodiversity Exploratories Long term Deadwood) experiment: Freshly cut logs of 13 temperate tree species [nine broadleaved species: Acer sp., Betula sp., Carpinus sp., Fagus sylvatica, Fraxinus excelsior, Populus spp., Prunus avium, Quercus spp. and Tilia spp., and four conifers: Larix decidua, Picea abies, Pinus sylvestris and Pseudotsuga menziesii] were placed. In order to investigate the spatial distribution of microbial communities between the heartwood and sapwood, sampling of wood chips from the 13 deadwood logs was carried out on three experimental beech plots at the Hainich National park in Central Germany (N 51.08, E 10.43) in June 2014. Distinguishable sapwood and heartwood samples were collected in the form of chips by driving an auger horizontally to the center of each of the selected logs. After bark removal, sapwood was collected by means of an initial drilling followed by a second drilling to collect heartwood.

Sapwood and heartwood fungal communities of deadwood logs of 13 different tree species using an amplicon based deep-sequencing analysis.
Here we provide the relative abundances of observed fungal OTUs.

title: Fungal ITS rhizosphere and root community composition, greenhouse experiment in the Botanical Garden in Halle (Saale), 2015, BELOW – OTU abundance table
abstract: The aim of the experiment was to evaluate the plant community effect of two plant species mixtures, plant functional groups and functional traits on the rhizosphere and plant root endophytic mycobiome communities. For that an experiment was set up with 10 common plant species of the Biodiversity Exploratories in the Botanical Garden of the Martin-Luther-University in Halle (Saale) in May 2015. The different plant species are 5 grasses (Arrhenatherum elatius, Dactylis glomerata, Alopecurus pratensis, Poa pratensis, Lolium perenne) and 5 forbs (Ranunculus acris, Galium verum, Plantago lanceolata, Achillea millefolium, Galium mollugo). The plant species were placed in pairs (including monoculture pairs) in ducts. We extracted the total DNA from rhizosphere soil and plant roots from each plant species combination to observe the fungal community composition on plant community level. Helge Bruelheide and Sylvia Haider conceived the research question and the study design (Martin Luther University Halle-Wittenberg, Institute of Biology / Geobotany and Botanical Garden, Halle (Saale), Germany). Robert Reuter carried out data collection of above- and belowground plant biomass (master thesis: „Auswirkung von Nachbarschaftseffekten auf oberirdische und unterirdische Merkmale und Produktivität von Gras- und Krautarten des Grünlandes“).

title: Cercozoa and Endomyxa (Rhizaria, protists), Illumina Sequences, all EPs, grassland and forest, 2011
abstract: We have assessed the diversity of two major protistan phyla Cercozoa and Endomyxa (Corticata:Harosa:Rhizaria), focussing on plant parasites in 2011. Data stem from 300 grassland and forest sites of the German Biodiversity Exploratories, using high-throughput Illumina sequencing of the V4 region of the small subunit rRNA gene. Data are raw abundances of 97% similarity operational taxonomic units. We provide in separate tables the taxonomic and functional assignment (nutrition, locomotion modes and morphology). We tested or will test, four hypotheses: (1) Land use management influences the community composition of protistan plant pathogens and the relative proportion of pathogens/saprotrophs/free-living protists; (2) High diversity of protistan plant pathogens will be correlated with high alpha-diversity of plant communities (testing negative plant-soil feedbacks); (3) There is an undiscovered diversity of Cercozoa, Endomyxa and especially plant pathogens in soil.

title: Quantification of antibiotic resistance genes and 16s genes in all EPs, 2017
abstract: The threshold cycles from the quantification of eight antibiotic resistance genes and 16s rRNA genes, were determined via quantitative real time PCR  in the soil of all Experimental Plots. This was done to identify land use techniques that increase the number of these medically relevant resistance genes.

abstract:
Dead wood inventory 2017-2018
Inventory of downed, standing dead wood and stumps on all forest EPs with a stratified sampling design

abstract:

Inventory of downed, standing dead wood and stumps on all forest EPs with a stratified sampling design

title: 1st Dead Wood Inventory of 148 forest EPs, item volumes, 2012
abstract: Dead wood volume and harvested wood volume based on the dataset "15386 Dead Wood Inventory 2012"

title: Abundant soil fungi on all 300 EPs (from Soil Sampling Campains 2011, 2014 and 2017; Illumina MiSeq) - OTU taxonomic look-up table
abstract: In terms of biomass, activity and interactions, fungi are one of the key groups of soil living organisms. Recent advances in next generation sequencing and investigation of fungal diversity within soil habitats led to reevaluate the estimated fungal species richness from 1.5 to 5 Mio taxa. Fungi are heterotrophs and behave as saprotrophs, parasites or symbionts. They exist in multiple and tight interactions to living or dead plants. Consequently, the diversity and functioning of terrestrial ecosystems largely depend on soil fungal communities that dictate not only the primary mobilization and cycling of major nutrients but also influence the competition and co-existence of plant communities. However, the biodiversity and biogeographic patterns of soil fungi are decoupled from those of plants at the global scale, which reflects that not only plants but also climatic, edaphic, and spatial variables operating at smaller scales and anthropogenic effects like management and land-use intensity are predictors of fungal diversity and community composition. Within the Core Project 8 (Microorganisms), our task is to regularly monitor the fungal diversity and community composition within soils of all Experimental Plots (EPs). We here provide the taxonomy and function of the general abundant soil fungal OTU from the soil sampling campaigns 2011, 2014 and 2017 on all EPs.

title: Novel antibiotic resistance genes in VIP soils, 2008, raw data
abstract: In contrast to clinical pathogens, bacterial communities inhabiting complex environments such as soil have been rarely considered within studies focusing on antibiotic resistance. To assess risks of environmental resistomes and develop strategies to tackle antibiotic resistance, an improved knowledge on the ecology of resistance determinants including their origins, diversity and underlying resistance mechanisms is urgently required. Antibiotic resistance genes were identified in soil samples derived from the VIP plots. For this purpose, function-based screening of soil metagenomic libraries was performed.

title: Assembled RAW diversity from forest EPs (2007-2015) for multidiversity synthesis
abstract:
A dataset including information on abundance for each single species for all trophic levels in forest EPs. 

This dataset is connected to dataset 21726 (taxonomic, trophic and functional information) by the "Species" column. 

We also provide an R script (ID 22046) to help merging this dataset with dataset 21726 (species information) and calculate various metrics (richness, abundance, diversity and multidiversity).

title: Assembled species information from forest EPs (2007-2015) for multidiversity synthesis
abstract:
A dataset including information on each species found in the in forest EPs. It provides information on broad taxonomic classification, trophic level and functional role of each species.

This the dataset version used in Penone et al. 2019.

This dataset is connected to dataset 24607(raw abundance) by the "Species" column. 

We also provide an R script (ID 22046) to help merging this dataset with dataset 24607 and calculate various metrics (richness, abundance, diversity and multidiversity).

title: Nutrient concentrations in plant biomass at 73 grassland MIPs, 2018, SADE
abstract:
The increase in agricultural management intensity has influenced vegetation patterns, composition and dynamics through increased vegetation disturbance (mowing, grazing) and altered soil fertility (fertilization). The chemical composition of the aboveground plant biomass- used as an indicator for plant nutrition and productivity- and fibre fractions of grassland biomass- used as measure of the quality and nutritive value of herbage fodder- both integrate spatial and temporal variation on soil resources during the growing season (Klaus et al, 2011).
The Seed Addition and Disturbance Experiment (SADE) addresses ecosystem resilience by assessing how fast grassland ecosystems including all their functions and processes recover after a drastic disturbance and return to the initial conditions, in dependency on pre-disturbance diversity and land-use intensity. On the other hand, we will determine to what degree seeding of non-resident species can increase the local plant diversity and how such an increase may benefit ecosystem services such as yield, forage quality or carbon fixation (Klaus et al. 2017).

title: Draft genome sequence of the wood-degrading ascomycete Kretzschmaria deusta DSM 104547
abstract: In the BLD-FFD-HZG projects, we identify the microbial community during decomposition processes, i.e. mainly fungi. For selected candidates of interest we provide in the next step the whole genome sequence, to find important enzymes involved in the decomposition of lignocellulosic material. Moreover, these resources are also important for metatranscriptomic and metaproteomic approaches.

title: ForMI dynamics - Forest Management Intensity Index Dynamics of all forest EPs
abstract: The dynamics of the index forest management intensity (ForMI) between 2008 and 2018 can be used to assess changes in forest management intensity and associated effects on biodiversity.

title: Acoustic indices based on environmental sound recordings on all grassland EPs, Alb, 2016
abstract:
Indices of acoustic diversity have been shown to correlate with vegetation structure, species richness of various taxa and landscape composition. Further acoustic monitoring is applicable across large spatial and temporal scales. It thus has a high potential for large scale ecosystem monitoring. Nonetheless the drivers of acoustic diversity in relation to land-use and landscape composition are yet not well understood. The acoustic niche hypothesis postulates that a higher organismic diversity should result in a higher acoustic richness and complexity. Land-use intensity affects biodiversity in various ways and therefore could have an indirect effect on acoustic diversity. This relationship is hypothesized to be modified by abiotic factors such as temperature and rain as well as noise from nearby roads and machinery mediated by altered calling behavior of vocalizing animals.
To test this conceptual framework we set up autonomous recording systems to record 1 minute every ten in grassland and forest plots established as long term research plots along a land-use and biodiversity gradient in three regions in Germany. We calculated two acoustic diversity indices - ADI and NDSI - to test these relationships.

title: Bird survey data 2012, all 300 EPs
abstract: Bird surveys were conducted to assess the effect of land use on species richness, abundance and assemblage composition of birds in differently managed forest and grassland systems. Standardized data of all EPs was collected during the years 2008-2012. Observations of birds were undertaken by trained and tested students (PhD and Master level) and free lancers.

title: Microbiological and chemical data of burried mineral containers with labelled roots on 10 ALB sites, SCALEMIC Phase 4 (2014-2017) WP2
abstract: We investigated microbial colonization of new surfaces and resource use of bacteria and fungi under different land-use intensities.

title: Untargeted Metabolome Analysis of Root Exudates LCMS (Harvest Campaign 2014, BELOW)  - processed data
abstract: In the rhizosphere plants are exposed to a multitude of different biotic and abiotic factors, to which they respond by exuding a wide range of secondary root metabolites. So far, it has been unknown to which degree root exudate composition is species-specific and is affected by land use, the local impact and local neighbourhood under field conditions. In this study root exudates of ten common grassland species were analysed, each five of forbs and grasses, in the German Biodiversity Exploratories using a combined phytometer and untargeted liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (LC-MS) approach.

title: Untargeted Metabolome Analysis of Root Exudates GCMS (Harvest Campaign 2015, BELOW) - processed data
abstract: Plants exude a diverse cocktail of metabolites into the soil as response to exogenous and endogenous factors. So far, root exudates have mainly been studied under artificial conditions due to methodological difficulties. In this study, each five perennial grass and forb species were investigated for polar and semi-polar metabolites in exudates under field conditions.

title: Untargeted Metabolome Analysis of Root Exudates LCMS (Harvest Campaign 2015, BELOW)  - processed data
abstract: Plants exude a diverse cocktail of metabolites into the soil as response to exogenous and endogenous factors. So far, root exudates have mainly been studied under artificial conditions due to methodological difficulties. In this study, each five perennial grass and forb species were investigated for polar and semi-polar metabolites in exudates under field conditions.

title: SADE Arbuscular mycorrhizal root colonization rates 2015, 2016
abstract: Based on the design of the SADE experiment (soil disturbance and seeding in 74 grassland plots) we assessed arbuscular mycorrhizal colonization rates in root samples from 2015 (all exploratories) and 2016 (only Schorfheide)

title: Sequencing data of alkaloid genes of different Epichloe fungi in different grass species sampled on grassland plots, June-August 2017, Defense II
abstract: Symbiotic Epichloë endophytes in cool-season grass species are able to produce different alkaloids, which can be toxic for vertebrates and/or invertebrates. Hence it is important to monitor the infections of grasses in Germany with Epichloë fungi, to be able to estimate possible intoxication risks.

title: Öffentlich verfügbare Klimadaten der Exploratorien / Open Climate Data of the Exploratories Project
abstract: Klimadatensatz - Zeitreihen von Lufttemperatur, Luftfeuchte,  Bodentemperatur, Bodenfeuchte, Niederschlag, Wind und Sonnenschein / Climate Data Set - Time Series Web Interface - a new climate data base system, includes all raw values from Advanced environmental monitoring units (AEMUs) + enhanced EMUs (EEMUs) + core EMUs (CEMU) - Automated environmental monitoring by including wind and precipitation - aggregated to 1hour + 1day + 1week + 1month + 1year

title: 16S rRNA gene (V3 region) DNA-based analysis of spatiotemporal bacterial colonization of minerals, SCALEMIC, 2014-2017
abstract:
Bacteria in soils are frequently attached to the surfaces of minerals, which are available as fresh inputs due to the process of mineral weathering and formation. So far, the patterns and dynamics of bacterial colonization of soil minerals have not been assessed in natural settings. Hence, high throughput Illumina sequencing was employed to investigate the colonization of artificial minerals exposed to natural grassland soils. We studied the impact of different types of organic carbon sources (simple carbon [WP1, 'minerals'] compounds versus plant detritus [WP2, 'roots']) on the development of distinct communities and evaluated the temporal dynamics of bacterial colonization of soil minerals, as compared to the soil bacteria (termed `adjacent soil´ and 'control'). The observed consistent temporal patterns suggest that the properties of de novo inserted minerals in soils drive the establishment of bacterial communities and override the effect of the type of carbon sources and other environmental filters. Specific bacterial sequence variants exhibited distinct colonization patterns, including early, intermittent, and late colonizers. These colonization patterns do not represent phylogenetically coherent properties, however. This study highlights the importance of minerals and reveals the trajectories of soil bacterial communities during soil colonization, which are key for a better understanding of bacterial community stability and resilience during soil formation. Based on our results, main soil minerals are not only colonized by specific bacterial communities but enable a succession of distinct bacterial communities that follow clear trajectories. Our results thereby expand the concept of the mineralosphere and provide novel insights into mechanisms of community assembly in the soil ecosystem.

In this dataset, we provide microbial sequence data from the mineral contains burried in the soil and of the surrounding soil along a temporal gradient. Details are below.

title: Plant-species specific assessment of invertebrate  herbivory  on all EPs, 2017/2018
abstract:
Insect herbivory is an important process in terrestrial ecosystems, which can be affected by land-use intensification through changes in either the community composition of herbivorous insects (structure and function), the plant community composition (structure and function) or the trophic interactions between insects and plants. 
Based on vegetation records from the previous year, we assessed insect herbivory on the most abundant plant species on all forest and grassland plots in all three regions. Leaf material was sampled in 2017 and 2018. On a random sample of leaves, we visually estimated the area damaged by herbivorous insects and gall mites (distinguished into different damage types) and measured leaf area using a leaf area meter.

title: Leaf traits of most abundant plant species from all EPs, 2017/2018
abstract:
Leaf traits, which are affected by environmental drivers such as land-use intensity, influence ecosystem processes such as biomass production and herbivory. Land-use drivers such as fertilization in grasslands are expected to affect leaf traits not only by changing the plant community composition, but also by affecting leaf traits within species, resulting in intraspecific variability in leaf traits along land-use intensity gradients.
We assessed three leaf measures (area, fresh weight, dry weight) on the most abundant plant species based on vegetation surveys in the previous years on all forest and grassland plots in all three regions in 2017/2018. Area was measured on single leaves using a leaf area meter, fresh and dry weight were measured for sets of 3-20 leaves.

title: Effects of forest management on nematode communities in natural tree holes (Sampling 2015)
abstract:
Water-filled tree holes are detritus-based ecosystems, which provide aquatic habitats for a wide range of invertebrates within forests. 
They are the most abundant type of small water bodies in temperate forests, yet it is unclear how different components of forest management affect nematode communities through environmental variables.
This study investigated the composition of the nematode community in ground and high (tree)holes in 12 forest experimental plots (1 ha) in the Biodiversity Exploratory Schorfheide-Chorin. Samples were taken during a sampling in March 2015. 
No difference in the relative abundance of nematodes (ind./hole/100 ml) between ground and high holes could be determined.  Furthermore, no influence of the management intensity on the nematode community in tree holes could be detected.

title: Bacterial alpha-diversity (DNA-based, V3 16S, OTU at 3% sequence similarity) in woodland tree holes, 2014
abstract:
Direct and indirect effects of forest management on tree-hole inhabiting aquatic organisms and their functional traits.
Water-filled tree holes are ecological islands of aquatic habitats within forests. It was shown recently that forest management intensity decreases diversity and alters the community structure of aquatic insects developing in tree holes. However, it is unclear how different components of forest management affect insect communities directly and indirectly, how management impacts functional trait diversity and trait composition of tree-hole insect communities, and whether other functional groups besides insects respond to management in the same way. To address these questions, we mapped all water-filled tree holes in 75 different forest plots (1 ha) under different management intensity, located in three different regions of Germany. We measured structural and climatic conditions at different spatial scales, sampled insect communities in 118 tree holes and bacterial and nematode communities in a subset of these.

title: 16S rRNA gene (V3 region) RNA-based analysis of microbial soil communities at sequence variant level in 148 grassland EP plots, using QIIME2-based bioinformatics, 2011
abstract:
We determine the microbial community composition in 297 EP plots from grassland and woodlands. Most bacteria in soil are dormant or inactive. A substantial fraction might even be dead. Hence, in order to quantify the living and active bacteria, we isolated RNA from soil and sequenced V3 16S rRNA amplicons. The presence and amount of ribosomes in a cell can be taken as a rough proxy for activity. The results indicate substantial difference between grassland and woodland soils. Moreover, bacterial communities can be additionally distinguished by their soil type.
Here, the data are provided as quality-checked but non-rarefied read counts of distinct exact sequence variants (Callahan et al 2017). 
A bacterial sequence variant in this data set is defined by a specific nucleotide sequence of the V3 16S rRNA gene region of 165 base pair length. 
That means, bacterial sequence variants are distinguished at the level of single nucleotide differences.

Callahan et al (2017) Exact sequence variants should replace operational taxonomic units in marker-gene data analysis. ISMEJ, https://doi.org/10.1038/ismej.2017.119

title: Dataset used in Boeddinghaus et al. (2019) "Plant functional trait shifts explain concurrent changes in the structure and function of grassland soil microbial communities" Journal of Ecology
abstract: We investigated whether the functioning and composition of microbial communities rapidly tracks short-term changes (within three years) in abiotic soil properties, land-use intensity, plant functional traits or plant biomass properties or if microbial changes are driven by the longer-term history of the site (legacy effect). In addition, we asked whether changes in microbial soil properties and functions were best explained by direct or indirect legacy or change effects of land-use intensity or in intermediate properties, namely changes to soil pH, plant functional traits and the quantity and nutritional quality of plant biomass.

title: 16S rRNA gene (V3 region) RNA-based analysis of microbial soil communities at sequence variant level in 149 woodland EP plots, using QIIME2-based bioinformatics, 2011
abstract:
We determine the microbial community composition in 297 EP plots from grassland and woodlands. Most bacteria in soil are dormant or inactive. A substantial fraction might even be dead. Hence, in order to quantify the living and active bacteria, we isolated RNA from soil and sequenced V3 16S rRNA amplicons. The presence and amount of ribosomes in a cell can be taken as a rough proxy for activity. The results indicate substantial difference between grassland and woodland soils. title: Leaf area index (LAI) of all forest EPs, 2008 - 2010
abstract: Leaf Area Index derived from airborne LiDAR Scanning for all forest EPs

title: Stable Isotope values for ant species in grassland plots in 2014/2015
abstract: Ants are an important functional group of temperate grassland ecosystems. Land-use intensification has been shown to have a negative influence on ant diversity. However the mechanisms leading to these effects are not well understood and may affect different ant species differently, as ant species may differ in trophic niche. The differences in the trophic niche are visible through different ratios of carbon and nitrogen isotopes. A higher trophic level results in an enrichment in values of 13C and 15N isotopes. Samples were conducted in all three regions. In 2014 in Alb and Hainich and 2015 in all three regions.

title: EP Grassland Landuse Information ALB 2019
abstract:
Information about the land use on the EPs in 2019, based on information given by the farmers or on observations by members of the exploratories.
This file will be updated continuously.
It should be used only for fieldwork planning, NOT FOR ANALYSIS!.

title: Arthropod mediated processes (dung and seed depletion) measured on all EPs in 2017
abstract: In June 2017, we investigated the dung depletion and seed removal after 48 h in all three Exploratory regions as arthropod mediated processes. We investigated (i) whether plot-level process rates and their spatial variation differed between forests and semi-natural grasslands, (ii) whether process rates were correlated among each other across sites and iii) whether the rates were affected by climate and land- use intensity at short and medium-term temporal scales.

title: Untargeted Metabolome Analysis of Root Exudates GCMS (Harvest Campaign 2014, BELOW)  - raw data
abstract: Primary and secondary metabolites exuded by plant roots have mainly been studied under laboratory conditions, while knowledge of root exudate patterns of plants growing in natural communities is very limited. Focusing on ten common European grassland plant species, we asked to which degree exuded metabolite compositions are specific to species or growth forms (forbs and grasses), depend on environments and local neighbourhoods, and reflect traditional plant functional traits. Root exudates were collected under field conditions and analysed using a non-targeted gas chromatography coupled mass spectrometry (GC-MS) approach.

title: Untargeted Metabolome Analysis of Root Exudates GCMS (Harvest Campaign 2015, BELOW) - raw data
abstract: Plants exude a diverse cocktail of metabolites into the soil as response to exogenous and endogenous factors. So far, root exudates have mainly been studied under artificial conditions due to methodological difficulties. In this study, each five perennial grass and forb species were investigated for polar and semi-polar metabolites in exudates under field conditions.

title: Untargeted Metabolome Analysis of Root Exudates LCMS (Harvest Campaign 2014, BELOW)  - raw data
abstract: In the rhizosphere plants are exposed to a multitude of different biotic and abiotic factors, to which they respond by exuding a wide range of secondary root metabolites. So far, it has been unknown to which degree root exudate composition is species-specific and is affected by land use, the local impact and local neighbourhood under field conditions. In this study root exudates of ten common grassland species were analysed, each five of forbs and grasses, in the German Biodiversity Exploratories using a combined phytometer and untargeted liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (LC-MS) approach.

title: Untargeted Metabolome Analysis of Root Exudates LCMS (Harvest Campaign 2015, BELOW)  - raw data
abstract: Plants exude a diverse cocktail of metabolites into the soil as response to exogenous and endogenous factors. So far, root exudates have mainly been studied under artificial conditions due to methodological difficulties. In this study, each five perennial grass and forb species were investigated for polar and semi-polar metabolites in exudates under field conditions.

title: Land snail abundances measured on all EPs in June 2017
abstract: In this study, we examined land snail communities in forests and grasslands in all three Exploratory regions. In June 2017, dead shells and living individuals were collected from field samples to determine abundances, diversity and community structure. We aimed to quantify the extent to which snail density, diversity and community composition in forests and grasslands are determined by (1) land-use intensity, (2) abiotic drivers and (3) biotic substrates, and (4) whether these effects are consistent across regions.

title: FT-ICR-MS spectra on forest VIPs in 2015
abstract: To improve our understanding of the effects of forest management, especially tree species selection and management intensity, on dissolved organic carbon (DOM) concentrations and properties of samples from different ecosystem fluxes, we studied throughfall (TF), stemflow (SF), litter leachate (LL) and mineral soil solution (TOP, SUB). The chemical composition of DOM strongly affects its role in the carbon and nutrient cycles of ecosystems. The chemical composition, in turn, depends on the DOM source and its processing along the water flow path through ecosystems.

title: Soil fungal (ITS) communities from 25 ALB grassland SADE-EPs (from Soil Sampling Campain 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018; Illumina MiSeq) - OTU abundances
abstract: Within the framework of SADE experiment, abundances of the general soil fungal OTUs from 25 grassland EPs collected during the soil sampling campaigns of 2015, 2016, 2017 and 2018.

title: SMI dynamics - Silvicultural Management Intensity Dynamics on all forest EPs, 2009/10 - 2015/16
abstract: The dynamics of the index of Silvicultural Management Intensity (SMI) between 2009/10 and 2015/16 can be used to assess changes in forest management intensity and associated effects on biodiversity.

title: 16S rRNA gene (V3 region) RNA-based analysis of microbial soil communities at sequence variant level in 150 woodland EP plots, using QIIME2-based bioinformatics, 2014
abstract:
We determine the microbial community composition in 300 EP plots from grassland and woodlands. Most bacteria in soil are dormant or inactive. A substantial fraction might even be dead.
