title: Input Data for LUI Calculation Tool  of all grassland plots since 2006 - revised 2019
abstract: The data derive from calculated values of the land use survey (annual interviews with all grassland land owners / users of the three Exploratories -basic Dataset 23746). These data are the land management components (mowing, grazing, fertilization) for the LUI Calculation Tool.

title: Aggregated species richness and habitat heterogeneity variables for testing the habitat-heterogeneity hypothesis, 2006-2018
abstract:
This data was used in "Heterogeneity-diversity relationships differ between and within trophic levels in temperate forests" (Heidrich et al. 2020, NatEcolEvol, 10.1038/s41559-020-1245-z)

The habitat-heterogeneity hypothesis predicts monotonously increasing biodiversity with increasing habitat heterogeneity, due to an increasing number of niches. The area-trade-off hypothesis, however, predicts a decrease in biodiversity at high levels of habitat heterogeneity because of a trade-off between heterogeneity and effective niche area. In this study, we used biodiversity data from twelve taxonomic-functional groups and classified a set of potentially important heterogeneity variables at the forest stand scale with support of airborne laser scanning.

To include a comprehensive gradient in heterogeneity, the data collected in the course of the Exploratories (150 plots) was supplemented by two further projects located in the Steigerwald (69 Plots) and in the Bavarian Forest (BIOKLIM, 278 Plots).

title: Canopy openness of forest EPs, 2014
abstract: The index quantifies canopy openness as percentage of sky pixels of a simulated hemisperical image for an opening angle of 60°. The simulated hemisperical image was computed based on terrestrial lidar data following the procedure proposed by Zheng, G., Moskal, L. M., & Kim, S. H. (2013).

title: Tea decomposition after 3, 12, 24 and 36 months in grassland MIPs, 2016-2019
abstract:
Changes in the balance between soil carbon storage and release can significantly amplify or attenuate global warming and are also driven by land-use intensity. Our study is part of the global initiative 'TeaComposition' that uses commercially available tea material to study litter decomposition rates across biomes. 
This dataset contains decomposition rates over three years on 70 grassland MIPs. Two two litter types (high-quality litter green tea and low-quality litter rooibos tea) were placed in the topsoil in June 2016 and four bags of each type removed after 3, 12 and 24 months. At each time point, we measured the mean percentage of decomposed material (i.e. initial weight - weight left) for both tea types and the standard deviation of each four replicates.

title: Gravimetric soil water content - Soil sampling campaign 2017, all experimental plots (EP), 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides essential information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all 301 experimental plots (EPs) of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the gravimetric soil water contents and dry matter contents in 0-10 cm depth from all EPs in 2017. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil water content has a dominant influence on plant growth, soil temperature, transport of chemical compounds, ground water recharge and soil aeration. The gravimetric soil water content is the mass of water in the soil, measured as the weight difference between the moist and the oven-dry soil. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-3, TR 1054/4-3, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Aggregated data of radar, Airborne Laser Scanning, and biodiversity measures on all forest EPs (2006-2018) used in "Radar vision for mapping forest biodiversity from space"
abstract: This dataset is an aggregated data (2006-2018) of environmental variables (independent variables) and different facets of biodiversity meausres (response variables) on all forest EPs used in "Radar vision for mapping forest biodiversity from space", submitted to Nature Communications. In environmental variables, two remote sensing techniques, spaceborne radar and airborne laser scanning, were employed to derive forest structure. In biodiversity measure, species composition, species richness, and phylogenetic diversity of 12 functional groups were included. To include a comprehensive gradient of forest structure, the data collected in the course of the Exploratories (150 plots) was supplemented by two further projects located in the Steigerwald (69 Plots) and in the Bavarian Forest (BIOKLIM, 244 Plots).

title: Soil water and dry matter content of SADE samples 2015-2018 ALB (SCALEMIC)
abstract: The Seed Addition and Disturbance Experiment (SADE) was designed on 25 MIP with four supplots on each plot: one 7m x 7m control plot, one 7m x 7m plot with seed addition, one 7m x 7m with disturbanc (rotary cultivation), one 7m x 7m with seed additiona and disturbance. The experiment addresses ecosystem resilience by assessing how fast grassland ecosystems including all their functions and processes recover after drastic disturbance and return to the initial conditions, in dependency on pre-disturbance diversity and land-use intensity. On the other hand, we will determine to what degree seeding of non-resident species can increase the local plant diversity and how such an increase may benefit ecosystem services such as yield, forage quality, pollination or carbon fixation. The seeding also allows one to estimate to what degree the current diversity of grassland is limited by a restricted dispersal capacity of plant species. Finally, the experiment tests the adaptive potential of grasslands to future climatic changes and extreme weather events, because a higher diversity of the vegetation could be associated with a higher resilience of the system. (Source: http://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/en/projects/current-projects/plants/sade/)

title: Synthetic Aperture Radar (Sentinel-1) metrics on all forest EPs, 2016
abstract: We used C-band Synthetic Aperture Radar (C-SAR) acquired by the Sentinel-1 mission in 2016 over all of Germany including all GPs. Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) data are a prime candidate to meet the demands for ecologically meaningful information on vegetation structure from space from regional to global scales. A big advantage of SAR is the ability to penetrate clouds, making it a suitable technique also for regions with almost constant cloud coverage, such as the tropics or mountain areas. See more details in Bae et al. (2019).

title: Biodegradation experiment on forest VIPs in 2012
abstract: To improve our understanding of the effects of forest management, especially tree species selection and management intensity, on dissolved organic carbon (DOM) concentrations and properties of samples from different ecosystem fluxes, we studied throughfall (TF), stemflow (SF), litter leachate (LL) and mineral soil solution (TOP, SUB). The chemical composition of DOM strongly affects its role in the carbon and nutrient cycles of ecosystems. The chemical composition, in turn, depends on the DOM source and its processing along the water flow path through ecosystems.

title: Fluorescence analysis on forest VIPs 2011-2013
abstract: To improve our understanding of the effects of forest management, especially tree species selection and management intensity, on dissolved organic carbon (DOM) concentrations and properties of samples from different ecosystem fluxes, we studied throughfall (TF), stemflow (SF), litter leachate (LL) and mineral soil solution (TOP, SUB). The chemical composition of DOM strongly affects its role in the carbon and nutrient cycles of ecosystems. The chemical composition, in turn, depends on the DOM source and its processing along the water flow path through ecosystems.

title: Cover of all vascular plant species in nested 2x2, 3x3 and 4x4m quadrats in 9 Grassland EPs per region, 2018
abstract: In order to estimate how vascular plant species cover and species richness changes when increasing the vegetation survey area size, we recorded all species in nested areas of 2m x 2m, 3m x 3m and 4m x 4m and estimated the percentage cover of each species in spring 2018, in 9 Grassland EPs per region.

title: PSF Field Experiment P. lanceolata SCH 2018
abstract: Plant-Soil Feedback (PSF) experiments look at the feedback between plants and their rhizosphere soil. Plants are influencing the soil through processes such as rotting litter and root exudation. These self-inflicted changes to the soil might then in turn influence plant performance. Land use influences soil biotic and abiotic properties and therefore might influence PSFs. PSF experiments in the field allow to assess the influence of microclimate and natural herbivore-induced changes on PSFs. Furthermore, PSF may lead to genetically heritable intraspecific variation among plant populations. In our field experiment, we investigated intraspecific variation in PSF in Plantago lanceolata in relation to land use, herbivory and microclimate.

title: Soil bacterial (16S) communities from 25 ALB grassland SADE-EPs (from Soil Sampling Campain 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018; Illumina MiSeq) - OTU abundances
abstract: Within the framework of SADE experiment, abundances of the soil bacterial OTUs from 25 grassland EPs collected during the soil sampling campaigns of 2015, 2016, 2017 and 2018.

title: Forest characteristics and vegetation data from the  Exploratories program, 2014-2015 used in: Exclusion of large herbivores in 147 forest plots affects understorey shrubs but not herbs, PLOS ONE
abstract:
The influence of herbivores on the diversity and composition of Central European forest communities is subject to a long and controversial debate. While there is a large body of literature focusing on the influence of large herbivores on tree species, their influence on understorey shrubs and herbs has been studied less. 
As many studies have shown that understorey vegetation is stronly influenced by different forest features and management intensity, we also analysed if the influence of large herbivores on understorey vegetation is affected by certain forest features. We asked the questions: i) Do large herbivores reduce the species richness, evenness and vegetation cover of shrubs and herbs? ii) Does the influence of large herbivores on shrub and herb communities depend on certain forest features or management intensity?

title: Synthetic Aperture Radar (Sentinel-1) remote sensing data in a raster format on all GPs, 2016
abstract: We used C-band Synthetic Aperture Radar (C-SAR) acquired by the Sentinel-1 mission in 2016 over all of Germany including all GPs. Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) data are a prime candidate to meet the demands for ecologically meaningful information on vegetation structure from space from regional to global scales. A big advantage of SAR is the ability to penetrate clouds, making it a suitable technique also for regions with almost constant cloud coverage, such as the tropics or mountain areas. See more details in Bae et al. (2019).

title: Gene accession numbers of reference sequences used for phylogeny trees of Epichloe ssp. and the sequencing data Dataset 24749, Defense II
abstract: Symbiotic Epichloë endophytes in cool-season grass species are able to produce different alkaloids, which can be toxic for vertebrates and/or invertebrates. Hence it is important to monitor the infections of grasses in Germany with Epichloë fungi, to be able to estimate possible intoxication risks.

title: Protists assessed by metatranscriptomics in one-year-old beech litter samples in VIP plots, taxonomic and functional assignment, 2014
abstract: We investigated the eukaryotic diversity from 18 samples of one-year beech (Fagus sylvatica) leaf litter by RNA-based high-throughput sequencing of the small-subunit ribosomal RNA gene (SSU). By applying a metatranscriptomic approach, we avoided biases inherent to PCR-based methods, and could therefore focus on elusive protistan groups. We obtained 14,589 eukaryotic assembled sequences (contigs) representing 2,223 unique taxa. Fungi dominated the eukaryotic assemblage, followed by an equal proportion of protists and plants. Among protists, the phylum Amoebozoa clearly dominated, representing more than twice the proportion of Alveolata (mostly ciliates) and Rhizaria (mostly Cercozoa), which are often retrieved as the dominant protistan groups in soils, revealing potential primer biases. By assigning functional traits to protists, we could assess that the proportion of free-living and heterotrophs was much higher than that of parasites and autotrophs, opening the way to a better understanding of the role played by the protistan communities and how biodiversity interacts with decomposition processes.

title: Microbial soil properties of all grassland EPs, soil sampling campaign (SSC) 2017, SCALEMIC
abstract: The study focussed on regional biogeography of soil microorganisms over time, i.e., how below ground microbial communities are organised and differentiated along geographic, climatic and environmental gradients. To address this question we characterised soil microbial communities by microbial biomass and fatty acid content. The three exploratories will allow us to up-scale the biogeography of soil microorganisms from plot to regional scale.

title: Soil enzyme activities of the SCALEMIC Experiment (AEG31, 2011)
abstract: Scalemic Experiment investigates the spatial and temporal changes in microbial community composition and nitrogen cycling processes at the plot scale (10m x 10m) under different stages of plant growth in a low land use intensity grassland.

title: Soil fungal (ITS) communities from 25 ALB grassland SADE-EPs (from Soil Sampling Campain 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018; Illumina MiSeq) - OTU taxonomic function look-up table
abstract: Within the framework of SADE experiment, abundances of the general soil fungal OTUs from 25 grassland EPs collected during the soil sampling campaigns of 2015, 2016, 2017 and 2018.

title: Abundant arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi on all 300 EPs (from Soil Sampling Campains 2011, 2014 and 2017; Illumina MiSeq) - putative AMF taxonomic look-up table
abstract:
Arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (AMF) form important mutualistic symbioses with more than 70% of all land plants. Currently, estimates assume up to 300-1600 AMF species. AMF support the nutrient uptake by enhancing the surfaces within the plant roots and by formation of extraradical mycelium. Particularly, in P-limited soils, plants invest in the formation of AMF. Besides, AMF increase the plants stress resistance and the overall soil stability.
Within the Core Project 8 (Microorganisms), our task is to regularly monitor the AMF diversity and community composition within soils of all Experimental Plots (EPs). We here provide the taxonomy from the soil sampling campaigns 2011, 2014 and 2017 on all EPs.

title: Abundant arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi on all 150 grassland EPs (from Soil Sampling Campain 2011; Illumina MiSeq) - putative AMF abundances
abstract:

title: Abundant arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi on all 150 forest EPs (from Soil Sampling Campain 2017; Illumina MiSeq) - putative AMF abundances
abstract:
Arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (AMF) form important mutualistic symbioses with more than 70% of all land plants. Currently, estimates assume up to 300-1600 AMF species. AMF support the nutrient uptake by enhancing the surfaces within the plant roots and by formation of extraradical mycelium. Particularly, in P-limited soils, plants invest in the formation of AMF. Besides, AMF increase the plants stress resistance and the overall soil stability.
Within the Core Project 8 (Microorganisms), our task is to regularly monitor the AMF diversity and community composition within soils of all Experimental Plots (EPs). We here provide the taxonomy from the soil sampling campaigns 2011, 2014 and 2017 on all EPs.

title: Soil bacterial (16S) communities from 25 ALB grassland SADE-EPs (from Soil Sampling Campain 2015, 2016, 2017, 2018; Illumina MiSeq) - OTU taxonomic look-up table
abstract: Within the framework of SADE experiment, abundances of the soil bacterial OTUs from 25 grassland EPs collected during the soil sampling campaigns of 2015, 2016, 2017 and 2018.

title: Draft genome sequence of Xylaria hypoxylon DSM 108379, an ubiquitous fungus on wood
abstract: In the BLD-FFD-HZG projects, we identify the microbial community during decomposition processes, i.e. mainly fungi. For selected candidates of interest we provide in the next step the whole genome sequence, to find important enzyme involved in the decomposition of lignocellulosic material. Moreover, these resources are also important for metatranscriptomic and metaproteomic approaches.

title: 16S and ITS bulk soil, rhizosphere, and root endosphere at 13 grassland plots each in Hainich (2014) and Schwäbische Alb (2015), BELOW - raw sequence data (fastq-files)
abstract:
Investigation of the rhizosphere bacterial and fungal community composition of forb (Achillea millefolium and Plantago lanceolata) and grass (Arrhenatherum elatius and Dactylis glomerata) phytometer plants out planted in sites of different land-use intensity in the German Biodiversity Exploratories (Hainich-Dün) by means of 16S and ITS rDNA paired-end amplicon sequencing using Illumina MiSeq. The studies focused on the effect of plant functional group (grasses vs. forbs) and land-use as well as edaphic parameters onto the bacterial and fungal community and diversity. 
Bulk soil, rhizosphere, and root endosphere samples of the four plant species from 13 experimental plots in Hainich-Dün region; Rhizosphere samples of two plant species (Plantago lanceolata and Dactylis glomerata) from 13 experimental plots in Schwäbische Alb.

title: Physico-chemical and microbial soil properties for 2015-2018 of 25 Alb grassland MIPs, cooperation SADE-SCALEMIC
abstract:
Cooperation SADE-Scalemic:
SADE = seed addition and disturbance experiment.
One 7m x 7m control plot, one 7m x 7m plot with seed addition, one 7m x 7m with disturbanc (rotary cultivation), one 7m x 7m with seed addition and disturbance. The experiment addresses ecosystem resilience by assessing how fast grassland ecosystems including all their functions and processes recover after drastic disturbance and return to the initial conditions, in dependency on pre-disturbance diversity and land-use intensity. On the other hand, we will determine to what degree seeding of non-resident species can increase the local plant diversity and how such an increase may benefit ecosystem services such as yield, forage quality, pollination or carbon fixation. The seeding also allows one to estimate to what degree the current diversity of grassland is limited by a restricted dispersal capacity of plant species. Finally, the experiment tests the adaptive potential of grasslands to future climatic changes and extreme weather events, because a higher diversity of the vegetation could be associated with a higher resilience of the system. (Source: http://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/en/projects/current-projects/plants/sade/)

This dataset contains the data that was consistently analysed on soil samples of the years 2015, 2016, 2017 and 2018 on all 25 SADE plots in the Schwäbische Alb.

title: Matrix of saproxylic beetles (abundance per species and site) used in the TreeScape project, 2007-2016
abstract: This data set contains an abundance matrix of all saproxylic beetles used for analysis in the TreeScape project. Therefore, samples from ground-based flight interception traps and pit fall traps collected in temporal proximity to the year of LiDar-measurements were chosen. the data collected in the course of the Exploratories (150 plots) was supplemented by two further projects located in the Steigerwald (69 Plots) and in the Bavarian Forest (BIOKLIM, 167 Plots).

title: Physico-chemical soil properties of all grassland EPs, soil sampling campaign (SSC) 2017, SCALEMIC
abstract: The study focussed on regional biogeography of soil microorganisms over time, i.e. how below ground microbial communities are organised and differentiated along geographic, climatic and environmental gradients. To address this question we characterised soil microbial communities at three levels of resolution (gene abundance, enzyme activity, and community level). The three exploratories will allow us to up-scale the biogeography of soil microorganisms from plot to regional scale.

title: Eukaryotic metatranscriptomics in one-year-old beech litter samples in VIP plots, 2014: contig sequences
abstract: Application of meta’omic approaches provides detailed insights into composition and activity of litter decomposer communities. We characterized the composition and transcriptional activity of fungal communities by high-throughput Illumina sequencing in one year old beach leaf-litter samples. The obtained paired end reads were assembled de novo by CLC Genomics Workbench (CLCbio, Qiagen, Valencia, CA, USA), using default settings for trimming, automatic word and bubble size and a minimum contig length of 110 bp. To determine the coverage of each contig, the reads were mapped against the assembled contigs.

title: Eukaryotic metatranscriptomics in one-year-old beech litter samples in VIP plots, 2014: contig coverage
abstract: Application of meta’omic approaches provides detailed insights into composition and activity of litter decomposer communities. We characterized the composition and transcriptional activity of fungal communities by high-throughput Illumina sequencing in one year old beach leaf-litter samples. The obtained paired end reads were assembled de novo by CLC Genomics Workbench (CLCbio, Qiagen, Valencia, CA, USA), using default settings for trimming, automatic word and bubble size and a minimum contig length of 110 bp. To determine the coverage of each contig, the reads were mapped against the assembled contigs.

title: Assembled RAW diversity from grassland EPs (2010-2017) for multidiversity synthesis - July 2019
abstract:
A dataset including information on abundance for each single species for all trophic levels in grassland EPs. 

This is an updated and more complete version of datasets 21766 and 24606. The script used to update this dataset from the previous version is available at: https://github.com/biodiversity-exploratories-synthesis/2019_grassland_diversity/blob/master/190715_UpdateGRLdataset.R

This dataset is connected to dataset 25646 (taxonomic, trophic and functional information) by the "Species" column.

We also provide an R script (ID 22046) to help merging this dataset with dataset 25646(species information) and calculate various metrics (richness, abundance, diversity and multidiversity).

IMPORTANT - PLEASE READ CAREFULLY: 
- Please read carefully the metadata of each single dataset included in the present dataset before use. Some groups were measured by different researchers with different protocols and different years.
- When aggregating by e.g. Trophic_level, make sure that the information from different groups was collected on the SAME plots. 
- When aggregating, in particular for abundance information, make sure that the methods are comparable.
- For soil bacteria, fungi and protists: we provide the number of OTUs for (e.g.) rarefaction purposes but do not use this as abundance information.
- For soil bacteria and fungi: missing combinations of plots X species are not NAs but zeros, they were not added to the dataset to limit its size (but note that bacteria miss plots AEG33 AEG34, these are NAs).
- For all the other groups plots with missing information (e.g. non measured plot) were removed from the dataset to reduce its size. For use in matrix format (plot x species) please fill missing information with NA's (and not zeros).
- Ant data is provided as presence/absence but abundance data is also available in BExIS.
- When using information on functional and trophic groups for snails, please cite: 
Falkner, G., Obrdlík, P., Castella, E., Speight, M. C. D. (2001). Shelled Gastropoda of Western Europe. Friedrich-Held-Gesellschaft, Munich.

title: Assembled species information from grassland EPs (2010-2017) for multidiversity synthesis - July2019
abstract:
A dataset including information on each species found in the in grassland EPs. It provides information on broad taxonomic classification, trophic level and functional role of each species.

This is an updated and more complete version of dataset 21726. The script used to update this dataset from the previous version is available at: https://github.com/biodiversity-exploratories-synthesis/2019_grassland_diversity/blob/master/190715_UpdateGRLdataset.R

This dataset is connected to dataset 25626 (raw abundance/presence-absence) by the "Species" column.

We also provide an R script (ID 22046) to help merging this dataset with dataset 25626 (raw abundance/presence-absence) and calculate various metrics (richness, abundance, diversity and multidiversity).

IMPORTANT - PLEASE READ CAREFULLY: 
- Please read carefully the metadata of each single dataset included in the present dataset before use. Some groups were measured by different researchers with different protocols and different years.
- When aggregating by e.g. Trophic_level, make sure that the information from different groups was collected on the SAME plots. 
- When aggregating, in particular for abundance information, make sure that the methods are comparable.
- For soil bacteria, fungi and protists: we provide the number of OTUs for (e.g.) rarefaction purposes but do not use this as abundance information.
- For soil bacteria and fungi: missing combinations of plots X species are not NAs but zeros, they were not added to the dataset to limit its size (but note that bacteria miss plots AEG33 AEG34, these are NAs).
- For all the other groups plots with missing information (e.g. non measured plot) were removed from the dataset to reduce its size. For use in matrix format (plot x species) please fill missing information with NA's (and not zeros).
- Ant data is provided as presence/absence but abundance data is also available in BExIS.
- When using information on functional and trophic groups for snails, please cite: 
Falkner, G., Obrdlík, P., Castella, E., Speight, M. C. D. (2001). Shelled Gastropoda of Western Europe. Friedrich-Held-Gesellschaft, Munich.

title: Code, example dataset, and instructions of Sentinel-1 data pre-processing and pixel-based summary statistics used in "Radar vision for mapping forest biodiversity from space"
abstract:
We used C-band Synthetic Aperture Radar (C-SAR) acquired by the Sentinel-1 mission in 2016 over all of Germany including all forest EPs in Bae et al. (2019). This dataset comprises of code, an example dataset, instructions, and expected output of Sentinel-1 data pre-processing and pixel-based summary statistics used in Bae et al. (2019). 
Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) data are a prime candidate to meet the demands for ecologically meaningful information on vegetation structure from space from regional to global scales. A big advantage of SAR is the ability to penetrate clouds, making it a suitable technique also for regions with almost constant cloud coverage, such as the tropics or mountain areas. See more details in Bae et al. (2019).

title: Phylogeny of Coleoptera species used in the TreeScape Project, 2007-2016
abstract: This data set contains the phylogenetic tree of beetles used for analysis in the TreeScape project, which was used for calculating phylogenetic distance matrices used in the TreeScape Project. The phylogeny comprises all beetle species collected in the Exploratories in 2008 (150 plots), in the Steigerwald (69 Plots) in 2016 and in the Bavarian Forest in 2007 (BIOKLIM, 167 Plots).

title: Soil physico-chemical and root biomass data for 2015 and 2018 of 25 SCH grassland MIPs, cooperation SADE-SCALEMIC
abstract:
Cooperation SADE-Scalemic:
SADE = seed addition and disturbance experiment.
One 7m x 7m control plot, one 7m x 7m plot with seed addition, one 7m x 7m with disturbanc (rotary cultivation), one 7m x 7m with seed addition and disturbance. The experiment addresses ecosystem resilience by assessing how fast grassland ecosystems including all their functions and processes recover after drastic disturbance and return to the initial conditions, in dependency on pre-disturbance diversity and land-use intensity. On the other hand, we will determine to what degree seeding of non-resident species can increase the local plant diversity and how such an increase may benefit ecosystem services such as yield, forage quality, pollination or carbon fixation. The seeding also allows one to estimate to what degree the current diversity of grassland is limited by a restricted dispersal capacity of plant species. Finally, the experiment tests the adaptive potential of grasslands to future climatic changes and extreme weather events, because a higher diversity of the vegetation could be associated with a higher resilience of the system. This dataset contains the data that was analysed on soil samples of the years 2015 and 2018 on all 25 SADE plots in the Schorfheide.

title: Soil chemical parameters beneath deadwood from the BELongDead experiment on 30 forest plots in 2017
abstract:
The dataset is connected to the BELongDead (Biodiversity Exploratories Long term Dead wood) experiment established on a total of 30 plots (VIP plots) in 2009. On each plot downded deadwood (logs) of 13 tree species were exposed. 
On the declared normal subplots, the influence of deadwood on chemical parameters in underlying soils was investigated after 8 years of wood decomposition. Soils beneath logs were compared to soils in 8 m distance (control) without recognizable influence of deadwood.

title: Soil microbial parameters beneath deadwood from the BELongDead experiment on 30 forest plots in 2017
abstract:
The dataset is connected to the BELongDead (Biodiversity Exploratories Long term Dead wood) experiment established on a total of 30 plots (VIP plots) in 2009. On each plot downded deadwood (logs) of 13 tree species were exposed.
On the declared normal subplots, the influence of deadwood on microbial parameters in underlying soils was investigated after 8 years of wood decomposition. Soils beneath logs were compared to soils in 8 m distance (control) without recognizable influence of deadwood.

title: Historical land-use/ land-cover shapes of 2-km buffers around grassland EP
abstract: The dataset comprises shapefiles of land use/ land cover of the three Exploratories derived from historical topographic maps of the 19th and 20th century (ca. 1850, 1930, 1960). Additionally, it includes land-use/ land-cover shapes from 2008/09 that are modified versions of the biotope layers from the dataset 'Landscape heterogeneity metrics' (BExIS ID 24046). All shapes cover a radius of 2 km around Experimental Plots (EP) on grasslands.

title: Historical land use and landscape metrics of grassland EP
abstract:
The dataset comprises various landscape metrics based on GIS layers derived from historical topographic maps of the 19th and 20th century (ca. 1850, 1930, 1960). Additionally, landscape metrics from 2008 are provided based on modified versions of the biotope layers from the dataset 'Landscape heterogeneity metrics' (BExIS ID 24046). The metrics were calculated on circular buffers around Experimental Plots (EP) with radii of 100, 250, 500, 1000 and 2000 m. Further, patch-level metrics and historical land-use/ land-cover type of the grassland sites on which the EP were located are included.

The landscape metrics of this dataset are listed below.

Patch-level metrics (only for the central patches containing the grassland EP): patch area, perimeter, shape index, nearest-neighbour distance, proximity index and Hanski index.
 
Class-level metrics (calculated for each land use/ land cover class within circular buffers around EP): total class area, proportional class area, mean patch area, area-weighted mean patch area, patch number, total edge, edge density, mean shape index, mean nearest-neighbour distance, median proximity index, median Hanski index.

Landscape-level metrics (calculated for the whole landscape within circular buffers around EP): patch density, edge density, Shannon diversity, Shannon evenness.

For more information on the landscape metrics, please see the word document "Metadata_LandMetrics" that is included in the zip folder of this dataset.

title: Oomycota (Stramenopiles, protists), Illumina sequencing, all EPs. grassland and forest, 2011
abstract: We have assessed the diversity of a major protistan phylum Oomycota(Stramenopiles), focussing on plant parasites in 2011. Data stem from 300 grassland and forest sites of the German Biodiversity Exploratories, using high-throughput Illumina sequencing of the ITS 1. Data are raw abundances of 97% similarity operational taxonomic units. We provide in separate tables the taxonomic and functional assignment to the genus (saprotroph, obligate or facultative biotroph, affecting plants or animals). We tested or will test, four hypotheses: (1) Land use management influences the community composition of protistan plant pathogens and the relative proportion of pathogens/saprotrophs/free-living protists; (2) High diversity of protistan plant pathogens will be correlated with high alpha-diversity of plant communities (testing negative plant-soil feedbacks); (3) There is an undiscovered diversity of Oomycota in soil.

title: Oomycota (Stramenopiles, protists), Illumina sequencing, all EPs. grassland and forest, 2017
abstract: We have assessed the diversity of a major protistan phylum Oomycota(Stramenopiles), focussing on plant parasites in 2017. Data stem from 300 grassland and forest sites of the German Biodiversity Exploratories, using high-throughput Illumina sequencing of the ITS 1. title: Oomycota (Stramenopiles, protists), taxonomic and functional annotation of OTUs, all EPs, grassland and forest, 2011 and 2017
abstract: We have assessed the diversity of a major protistan phylum Oomycota(Stramenopiles), focussing on plant parasites in 2011. title: Arthropod data from 150 grassland plots, 2008-2017, and 140 forest plots, 2008-2016, used in "Arthropod decline in grasslands and forests is associated with drivers at landscape level", Nature
abstract: To disentangle local and landscape-level effects of land use on the temporal trends of arthropod communities in grasslands and forests, arthropod data were collected annually during the growing period from 2008 to 2017 by standardized  sampling at 150 grassland plots and from 2008 to 2016 at 30 forest plots. An additional 118 forest plots were sampled in 2008, 2011 and 2014 to test the overall trend across a larger number of plots. Both grassland and forest plots cover gradients in local land-use intensity. Land-use intensity was quantified in the form of compound indices based on grazing, mowing and fertilization intensity in grasslands (LUI), and on recent biomass removal, the proportion of non-native tree species and deadwood origin in forests (ForMI). To analyze landscape-level effects, we quantified the cover of arable fields and grassland within 1500m radius around each sampling plot (based on ATKIS DLM). We modelled temporal trends in biomass, abundance and species number of arthropods and of different dispersal and trophic guilds separately for grasslands and forests, and tested for effects of local and landscape-scale land-use intensity on these trends, accounting for weather conditions and different spatial scales.

title: Predation marks on dummy caterpillars measured on all EPs in 2017
abstract: In June 2017, we investigated predation on dummy caterpillars over 48 h in all three Exploratory regions. We investigated (i) whether plot-level process rates and their spatial variation differed between forests and semi-natural grasslands, (ii) whether process rates were correlated among each other across sites and (iii) whether the rates were affected by climate and land- use intensity at short and medium-term temporal scales.

title: Predation rates based on dummy caterpillars measured on all EPs in 2017
abstract: In June 2017, we investigated predation on dummy caterpillars over 48 h in all three Exploratory regions. We investigated (i) whether plot-level process rates and their spatial variation differed between forests and semi-natural grasslands, (ii) whether process rates were correlated among each other across sites and (iii) whether the rates were affected by climate and land- use intensity at short and medium-term temporal scales.

title: Trifolium pratense was sampled on the plots HG13, HG08, HG15 and HG42 in the year 2014 for RNA-Seq
abstract: Red clover is an important fodder crop, due to its advantages like soil improving characteristics. Nevertheless it lacks a high persistency for example after mowing or cutting. Additionally it has a well described drastic phenotypic reaction, well documented in response to regrowth. Nevertheless the molecular basis of this regrowth reaction needs still to be understood. Therefore we collected red clover plants from the previous mentioned plots and from greenhouse populations. The aim by comparative transcriptome analysis to identify genes involved in the regrowth reaction under land use scenarios.

title: Biological soil crust NLFA concentrations (sampling 2017)
abstract: The microbiota in three terrestrial habitats (biological soil crusts - crust, transition zone below - trans, and crust-free soil - soil) were studied in 33 temperate forest stands of the Schorfheide-Chorin differing in forest management intensity (ForMI). The results showed that biological soil crusts (BSC) and the transition zone below provide habitats of different suitability for microbiota, resulting in specific, adapted communities. These are shaped by management intensity and nutrient availability, suggesting BSC as suitable indicators to assign land use in temperate forest ecosystems.

title: Vegetation Records for 151 Forest EPs, 2009 - 2018
abstract: To create a dataset of a large-scale long-term time series of vegetation composition we conduct an annual monitoring of plant diversity in an area of 20 m x 20 m in all 151 forest EPs.

title: Spectral diversity metrics of all grassland EPs, 2017 - 2019
abstract:
Spectral variation is recently utilized as highly abstract surrogate for functional diversity (i.e. spectral variation hypothesis, see overview Rocchini et al. 2015). It can be used as explanatory data layer in functional biodiversity research. In order to provide a common database, spectral indices describing the variability of reflection functions across different scales are provided here.

Rocchini, D., Hernández-Stefanoni, J. L., & He, K. S. (2015). Advancing species diversity estimate by remotely sensed proxies: A conceptual review. Ecological Informatics, 25, 22–28. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ecoinf.2014.10.006

title: Soil microbial and extractable carbon and nitrogen at 23 Hainich grassland MIPs in 2015 and 2018, SADE
abstract: The Seed Addition and Disturbance Experiment (SADE) addresses ecosystem resilience by assessing how fast grassland ecosystems including all their functions and processes recover after drastic disturbance and return to the initial conditions, in dependency on pre-disturbance diversity and land-use intensity. On the other hand, we will determine to what degree seeding of non-resident species can increase the local plant diversity and how such an increase may benefit ecosystem services such as yield, forage quality, pollination or carbon fixation. title: Soil organic and inorganic phosphorous (Olsen P) at 73 grassland MIPs, 2018, SADE
abstract: The Seed Addition and Disturbance Experiment (SADE) addresses ecosystem resilience by assessing how fast grassland ecosystems including all their functions and processes recover after drastic disturbance and return to the initial conditions, in dependency on pre-disturbance diversity and land-use intensity. On the other hand, we will determine to what degree seeding of non-resident species can increase the local plant diversity and how such an increase may benefit ecosystem services such as nutrient cycling, yield or carbon cycling. Finally, the experiment tests the adaptive potential of grasslands to future climatic changes and extreme weather events, because a higher diversity of the vegetation could be associated with a higher resilience of the system.

title: Design of the Seed Addition and Disturbance Experiment at 73 grassland plots - SADE
abstract:
OBJECTIVES
Our experiment addresses several unanswered questions which are highly important for basic ecological research but also for applied sciences of agriculture and nature conservation. On the one hand, these questions address ecosystem resilience, which is a measure of resistance against permanent changes. The resilience represents an important component of the stability of an ecosystem. Hereby, we will assess how fast grassland ecosystems including all their functions and processes recover after drastic disturbance and return to the initial conditions, in dependency on pre-disturbance diversity and land-use intensity. On the other hand, we will determine to what degree seeding of non-resident species can increase the local plant diversity and how such an increase may benefit ecosystem services such as yield, forage quality, pollination or carbon fixation. The seeding also allows one to estimate to what degree the current diversity of grassland is limited by a restricted dispersal capacity of plant species. Finally, the experiment tests the adaptive potential of grasslands to future climatic changes and extreme weather events, because a higher diversity of the vegetation could be associated with a higher resilience of the system.

GUIDING QUESTIONS
How strongly does the resilience of a grassland ecosystem depend on plant diversity and land-use intensity?
How long do grasslands need to fully recover after disturbance with and without addition of species, including all ecosystem functions?
How strongly is the current vegetation limited by seed and microsite availability?
Which biotic, abiotic and land use driven filters determine the species composition of the grassland plant communities?
Has an experimental raise of plant diversity further positive effects on ecosystem functioning such as resilience, nutrient cycling and drought tolerance?

title: List of plant species sown in the SADE Experiment
abstract:

On the one hand, these questions address ecosystem resilience, which is a measure of resistance against permanent changes. On the other hand, we will determine to what degree seeding of non-resident species can increase the local plant diversity and how such an increase may benefit ecosystem services such as yield, forage quality, pollination or carbon fixation. The seeding also allows one to estimate to what degree the current diversity of grassland is limited by a restricted dispersal capacity of plant species. Finally, the experiment tests the adaptive potential of grasslands to future climatic changes and extreme weather events, because a higher diversity of the vegetation could be associated with a higher resilience of the system.

GUIDING QUESTIONS

How long do grasslands need to fully recover after disturbance with and without addition of species, including all ecosystem functions?
How strongly is the current vegetation limited by seed and microsite availability?
Which biotic, abiotic and land use driven filters determine the species composition of the grassland plant communities?
Has an experimental raise of plant diversity further positive effects on ecosystem functioning such as resilience, nutrient cycling and drought tolerance?

title: Standardized questionnaire template of grassland management
abstract: Interviews with members of the LMTs (mainly the grassland experts) and the land users took place retrospectively for the previous year on all permanently established 150 grassland sites since 2006, based on a standardised questionnaire, which was identical for all three exploratory regions. The results of the questionnaire are inserted within the land use data set 23746 together with own observations of the LMTs and explorers visiting the sites.

title: Landcover in plot surroundings based on ATKIS-DLM
abstract: Information on land use types in the plot surroundings is of great importance for biodiversity research. The dataset provides information on the cover of different land use types (arable field, forest, grassland, heathland, and swamp) in the plot surroundings of all experimental plots (EP). Landuse types were extracted from ATKIS DLM and their proportion within different radii (250, 500, 1000, 1500, and 2000m) around each plot were calculated.

title: List of plots without complete sampling or data for sweep-netting of arthropods on grassland EPs 2008 to 2022
abstract: Arthropod diversity has been studied on all 150 grassland EP plots since 2008 to provide data for various analysis, e.g. effects of land use on arthropods. In very few plot*year combinations, one or both samplings could not be conducted, e.g. due to grazing. These plots should be excluded from analysis. The dataset specifies all grassland plots with incomplete data.

title: Moth abundance from lighttrapping on all grassland and forest plots 2018
abstract: Nocturnal moth are a species-rich and functional important insect group which may by affected land-use practices.

title: Infection rates with Epichloe festucae var. lolii and alkaloid contents in Lolium perenne, grassland EPs, Defense II, June-August 2017
abstract: Symbiotic Epichloë endophytes in cool-season grass species are able to produce different alkaloids, which can be toxic for vertebrates and/or invertebrates. Hence it is important to monitor the infections of grasses in Germany with Epichloë fungi, to be able to estimate possible intoxication risks. In this dataset we focus on Epichloe festucae var. lolii infecting Lolium perenne.

title: Infection rates and alkaloid contents of Epichloe festucae var. lolii in Lolium perenne on five plots in the Schorfheide-Chorin during the course of one year from April 2018 until January 2019, Defense II,
abstract: Symbiotic Epichloë endophytes in cool-season grass species are able to produce different alkaloids, which can be toxic for vertebrates and/or invertebrates. Hence it is important to monitor the infections of grasses in Germany with Epichloë fungi, to be able to estimate possible intoxication risks. In this dataset we focus on Epichloe festucae var. lolii infecting Lolium perenne on five plots in the Schorfheide-Chorin.

title: Microbial metaproteome data from decayed beech dead wood (HEW11 BU017, 2017)
abstract: In the Biodiversity Exploratory Hainich-Dün (Germany), we collected in spring 2017 from the beech log, dead wood chips for extraction testing as outlined previously.  The wood chips was roughly sliced with a cutting blade and then milled with added liquid nitrogen in the analytical mill (IKA A11 basic, IKA grinder) into fine powder. 1 g of powder were divided on eight 15 ml tube and used for testing for the different protein extraction protocols; cell lysis with sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS) buffer (2% (w/v) SDS, 50 mM DTT, 50 mM EDTA, 1 mM PMSF, 100 mM Tris) or sulfobetain-14, and additional phenol extraction or trichloroacetic acid (TCA)-acetone (10% (w/v) TCA, 2-Mercaptoethanol, acetone) precipitation. Two samples were analyzed for each combination. Cell lysis: 5 ml lysis buffer (SDS or Sulfobetain-14 buffer), 10 glass beads (2,85 – 3,45 mm diameter, CarlRoth) and 3 scoops of zirconium beads (0,1 mm diameter, Biospec.) were added to samples, shaken for 30 minutes at room temperature and disrupted by FastPrep (3x1 min, 5.5 ms-1, MP Biomedicals). After centrifugation (7,200 x g, 10 min, 4 °C), the supernatant were transferred to 50 ml tubes and the proteins were extracted. For all extraction methods, the dried pellets were proteolytic digested in gel. Therefore, the pellets were dissolved in SDS sample buffer (2% w/v SDS, 2 mM beta-mercaptoethanol, 4% v/v glycerol, 40 mM Tris–HCl pH 6.8, 0.01% (w/v) bromophenol blue), heated to 90 °C for 4 minutes and separated by SDS polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. Proteins were stained in gel with Coomassie G-250 (Merck). Then, the gel was cut into small pieces (band per samples), detained, dehydrated and proteolytically cleaved overnight at 37 °C with trypsin (Promega). The digested peptides were extracted and desalted using ZipTip-μC18 tips (Merck Millipore, Darmstadt, Germany). Following, the peptide lysates were re-suspended in 0.1% formic acid and injected to liquid chromatography mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS).

title: Vegetation Records for Grassland EPs, 2008 - 2019
abstract: To create a dataset of a large-scale long-term time series of vegetation composition we conduct an annual monitoring of plant species richness and community composition. In spring of the years 2008-2019, we sampled all species in an area of 4m x 4m and estimated the percentage cover of each species.

title: Soil physico-chemical and root biomass data for 2015 and 2018 of 25 HAI grassland MIPs, cooperation SADE-SCALEMIC
abstract:
Cooperation SADE-Scalemic:
SADE = seed addition and disturbance experiment.
One 7m x 7m control plot, one 7m x 7m plot with seed addition, one 7m x 7m with disturbanc (rotary cultivation), one 7m x 7m with seed addition and disturbance. The experiment addresses ecosystem resilience by assessing how fast grassland ecosystems including all their functions and processes recover after drastic disturbance and return to the initial conditions, in dependency on pre-disturbance diversity and land-use intensity. On the other hand, we will determine to what degree seeding of non-resident species can increase the local plant diversity and how such an increase may benefit ecosystem services such as yield, forage quality, pollination or carbon fixation. The seeding also allows one to estimate to what degree the current diversity of grassland is limited by a restricted dispersal capacity of plant species. Finally, the experiment tests the adaptive potential of grasslands to future climatic changes and extreme weather events, because a higher diversity of the vegetation could be associated with a higher resilience of the system. (Source: http://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/en/projects/current-projects/plants/sade/)

This dataset contains the data that was analysed on soil samples of the years 2015 and 2018 on all 25 SADE plots in the Hainich.

title: Soil enzyme activities of all grassland EPs, soil sampling campaign (SSC) 2017, SCALEMIC
abstract: The study focussed on regional biogeography of soil microorganisms over time, i.e. how below ground microbial communities are organised and differentiated along geographic, climatic and environmental gradients. To address this question we characterised soil microbial communities at three levels of resolution (gene abundance, enzyme activity, and community level). The three exploratories will allow us to up-scale the biogeography of soil microorganisms from plot to regional scale.

title: Microbiological and chemical data of burried mineral containers with labelled artificial root exudates on 10 ALB sites, SCALEMIC Phase 4 (2014-2017) WP1
abstract: We investigated microbial colonization of new surfaces and resource use of bacteria and fungi under different land-use intensities.

title: FTIR measures of standards for burried mineral containers with labelled artificial root exudates on 10 ALB sites, SCALEMIC Phase 4 (2014-2017) WP1
abstract: We investigated microbial colonization of new surfaces and resource use of bacteria and fungi under different land-use intensities.

title: FTIR measures of burried mineral containers with labelled artificial root exudates on 10 ALB sites, SCALEMIC Phase 4 (2014-2017) WP1
abstract: We investigated microbial colonization of new surfaces and resource use of bacteria and fungi under different land-use intensities.

title: Vegetation Records for 150 Grassland EPs in 2019, Header Data without Species Identities (incl. biomass)
abstract:
To create a dataset of a large-scale long-term time series of vegetation composition we conduct an annual monitoring of plant species richness and community composition. In spring of the years 2008-2019, we sampled all species in an area of 4m x 4m and estimated the percentage cover of each species. This area is not disturb by other experiment and is called core area ("Heilige Fläche (HF)" in German).  

Biomass was clipped in two subplots. In each subplot we clipped all plants of two 1m x 1m plots at the height of 2cm.
The height was measured as well.

title: Biocrust and soil surface water content, pH, phosphorus, nitrogen and carbon contents (several forest plots 2018) - CRUSTFUNCTION II
abstract:
Biocrusts play an important role in the nutrient of carbon, nitrogen, and phosphorus.
Therefore, we determined the following parameters in the two soil surface compartments 'biological soil crust' ('biocrust', 0-5 mm) and 'crust-free bare soil' (‘bare_soil’, 0-5 mm): 
- total P concentrations
- inorganic P (Pi) concentrations of labile P (Pi-H2O and Pi-NaHCO3)
- total N, NH4, NO3 and total dissolved nitrogen concentrations
- total carbon concentrations
- pH and 
- water contents.

title: Biocrust and Bulk Soil Gene Abundance Bacteria, N and P Cycle qPCR; several forest plots 2018 - CRUSTFUNCTION II
abstract: This study was conducted to investigate the bacterial role in Phosphorus (P) and Nitrogen (N) cycle in biological soil crusts. We determined the abundance of the following functional genes in the two soil surface compartments 'biological soil crust' (biocrust, BSC, 0-5 mm) and 'crust-free bare soil' (bulk soik, BS, 0-5 mm) of P cycle as pstS, pitA (P uptake), phoD, phnX (P mineralization), gcd (P solubilization) and N cycle as nosZ, nirS, nirK (denitrification), nifH (N fixation), chiA, apr (N mineralization), amoA AOB, amoA AOA, Nitrospira 16S rRNA, nxrA Nitrobacter (denitrification), Bacteria 16S rRNA (bacterial abundance).

title: Approximated pore size distribution of grassland EPs (SSC 2014) SCALEMIC
abstract:
The synthesis proposal 018a by Boeddinghaus et al. intended to investigate the "Effects of physical soil properties on microbial community structure in grassland ecosystems".
Physical soil characteristics shape the environment of soil biota at various scales. From soil texture, that influences the fine porous space and nutrient availability, to soil structure and aggregation which determine water balance and oxygen supply. Physical soil characteristics determine the number of available habitats for different members of soil biota. 
Within the Biodiversity Exploratories framework we have the unique opportunity to investigate the relationships of soil microorganisms, i.e. bacteria, fungi, archaea and protozoa, and soil biogeophysical characteristics (e.g. pore size distribution, root density, soil structure, soil texture, water holding capacity, and soil climatic conditions) of 150 grassland sites in three different climatic regions in Germany.

title: Chemical traits of fine roots (organic soil layers) from 150 forest plots, soil sampling 2017
abstract: The objective was to investigate the relationship between fine root chemical traits and diversity of the root-associated fungal community in temperate forests. The sampling campaign took place on 1-12th May, 2017.

title: Abundance of beech root-associated fungi 2014 and 2017 in Schorfheide-Chorin (Beech Transplant Experiment)
abstract: The relationship between trees and root-associated fungal communities is complex. By specific root deposits and other signal cues, different tree species are able to attract divergent sets of fungal species. Plant intraspecific differences can lead to variable fungal patterns in the root’s proximity. Therefore, within the Beech Transplant Experiment,   we analyzed the impact of three different European beech ecotypes on the fungal communities in roots and the surrounding rhizosphere soil at two time points. Beech nuts were collected in three German sites in 2011. After one year, seedlings of the different progenies were out-planted on one site and eventually re-sampled in 2014 and 2017. We applied high-throughput sequencing of the fungal ITS2 to determine the correlation between tree progeny, a possible home-field advantage, plant development and root-associated fungal guilds under field conditions.

title: Flower and leaf bacterial community composition (16S rRNA gene - V4 region) of Ranunculus acris and Trifolium pratense, several grassland EPs, 2017
abstract: Relative abundances of sequence read counts of bacterial taxa at genus level, as determined by high-throughput sequencing of the 16S rRNA gene V4 region. We sampled from Ranunculus acris and Trifolium pratense flowers and leaves in all three regions in 2017 from June to August. We visited all 150 plots, but were only able to sample on 43 plots, whenever both plant species co-occurred on a plot. Whole flowers (Ranunculus acris) and inflorescences (Trifolium pratense) as well as leaf sample swabs were sampled in triplicates/plot and stored in DNA/RNA Shield(Zymo Research) with bashing beads in the field and stored at -20°C until further processing in the lab.

title: Abundance of carrion-assoc invertebrates baited with synthetic cadaver blends on 5 forest plots, 2018
abstract: In this study, we investigated how the geotrupid dung beetle Anoplotrupes stercorosus uses volatiles to locate carrion as a resource. Using chemo-ecological methodologies, we tested which volatiles out of two distinct carrion odor bouquets the beetle is able to perceive, and secondly, whether we could bait A. stercorosus with synthetic mixtures out of these volatiles in German forests.

title: Potential soil atmospheric methane oxidation rates of all EP Plots, Soil sampling campaign 2017
abstract: In the project BE_CH4 we want to investigate the effect of land use intensity on methane fluxes and methane cycling microorganisms.

title: Bacterial and fungal biodiversity of Fagus sylvatica deadwood in a late decay stage on Hainich forestplots with wood decay parameters from 2017
abstract: In this study, we investigate the effect of two temperature regimes on a richness-reduced and natural microbial community inhabiting Fagus sylvatica deadwood in a late decay stage in the Hanich-Dün exploratory. The samples were taken in spring 2017. Microcosms were prepared and incubated for eight weeks. Decomposition activity, wood pH, gas emission (nitrogen, oxygen, carbon dioxide and methane), bacterial and fungal diversity and co-occurrence networks were calculated.

title: Oribatid mite abundances, diversity, sex ratio and numbers of eggs in females from 15 forest and 15 grassland plots in the Swabian Alb and the Schorfheide, 2017
abstract: We investigated the impact of land-use on oribatid mite diversity and abundances in 15 forest and 15 grassland plots in the Swabian Alb and the Schorfheide-Chorin in 2017.

title: Land use in grasslands: raw data of yearly owner interviews
abstract:
The present dataset summarises management information collected from 2006 ongoing for 150 grassland plots in three exploratories (three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin)). Data are based on annual interviews of the respective farmers, land owners or tenants involved in land management activity, using a standardised questionnaire (dataset ID 26006 - in German). The dataset provides information on land use in grasslands, in particular on mowing, grazing, fertilization and maintenance measures, as well as drainage and management history. Out of this dataset, the LUI components, used in the LUI-Tool in BExIS, are calculated. LUI (Land Use Index) is a quantitative index that is calculated out of intermediate values for grazing, mowing and fertilization. Thereby, different land-use intensities of the grassland plots can be described. 

A continuation of the dataset including also data after 2022 can by found via ID 31767.

title: Ca, K, Mg concentrations in soil at 73 grassland MIPs captured with resin bags, 2018, SADE
abstract: The Seed Addition and Disturbance Experiment SADE aims to understand the roles of land use and biodiversity in the resilience and ecosystem functioning of grasslands. By capturing soil nutrients with resin bags during the vegetation growing season we are able to test how effects of sward disturbance, land use and diversity affect the availability of nutrients for plants and potential leaching risks.

title: Ca, K, Mg concentrations in soil at 77 non-SADE grassland EPs captured with resin bags, 2018, ESCAPE
abstract: Soil Calcium, Potassium and Magnesium are important nutrients for plants. We have measured the availailtiy of these nutrients during over almost the entire growing period to quantify the availability of these nutrients. this data can be used to infer effect of land use and soil properties on soil nutrient contrations.

title: Nutrient concentrations in plant biomass at all grassland EPs, 2018, ESCAPE
abstract: The increase in agricultural management intensity has influenced vegetation patterns, composition and dynamics through increased vegetation disturbance (mowing, grazing) and altered soil fertility (fertilization). The chemical composition of the aboveground plant biomass- used as an indicator for plant nutrition and productivity- and fibre fractions of grassland biomass- used as measure of the quality and nutritive value of herbage fodder- both integrate spatial and temporal variation on soil resources during the growing season (Klaus et al, 2011).

title: Nutrient concentrations in plant biomass at all grassland EPs, 2019, ESCAPE
abstract: The increase in agricultural management intensity has influenced vegetation patterns, composition and dynamics through increased vegetation disturbance (mowing, grazing) and altered soil fertility (fertilization). The chemical composition of the aboveground plant biomass- used as an indicator for plant nutrition and productivity- and fibre fractions of grassland biomass- used as measure of the quality and nutritive value of herbage fodder- both integrate spatial and temporal variation on soil resources during the growing season (Klaus et al, 2011).

title: Nutrient concentrations in plant biomass at 73 grassland MIPs, 2019, SADE
abstract:
The increase in agricultural management intensity has influenced vegetation patterns, composition and dynamics through increased vegetation disturbance (mowing, grazing) and altered soil fertility (fertilization). The chemical composition of the aboveground plant biomass- used as an indicator for plant nutrition and productivity- and fibre fractions of grassland biomass- used as measure of the quality and nutritive value of herbage fodder- both integrate spatial and temporal variation on soil resources during the growing season (Klaus et al, 2011).
The Seed Addition and Disturbance Experiment (SADE) addresses ecosystem resilience by assessing how fast grassland ecosystems including all their functions and processes recover after a drastic disturbance and return to the initial conditions, in dependency on pre-disturbance diversity and land-use intensity. On the other hand, we will determine to what degree seeding of non-resident species can increase the local plant diversity and how such an increase may benefit ecosystem services such as yield, forage quality or carbon fixation (Klaus et al. 2017).

title: Fine root and mycorrhizal traits of 82 grassland species measured in a greenhouse experiment on sand, 2018
abstract: We measured fine root traits along with mycorrhizal colonization over a large species set to be able to determine species interspecific differences and functional trade-offs related to soil nutrient uptake by grassland plant roots.

title: Soil macrofauna abundances on group level from 48 forest plots sampled in spring 2017
abstract: Soil animals are important drivers of decomposition processes, nutrient cycling and plant growth. Belowground food webs acquire a major fraction of their energy from detritus and therefore are viewed as decomposer or brown food webs. In forests most species either directly consume dead organic matter, in particular leaf litter, feed on microbial decomposers or prey on primary and secondary decomposer animals thereby forming part of the decomposer food web.

title: Soil mesofauna abundances on group level from 48 forest plots sampled in spring 2017
abstract: Soil animals are important drivers of decomposition processes, nutrient cycling and plant growth. Belowground food webs acquire a major fraction of their energy from detritus and therefore are viewed as decomposer or brown food webs. In forests most species either directly consume dead organic matter, in particular leaf litter, feed on microbial decomposers or prey on primary and secondary decomposer animals thereby forming part of the decomposer food web.

title: 16S rRNA gene (V3 region) RNA-based analysis of microbial soil communities at sequence variant level in 150 grassland EP plots, using QIIME2-based bioinformatics, 2017
abstract:
We determine the microbial community composition in 300 EP plots from grassland and woodlands. Most bacteria in soil are dormant or inactive. A substantial fraction might even be dead. Hence, in order to quantify the living and active bacteria, we isolated RNA from soil and sequenced V3 16S rRNA amplicons. The presence and amount of ribosomes in a cell can be taken as a rough proxy for activity. The results indicate substantial difference between grassland and woodland soils. Moreover, bacterial communities can be additionally distinguished by their soil type.
Here, the data are provided as quality-checked but non-rarefied read counts of distinct exact sequence variants (Callahan et al 2017). 
A bacterial sequence variant in this data set is defined by a specific nucleotide sequence of the V3 16S rRNA gene region of 165 base pair length. 
That means, bacterial sequence variants are distinguished at the level of single nucleotide differences.

Callahan et al (2017) Exact sequence variants should replace operational taxonomic units in marker-gene data analysis. ISMEJ, https://doi.org/10.1038/ismej.2017.119

title: 16S rRNA gene (V3 region) RNA-based analysis of microbial soil communities at sequence variant level in 150 woodland EP plots, using QIIME2-based bioinformatics, 2017
abstract:
We determine the microbial community composition in 300 EP plots from grassland and woodlands. Most bacteria in soil are dormant or inactive. A substantial fraction might even be dead. Hence, in order to quantify the living and active bacteria, we isolated RNA from soil and sequenced V3 16S rRNA amplicons. The presence and amount of ribosomes in a cell can be taken as a rough proxy for activity. The results indicate substantial difference between grassland and woodland soils. Moreover, bacterial communities can be additionally distinguished by their soil type.
Here, the data are provided as quality-checked but non-rarefied read counts of distinct exact sequence variants (Callahan et al 2017).

title: Trifolium pratense regrowth measurements on test field 2017
abstract:
Plants are exposed to various biotic and abiotic factors which they cannot evade due to their sessile nature. Therefore, they adapt their growth behaviour to local environmental constraints leading to phenotypic variation owing to their open bauplan. A major factor inducing phenotypic plasticity is the loss of biomass through herbivory or cutting. The Fabaceae Trifolium repens reacts to cutting by producing more but smaller leaves compared to uncut plants. As T. repens is a common fodder plant this effect might be of agronomical importance, as repeated cutting could reduce the amount of harvested biomass.
A close relative to Trifolium repens, Trifolium pratense L. (red clover), is used in many parts of the world as high-quality fodder plant due to its naturally high protein content and its deep root systems and high yield which give T. pratense preference over T. repens. It is grown in monocultures or in a grass mixture where it increases the nitrogen content of the surrounding plants. In a previous study, phenotypic plasticity of red clover during regrowth after cutting/mowing was analysed in a common garden experiment. After cutting, red clover produces, similar to T. repens, more leaves than uncut plants but they are of the same size than before cutting. Only the length of newly formed petioles is reduced when compared to uncut plants.

title: Above- and below-ground trait data for Grasslands EPs plants at the species level measured in controlled conditions 2017-2018
abstract:
-!-!-!-!-!-!-!-!-!-!-!-!-!-!-!-!-!-!
Data openly available, not need of elaborate requests, just write a few words.
-!-!-!-!-!-!-!-!-!-!-!-!-!-!-!-!-!-!
The root scans pictures are available on demand (send a mail) as the files are very large
---------------------------------

To investigate how the traits of grassland species vary across environmental gradients we measured above- and below-ground traits on the species occurring in the grasslands EPs. Traits were measured on plants grown from seeds.

This is the dataset for the traits measured at the species level (1 value per trait per plant species), by averaging the values of individual replicates for each species, for the data at the individual level please refer to dataset ID 31432: https://www.bexis.uni-jena.de/ddm/data/Showdata/31432

We conducted three traits screening, (1) on plant and particularly root morphology (2) on rooting depth (3) on nitrate and ammonium update.
For now (August 2020), data on (1) plant morphology and (2) rooting depth are available. Data on (3) Nitrate and ammonium uptake will be added when we receive and clean the data, estimated in Autumn 2020

title: Trifolium pratense masses of harvested biomass from test field 2017
abstract: Plants are exposed to various biotic and abiotic factors which they cannot evade due to their sessile nature. Therefore, they adapt their growth behaviour to local environmental constraints leading to phenotypic variation owing to their open bauplan. The Fabaceae Trifolium repens reacts to cutting by producing more but smaller leaves compared to uncut plants. As T. repens is a common fodder plant this effect might be of agronomical importance, as repeated cutting could reduce the amount of harvested biomass. A close relative to Trifolium repens, Trifolium pratense L. (red clover), is used in many parts of the world as high-quality fodder plant due to its naturally high protein content and its deep root systems and high yield which give T. pratense preference over T. repens.
