title: Flower and leaf bacterial diversity indices based on 16S rRNA gene sequences (V4) of Ranunculus acris and Trifolium pratense, several grassland EPs, 2017
abstract: Diversity indices based on bacteria related amplicon sequence variants (ASVs), as determined by high-throughput sequencing of the 16S rRNA gene V4 region and based on the RDP v16 reference database. We sampled from Ranunculus acris and Trifolium pratense flowers and leaves in all three regions in 2017 from June to August. We visited all 150 plots, but were only able to sample on 43 plots, whenever both plant species co-occurred on a plot. Whole flowers (Ranunculus acris) and inflorescences (Trifolium pratense) as well as leaf sample swabs were sampled in triplicates/plot and stored in DNA/RNA Shield (Zymo Research) with bashing beads in the field and stored at -20°C until further processing in the lab.

title: Sugars on flowers and leaves of Ranunculus acris and Trifolium pratense, several grassland EPs, 2017
abstract: The availability of sugars play an important role in the determination of microbial communities on flowers and leaves. Sugar concentrations on above-ground plant parts may also vary between land use management systems. Hence, it is important to quantify the availability of sugars to estimate their impact on bacterial diversity in different ecosystems.

title: Diversity of cadaver visiting Staphylinidae at forest EPs 2014
abstract:
In the project “NecroPig” we are studying the influence of land use intensity on the decomposition rate of dead mammals. In terrestrial ecosystems, decomposition rate of animal biomass is heavily dependent on the availability of decomposers and detritivores and on abiotic factors of a certain habitat. Therefore, the aim of this project is to understand how the habitat structure and land use intensity influences the decomposition and removal rate of dead mammals in conjunction with the biodiversity of the associated arthropod fauna at spatial scales. 
Fieldwork was performed in August 2014. Seven inspections (days 2, 4, 6, 9, 16, 23, 30) were conducted after stillborn piglet cadaver exposition (day 0). Staphylinids were collected using pitfall traps opened for 48 hours before each inspection. On every inspection, pitfall traps were emptied. Specimens were preserved in 70 % ethanol and stored in urinary containers for later species determination and for counting of individuals.

title: Flower and leaf volatile organic compounds (VOCs) of Ranunculus acris and Trifolium pratense, several grassland EPs, 2017
abstract: Floral scents are known to play  a major role for the attraction of pollinators or for the defense against herbivory insects and microbial pathogens. However, many bacterial taxa show resistance against emitted volatile organic compounds (VOCs). Remarkably, some bacterial taxa are able to degrade specific VOCs and use it as carbon sources. Hence, the emission of VOCs may play an important role in the determination of microbial communities on flowers and leaves and may vary between ecosystems under different land use intensities.

title: Single species data of cadaver visiting Staphylinidae at forest EPs 2014
abstract:
In the project “NecroPig” we are studying the influence of land use intensity on the decomposition rate of dead mammals. In terrestrial ecosystems, decomposition rate of animal biomass is heavily dependent on the availability of decomposers and detritivores and on abiotic factors of a certain habitat. Therefore, the aim of this project is to understand how the habitat structure and land use intensity influences the decomposition and removal rate of dead mammals in conjunction with the biodiversity of the associated arthropod fauna at spatial scales. 
Fieldwork was performed in August 2014. Seven inspections (days 2, 4, 6, 9, 16, 23, 30) were conducted after stillborn piglet cadaver exposition (day 0). Staphylinids were collected using pitfall traps opened for 48 hours before each inspection. On every inspection, pitfall traps were emptied. Specimens were preserved in 70 % ethanol and stored in urinary containers for later species determination and for counting of individuals.

title: Predation marks on dummy caterpillars measured on VIPs in 2018
abstract: In August 2018, we investigated predation on dummy caterpillars over 48 h in all three Exploratory regions. We investigated (i) whether plot-level process rates and their spatial variation differed between forests and semi-natural grasslands, (ii) whether process rates were correlated among each other across sites and (iii) whether the rates were affected by climate and land- use intensity at short and medium-term temporal scales.

title: Predation marks on dummy caterpillars measured on VIPs in 2019
abstract: In May 2019, we investigated predation on dummy caterpillars over 48 h in all three Exploratory regions. We investigated (i) whether plot-level process rates and their spatial variation differed between forests and semi-natural grasslands, (ii) whether process rates were correlated among each other across sites and (iii) whether the rates were affected by climate and land- use intensity at short and medium-term temporal scales.

title: Arthropod mediated processes (dung and seed depletion) measured on VIPs in 2018
abstract: In August 2018, we investigated the dung depletion and seed removal after 48 h in all three Exploratory regions as arthropod mediated processes. We investigated (i) whether plot-level process rates and their spatial variation differed between forests and semi-natural grasslands, (ii) whether process rates were correlated among each other across sites and iii) whether the rates were affected by climate and land-use intensity at short and medium-term temporal scales.

title: Arthropod mediated processes (dung and seed depletion) measured on VIPs in 2019
abstract: In May 2019, we investigated the dung depletion and seed removal after 48 h in all three Exploratory regions as arthropod mediated processes. We investigated (i) whether plot-level process rates and their spatial variation differed between forests and semi-natural grasslands, (ii) whether process rates were correlated among each other across sites and iii) whether the rates were affected by climate and land-use intensity at short and medium-term temporal scales.

title: Trifolium pratense nitrogen contents after mowing 2017
abstract: Plants are exposed to various biotic and abiotic factors which they cannot evade due to their sessile nature. Therefore, they adapt their growth behaviour to local environmental constraints leading to phenotypic variation owing to their open bauplan. A major factor inducing phenotypic plasticity is the loss of biomass through herbivory or cutting. The Fabaceae Trifolium repens reacts to cutting by producing more but smaller leaves compared to uncut plants. As T. repens is a common fodder plant this effect might be of agronomical importance, as repeated cutting could reduce the amount of harvested biomass. A close relative to Trifolium repens, Trifolium pratense L. (red clover), is used in many parts of the world as high-quality fodder plant due to its naturally high protein content and its deep root systems and high yield which give T. pratense preference over T. repens. It is grown in monocultures or in a grass mixture where it increases the nitrogen content of the surrounding plants. In a previous study, phenotypic plasticity of red clover during regrowth after cutting/mowing was analysed in a common garden experiment. After cutting, red clover produces, similar to T. repens, more leaves than uncut plants but they are of the same size than before cutting. Only the length of newly formed petioles is reduced when compared to uncut plants.

title: EP Grassland Landuse Information ALB 2020
abstract:
Information about the land use on the EPs in 2020, based on information given by the farmers or on observations by members of the exploratories.
This file will be updated continuously.
It should be used only for fieldwork planning, NOT FOR ANALYSIS!.

title: Throughfall, rainfall, soil solution, stem flow - Cl, TN, NH4-N, PO4-P, NO3-N, TP analysis in water samples (2009 - 2016, all VIPs)
abstract:
The aims of this study are to determine cycling of water, nutrient, and carbon for the VIPs of the Biodiversity Exploratories and relate soil acidification, nutrient loss and greenhouse gas emissions to land-use and biodiversity. Nutrient balance studies help to determine the sustainability of type and intensity of management. Nutrient-input via precipitation is one of the main external sources in natural ecosystems and is also an additional nutrient source in managed ecosystems. Furthermore, precipitation of water is of high relevance for water supply of plants and plays a key role in soil processes like mineralization.

Concentrations of N in NH4+, N in NO3-, TDN, Cl-, P in PO43-, and TDP in water samples. Used to calculate waterbound fluxes of these species.

title: Throughfall, rainfall, soil solution, stem flow - Al, Ca, Fe, K, Mg, Mn, Na, P, S, Si analysis in water samples (2009 - 2016, all VIPs)
abstract:
The aims of this study are to determine cycling of water, nutrient, and carbon for the VIPs of the Biodiversity Exploratories and relate soil acidification, nutrient loss and greenhouse gas emissions to land-use and biodiversity. Nutrient balance studies help to determine the sustainability of type and intensity of management. Nutrient-input via precipitation is one of the main external sources in natural ecosystems and is also an additional nutrient source in managed ecosystems. Furthermore, precipitation of water is of high relevance for water supply of plants and plays a key role in soil processes like mineralization.

Concentrations of Al, Ca, Fe, K, Mg, Mn, Na, P, S and Si in water samples from Schwäbische Alb, Hainich Dün and Schorfheide-Chorin. Used to calculate waterbound fluxes of these elements.

title: Vegetation records for grassland SADE on 73 EPs, 2015 - 2019
abstract: SADE is an abbreviation for "seed addition and disturbance experiment". The goal of this project is to study the effect of disturbance and/or seed addition in grasslands. In spring of the years 2015-2019, we sampled all species in area of 2m by 2m and estimated the percentage cover of each species for each treatment separately.

title: Vegetation records SADE on 73 Grassland EPs; 2019, Header data without species identity (incl. biomass)
abstract: A major challenge in ecological restoration is to effectively restore plant diversity in permanent grasslands. As species richness is often limited by seed dispersal, introducing locally absent species by seed addition is often crucial. We established a full-factorial experiment with high-diversity seeding and topsoil disturbance in 73 grasslands along land-use intensity and productivity gradients and evaluated the restoration success over 5 year (SADE is an abbreviation for "seed addition and disturbance experiment"). We found that plant diversity increased considerably when seeding and disturbance were combined while seeding alone only slightly increased species richness. Along land-use gradients, we found no direct effects of grazing or mowing on the establishment of sown species, but fertilization indirectly limited establishment in the combined treatment via a negative effect of productivity. Our results highlight the potential of using diverse seed mixtures for biodiversity restoration in a wide range of permanent grasslands, especially when combined with topsoil disturbance.

abstract:

title: Infiltration capacity and hydraulic conductivity of 50 grassland soils with varying land-use intensity and biodiversity in southern Germany (Schwäbische Alb) in 2017
abstract:
Up to now only little attention has been given to the role of biodiversity for soil erosion and flood generation. Both, soil erosion and flood generation are driven by the capability of soils to take up (infiltration) and conduct water to deeper soil layers (hydraulic conductivity). A high infiltration capacity (i.e., maximum infiltration rate under a given matrix potential) reduces the risk of surface runoff and thus soil erosion. A high hydraulic conductivity facilitates the storage of water in the deeper soil, which mediates the time until rainwater reaches groundwater or a stream and thus affects flood generation. The main objective of our study was to determine if biodiversity affects the infiltration capacity (vB) and the saturated (K*) and unsaturated (Ku) hydraulic conductivity near saturation of soils in established and agriculturally managed grassland systems.
For this, we measured vB with a hood infiltrometer at several matrix potentials on 50 grassland plots along a land-use intensity gradient in the Biodiversity Exploratory Schwäbische Alb, Germany,  and calculated the saturated and unsaturated K. The studied plots were agriculturally managed grasslands with varying biodiversity and their size was 50 m x 50 m (i.e. the 50 grassland EPs of the Exploratory Schwäbische Alb). The measurements were done between 26 September and 20 October 2017.
The work has been funded by the DFG Priority Program 1374 ”Infrastructure-Biodiversity-Exploratories” and the Stiftung Landesbank Baden-Württemberg.

title: 1st sapling inventory on all forest EPs, 2014-2017
abstract:
Sapling inventory 2014 - 2017
Inventory of trees smaller 1.3 m in height on all forest EPs.

title: 1st small trees inventory on all forest EPs, 2014-2017
abstract:
Small trees inventory 2014 - 2017
Inventory of trees with dbh smaller 7 cm on all forest EPs.

title: Description of Usitatibacter
abstract:
Members of the metabolically diverse order Nitrosomonadales inhabit a wide range of environments. Two strains affiliated to this order were isolated from soils in Germany and characterized by a polyphasic approach.

One strain arises from soil from plot AEW08.

title: Raw data for the spatial structure and environmental factors on all forest EPs (2006-2018) used in "Dispersal ability, trophic position and body size mediate species turnover processes: insights from a multi-taxa and multi-scale approach"
abstract: This dataset is raw data for the regional and landscape spatial structure and environmental factors on all forest Eps used in "Dispersal ability, trophic position and body size mediate species turnover processes: insights from a multi-taxa and multi-scale approach", submitted to Diversity and Distribution. In the paper, regional species pool was represented by the regional spatial structure, neutral processes by landscape spatial structure, environmental filtering by environmental factors related to vegetation, repectively.The environmental factors were composed of herb and tree layer composition and forest physiognomy.

title: Quantification of Candidatus Udaeobacter in soil microcosms treated with antibiotics, 2017
abstract: The absolute 16S rRNA gene abundance of Candidatus Udaeobacter representatives in soil microcosms treated with six different antibiotics in high concentration was determined over 20 days of incubation. This was done to validate that these bacteria grow in absolute abundance upon exposure to antibiotics.

title: Soil Texture and pH in VIP grassland plots 2017
abstract: As part of the LandUseSAC project we measured pH and soil texture in all VIP plots.

title: Enzymatic capabilities of fungal isolates from VI-plots 2017
abstract: The functional significance of fungi in soil based ecosystem services, such as soil structure formation, nutrient cycling, and plant productivity, is widely acknowledged. However, a comprehensive link between individual fungal taxa and ecosystem services is currently impossible, due to a lack of knowledge of functional traits of these taxa. We currently engage in large scale, high throughput culturing of saprobic fungi from the very intensive (VI) grassland plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories.

title: MinSoil 2018-19: Soil respiration in forests and grasslands
abstract: The core project ‘Soil' provides essential information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all 300 Experimental Plots (EPs) of the Biodiversity Exploratories. Soil respiration, measured as the CO2 efflux from soil surface, originates from the soil fauna and microbial (heterotrophic) respiration and root (autotrophic) respiration. Soil respiration is one of the most important C fluxes in terrestrial ecosystems and it is influenced by biotic and abiotic factors as well as land use and management intensification.

title: Literature-based plant-herbivore interaction database for Exploratory species (vascular plants; Hemiptera: Auchenorryhncha, Hemiptera: Heteroptera, Coleoptera, Orthoptera)
abstract: Food plants of herbivore insect species have been documented in a vast literature. Here, we compile this information for the herbivorous insect species sampled in the Biodiversity Exploratories from a thorough literature search. This information can e.g. be used to infer plot-based plant-herbivore interaction networks, which can then be analysed along land-use intensity gradients.

title: Mineral soil respiration - all forest experimental plots (EPs), 2018 + 2019
abstract: The core project ‘Soil' provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. Soil respiration, measured as the CO2 efflux from soil surface, originates from the soil fauna and microbial (heterotrophic) respiration and root (autotrophic) respiration. Soil respiration is one of the most important C fluxes in terrestrial ecosystems and it is influenced by biotic and abiotic factors as well as land use and management intensification.

title: Enzyme kinetics during tea decomposition and in soil after 3 and 12 months at 23 grassland MIPs, 2016 - 2017
abstract: Measurement of activities and calculation of the Michaelis-Menten kinetics (Vmax and Km) of five different enzymes (beta-glucosidase, cellobiohydrolase, cellotriohydrolase, N-acetyl-glucosaminidase, phosphatase) by fluorescence analysis (4-methylumbelliferone) in litter of two qualities (tea bags containing either Camellia sinensis or Aspalanthus linearis) after 3 months and after 12 months of decomposition in the mineral topsoil (0-5 cm). In addition, after 3 months enzyme kinetics in the soil surrounding the tea bag (soil from "teasphere") were determined. The selected sites show different intensities of use and are located in the German Biodiversity Exploratories (Hainich-Dün). Tea bags and teasphere soil samples from 23 experimental plots in Hainich-Dün region.

title: Non-structural carbohydrates in the tap root of Plantago lanceolata grown in a common garden, 2018
abstract: In 2017, we collected seeds from 10 mother plants (seed families) of Plantago lanceolata on 63 plots to plant them in a common garden in 2018 to analyse non-structural carbohydrates in the taproot.

title: Collembolan species abundance on all 150 grassland EPs from 2019
abstract: Fauna Inventory of all grassland EPs to understand soil fauna community assembly and resilience dependence on land use.

title: Height measurement of beech seedlings in the translocation experiment in the years 2013, 2014, 2015 and 2018
abstract: In the project the adaptation potential of European beech was investigated. One part of the project was the establishment of a reciprocal translocation experiment, in which adaptation of seedlings with different origin was observed. Here, we measured plant height of the beech seedlings to identify differences in height increment of the different populations.

title: Root associated bacterial communities of Dactylis glomerata in 8 ALB grassland plots May, June, and October 2015
abstract: In this study, we investigated the impact of different land use intensities on the root-associated core microbiome of Dactylis glomerata (Orchardgrass).

title: Soil parameters: Root associated bacterial communities of Dactylis glomerata in 8 ALB grassland plots May, June, and October 2015
abstract: In this study, we investigated the impact of different land use intensities on the root-associated microbiome of Dactylis glomerata (Orchardgrass).

title: BelongDead - Wood density of 13 tree species, 30 VIPs, 2009-2018
abstract: This dataset involves wood density measurements of 13 tree species of BelongDead decaying in forest plots since 2009. The BELongDead experiment was conceived in 2008 with the intention to monitor the impact of habitats on the dead wood decomposition processes and to observe colonization patterns of various saproxylic organisms over long time.

title: Phenology of forest herbs 2017 from 100 plots
abstract: Flowering phenology of forest understory plants

title: Observation of landuse and landuse change (2006-2019,  all exploratories)
abstract: The dataset contains the observation of landuse and results of conducted surveys with farmers and landusers, and the documentation of landuse change over the years.

title: Eubacteria in 27 VIP grassland plots 2017
abstract: The aim of the project LandUseSAC was to assess how spatial variability influences alpha and beta diversity of bacteria and fungi. To do so we worked on a 6 x 6 m plot and 4 satellite plots which were located 10 m N, E, S, W (i.e. names respectively satellite 1, 2, 3 and 4 samples) from the core plot. Here we present relative abundance data on bacteria.

title: Eumycota in 27 VIP plots 2017
abstract: The aim of the project LandUseSAC was to assess how spatial variability influences alpha and beta diversity of bacteria and fungi. To do so we worked on a 6 x 6 m plot and 4 satellite plots which were located 10 m N, E, S, W (i.e. names respectively satellite 1, 2, 3 and 4 samples) from the core plot. Here we present relative abundance data on fungi..

title: Trap nesting solitary bee species measured on all grassland VIPs 2017-2018
abstract:
Biodiversity loss, often found in intensively managed agricultural landscapes, correlates with reduced ecosystem functioning, e.g. insect pollination and altered floral resource diversity, abundance and composition. 
To better understand impacts of land-use intensification on wild bee-plant interactions, we investigated how land-use intensification affects the diversity and composition of trap nesting solitary bee species.

title: Fatty acids in pollen of Osmia bicornis larval provisions 2017-2018
abstract: Biodiversity loss, often found in intensively managed agricultural landscapes, correlates with reduced ecosystem functioning, e.g. insect pollination and altered floral resource diversity, abundance and composition. How this affects bee foraging and larval diets in solitary wild bees is largely unclear. To better understand impacts of land-use intensification on wild bee-plant interactions, we investigated communities of trap nesting solitary bees, their pollen foraging and the nutritional quality of larval food composed in grasslands along a land-use intensity gradient across three bioregions (Swabian Alb, Hainich- Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) in Germany.

title: Amino acids in pollen of Osmia bicornis larval provisions 2017-2018
abstract: Biodiversity loss, often found in intensively managed agricultural landscapes, correlates with reduced ecosystem functioning, e.g. insect pollination and altered floral resource diversity, abundance and composition. How this affects bee foraging and larval diets in solitary wild bees is largely unclear. To better understand impacts of land-use intensification on wild bee-plant interactions, we investigated communities of trap nesting solitary bees, their pollen foraging and the nutritional quality of larval food composed in grasslands along a land-use intensity gradient across three bioregions (Swabian Alb, Hainich- Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) in Germany.

title: Plant species diversity based on rDNA gene sequences (ITS2) of trap nesting solitary bee species 2017-2018
abstract: Biodiversity loss, often found in intensively managed agricultural landscapes, correlates with reduced ecosystem functioning, e.g. insect pollination and altered floral resource diversity, abundance and composition. title: Vegetation Records for 151 Forest EPs, 2009 - 2019
abstract: To create a dataset of a large-scale long-term time series of vegetation composition we conduct an annual monitoring of plant diversity in an area of 20 m x 20 m in all 151 forest EPs.

title: Soil nutrient leaching in forests and grasslands - all experimental plots (EPs), 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project ‘Soils' provides essential information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all 300 Experimental Plots (EPs) of the Biodiversity Exploratories. Nutrient leaching is the downward movement of nutrients through the soil with the percolating water. Nutrient leaching, and especially nitrogen and phosphorus leaching, is a loss of a vital resource for the agricultural production, and, at the same time, a potential danger for public health and aquatic ecosystems. Here, we provide data for the annual leaching for seven nutrients (nitrate, ammonium,  phosphate, sulfate, calcium, magnesium and potassium) from the top soil (upper 10 cm of mineral soil) of forests and grasslands (300 EPs). Nutrient fluxes reported are expressed as flux of the element of interest. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-3, TR 1054/4-3, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/)

title: Soil Oribatida abundances on species level from 48 forest plots sampled in spring 2017
abstract: Soil animals are important drivers of decomposition processes, nutrient cycling and plant growth. Belowground food webs acquire a major fraction of their energy from detritus and therefore are viewed as decomposer or brown food webs. In forests most species either directly consume dead organic matter, in particular leaf litter, feed on microbial decomposers or prey on primary and secondary decomposer animals thereby forming part of the decomposer food web.

title: PLFA of soil in HEW and SEW after one (2012) and three (2014) years of root excusion
abstract: The input of plant leaf litter has been assumed to be the most important resource for soil organisms of forest ecosystems, but there is increasing evidence that root-derived resources may be more important. By trenching roots of trees in deciduous and coniferous forests, we cut-off the input of root-derived resources and investigated the response of microorganisms using phospholipid fatty acid (PLFA) analysis.

title: Microbial biomass in soil and litter of 32 forest HEW and SEW plots after one (2012) and three (2014) years of root exclusion
abstract: The input of plant leaf litter has been assumed to be the most important resource for soil organisms of forest ecosystems, but there is increasing evidence that root-derived resources may be more important. By trenching roots of trees in deciduous and coniferous forests, we cut-off the input of root-derived resources and investigated the response of microorganisms using substrate-induced respiration a measure for microbial biomass.

title: Soil macrofauna abundances on species level from 48 forest plots sampled in spring 2017
abstract: Soil animals are important drivers of decomposition processes, nutrient cycling and plant growth  Belowground food webs acquire a major fraction of their energy from detritus and therefore are viewed as decomposer or brown food webs. In forests most species either directly consume dead organic matter, in particular leaf litter, feed on microbial decomposers or prey on primary and secondary decomposer animals thereby forming part of the decomposer food web.

title: Soil meso- and macrofauna abundances on group level of 32 forest plots in HEW and SEW one (2012) and three years (2014) after root trenching
abstract: Forest soil food webs have been assumed to be fueled substantially by root-derived resources. However, until today the flux of root-derived resources into soil animals has been investigated virtually exclusively using isotope labeling experiments, whereas studies on the consequences of disrupting the flux of root-derived resources into the soil animal food web are scarce. We here investigated the importance of root-derived resources for a range of soil animals by interrupting resource flux into the soil of different forest types in Central Europe for three years, using a trenching experiment.

title: Soil meso- and macrofauna biomass on group level of 32 forest plots in HEW and SEW three (2014) years after root trenching
abstract:
Forest soil food webs have been assumed to be fueled substantially by root-derived resources. However, until today the flux of root-derived resources into soil animals has been investigated virtually exclusively using isotope labeling experiments, whereas studies on the consequences of disrupting the flux of root-derived resources into the soil animal food web are scarce. We here investigated the importance of root-derived resources for a range of soil animals by interrupting resource flux into the soil of different forest types in Central Europe for three years, using a trenching experiment.
Biomass is a good measure for shifts in population growth.

title: R script to reproduce the analyses of "Land-use intensity alters networks between biodiversity, ecosystem functions and services", PNAS (Felipe-Lucia et al. 2020)
abstract: We use correlation networks to provide a holistic view of the effects of land-use intensity on the relationships between the biodiversity of multiple trophic groups, ecosystem functions, and ecosystem services for two major temperate ecosystems, grasslands and forests.

title: An mRNA-Genotyping-by-Sequencing (mRNA-GBS) approach to link association studies with expression profiling in non-model species (Trifolium pratense (Fabaceae)) - On four grassland plots in Hainich Dünn, 2014. TRATSCH I
abstract: TRATSCH - Trifolium RNA analysis to screen character heterogeneity: An mRNA-Genotyping-by-Sequencing (mRNA-GBS) approach to link association studies with expression profiling in non-model species. Within this Project we have two phases of TRTASCH called TRATSCH I and TRATSCH II with the title: Comparative transcriptome analysis and phenotypic monitoring of Trifolium pratense (Fabaceae) under land use scenarios.

title: An mRNA-Genotyping-by-Sequencing (mRNA-GBS) approach to link association studies with expression profiling in non-model species (Trifolium pratense (Fabaceae)) - On 18 grassland plots of the three Biodiversity Exploratories, 2017. TRATSCH II
abstract: TRATSCH - Trifolium RNA analysis to screen character heterogeneity: An mRNA-Genotyping-by-Sequencing (mRNA-GBS) approach to link association studies with expression profiling in non-model species. Within this Project we have two phases of TRTASCH called TRATSCH I and TRATSCH II with the title: Comparative transcriptome analysis and phenotypic monitoring of Trifolium pratense (Fabaceae) under land use scenarios.

title: Vegetation Records for Grassland EPs, 2008 - 2020
abstract: To create a dataset of a large-scale long-term time series of vegetation composition we conduct an annual monitoring of plant species richness and community composition. In spring of the years 2008-2020, we sampled all species in an area of 4m x 4m and estimated the percentage cover of each species.

title: Acari abundance (Oribatida to species level) on all 150 grassland EPs from 2019
abstract: Fauna Inventory of all grassland EPs to understand soil fauna community assembly and resilience dependence on land use.

title: Vegetation Records for 150 Grassland EPs in 2020, Header Data without Species Identities (incl. biomass)
abstract:
To create a dataset of a large-scale long-term time series of vegetation composition we conduct an annual monitoring of plant species richness and community composition. In spring of the years 2008-2020, we sampled all species in an area of 4m x 4m and estimated the percentage cover of each species. This area is not disturb by other experiment and is called core area ("Heilige Fläche (HF)" in German).  

Biomass was clipped in two subplots. In each subplot we clipped all plants of two 1m x 1m plots at the height of 2cm.
The height was measured as well.

title: Comparision of fungal communities in bark beetle affected und unaffected spruces on HEW51
abstract:
In recent years, climate change let to mass infestations of bark beetles with tremendous economic and ecological consequences. Fungi as independent kingdom and as key players in nutrient cycles fulfill important roles in forest ecosystems.
The development of molecular methods like high throughput sequencing and maintained databases facilitate fungal analysis of environmental samples.The main aim of this study was in understanding the impact of bark beetle infection on fungal diversity and communities in soil, litter and wood of infested and not infested Norway spruce trees (Picea abies (L.) H.Karst., Pinaceae). 
In January, 2020, infested and not infested trees were sampled within one forest plot belonging to the Biodioversity Exploratories in Hainich-Dün in Central Germany. Using Illumina MiSeq, the fungal internal transcribed spacer region (ITS) was sequenced and subsequently bioinformatically processed. The obtained fungal matrix, together with information on taxonomical and functional fungal assignments, and further describtions of the taken samples.

title: Soil Collembola biomass of 32 forest plots in HEW and SEW three years (2014) after root trenching
abstract: Forest soil food webs have been assumed to be fueled substantially by root-derived resources. However, until today the flux of root-derived resources into soil animals has been investigated virtually exclusively using isotope labeling experiments, whereas studies on the consequences of disrupting the flux of root-derived resources into the soil animal food web are scarce. We here investigated the importance of root-derived resources for a range of soil animals by interrupting resource flux into the soil of different forest types in Central Europe for three years, using a trenching experiment.

abstract: Forest soil food webs have been assumed to be fueled substantially by root-derived resources. abstract:
Forest soil food webs have been assumed to be fueled substantially by root-derived resources. However, until today the flux of root-derived resources into soil animals has been investigated virtually exclusively using isotope labeling experiments, whereas studies on the consequences of disrupting the flux of root-derived resources into the soil animal food web are scarce. title: Earthworm and isopod stable isotope signatures of forest plots in HEW and SEW three/four years (2014/2015) after root trenching
abstract: Forest soil food webs have been assumed to be fueled substantially by root-derived resources. However, until today the flux of root-derived resources into soil animals has been investigated virtually exclusively using isotope labeling experiments, whereas studies on the consequences of disrupting the flux of root-derived resources into the soil animal food web are scarce. We here investigated the importance of root-derived resources for a range of soil animals by interrupting resource flux into the soil of different forest types in Central Europe for three years, using a trenching experiment. Root exclusion will affect the diet of soil animals resulting in a shift of stable isotope signature of soil animals

title: Common garden fertilization experiment, A. millefolium, B. hordeaceus, P. lanceolata, 2017/2018
abstract: In 2017, we collected seeds from three common grassland species (Achillea millefolium, Bromus hordeaceus, Plantago lanceolata) from 58, 69, 63 plots respectively to conduct a common garden experiment with a fertilization treatment to study the evolution of plant phenotypic plasticity in reponse to grassland management. To specify, we studied the opportunistic response after fertilization in terms of chlorophyll content (dataset 27507), C:N ratio of the leaves (dataset 27508) and aboveground biomass (dataset 27506). This dataset contains biomass data and covariates.

title: Common garden fertilization experiment, A. millefolium, B. hordeaceus, P. lanceolata, 2017/2018 - chlorophyll measurements
abstract: In 2017, we collected seeds from three common grassland species (Achillea millefolium, Bromus hordeaceus, Plantago lanceolata) from 58, 69, 63 plots respectively to conduct a common garden experiment with a fertilization treatment to study the evolution of plant phenotypic plasticity in reponse to grassland management. To specify, we studied the opportunistic response after fertilization in terms of chlorophyll content, C:N ratio of the leaves (dataset 27508) and aboveground biomass (dataset 27506). This dataset contains the measurements of chlorophyll content (SPAD value) of B. hordeaceus and P. lanceolata.

title: Common garden fertilization experiment, A. millefolium, B. hordeaceus, P. lanceolata, 2017/2018 - C and N measurements
abstract: In 2017, we collected seeds from three common grassland species (Achillea millefolium, Bromus hordeaceus, Plantago lanceolata) from 58, 69, 63 plots respectively to conduct a common garden experiment with a fertilization treatment to study the evolution of plant phenotypic plasticity in reponse to grassland management. To specify, we studied the opportunistic response after fertilization in terms of chlorophyll content (dataset 27507) and aboveground biomass (dataset 27506). This dataset contains measurments of leaf carbon and nitrogen.

title: Nematode abundances on species level and feeding guilds of forest plots in HEW and SEW three years (2014) after root trenching
abstract: Forest soil food webs have been assumed to be fueled substantially by root-derived resources. However, until today the flux of root-derived resources into soil animals has been investigated virtually exclusively using isotope labeling experiments, whereas studies on the consequences of disrupting the flux of root-derived resources into the soil animal food web are scarce. We here investigated the importance of root-derived resources for a range of soil animals by interrupting resource flux into the soil of different forest types in Central Europe for three years, using a trenching experiment.

title: Herbivory on experimental plants at 7 grassland plots, LandUseFeedback, Hainich, 2018 and 2019
abstract: Under natural conditions, aboveground herbivory and plant-soil feedbacks (PSFs) are omnipresent interactions strongly affecting individual plant performance and community composition. Although recent research suggests that the intensity of aboveground insect herbivory influence the outcome of these PSFs, it is unclear whether the PSF process itself is impacted by the level of herbivore damage. Therefore, we performed a standardized comparative PSF experiment in seven grasslands that differed in land-use related intensity of aboveground herbivory.

title: Biomass experimental plants at 8 grassland plots, LandUseFeedback, field experiment Hainich 2019
abstract: Under natural conditions, aboveground herbivory and plant-soil feedbacks (PSFs) are omnipresent interactions strongly affecting individual plant performance and community composition. Although recent research suggests that the intensity of aboveground insect herbivory influence the outcome of these PSFs, it is unclear whether the PSF process itself is impacted by the level of herbivore damage - or whether it is only the outcome that is changed. Therefore, we performed a standardized comparative PSF experiment in eight grasslands that differed in land-use related intensity of aboveground herbivory.

title: Biomass plant-soil feedback experiment, LandUseFeedback, 2019
abstract: Under natural conditions, aboveground herbivory and plant-soil feedbacks (PSFs) are omnipresent interactions strongly affecting individual plant performance and community composition. Although recent research suggests that the intensity of aboveground insect herbivory influence the outcome of these PSFs, it is unclear whether the PSF process itself is impacted by the level of herbivore damage. Therefore, we performed a standardized comparative PSF experiment in seven grasslands that differed in land-use related intensity of aboveground herbivory.

title: Biomass 2 grass species in competition experiment in soils conditioned at 5 grassland plant, LandUseFeedabck, 2019
abstract: Under natural conditions, aboveground herbivory, competition and plant-soil feedbacks (PSFs) are omnipresent interactions strongly affecting individual plant performance and community composition. Although recent research suggests that the intensity of aboveground insect herbivory influence the outcome of these PSFs, it is unclear whether the PSF process itself is impacted by the level of herbivore damage as well as the competition between species. Therefore, we performed a standardized comparative PSF experiment in five grasslands that differed in land-use related intensity of aboveground herbivory.

title: Plant-soil feedback values of 2 grasses in PSF-field-experiment, LandUseFeedback, Hainich 2019
abstract: Under natural conditions, aboveground herbivory and plant-soil feedbacks (PSFs) are omnipresent interactions strongly affecting individual plant performance and community composition. Although recent research suggests that the intensity of aboveground insect herbivory influence the outcome of these PSFs, it is unclear whether the PSF process itself is impacted by the level of herbivore damage. Therefore, we performed a standardized comparative PSF experiment in seven grasslands that differed in land-use related intensity of aboveground herbivory.

title: Plant-soil feedback values in experimentally and naturally conditioned soils of 7 grasslands, LandUseFeedback, 2019
abstract: In plant-soil feedback research it remains poorly understood whether experimental soil conditioning really reflects the soil conditioning effects in nature. Therefore, we tested whether experimental soil conditioning yielded in similar results compared to natural soil conditioing.

title: Nematode communities in sapwood and heartwood of the BELongDead logs (selection cutting, Hainich NP, 2014)
abstract:
Sapwood and heartwood nematode communities of 13 different deadwood tree species were investigated (BELongDead-Experiment, selection cutting HEW7, HEW8, HEW9) using an amplicon-sequencing analysis.
Here we provide the relative abundances of all observed OTUs. These include not only sequences assigned to the Phylum Nematoda but also other non-target groups as we discuss this ratio in the related manuscript. The data are non-rarefied.

title: Acoustic diversity index based on environmental sound recordings on all forest EPs, HAI, 2016
abstract:
Indices of acoustic diversity have been shown to correlate with vegetation structure, species richness of various taxa and landscape composition. Further acoustic monitoring is applicable across large spatial and temporal scales. It thus has a high potential for large scale ecosystem monitoring. Nonetheless the drivers of acoustic diversity in relation to land-use and landscape composition are yet not well understood. The acoustic niche hypothesis postulates that a higher organismic diversity should result in a higher acoustic richness and complexity. Land-use intensity affects biodiversity in various ways and therefore could have an indirect effect on acoustic diversity. This relationship is hypothesized to be modified by abiotic factors such as temperature and rain as well as noise from nearby roads and machinery mediated by altered calling behavior of vocalizing animals.
To test this conceptual framework we set up autonomous recording systems to record 1 minute every ten in grassland and forest plots established as long term research plots along a land-use and biodiversity gradient in three regions in Germany. We calculated the acoustic diversity index - ADI - to test these relationships.

title: Acoustic diversity index based on environmental sound recordings on all forest EPs, Alb, 2016
abstract:
Indices of acoustic diversity have been shown to correlate with vegetation structure, species richness of various taxa and landscape composition. Further acoustic monitoring is applicable across large spatial and temporal scales. It thus has a high potential for large scale ecosystem monitoring. Nonetheless the drivers of acoustic diversity in relation to land-use and landscape composition are yet not well understood. The acoustic niche hypothesis postulates that a higher organismic diversity should result in a higher acoustic richness and complexity. Land-use intensity affects biodiversity in various ways and therefore could have an indirect effect on acoustic diversity. This relationship is hypothesized to be modified by abiotic factors such as temperature and rain as well as noise from nearby roads and machinery mediated by altered calling behavior of vocalizing animals.
To test this conceptual framework we set up autonomous recording systems to record 1 minute every ten in grassland and forest plots established as long term research plots along a land-use and biodiversity gradient in three regions in Germany. We calculated the acoustic diversity index - ADI - to test these relationships.

title: Acoustic diversity index based on environmental sound recordings on all forest EPs, SCH, 2016
abstract:
Indices of acoustic diversity have been shown to correlate with vegetation structure, species richness of various taxa and landscape composition. Further acoustic monitoring is applicable across large spatial and temporal scales. It thus has a high potential for large scale ecosystem monitoring. Nonetheless the drivers of acoustic diversity in relation to land-use and landscape composition are yet not well understood. The acoustic niche hypothesis postulates that a higher organismic diversity should result in a higher acoustic richness and complexity. Land-use intensity affects biodiversity in various ways and therefore could have an indirect effect on acoustic diversity. This relationship is hypothesized to be modified by abiotic factors such as temperature and rain as well as noise from nearby roads and machinery mediated by altered calling behavior of vocalizing animals.
To test this conceptual framework we set up autonomous recording systems to record 1 minute every ten in grassland and forest plots established as long term research plots along a land-use and biodiversity gradient in three regions in Germany. We calculated the acoustic diversity index - ADI - to test these relationships.

title: Raw plant trait data from TRY
abstract:
This dataset is the raw data from TRY (request n°11741, requested in September 2020) used to estimate trait values for all species in the exploratories. Traits include surface leaf area (SLA), plant height, SSD, seed mass, leaf N, leaf P, leaf dry matter content (LDMC), mycorrhizal infection intensity, and mycorrhizal type. 
                             
This raw  data is provided as a reference, but users are advised to use the cleaned version of the data, in which species names are matched to species used in the exploratories.

Clean data can be found in datasets 27610 (species trait data), and 27606 (community-weighted mean data).

The full description of the cleaning and matching processes, along with sensitivity analyses, can be found in dataset 27607. The code to reproduce the results (using this dataset as input) is referenced in dataset 27609.

title: Community-weighted mean for plant above-ground traits - 300 forest and grassland EPs - 2008-2018
abstract:
This dataset provides community-weighted means for major above-ground plant traits.

Traits include Surface Leaf Area (with petiole (SLA_with_petiole) or undefined if with or without petiole (SLA)), Leaf Dry Matter Content (LDMC), leaf N content, leaf P content, plant height and seed mass.

The dataset also provides "coverage" data as a quality indicator, i.e. the proportion of cover in each plot and for each trait for which trait values were available (1 = all the cover was accounted for; 0 = no trait data for any of the species found in this plot). It is recommended to set a 'minimum coverage' threshold (e.g., coverage > 60%) to insure the quality of the analyses.

*** Please cite TRY as the primary trait data source ***
Kattge, J, Boenisch, G, Diaz, S, et al. TRY plant trait database - enhanced coverage and open access. Glob Change Biol. 2020; 26: 119-188. https://doi.org/10.1111/gcb.14904 as the TRY reference.

title: Protocol for cleaning and matching TRY trait data (with sensitivity analyses)
abstract:
We aggregated TRY data and matched it to species names found in the Biodiversity Exploratories. This document details the protocol that was used. The corresponding R code and final data can be found in dataset 27609 and 27610.

It also presents the results of some sensitivity analyses for the main decisions made during the process (i.e. effect of restricting by geographic origin and growing conditions, and using or not synonyms in the assignement of trait values from TRY).

title: Community-weighted mean for plant below-ground traits - 300 forest and grassland EPs - 2008-2018
abstract:
This dataset provides community-weighted means for below-ground plant traits.

Traits include specific root length, root weight ratio (= root system biomass/total plant biomass), rooting depth, fine roots diameter, root tissue density and mycorrhizal infection intensity.

The dataset also provides "coverage" data as a quality indicator, i.e. the proportion of cover in each plot and for each trait for which trait values were available (1 = all the cover was accounted for; 0 = no trait data for any of the species found in this plot). A threshold of 1% coverage was applied, under which CWM values were not calculated. It is recommended to use a higher threshold (e.g. >60%) for further analyses.

!!! Warning: the species included in the original datasets were mostly grassland species, e.g. excluding most tree species, so forests plots usually have low coverage and should be analysed with caution.

title: R script used to clean and match plant trait data
abstract:
This script was used to clean raw TRY data (for above-ground traits) and trait data measured in the Biodiversity Exploratories (for most below-ground traits) and match it to species names used in the Biodiversity Exploratories.

It also contains the code used to measure community-weighted means in both grassland and forest plots.

The datasets necessary to run the analysis are detailed in the script.

title: Trait data for all plant species, cleaned and aggregated from TRY
abstract: We cleaned and aggregated trait data for most plant species found in the Biodiversity Exploratories, from the TRY database.

title: Plant species list used for aggregating trait data
abstract:
We aggregated all species names (including synonyms based on the plant list, spelling variations, etc) currently used in the Biodiversity Exploratories and homogenised the format. We also matched aggregated species names with the different species they represent.

This table is not intended to be used by itself, but as a raw data to re-run trait analyses (R script can be found in dataset 27609, detailed protocol dataset 27607) to reproduce species trait data (datasets 27610) and community-weighted mean (datasets 27606 and 27608).

title: Soil microbial phospholipid fatty acids (PLFAs) and soil enzyme activities measured on 10 SADE plots in the ALB, 2015-2018, cooperation SADE-SCALEMIC
abstract:
Cooperation SADE-Scalemic:
SADE = seed addition and disturbance experiment.
One 7m x 7m control plot, one 7m x 7m plot with seed addition, one 7m x 7m with disturbanc (rotary cultivation), one 7m x 7m with seed addition and disturbance. The experiment addresses ecosystem resilience by assessing how fast grassland ecosystems including all their functions and processes recover after drastic disturbance and return to the initial conditions, in dependency on pre-disturbance diversity and land-use intensity. On the other hand, we will determine to what degree seeding of non-resident species can increase the local plant diversity and how such an increase may benefit ecosystem services such as yield, forage quality, pollination or carbon fixation. The seeding also allows one to estimate to what degree the current diversity of grassland is limited by a restricted dispersal capacity of plant species. Finally, the experiment tests the adaptive potential of grasslands to future climatic changes and extreme weather events, because a higher diversity of the vegetation could be associated with a higher resilience of the system. (Source: http://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/en/projects/current-projects/plants/sade/)

This dataset contains the data that was analysed on soil samples of the years 2015, 2016, 2017 and 2018 on 10 selected SADE plots in the Schwäbische Alb.

title: Plant community properties for all grassland EP's 2008-2015
abstract: In order to compare plant communities of biodiversity ecosystem functioning experiments and related real-world systems, Exploratories grasslands were used as a real-world counterpart for the Jena Experiment. Several plant community properties were calculated based on annual plant species specific cover data.

title: Assembled species information from grassland EPs (2008-2020) for multidiversity synthesis - November 2020
abstract:
A dataset including information on each species found in the in grassland EPs. It provides information on broad taxonomic classification, trophic level and functional role of each species.

This is an updated and more complete version of datasets 21726 and 25646. 
This dataset is connected to dataset 27707 (raw abundance/presence-absence) by the "Species" column.

The script used to update this dataset from the previous version is available at: https://github.com/biodiversity-exploratories-synthesis/Synthesis_dataset_diversity_grassland
The first lines of the script describe the changes that have been made to the dataset.

Manual. We have prepared a document the describes how to handle the datasets, provides tips and outlines the common issues when analysing the data: https://github.com/biodiversity-exploratories-synthesis/Synthesis_dataset_manual


Merge and use. We also provide an R script (ID 22046) to help merging this dataset with dataset 27707 (raw abundance/presence-absence) and calculate various metrics (richness, abundance, diversity and multidiversity. Please consider this script as an example and use it carefully. Many decisions on how to calculate these metrics are dependent on the research question. Please refer to the manual for more information.

IMPORTANT - PLEASE READ CAREFULLY: 
- Please read carefully the metadata of each single dataset included in the present dataset before use. Some groups were measured by different researchers with different protocols and different years.
- When aggregating by e.g. Trophic_level, make sure that the information from different groups was collected on the SAME plots.
- When aggregating, in particular for abundance information, make sure that the methods are comparable.
- For soil bacteria, fungi and protists: we provide the number of OTUs for (e.g.) rarefaction purposes but do not use this as abundance information.
- For soil bacteria and fungi: missing combinations of plots X species are not NAs but zeros, they were not added to the dataset to limit its size (but note that bacteria miss plots AEG33 AEG34, these are NAs).
- For other groups plots with missing information (e.g. non measured plot) were removed from the dataset to reduce its size. For use in matrix format (plot x species) please fill missing information with NA's (and not zeros).
- Ant data is provided as presence/absence but abundance data is also available in BExIS.
- When using information on functional and trophic groups for snails, please cite:
Falkner, G., Obrdlík, P., Castella, E., Speight, M. C. D. (2001). Shelled Gastropoda of Western Europe. Friedrich-Held-Gesellschaft, Munich.
- Single datasets may contain more information (e.g. birds were also measured at larger spatial scales)
- More detailed information can be found here: https://github.com/biodiversity-exploratories-synthesis/Synthesis_dataset_manual/blob/main/Synthesis%20datasets%20%20How%20to%20use.md

title: Assembled RAW diversity from grassland EPs (2008-2020) for multidiversity synthesis - November 2020
abstract:
A dataset including information on abundance for each single species for all trophic levels in grassland EPs. 

This is an updated and more complete version of datasets 21766, 24606 and 25626.
This dataset is connected to dataset 27706 (taxonomic, trophic and functional information) by the "Species" column.

The script used to update this dataset from the previous version is available at: https://github.com/biodiversity-exploratories-synthesis/Grassland_diversity_dataset (see scripts description there).
The first lines of the script describe the changes that have been made to the dataset.

Manual. We have prepared a document the describes how to handle the datasets, provides tips and outlines the common issues when analysing the data: https://github.com/biodiversity-exploratories-synthesis/Synthesis-dataset-manual/blob/main/Synthesis%20datasets%20%20How%20to%20use.md

Merge and use. We also provide an R script (ID 22046) to help merging this dataset with dataset 27706 (species information) and calculate various metrics (richness, abundance, diversity and multidiversity. Please consider this script as an example and use it carefully. Many decisions on how to calculate these metrics are dependent on the research question. Please refer to the manual for more information.

IMPORTANT - PLEASE READ CAREFULLY:
- Please read carefully the metadata of each single dataset included in the present dataset before use. Some groups were measured by different researchers with different protocols and different years.
- When aggregating by e.g. Trophic_level, make sure that the information from different groups was collected on the SAME plots. 
- When aggregating, in particular for abundance information, make sure that the methods are comparable.
- For soil bacteria, fungi and protists: we provide the number of OTUs for (e.g.) rarefaction purposes but do not use this as abundance information.
- For soil bacteria and fungi: missing combinations of plots X species are not NAs but zeros, they were not added to the dataset to limit its size (but note that bacteria miss plots AEG33 AEG34, these are NAs).
- For other groups plots with missing information (e.g. non measured plot) were removed from the dataset to reduce its size. For use in matrix format (plot x species) please fill missing information with NA's (and not zeros).
- Ant data is provided as presence/absence but abundance data is also available in BExIS.
- When using information on functional and trophic groups for snails, please cite: 
Falkner, G., Obrdlík, P., Castella, E., Speight, M. C. D. (2001). Shelled Gastropoda of Western Europe. Friedrich-Held-Gesellschaft, Munich.
- Single datasets may contain more information (e.g. birds were also measured at larger spatial scales)
- More detailed information can be found here: https://github.com/biodiversity-exploratories-synthesis/Synthesis-dataset-manual/blob/main/Synthesis%20datasets%20%20How%20to%20use.md

title: Land cover (LBM-DE) of all Biodiversity Exploratories regions
abstract: This dataset provides wall-to-wall land cover information for the entire extent of all three Exploratories. It can be used to analyze the land cover at the plot, plot-surrounding and landscape scale.

title: Digital landscape models (Basis-DLM) of all Biodiversity Exploratories regions
abstract: The Digital Landscape Model (DLM) is a description of the topographic objects of the landscape in vector format based on the definitions of the ATKIS® object type catalog (ATKIS®-OK). The scope of information of the basic DLM is based on the content of the Topographic Map 1:10 000/1:25 000, but has a higher positional accuracy (± 3 m) for the most important linear objects. It is non-symbolized vector data that can be visualized in applications or GIS systems. The object-structured data allow geometrical and attributive analyses and data processing.

title: Digital terrain models (DGM-5) of all Biodiversity Exploratories regions
abstract: Digital terrain models (DTM) describe the terrain forms of the earth's surface by a set of points arranged in a regular grid and georeferenced in position and height.

title: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) / drone images from all Exploratory grassland regions
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) or drones provide remote sensing images with a very high spatial resolution which can be used to analyze the small scale variation / spatial heterogeneity of grasslands. Such data can also be used to support the field work or as training data for the development of classification models

title: RapidEye satellite image time series of all Biodiversity Exploratories regions
abstract: The RapidEye satellite system collects satellite images with a spatial resolution of 6.5 m.  It consists of 5 similar satellites and sensors and has thus a high temporal resolution which provides multiple coverages within one vegetation period.

title: Phenology of forest herbs, from 2017 and 100 plots, used in "Spring understory herbs flower later in intensively managed forests", Ecological Applications
abstract:
Many organisms respond to anthropogenic environmental change through shifts in their phenology. 
We disentangled how forest management would change forest structure and thereby microclimatic conditions and, as a consequence, flowering phenology. To investigate this, we studied the phenology of 20 early-flowering forest herb species on 100 forest plots of different management type and intensity. The studied forest plots ranged from protected unmanaged forests and extensively managed selection system forests to managed deciduous age-class forests (from young thickets to mature timber plots) and intensively managed Norway spruce plantations. Statistical analyses were restricted to the 16 most abundant species.

title: Amino acid isotopes of Collembola and Oribatida in Hainich 2016
abstract: Soil microarthropods are essential for nutrient cycling in forest ecosystems as they are integral components of decomposer food webs. They channel carbon and nutrients from leaf litter and roots to higher trophic levels; however, knowledge on the relative importance of different channels and on their variation with forest type is lacking. Although the importance of root-derived inputs for sustaining soil food webs is increasingly recognized, the pathways by which they are channelled to higher trophic levels are little understood. For the channelling ectomycorrhizal fungi may play a significant role, but until now methods allowing to separate the contribution of ectomycorrhizal and saprotrophic fungi to the nutrition of soil animal communities are lacking. Using dual analysis of 15N and 13C in amino acids (AAs), we investigated trophic positions and basal resources of two major groups of soil microarthropods, Collembola and Oribatida, in beech and spruce forests in Germany.

title: 16S rRNA gene (V3 region) DNA-based analysis of bacterial soil communities at sequence variant level in 60 grassland EP plots, using QIIME2-based bioinformatics, 2011
abstract:
We determine the bacterial community composition in 60 EP plots from grasslands based on DNA extractions.
The purpose is to compare the DNA-based bacterial community composition data to the RNA-based bacterial community composition data.
DNA-based data typically reflect the entire community (including inactive, dormant and even dead cells, whereas RNA-based data (presence and amount of ribosomes in a cell can be taken as rough proxy for activity) typically reflect the active bacterial community.
From both types of nucleic acid we sequenced the V3 16S rRNA gene amplicons.
The corresponding RNA-based data are in BExIS ID 24866.

Here, the data are provided as quality-checked but non-rarefied read counts of distinct exact sequence variants (Callahan et al 2017). 
A bacterial sequence variant in this data set is defined by a specific nucleotide sequence of the V3 16S rRNA gene region of 165 base pair length. 
That means, bacterial sequence variants are distinguished at the level of single nucleotide differences.

Callahan BJ, McMurdie PJ, and Holmes SP (2017) Exact sequence variants should replace operational taxonomic units in marker-gene data analysis. ISMEJ, https://doi.org/10.1038/ismej.2017.119

title: Temporal variation of single Staphylinidae species on carrion at forest EPs 2014
abstract:
In the project “NecroPig” we are studying the influence of land use intensity on the decomposition rate of dead mammals. In terrestrial ecosystems, decomposition rate of animal biomass is heavily dependent on the availability of decomposers and detritivores and on abiotic factors of a certain habitat. Therefore, the aim of this project is to understand how the habitat structure and land use intensity influences the decomposition and removal rate of dead mammals in conjunction with the biodiversity of the associated arthropod fauna at spatial scales. 
Fieldwork was performed in August 2014. Seven inspections (days 2, 4, 6, 9, 16, 23, 30) were conducted after stillborn piglet cadaver exposition (day 0). Staphylinids were collected using pitfall traps opened for 48 hours before each inspection. On every inspection, pitfall traps were emptied. Specimens were preserved in 70 % ethanol and stored in urinary containers for later species determination and for counting of individuals.

title: Nematode abundance from 9 VIPs in HEG from Fieldexperiment
abstract: Soil Fauna inventory to understand soil fauna responses to artificial disturbance and resilience in dependence on land use.

title: Effective number of layers (ENL) - Dynamics - Forest EPs
abstract: Based on terrestrial laser scanning data (TLS), the index quantifies vertical stand structure by applying the inverse Simpson-Index to the vertical distribution of points in 3D space. Index values increase with increasing stand height and a more even occupation of 3D space by foliage, branches and stems along the vertical axis. Detailed information on index construction can be found in Ehbrecht, M., Schall, P., Juchheim, J., Ammer, C., & Seidel, D. (2016). Effective number of layers: A new measure for quantifying three-dimensional stand structure based on sampling with terrestrial LiDAR. Forest Ecology and Management, 380, 212-223.

title: Stand Structural Complexity Index (SSCI) - Dynamics - Forest EPs
abstract: The index quantifies stand structural complexity based on the fractal dimension of cross-sectional polygons. As the fractal dimension itself is scale-independent, the effective number of layers (dataset 19986), a measure of vertical structure, is used the scale fractal dimension values. Detailed information on index construction can be found in Ehbrecht et al. (2017), Quantifying stand structural complexity and its relationship with forest management, tree species diversity and microclimate, Agricultural & Forest Meteorology 242, 1–9. doi: 10.1016/j.agrformet.2017.04.012

title: Canopy openness - Dynamics - Forest EPs
abstract: The index quantifies canopy openness as percentage of sky pixels of a simulated hemisperical image for an opening angle of 60°. The simulated hemisperical image was computed based on terrestrial lidar data following the procedure proposed by Zheng, G., Moskal, L. M., & Kim, S. H. (2013). Retrieval of effective leaf area index in heterogeneous forests with terrestrial laser scanning. IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing, 51(2), 777-786.

title: Cover of all vascular plant species in representative 2x2 quadrats of the major surrounding homogeneous vegetation zones in a 75-m radius of the 150 grassland EPs, 2017-2018
abstract: To assess the surrounding plant diversity of each grassland plot, we surveyed the vegetation within the major surrounding homogeneous vegetation zones in a 75-m radius of each grassland EP in 2017 and 2018.

title: d13C and d15N stable isotope ratios in plant biomass at 73 grassland MIPs, 2018, SADE
abstract:
Ratios of stable carbon and nitrogen isotopes (d13C and d15N) in plant biomass are powerful integrators of ecological and biogechemical processes in grasslands. d13C, for example, can be used as an indicator of drought stress. To save water, palnts close their stomata and are forced to increase their uptake of heavier 13C isotopes. As a result, the d13C signal in plant biomass increases.
On the other hand, is closely related to plant and soil nitrogen cycling processes. Under a surplus of plant available nitrogen or relatively loose nitrogen cycles, the lighter 14N isotope is lost via denitrification or leaching. This results in a higher d15N reatio of the remaining nitrogen pools. 

Biodiversity ecosystem functioning theory predicts that plant diversity buffers drought effects and nitrogen losses by higher complementary resource use compared to less diverse communities. Empirical work on community biomass stable isotopes, also in the Biodiversity Exploratories, has shown reduced drought stress and tighter nitrogen cycles in diverse communities. 

In the Seed Addition and Disturbance Experiment, implemented in the Bioiversity Exploratories framework, we experimentally increased plant species richness via seeding.

title: Seed rain header data on 71 grassland MIPs captured with sand trays, 2018, SADE
abstract:
Seed rain, the seeds dispersed to a side, plays a key role in dispersal, plant population dynamics, and recovery after disturbances. 
To understand which factros determine the density and composition of seed rain, and how these relate to land-use intensity, therefore is key to understand plant population dynamics and to plan restoration interventions.

title: Seed rain species data on 71 grassland MIPs captured with sand trays, 2018, SADE
abstract:
Seed rain, the seeds dispersed to a side, plays a key role in dispersal, plant population dynamics, and recovery after disturbances. 
To understand which factros determine the density and composition of seed rain, and how these relate to land-use intensity, therefore is key to understand plant population dynamics and to plan restoration interventions.

title: Seed rain header data on 74 grassland EPs captured with sand trays, 2018, SADE
abstract:

To understand which factros determine the density and composition of seed rain, and how these relate to land-use intensity, therefore is key to understand plant population dynamics and to plan restoration interventions.

title: Seed rain species data on 74 grassland EPs captured with sand trays, 2018, SADE
abstract:
