To understand which factros determine the density and composition of seed rain, and how these relate to land-use intensity, therefore is key to understand plant population dynamics and to plan restoration interventions.

title: Vegetation Records 2020 for new grassland experiment REX and LUX
abstract:
This dataset is containing data of the REX and the LUX experiments in grassland

REX is the abbreviation for "Reduced Land-use Intensity Experiment"

LUX is the abbreviation for "Land-Use Experiment"

title: Plant and herbivore abundance from grassland and forests EPs along with trait and land use data, used in "Changes in plant–herbivore network structure and robustness along land-use intensity gradients in grasslands and forests"
abstract: To analyse the structure of interaction networks between insect herbivores and their food plants, abundance data of both plants and herbivores was combined with a literature-based interaction database. Abundance data was sampled on 150 grassland plots and 139 forest plots, both covering land-use intensity gradients within the respective ecosystem. Data on plant abundance was collected with yearly vegetation records on all plots (subplots in forests and grasslands), two tree inventories in forests and an inventory of tree regeneration in forests and aggregated to represent average plant-species specific cover and biomass. Data on insect abundance was collected with yearly sweep netting records on all grassland plots (twice a year) between 2008 and 2017 and with flight-interception traps on all forest plots in 2008, 2011, 2014 and aggregated to represent total species-specific abundance. Land-use intensity in grasslands was quantified with a compound index based on mowing, fertilization and grazing intensity (LUI index), which was recorded annually between 2006 and 2017. Land-use intensity in forests was quantified with a compound index based on tree species composition, harvest intensity and deadwood origin (ForMI index), which was determined based on two tree inventories (2008-2014; 2015-2018) and two deadwood and stump inventories (2012; 2017-2018). From plant and herbivore abundance and a literature-based interaction data base (BExIS ID 26926), weighted interaction networks were constructed for all plots. Relations among network structure and robustness were analyzed as well as change of networks along land-use intensity gradients.

title: Predation marks on dummy caterpillars measured on VIPs in 2020
abstract: In July and August 2020, we investigated predation on dummy caterpillars over 48 h in all three Exploratory regions. We investigated (i) whether plot-level process rates and their spatial variation differed between forests and semi-natural grasslands, (ii) whether process rates were correlated among each other across sites and (iii) whether the rates were affected by climate and land- use intensity at short and medium-term temporal scales.

title: Predation marks on dummy caterpillars measured in FOX in 2020 and 2024
abstract: In July and August 2020 (and again in 2024), we investigated predation on dummy caterpillars over 48 h in all three Exploratory regions. We investigated (i) whether plot-level process rates and their spatial variation differed among treatments of the FOX experiment, (ii) whether process rates were correlated among each other across sites and (iii) whether the rates were affected by climate and land- use intensity at short and medium-term temporal scales.

title: CRUSTFUNCTION organic matter composition and stability of crust, crust-adhering soil and crust free-soil determined by Py-FIMS (11 SEWs, 2014/2015)
abstract: This dataset gives information about organic matter composition and stability in the 3 compartments 'biological soil crust' ('BSC', 2 mm), 'crust-adhering soil' (2-5 mm) and 'crust-free soil' (5 mm) of selected SEW plots as determined by pyrolysis field ionization mass spectrometry (Py-FIMS).

title: Loss of wood mass for 3900 woodblocks from 13 different tree species decayed on Hainich, Swabian Alb & Schorfheide research plots of the BEshortDead - FunWood IV Project, 2017-2018.
abstract:
Analysis of the deadwood mass loss of fresh woodblocks from 8 deciduous and 4 conifer tree species (beech, oak, lime, mapel, poplar, cherry, ash, birch, hornbeam, douglas fir, pine, spruce, larch). The study sites were 50 forest research plots and 50 grassland research plots each located in Germany (Hainich, Swabian Alb and Schorfheide - overall 300 research plots). The woodblocks were exposed to the environment from 2017 until 2018 and the wood mass was weighed at the beginning and at the end. 
This project was part of the FunWood IV core project and funded by the German Research Foundation (DFG).

title: Vegetation Records for 151 Forest EPs, 2009 - 2020
abstract: To create a dataset of a large-scale long-term time series of vegetation composition we conduct an annual monitoring of plant diversity in an area of 20 m x 20 m in all 151 forest EPs.

title: Litter decomposition on 67 grassland MIPs measured with tea bags, 2017-2019, SADE
abstract:
Changes in litter decomposition due to soil perturbations can critically affect soil carbon cycling. Land use and litter quality are important drivers of litter decomposition, and plant diversity is assumed to affect both litter decomposition and the response of litter decomposition to soil perturbations. 
This dataset contains decomposition rates for high- and low-quality litter types of a seed addition and soil disturbance experiment, measured using two standardized tea types.

title: Data and Code for the manuscript Freitag et al. 'Restoration of plant diversity in permanent grassland by seeding: assessing the limiting factors along land-use gradients'
abstract: This is the data and code to reproduce the analysis of the manuscript Freitag et al. 'Restoration of plant diversity in permanent grassland by seeding: assessing the limiting factors along land-use gradients'. The data comes as a .zip folder of a RStudio project with data (in the data/ folder), R scripts and rmardown files (in the doc/ folder) to reproduce the analyses and manuscript. Code without data can also be found at https://github.com/martin-freitag/restoration-by-seeding/tree/v1.0.0.

title: The active deadwood microbiome from 8 plots in a Fagus sylvatica dominated forest site and 8 plots in a Picea abis dominated forest site in 2018 - Environmental Parameters
abstract: Deadwood decay is performed by manifold organisms at which fungal and bacterial community members are the main colonizers and active decomposers. In this study, we placed gamma sterilized beech and spruce sapwood specimen with the same dimensions and wood density on the forest ground of 8 beech and 8 spruce dominated forest sites. After 370 days of exposure, we incubated each deadwood specimen with Bromdeoxyuridine (BrdU) for 48 h to label the nucleic acids of proliferating microorganisms. Thereafter, wood blocks were used to calculate the mass loss, to estimate the absolute carbon (C) and nitrogen (N) and its respective isotopic signature as well as the enzyme activities of hydrolytic and lignin-modifying enzyme activities. Finally the nucleic acids were extracted, the BrdU enriched DNA was captured and these metabolic active fungal and bacterial community members were assessed by an amplicon sequencing approach. As result high enzyme activities and N enrichment were significantly correlated to mass loss. A very selected active fungal community mainly of saprotrophs colonized and were accompanied with a defined bacterial community that was capable for cellulose degradation, aromatic depolymerisation and N fixation (diazotrophs).Network analyses revealed that members of the diazotrophic genus Sphingomonas were co-present with the majority of saprotrophic fungi regardless whether beech or spruce deadwood was decayed. Taken together few fungal taxa were successfully able to colonize and decompose deadwood and were supported by a selected set of bacteria. For the first time, our study revealed taxonomic and functions of metabolically active wood-inhabiting bacteria and fungi, their cross-kingdom relationships and their interactions with environments.

title: LIDAR-based canopy cover above BELongDead subplots 2008-2009
abstract:
Canopy cover was assessed by airborne LiDAR surveying, which was conducted over the three study regions by Milan GmbH in 2008 (HAI) and 2009 (ALB, SCH) during leaf-on conditions. A Riegl LMS-Q560 full-wave form scanner (Riegl Laser Measurement Systems, GmbH, Horn, Austria) was operated at 240 kHz from 400-600 m above ground level with a beam divergence of 0.5 mrad. An average pulse density of 21.96 returns per m² was achieved across the study sites. The geo-located LiDAR point clouds were reprojected into the UTM 32N projection and classified into ground and vegetation returns using the LAStools suite of 
processing tools (rapidlasso GmbH). A high-resolution digital terrain model (DTM) was interpolated from the ground-classified points at 1 m spatial resolution using a triangulated network (TIN) approach. The DTM was used to normalize the LiDAR point clouds to height above ground level. Field subplot center locations were imported into the same projection system and buffered to create circular polygons with a 20 m radius. These polygons were used 
to clip and export the normalized LiDAR points falling inside each of the field subplots for further analysis. We computed the forest canopy cover of each subplot by extracting the proportion of first returns > 2m, >4m, >6m, >8m, >10m, >12m, >14m, >16m, >18m, >20m in height relative to the total number of first returns in each 
subplot.

title: The active deadwood microbiome from 8 plots in a Fagus sylvatica dominated forest site and 8 plots in a Picea abis dominated forest site in 2018 - Active Bacteria
abstract: Deadwood decay is performed by manifold organisms at which fungal and bacterial community members are the main colonizers and active decomposers. In this study, we placed gamma sterilized beech and spruce sapwood specimen with the same dimensions and wood density on the forest ground of 8 beech and 8 spruce dominated forest sites. Taken together few fungal taxa were successfully able to colonize and decompose deadwood and were supported by a selected set of bacteria. For the first time, our study revealed taxonomic and functions of metabolically active wood-inhabiting bacteria and fungi, their cross-kingdom relationships and their interactions with environments.

title: Leaf-endophytic assemblages and phytochemistry in transplanted beech trees, 2014
abstract: Fungal endophytes are an integral part of the leaf microbiome of forest trees. Most of these endophytes are horizontally transmitted, however little is known about their assembly drivers. Endophytic assemblages differ in composition according to geography and host individuals. In addition, climate and genetic diversity are also reported to lead to host plant adaptation. To determine the impact of the host progeny and respective adaptation to environmental conditions on endophytic assemblages, we designed a transplantation experiment in beech trees (Fagus sylvatica). Beech nuts were collected from distant geographical regions and germinated in a common greenhouse. One-year-old beech seedlings were transplanted to the different locations and the leaf-endophytic assemblages were characterized in second growth season after planting by cultivation-independent metabarcoding. Furthermore, the chlorophyll and flavonoid content of the leaves were measured. The results revealed host progeny effects in shaping leaf-endophytic fungal assemblages, that might be concealed by major geographical effects.

title: Qualitative Interviews 2019
abstract: This dataset contains all the transcripts of the qualitative interviews conducted as part of the SoCuDES project in spring 2019.

title: The active deadwood microbiome from 8 plots in a Fagus sylvatica dominated forest site and 8 plots in a Picea abis dominated forest site in 2018 - Active Fungi
abstract: Deadwood decay is performed by manifold organisms at which fungal and bacterial community members are the main colonizers and active decomposers. title: Arthropod mediated processes (dung and seed depletion) measured on VIPs in 2020
abstract: In July and August 2020, we investigated the dung depletion and seed removal after 48 h in all three Exploratory regions as arthropod mediated processes. We investigated (i) whether plot-level process rates and their spatial variation differed between forests and semi-natural grasslands, (ii) whether process rates were correlated among each other across sites and iii) whether the rates were affected by climate and land-use intensity at short and medium-term temporal scales.

title: Arthropod mediated processes (dung and seed depletion) measured in FOX in 2020 and 2024
abstract: In July and August 2020 (and again in 2024), we investigated the dung depletion and seed removal after 48 h in all three Exploratory regions. We investigated (i) whether plot-level process rates and their spatial variation differed among treatments of the FOX experiment, (ii) whether process rates were correlated among each other across sites and (iii) whether the rates were affected by climate and land- use intensity at short and medium-term temporal scales.

title: Vegetation records for 150 forest EPs 2019-2020, Header data without species identities
abstract: To create a dataset of a large-scale long-term time series of vegetation composition we conduct annual monitoring of plant species richness and community composition. Since 2008, we sampled each year all species in an area of 20 m x 20 m and estimated the percentage cover of each species. The monitoring is done each year twice, once in spring (April) to look at early plants and a second time in summer to do a complete vegetation survey. This area is not disturbed by other experiments and is called the core area ("Heilige Fläche (HF)" in German).

title: The active deadwood microbiome from 8 plots in a Fagus sylvatica dominated forest site and 8 plots in a Picea abis dominated forest site in 2018 - Raw Sequences
abstract: Deadwood decay is performed by manifold organisms at which fungal and bacterial community members are the main colonizers and active decomposers. In this study, we placed gamma sterilized beech and spruce sapwood specimen with the same dimensions and wood density on the forest ground of 8 beech and 8 spruce dominated forest sites. The forest type as well as the forest management intensity index were recorded and used for correlations. After 370 days of exposure, we incubated each deadwood specimen with Bromdeoxyuridine (BrdU) for 48 h to label the nucleic acids of proliferating microorganisms. Thereafter, wood blocks were used to calculate the mass loss, to estimate the absolute carbon (C) and nitrogen (N) and its respective isotopic signature as well as the enzyme activities of hydrolytic and lignin-modifying enzyme activities. Finally the nucleic acids were extracted, the BrdU enriched DNA was captured and these metabolic active fungal and bacterial community members were assessed by an amplicon sequencing approach. As result high enzyme activities and N enrichment were significantly correlated to mass loss. A very selected active fungal community mainly of saprotrophs colonized and were accompanied with a defined bacterial community that was capable for cellulose degradation, aromatic depolymerisation and N fixation (diazotrophs).Network analyses revealed that members of the diazotrophic genus Sphingomonas were co-present with the majority of saprotrophic fungi regardless whether beech or spruce deadwood was decayed. Taken together few fungal taxa were successfully able to colonize and decompose deadwood and were supported by a selected set of bacteria. For the first time, our study revealed taxonomic and functions of metabolically active wood-inhabiting bacteria and fungi, their cross-kingdom relationships and their interactions with environments.

title: Verrucomicrobia in EP soils, 2017, raw data
abstract: Verrucomicrobia affiliated with “Candidatus Udaeobacter” belong to the most abundant soil bacteria worldwide. Here, we utilized a recently designed primer pair, specifically targeting “Candidatus Udaeobacter”, to analyze its abundance and phylotype composition in EP plot soils. In this context, we generated partial 16S rRNA gene amplicons, which were subjected to high-throughput sequencing.

title: Vegetation Records 2020 for grassland experiment REX and LUX, Header data without species identity (incl. biomass)
abstract:
In order to better understand the effect of land-use intensity in grassland on biodiversity and ecosystem functioning, two new grassland experiments were created. 

This dataset is containing general data of the REX (Reduced Land-use Intensity experiment) and the LUX (Land-use experiment) surveys from 2020. These data are the date of survey, vegetation height, the cover of the 2x2 survey plot (shrubs, herbs, lichens, litter, deadwood, rocks, bare soil), vascular plant species richness, cumulative cover, and dry biomass. 

This dataset doesn't contain individual species identity and cover.

title: Flower metabolic fingerprints of Ranunculus acris and Trifolium pratense, several grassland EPs, 2017
abstract: Floral metabolic profiles are important drivers determining microbial colonization within this specific micro-habitat. On the other side, microbial symbionts of the anthosphere are known to modulate floral chemistry, which impacts host´s fitness or pollinator attraction.  Here, we analyzed metabolic fingerprints from floral organs (petals) of to plant species, which were extracted at the field site in the flowering season 2017. The collection and analysis of the chemical trait data was  was part of the project anthoDiv within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories.

title: Sentinel-2 satellite image time series for all Biodiversity Exploratories regions
abstract:
The Sentinel-2 satellite constellation collects optical images with a spatial resolution between 10 and 60 m. It consists of two satellites (S2A +S2B) which have a joined revisit time of five days. However, due to cloud and haze the frequency of useable images is lower. The dataset contains a level 3 time series with a regular interval of 14 days from 2017 to 2023. The time series was created from level-2 Sentinel-2 data which was processed using the FORCE processor V. 3.7.10.  For details please see Franz D. (2019). 
The data provided in this dataset covers the full extent of all three Exploratories.

title: EP Grassland Landuse Information ALB 2021
abstract:
Information about the land use on the EPs in 2021, based on information given by the farmers or on observations by members of the exploratories.
This file will be updated continuously.
It should be used only for fieldwork planning, NOT FOR ANALYSIS!.

title: Abundant of root-associated fungi from the organic layer and mineral soil across 150 forest experimental plots (soil sampling campaign, 2017) - OTU taxonomic look-up table
abstract: The objective was to investigate the root-associated fungal vertical assemblages patterns in organic layer and mineral topsoil in temperate forest

title: Abundant of root-associated fungi from organic layer and mineral soil across 150 forest experimental plots (soil sampling campaign, 2017)
abstract: The objective was to investigate the root-associated fungal vertical assemblages patterns in the organic layer and mineral topsoil in temperate forest.

title: Absolute abundances of soil nitrification genes in 25 ALB grassland SADE-EPs (2015-2017)
abstract: Within the framework of SADE experiment, abundances of nitrification genes in soil from 25 ALB grassland EPs collected during the soil sampling campaigns of 2015, 2016, 2017.

title: Deadwood data from 43 forest plots, 2012 and 2017, used in "Among stand heterogeneity is key for biodiversity in managed beech forests but does not question the value of unmanaged forests: Response to Bruun & Heilmann Clausen (2021)", JAPPL
abstract: This dataset summarizes the deadwood item volumes given in the publicly available BExIS-datasets ID 24546 (year 2012) and 24526 (year 2017) per research plot of even-aged, uneven-aged and unmanaged forests considering deadwood diameter classes. It was used to prepare Fig. 1 of "Schall et al. (2021) Among stand heterogeneity is key for biodiversity in managed beech forests but does not question the value of unmanaged forests: Response to Bruun & Heilmann Clausen (2021), JAPPL".

title: Tree related microhabitat data from 43 forest plots, 2017, used in "Among stand heterogeneity is key for biodiversity in managed beech forests but does not question the value of unmanaged forests: Response to Bruun & Heilmann Clausen (2021)", JAPPL
abstract: This dataset summarizes the tree related microhabitat abundance TreM given in the publicly available BExIS-dataset ID 23646 per research plot of even-aged, uneven-aged and unmanaged forests considering TreM types. It was used to prepare Fig. 2 of "Schall et al. (2021) Among stand heterogeneity is key for biodiversity in managed beech forests but does not question the value of unmanaged forests: Response to Bruun & Heilmann Clausen (2021), JAPPL".

title: Saproxylic beetles data from 43 forest plots, 2008, used in "Among stand heterogeneity is key for biodiversity in managed beech forests but does not question the value of unmanaged forests: Response to Bruun & Heilmann Clausen (2021)", JAPPL
abstract: This dataset summarizes the presence of deadwood saproxylic beetles given in the publicly available BExIS-dataset ID 16866 per research plot of even-aged, uneven-aged and unmanaged forests considering forest layers (i.e. ground, understorey, upper canopy). It was used to prepare Fig. 3 of "Schall et al. (2021) Among stand heterogeneity is key for biodiversity in managed beech forests but does not question the value of unmanaged forests: Response to Bruun & Heilmann Clausen (2021), JAPPL".

title: Producer, consumer and predator data from 43 forest plots, 2008/2009, used in "Among stand heterogeneity is key for biodiversity in managed beech forests but does not question the value of unmanaged forests (2021)", JAPPL
abstract: This dataset summarizes the presence of vascular plants and arthropods given in publicly available BExIS-datasets IDs 16866 (Coleoptera), 16867 (Hemiptera), 16868 (Araneae), 16869 (Neuroptera and others), 16887 (Opiliones and Pseudoscorpiones) and 23686 (Vascular plants) per research plot of even-aged, uneven-aged and unmanaged forests considering the trophic level in arthropods (i.e. herbivore or carnivore). It was used to prepare Fig. 4 of "Schall et al. (2021) Among stand heterogeneity is key for biodiversity in managed beech forests but does not question the value of unmanaged forests: Response to Bruun & Heilmann Clausen (2021), JAPPL".

title: Carbon dioxide and methane emission rates of 1300 woodblocks from 13 different tree species for grassland and forest EP (Schorfheide)
abstract:
Analysis of the deadwood carbon dioxide and methane emission rates from 8 deciduous and 4 conifer tree species (beech, oak, lime, maple, poplar, cherry, ash, birch, hornbeam, douglas fir, pine, spruce, larch). The study sites were 50 forest research plots and 50 grassland research plots each located in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin Exporatories). The woodblocks were exposed to the environment from 2017 until 2018, collected and transferred in 100 ml gas-tight glass vials. After 90 min incubation, 4 ml of the headspace were transferred to 3 ml vial and analyzed by using a gas chromatography. 
This project was part of the FunWood IV core project and funded by the German Research Foundation (DFG).

title: Plant trait measurements from the Swabian Alb research plots of the Exploratories project, 2020 used in: DarkDiv
abstract:
The DarkDiv cooperation project aims to contribute to the global DarkDivNet in assembling data on species pools around the globe with vegetation records and soil samples from the Exploratory region “Schwäbische Alb”. 
DarkDivNet is a global research network led by researchers from Tartu University (Estonia, https://www.botany.ut.ee/macroecology/en/darkdivnet) that aims to explore the dark diversity of plant communities—the set of species present in a region but absent in a site, albeit the site conditions are potentially suitable. The network seeks for the contribution of vegetation surveys paired with measurements of plant traits replicated on the global scale to advance dark diversity studies. This dataset comprises the data on plant traits of all species in all sampled plots (30 forest, 21 grassland EPs in the ALB exploratory).

title: Vegetation records from the Swabian Alb research plots of the Exploratories project, 2020 used in: DarkDiv
abstract:
The DarkDiv cooperation project aims to contribute to the global DarkDivNet in assembling data on species pools around the globe with vegetation records and soil samples from the Exploratory region “Schwäbische Alb”. 
DarkDivNet is a global research network led by researchers from Tartu University (Estonia, https://www.botany.ut.ee/macroecology/en/darkdivnet) that aims to explore the dark diversity of plant communities—the set of species present in a region but absent in a site, albeit the site conditions are potentially suitable. The network seeks for the contribution of vegetation surveys paired with measurements of plant traits replicated on the global scale to advance dark diversity studies. This dataset comprises the data on plant composition of all sampled plots (30 forest, 21 grassland EPs in the ALB exploratory).

title: Digital orthophotos (DOP-20) of all Biodiversity Exploratories regions
abstract: The Digital Orthophotos (DOP) provide georeferences aerial images of all Exploratories including the blue, green, and red channels. The spatial resolution is 20 cm with a positional accuracy of +/- 40cm.

title: The soil macrofauna grouplevel from 48 forest plots sampled in spring 2020
abstract: Soil animals are important drivers of decomposition processes, nutrient cycling and plant growth. Belowground food webs acquire a major fraction of their energy from detritus and therefore are viewed as decomposer or brown food webs. In forests most species either directly consume dead organic matter, in particular leaf litter, feed on microbial decomposers or prey on primary and secondary decomposer animals thereby forming part of the decomposer food web.

title: Land use in grasslands: raw data of yearly owner interviews on the new experimental grassland plots
abstract:
Within the Reduced land-use intensity experiment REX and the Land-use experiment LUX additional reduced land-use intensity plots (RP) and additional unfertilized plots (UP) were installed in the three exploratories.

The land-use treatments on the plots are adjusted according to the experimental design and documented in the attached dataset. RPs are mown only once a year and excluded from grazing and fertilization. UPs are treated similarly to the adjacent EP while only the fertilization is excluded. Several subplots exclude or include different land-use treatments in order to simulate different land-use types and intensities. 

The dataset will be complemented with the dataset "Land use in grasslands: raw data of singular plot treatment on the new experimental grassland plots" where only singular, non-repeated treatments are listed.

title: 1H-NMR spectroscopy of polar and apolar compounds from autumn leaves and 1-year-old litter, 2014
abstract: In forest ecosystems, decomposition is essential for carbon and nutrient cycling and therefore a key process for ecosystem functioning. During the complex decomposition process, litter chemistry, involved organisms and enzymatic activity change interdependently. However, chemical composition of the litter is the most complex and dynamic component in the decomposition process and therefore challenging to assess holistically. In this study, we aimed at characterizing chemical shifts during decomposition, and link them to changes to decomposer fungal activity. We characterized the chemical composition of freshly fallen autumn leaves of European beech (Fagus sylvatica) and the corresponding leaf litter after one year of decomposition by proton nuclear magnetic resonance (1H-NMR) spectroscopy at 14 forest plots across Germany. The composition and transcriptional activity of fungal communities was assessed by high-throughput Illumina sequencing in the same litter samples.

title: Aggregated environmental and land-use covariates of the 150 grassland EPs used in "Contrasting responses of above- and belowground diversity to multiple components of land-use intensity"
abstract: Aggregated environmental and land-use covariates of the 150 grassland EPs used in the analyses of the paper Le Provost et al. 2021, Nature Communications. "Contrasting responses of above- and belowground diversity to multiple components of land-use intensity". It contains data on environmental variables, plot-level (50 m × 50 m), field-level (75-m radius) and landscape-level (500-, 1000-, and 2000-m radii) factors.

title: Thermal (TIR) UAV images of several grassland plots HAI & ALB 2017-2019
abstract: We used Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) to capture high resolution remote sensing images of land surface temperature of vegetation & soil (LST) on selected grassland plots to analyze spatial heterogeneity. These images (raster-mosaics) are the basis for the creation of datasets of actual evapotranspiration (ETa) by energy-balance modelling.

title: Small mamal abundance HAI region 2017-2019
abstract:
Rodents are important reservoirs for zoonotic pathogens that cause severe diseases in humans. Recent investigations revealed that factors like land-use and small mammal biodiversity have the potential to mitigate the underlying transmission processes on various levels. Biodiversity is hypothesized to be more closely related to pathogen prevalence on the population level, through direct mitigation of transmission rates while certain landscape features might also promote or hinder transmission. Although these factors are crucial to estimate potential future changes in human infection risk, they remain poorly understood. In this contribution we present the first results of an ongoing large-scale field experiment.
In Central Germany small mammals were trapped and analysed for Leptospira, an ubiquitous bacterium, and Tula orthohantavirus prevalence in spring, summer and autumn 2017-2019. Trapping was conducted on woodlands and adjacent grassland that differed in the intensity of land use. Prevalences ranged between 0-58% for Tula orthohantavirus and Leptospira prevalences reached 41% in Microtus species in autumn. First analysis revealed a strong impact of small mammal biodiversity on the growth rates of the common vole (Microtus arvalis) population. 
This study will generate a better understanding of natural pathogen-host dynamics, allowing public health recommendations and policy advice according to predicted future biodiversity scenarios.
The data available are relative abundance indices of all trapped small mammals within the study period. The index is standardized as individuals per 100 trap nights.

title: Single species data of cadaver visiting flies at forest EPs 2014
abstract:
In the project “NecroPig” we are studying the influence of land use intensity on the decomposition rate of dead mammals. In terrestrial ecosystems, decomposition rate of animal biomass is heavily dependent on the availability of decomposers and detritivores and on abiotic factors of a certain habitat. Therefore, the aim of this project is to understand how the habitat structure and land use intensity influences the decomposition and removal rate of dead mammals in conjunction with the biodiversity of the associated arthropod fauna at spatial scales.
Fieldwork was performed in August 2014. Seven inspections (days 2, 4, 6, 9, 16, 23, 30) were conducted after stillborn piglet cadaver exposition (day 0). Insects were collected using pitfall traps opened for 48 hours before each inspection. On every inspection, pitfall traps were emptied. Specimens were preserved in 70 % ethanol and stored in urinary containers for later species determination and for counting of individuals. Flies of the families Calliphoridae, Sarcophagidae, Muscidae and Fanniidae were identified and are presented in this dataset.

title: Single compound data of cadaver emitted volatiles at forest EPs 2014
abstract: In the project “NecroPig” we are studying the influence of land use intensity on the decomposition rate of dead mammals. In terrestrial ecosystems, decomposition rate of animal biomass is heavily dependent on the availability of decomposers and detritivores and on abiotic factors of a certain habitat. Therefore, the aim of this project is to understand how the habitat structure and land use intensity influences the decomposition and removal rate of dead mammals in conjunction with the biodiversity of the associated arthropod fauna at spatial scales. Fieldwork was performed in August 2014. Seven inspections (days 2, 4, 6, 9, 16, 23, 30) were conducted after stillborn piglet cadaver exposition (day 0). Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) were sampled at each inpection and idientified using gas chromatography coupled with mass spectrometry.

title: Single sequence variants of cadaver-associated bacteria at forest EPs 2014
abstract: In the project “NecroPig” we are studying the influence of land use intensity on the decomposition rate of dead mammals. In terrestrial ecosystems, decomposition rate of animal biomass is heavily dependent on the availability of decomposers and detritivores and on abiotic factors of a certain habitat. Therefore, the aim of this project is to understand how the habitat structure and land use intensity influences the decomposition and removal rate of dead mammals in conjunction with the biodiversity of the associated arthropod and bacteria fauna at spatial scales. Fieldwork was performed in August 2014. Seven inspections (days 2, 4, 6, 9, 16, 23, 30) were conducted after stillborn piglet cadaver exposition (day 0). Bacteria samples were taken from the piglet snout mucosae and were characterized using Illumina next generation sequencing.

title: 60 Metatranscriptomes for two depths of SEG9 and SEG15
abstract:
We wanted to link the interactions of CH4-cycling microbiome to net greenhouse gas fluxes (CH4 and CO2). We prepared 60 metatranscriptomes from 2 depths (0-10 cm and 20-30 cm) across four seasons (sampling dates: 2017-11-09, 2018-03-08, 2018-05-30, 2018-10-13). 
The study sites are 50 by 50m sites in Schorfheide-Chorin, Germany.
The collection of soil samples and preparation of the metatranscriptomes was part of the project BE_CH4 within the ramework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Sampling protocol - soil sampling campaign 2021, all experimental plots (EPs), organic layer + 0-10 cm
abstract:
The core project Soil provides essential information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all 301 Experimental Plots (EPs) of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the three sampling protocols of the coordindated soil sampling for the EPs, the REX-LUX experiment, and the FOX experiment. Together with core projects 8, 1 and 2 (Microorganisms, BEO; LMTs), we organized the 4th coordinated soil sampling on all 300 Experimental Plots of the Exploratories in May 2021. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). At all plots composite samples from the mineral soil (0-10 cm depth) were sampled. At all forest plots additional samples from the organic layer were taken. Due to the Corona crisis, sampling had to be postponed for 1 year and was made up in spring 2021. We used the same sampling design as in 2011, 2014, 2017 to allow comparisons with previous soil samplings.
The soil sampling protocol considered the requirements of each of the 12 participating soil groups. Approximately 60 people from 4 core projects and 8 contributing projects were involved in the fieldwork.

The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-4, TR 1054/4-4, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Basic information of all forest experimental plots (FOX)
abstract: Major information of all forest experimental plots including coordinates, elevation and slope

title: Root dynamics in organic layer across 150 forest plots in Exploratories (soil sampling campaign, 2017)
abstract: The objective was to determine the main tree species and tree species richness at the plot level based on the abundance of the fine roots.

title: Root dynamics in mineral topsoil across 150 forest plots in Exploratories (soil sampling campaign, 2017)
abstract: The objective was to determine the main tree species and tree species richness at the plot level based on the abundance of the fine roots.

title: Cmic, Nmic, NH4+ and NO3- from SEG9 and SEG15 autumn 2017 - summer 2018
abstract:
We wanted to link net greenhousegasfluxes to dynamics of CH4-cycling community and soil properties.
The two study sites are 50 by 50m plots located in the Schorfheide-Chorin, Germany. The data were collected at four time points: 09.11.2017, 08.03.2018, 31.05.2018 and 13.09.2018.
We measured surface net gas fluxes with the closed-chamber method.
The data collection/analysis was part of the project BE_CH4 within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Fungal communities of BELongDead logs in 2012, 2015, 2017 (ITS amplicon sequencing)
abstract:
In late 2008 the BELongDead (Biodiversity Exploratories Long term Deadwood) experiment for investigating deadwood decomposition was established. Freshly cut logs of 13 temperate tree species [nine broadleaved species: Acer sp., Betula sp., Carpinus sp., Fagus sylvatica, Fraxinus excelsior, Populus spp., Prunus avium, Quercus spp. and Tilia spp., and four conifers: Larix decidua, Picea abies, Pinus sylvestris and Pseudotsuga menziesii were placed on the forest floor. 

In order to investigate fungal communities in relation to host tree and during the decomposition process, sampling from these 13 deadwood logs was performed on all so called BELongDead 'normal plots' in 2012, 2015 and 2017. After bark removal, samples were collected in the form of chips by driving an auger horizontally to the center of each of the selected logs. Fungal communities were analysed using DNA-amplicon sequencing of the ITS2 region.
 
Here, we provide the abundances of observed fungal ASVs (amplicon sequence variants). Data are not rarefied and need to be standardized according to the respective research question.

title: BELongDead fungi sporocarp inventory 2012-2018
abstract: The BELongDead experiment was conceived in 2008 under the direction of Prof. E. D. Schulze (MPI Biogeochemistry Jena) with the intention to monitor the impact of habitats on the dead wood decomposition processes and to observe colonization patterns of various saproxylic organisms over long time. Its central questions are I) how does the surrounding ecosystem influence wood decomposition, II) how does succession of the substrates proceed and III) how do microorganisms mediate wood decay and subsequently impact ecosystem processes like element turnover and storage. This enables us now to investigate the direct influence of different forest management regimes on a sizeable set of 12 (+1 less frequent) different dead wood tree species each homogenous in their initial wood properties (decay stage, volume, water content) and evenly distributed in replicates across plots, landscapes and management types.

title: Prokaryotic communities of BELongDead logs in 2012, 2015, 2017 (16S amplicon sequencing)
abstract:
In late 2008 the BELongDead (Biodiversity Exploratories Long term Deadwood) experiment for investigating deadwood decomposition was established. Freshly cut logs of 13 temperate tree species [nine broadleaved species: Acer sp., Betula sp., Carpinus sp., Fagus sylvatica, Fraxinus excelsior, Populus spp., Prunus avium, Quercus spp. and Tilia spp., and four conifers: Larix decidua, Picea abies, Pinus sylvestris and Pseudotsuga menziesii were placed on the forest floor. 

In order to investigate prokaryotic communities in relation to host tree and during the decomposition process, sampling from these 13 deadwood logs was performed on all so called BELongDead 'normal plots' in 2012, 2015 and 2017. After bark removal, samples were collected in the form of chips by driving an auger horizontally to the center of each of the selected logs. Prokaryotic communities were analysed using DNA-amplicon sequencing of the 16S region.
 
Here, we provide the abundances of observed prokaryotic ASVs (amplicon sequence variants). Data are not rarefied and need to be standardized according to the respective research question.

title: Results of the survey "Knowledge Transfer between the Biodiversity Exploratories and Forestry and Nature Conservation Practice" - Part one: scientists
abstract:
The overall goal of the KnowledgeTransferProject of the Biodiversity Exploratories (BE) is to foster the bilateral transfer of results, knowledge, and experiences between the BE and forestry and nature conservation practice, and thereby increasing the effectiveness of biodiversity research for biodiversity conservation.

Main objectives of the project:
* to assess and improve the transfer of knowledge between the Biodiversity Exploratories (BE) and the local stakeholders of forestry and nature conservation,
* to identify gaps in current data collection and analyses that preclude comprehensive answers to practice-relevant questions until now,
* to identify new and most urgent practice-relevant research questions.

Methodological approach:
* Anonymous questionnaire with closed respondent groups,
* Specific questionnaire for scientists and stakeholders,
* Online questionnaire via LimeSurvey,
* Duration: January to February 2018.

This dataset contains for example the anonymized scientist survey results, the questionnaire, and some statistics.

The data collection was part of the KnowledgeTransferProject within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Phospholipid Lipid Fatty Acids (PLFA), weighted δ13C, 27 grassland VIPs, May 2017
abstract: The dataset describes, weighted with abundances of individual signatures, δ13C values for the main microbial groups. These were assayed at the James Hutton Institute via a GC-C-IRMS approach.

title: Soil pH - soil sampling campaign 2021, all experimental plots (EPs), 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides essential information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the soil pH values in 0-10 cm depth from all Experimental Plots (EPs) in 2021. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil pH is considered a master variable in soil science as it affects many chemical processes in soils. Most importantly, the plant nutrient availability is greatly affected by the soil pH as it controlls the chemical forms of the different nutrients and influences the chemical reactions they undergo. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-4, TR 1054/4-4, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Gravimetric soil water content - Soil sampling campaign 2021, all experimental plots (EP), 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides essential information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all 301 experimental plots (EPs) of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the gravimetric soil water contents and dry matter contents in 0-10 cm depth from all EPs in 2021. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil water content has a dominant influence on plant growth, soil temperature, transport of chemical compounds, ground water recharge and soil aeration. The gravimetric soil water content is the mass of water in the soil, measured as the weight difference between the moist and the oven-dry soil. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-4, TR 1054/4-4, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Gravimetric soil water content - Soil sampling campaign 2011, all experimental plots (EP), 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides essential information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all 300 Experimental Plots (EPs) of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the gravimetric soil water contents and dry matter contents in 0-10 cm depth from all EPs in 2011. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil water content has a dominant influence on plant growth, soil temperature, transport of chemical compounds, ground water recharge and soil aeration. The gravimetric soil water content is the mass of water in the soil, measured as the weight difference between the moist and the oven-dry soil. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-1, TR 1054/4-1, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Ectomycorrhizal fungi species in Hainich-Dün and Schorfheide Chorin
abstract: The aim was to identify the ectomycorrhizal fungi species that are colonized in beech and pine roots. The sampling took place in spring, summer, and autumn from 17.04.2018 to 23.04.2019 in Hainich-Dün and Schorfheide Chorin.

title: Fine root tip dynamics of beech and pine trees in Hainich-Dün and Schorfheide Chorin
abstract: The aim was to perform the morphological assessment of the fine roots of beech and pine trees. The sampling took place in spring, summer, and autumn from 17.04.2018 to 23.04.2019 in Hainich-Dün and Schorfheide Chorin.

title: Ammonium and nitrate uptake by roots of young beech and pine trees in Hainich-Dün and Schorfheide Chorin
abstract: Stable isotope experiments were conducted to investigate the ammonium and nitrate uptake by roots of beech and pine trees from two Exploratories. The sampling took place in spring, summer and autumn from 17.04.2018 to 23.04.2019 in Hainich-Dün and Schorfheide Chorin.

title: BE fieldwork overview table 6th phase since 2020
abstract: During the year 2019 assembly, there was an increasing request for tables containing, who does what on which plots and when. These were set up then in the context of the discussion and group meetings to the various topics. For a better overview, we thought it would be helpful to compile these different tables into a uniform format and continue them in the future.

title: Ammonium and nitrate enrichment in ectomycorrhiza fungal species in Hainich-Dün and Schorfheide Chorin
abstract: Stable isotope experiment were performed to investigate the ammonium and nitrate enrichment in ectomycorrhiza fungal (EMF) species of beech and pine tree species. The sampling took place in spring, summer and autumn from 17.04.2018 to 23.04.2019 in Hainich-Dün and Schorfheide Chorin.

title: Meteorological data of several grassland plots HAI & ALB 2017-2019
abstract: Meteorological data (up- and downward radiation, wind speed, air temperature, humidity, air pressure) was acquired on selected grassland plots simultaneously to UAV flights (ID 31025) as a basis for the calculation of actual evapotranspiration (ETa) by energy-balance modelling.

title: Bacterial diversity indices based on 16S rRNA gene sequences (V4) of several trap-nesting solitary bee species in grassland VIPs, 2017/2018
abstract: Diversity indices based on bacteria related amplicon sequence variants (ASVs), as determined by high-throughput sequencing of the 16S rRNA gene V4 region and based on the RDP v16 reference database. We sampled from several trap-nesting solitary bee species in all three bioregions in 2017 & 2018 from March to October. We visited all 9 VIP plots, but were only able to sample on 24 plots, whenever we found closed reeds in trap nests. We sampled microbiomes of guts of bee larvae or pupae and pollen provisions. All samples were stored in DNA/RNA Shield (Zymo Research) with bashing beads in the field and stored at -20°C until further processing in the lab.

title: Ecosystem service values in simulated landscapes -  used in Neyret et al. 2021 (Assessing the impact of grassland management on landscape multifunctionality, Ecosystem Services)
abstract:
Land-use intensification has contrasting effects on different ecosystem services, often leading to land-use conflicts. While multiple studies have demonstrated how landscape-scale strategies can minimise the trade-off between agricultural production and biodiversity conservation, little is known about which land-use strategies maximise the landscape-level supply of multiple ecosystem services (landscape multifunctionality), a common goal of stakeholder communities. 

Results are made accessible through an online tool that provides information on which compositions best meet any combination of user-defined priorities (https://neyret.shinyapps.io/landscape_composition_for_multifunctionality/). The tool presented can aid informed decision-making by predicting the impact of future changes in landscape composition, and by allowing for the relative roles of stakeholder priorities and biophysical trade-offs to be understood by scientists and practitioners alike. 

********************

This dataset contains the landscape-level ecosystem service values from simulated landscapes. Original datasets are listed in the 'Read me' file. R scripts to reproduce the results of the paper from these landscape-level data (and to reproduce the simulations from raw data) are available on GitHub (https://github.com/mneyret/Neyret_et_al_2021_Ecosystem_Services,  https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.5521457).

title: Small mammal demographics and infection HAI 2017-2019
abstract: Rodents are important reservoirs for zoonotic pathogens that cause severe diseases in humans. Recent investigations revealed that factors like land-use and small mammal biodiversity have the potential to mitigate the underlying transmission processes on various levels. Biodiversity is hypothesized to be more closely related to pathogen prevalence on the population level, through direct mitigation of transmission rates while certain landscape features might also promote or hinder transmission. Although these factors are crucial to estimate potential future changes in human infection risk, they remain poorly understood. In Central Germany small mammals were trapped and analysed for Leptospira, an ubiquitous bacterium, and Tula orthohantavirus prevalence in spring, summer and autumn 2017-2019. Trapping was conducted on 21 sites (5 of them overlap with BE EPs)on woodlands and adjacent grassland that differed in the intensity of land use. The data available are relative individual demographic data on sex, weight, reproductive status as well as infection with the abovementioned pathogens.

title: Agricultural land use 2017 to 2019 in all Explo regions
abstract: Maps of the agricultural land use in the areas of the three exploratories. The maps contain the most dominant crop types, grassland and small woody features and were derived from different sources of satellite data and processed as a rasterlayer with a resolution of 10m x 10m for three consecutive years (2017-2019).

title: Mowing events 2017-2020 for all Explo regions
abstract: The dataset contains area-wide assessments of mowing events (date, frequency) for the areas of the three exploratories. Data were generated from dense time series of satellite data for four consecutive year (2017 to 2020).

title: Socio-cultural dynamics of Ecosystem Services - Survey results 2019
abstract: It includes the data collected on the relationship between ES prioritization by stakeholders and underlying cultural (e.g. cultural worldview, and related environmental nature and risk perceptions), socio-cultural (e.g. region, stakeholder group, political party preference) and socio-demographic factors. The survey was used in the publication "Cultural worldviews consistently explain bundles of ecosystem service prioritisation across rural Germany" (in press).

title: Predation marks on dummy caterpillars measured on VIPs in 2021
abstract:
In May 2021, we investigated predation on dummy caterpillars over 48 h in all three Exploratory regions. We investigated (i) whether plot-level process rates and their spatial variation differed between forests and semi-natural grasslands, (ii) whether process rates were correlated among each other across sites and (iii) whether the rates were affected by climate and land- use intensity at short and medium-term temporal scales.
The data contain the presence/absence of attack marks separated by arthropods, small mammals, birds and snails. As potential covariates, vegetation cover, vegetation height and canopy cover are given.

title: Predation marks on dummy caterpillars measured in grassland experiments (RPs and UPs, including corresponding EPs) in 2021 and 2023
abstract:
In May 2021 and again in May 2023, we investigated predation on dummy caterpillars over 48 h in all three Exploratory regions. We investigated (i) whether plot-level process rates and their spatial variation differed among treatments of the grasslands experiments (RPs and UPs), (ii) whether process rates were correlated among each other across sites and (iii) whether the rates were affected by climate and land- use intensity at short and medium-term temporal scales.
The data contain the presence/absence of attack marks separated by arthropods, small mammals, birds and snails. As potential covariates, vegetation cover, vegetation height and canopy cover are given.

title: Arthropod mediated processes (dung and seed depletion) measured on VIPs in 2021
abstract:
In May 2021, we investigated the dung depletion and seed removal after 48 h in all three Exploratory regions as arthropod mediated processes. We investigated (i) whether plot-level process rates and their spatial variation differed between forests and semi-natural grasslands, (ii) whether process rates were correlated among each other across sites and iii) whether the rates were affected by climate and land-use intensity at short and medium-term temporal scales.
The data contain the retrieval rates for seeds and dung. As potential covariates, vegetation cover, vegetation height and canopy cover are given.

title: Arthropod mediated processes (dung and seed depletion) measured in grassland experiments (RPs and UPs, including corresponding EPs) in 2021 and 2023
abstract:
In May 2021 and again in May 2023, we investigated the dung depletion and seed removal after 48 h in all three Exploratory regions. We investigated (i) whether plot-level process rates and their spatial variation differed among treatments of the grasslands experiments (RPs and UPs), (ii) whether process rates were correlated among each other across sites and (iii) whether the rates were affected by climate and land- use intensity at short and medium-term temporal scales.
The data contain the retrieval rates for seeds and dung. As potential covariates, vegetation cover, vegetation height and canopy cover are given.

title: Sweep net samples from grasslands in 2018: Araneae, Coleoptera, Hemiptera, Orthoptera
abstract: Arthropod diversity has been studied on all 150 grassland VIP plots since 2008 to provide data for various analysis, e.g. effects of land use on arthropods. This dataset is the 2018 data. The full time series from 2008-2017 can be found in dataset 21969.

title: Greenhouse gase fluxes (CH4, CO2, N2O) from SEG9 and SEG15 autumn 2017 - summer 2018
abstract:
We wanted to link net greenhousegasfluxes to dynamics of CH4-cycling community.
The two study sites are 50 by 50m plots located in the Schorfheide-Chorin, Germany. The data were collected at four time points: 09.11.2017, 08.03.2018, 31.05.2018 and 13.09.2018.
We measured surface net gas fluxes with the closed-chamber method.
The data collection/analysis was part of the project BE_CH4 within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Measure of plant spatial distribution: subplot species richness of 147 grassland EPs
abstract: The goal of this dataset is to measure the plant species homogeneity in grassland plots. We measured the species richness on two different plot sizes (0.2 x 0.2 m and 1 x 1 m) with replicates.

title: Measure of plant spatial distribution: subplots species richness of 150 forest EPs
abstract: The goal of this dataset is to measure the plant species heterogeneity in forest plots. We measured the species richness on two different plot sizes (4 x 4 m and 1 x 1 m) with replicates.

title: Body size and life-history traits of arthropod species
abstract:
This data set contains mean body size, feeding guild, stratum use and dispersal ability for all arthropod species identified in the standardized long-term monitoring data of the Arthropods Core project. Data can be matched (via species ID) to the monitoring data from grasslands and forests (including FOX) and allow a coarse functional classification of arthropod assemblages.

Data can be merged with the plot-specific species data given (for example) in the data sets 21969 (time series in grasslands, swep-netting) or 22007 and 22008 (time series in forest, flight interception traps), and also with the flight interception trap data from FOX (31245).

title: Beetles on different tree species, all forest VIPs, normal subplots, 2010 to 2017, BELongDead
abstract:
The BELongDead Experiment was initiated to study effects of tree species identity and forest stand attributes on saproxylic communities and wood decomposition. Freshly cut logs of 13 different tree species were placed on 29 forest plots in 2009/2010. Sampling started in 2010 and is still continued.

This is the full data containing all collected beetle species (including specimens only identified to genus). Data can be subset to saproxylic species (compare dataset 22726) with the information contained in the dataset.

title: Saproxylic beetles on different tree species, all forest VIPs, normal subplots, 2010 to 2017, BELongDead, logs with complete data
abstract:
The BELongDead Experiment was initiated to study effects of tree species identity and forest stand attributes on saproxylic communities and wood decomposition. Freshly cut logs of 13 different tree species were placed on 29 forest plots in 2009/2010. Sampling started in 2010 and is still continued.

This is the filtered data containing only collected saproxylic beetle species for logs that have complete data in all years and month (2010-2017). 

Full beetle data are available in dataset 31123. Compare also the now outdated dataset 22726 (2010-2015).

title: Draft genome sequence of Truncatella angustata (Anamorph) S358
abstract:
The ascomycete Truncatella angustata has a worldwide distribution. Commonly, it is associated with plants as an endophyte, pathogen or saprotroph. The genome assembly has a size of 44.9 Mbp, a G+C content of 49.2% and includes 12,353 predicted genes, among them 12 unspecific peroxygenases (EC 1.11.2.1).
This Whole Genome Shotgun project has been deposited at DDBJ/ENA/GenBank under the accession JAJJMK000000000. The version described in this paper is version JAJJMK010000000. The Sequence Read Archive (SRA) number is SRR16694223.
In the BLD-MFD-HZG projects, we identify the microbial community during decomposition processes, i.e. mainly fungi. For selected candidates of interest we provide the whole genome sequence, to find important enzyme involved during decomposition of lignocellulosic material. Albeit getting knowledge of the ecophysiology of this fungus, these resources are also important for metatranscriptomic and metaproteomic approaches.

title: Visitation records of bees in Germany (57 plots) and Belgium (9 plots) in 2020 and 2021
abstract:
Bees are one of the most relevant pollinators in grasslands, providing valuable pollination services for both crops and wild plants. Yet there is still much unknown regarding their nutritional needs as well as the effects that land use and flower availability can have in shaping flower visitation, particularly for wild bees other than honeybee. 
Over a two-year field campaign in German and Belgian grasslands, we recorded 5563 bee-flower interactions, from 162 bee species. We identified plant and bee species with identification keys in the field and barcoding in the lab and performed a plant diversity assessment when sampling. 
This project is part of a collaboration project with the Biodiversity Exploratories funded by Biodiversa EU and the DFG.

title: Soil conditions drive belowground trait space in temperate agricultural grasslands - Dataset
abstract:
1.	Plant belowground organs perform essential functions, including water and nutrient uptake, anchorage, vegetative reproduction and recruitment of mutualistic soil microbiota. Recently, multivariate analyses showed that root traits of species can largely be linked to a ‘conservation’ and a ‘collaboration’ gradient. Here, we tested whether this species-level bidimensional belowground trait space also exists at the community level in grasslands. Furthermore, we tested whether the position of grassland communities in belowground trait space relates to environmental variables.

2.	For a total of 313 species, we collected data on eight belowground traits in greenhouse and common garden experiments and supplemented it with data on bud-bank size and specific leaf area from databases. We calculated community weighted means (CWMs) of these ten traits for 150 temperate grassland plots to investigate belowground plant-trait dimensionality and its variation along ten soil and land-use parameters.

title: Size data of bumble bees at grassland EPs 2018
abstract: For preliminary experiments in the HealthyPollination project, we wanted to know how land-use intensity in grasslands affects bumblebee fitness. We sampled 307 individuals from 42 plots and used body size of bumble bees as a proxy for fitness, since it plays an important role in colony maintenance in bumble bees. We used wing length as a measure for body size, since both show a very strong correlation. Body size in bumblebees is related to foraging and can affect foraging distance or thermoregulation. Smaller individuals are known to have smaller foraging distances and forage at higher temperatures due to a worse thermoregulation.

title: Land use in grasslands: raw data of singular plot treatment on the new experimental grassland plots
abstract:
Within the Reduced land-use intensity experiment REX and the Land-use experiment LUX additional reduced land-use intensity plots (RP) and additional unfertilized plots (UP) were installed in the three exploratories.

In this Dataset only singular, non-repeated treatments are listed. Repeated treatments are listed in the dataset 31001
"Land use in grasslands: raw data of yearly owner interviews on the new experimental grassland plots"

title: Tick abundance Hainich Region 2020 - 2021
abstract:
Ticks are vectors for several potential zoonotic pathogens all over the world. With rodents as potential pathogen reservoirs, they contribute to multiple infection cycles affecting many vertebral species, especially humans. After vector and reservoir, another variable in the vector-borne disease ecology is the degradation of natural habitats and the intensity of human land use. 
As explained by the dilution hypothesis, a loss of biodiversity due to land-use changes contains the risk of losing species with a low potential of transmitting or amplifying the vector-borne pathogen in question. These so-called low competence hosts dilute the pathogen within the observed system. So, in theory, a change in the degree of anthropression of habitats with a subsequent loss of biodiversity may increase disease transmission.
Our part of this large-scale study investigates the prevalence of the pathogen Neoehrlichia mikurensis in ticks and rodents along a land-use gradient in the Hainich-Dün region. Ticks and rodents were gathered and PCR-screened for the pathogen above to show possible dilution or amplification effects along with this land-use grade. 
To investigate this issue, we selected 50 spots already established in the Biodiversity Exploratories framework, 25 plots of grass- and 25 plots of woodland with different intensities of anthropression. The sampling took place three times per year (2020–2021) to show seasonal changes in tick and rodent abundance and changes in the prevalence of the selected pathogens. In order to collect questing ticks, our study group used the flagging method covering 100 m2 of herb layer vegetation with a 1 m2 sized cotton flag. 
We hope that our study will provide more information about the connection between human-induced habitat changes and disease ecology. Furthermore, we hope to contribute information about the ecology of Neoehrlichia mikurensis and its highly assumed rodent reservoir.
This data set shows the ticks already gathered concerning the collection date, season, species, and location.

title: Single compound data of cuticular surface of bumble bees at grassland EPs 2018
abstract: For preliminary experiments in the HealthyPollination project, we wanted to know how land-use intensity in grasslands affects bumblebee fitness. We used chemical surface profiles as a proxy for fitness, since they play an important role in colony maintenance in bumble bees. Chemical communication is very important in bumblebees, because important behavioral patterns like mating, dominance and the fertility status of individuals are represented by their individual chemical profile. Changes in this profile can cause a disruption of the social structure in a colony and thus also affect colony maintenance. In total, we analysed 307 surface extracts of Bombus lapidarius worker from 42 different plots.

title: Forest properties aggregated to 10m cells for southern Hainich EPs, 2015
abstract: This dataset provides number of trees, basal area, crown projection area, volume, dbh and height aggregated to 10 m cells for middle and southern Hainich. It serves to provide BE date to the group of Markus Zehner, Jena.

title: Plant species diversity and habitat heterogeneity measures at grasslands of Hainich-Dün in 2017 - habitat data
abstract:
Land use changes are the main determinant of the current biodiversity crisis. The direct effects of land use on diversity, like a reduction in diversity with an increase in fertilization, are well known. However, the indirect effects of land use on diversity by shaping habitat heterogeneity are not yet clear, but are vital to obtain a comprehensive picture on impacts of land use changes.
It has been suggested that differences in diversity among differently managed grasslands could be mediated by small-scale habitat heterogeneity. This assumption was tested by assessing land use effects on α- and γ-diversity, as well as β-diversity across different scales.
I sampled the data at 20 grasslands with a clustered design distributed over 10 m by 10 m in Mai and June 2017 in Hainich-Dün, Germany (and in 2018 with the same design on the Swabian Alb, Germany, see dataset 31139). For each plot I had 25 sampling units in the size of 20 cm x 20 cm, on which I took plant species, and their cover, as well as biomass, percent of light availability at ground level, percent of vegetation cover and cover of dead material, soildepth (up to 45 cm), soil moisture, plant hight, and soil temperature difference between 5 cm and 15 cm depth, soil nutrients (Ca, Cu, Fe, K, Mn, P, Zn), and pH.
The data collection was part of the project HEDGE II within the framework of the DFG-founded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Plant species diversity and habitat heterogeneity measures at grasslands of Swabian Alb 2018 - habitat data
abstract:
Land use changes are the main determinant of the current biodiversity crisis. The direct effects of land use on diversity, like a reduction in diversity with an increase in fertilization, are well known. However, the indirect effects of land use on diversity by shaping habitat heterogeneity are not yet clear, but are vital to obtain a comprehensive picture on impacts of land use changes.
It has been suggested that differences in diversity among differently managed grasslands could be mediated by small-scale habitat heterogeneity. This assumption was tested by assessing land use effects on α- and γ-diversity, as well as β-diversity across different scales.
I sampled the data at 20 grasslands with a clustered design distributed over 10 m by 10 m in Mai and June 2018 on the Swabian Alb, Germany (and in 2017 with the same design in Hainich-Dün, Germany, see dataset 31138). For each plot I had 25 sampling units in the size of 20 cm x 20 cm, on which I took plant species, and their cover, as well as biomass, percent of light availability at ground level, percent of vegetation cover and cover of dead material, soildepth (up to 45 cm), soil moisture, plant hight, and soil temperature difference between 5 cm and 15 cm depth, soil nutrients (Ca, Cu, Fe, K, Mn, P, Zn), and pH.
The data collection was part of the project HEDGE II within the framework of the DFG-founded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Plant species diversity and habitat heterogeneity measures at grasslands of Hainich-Dün in 2017 - species data
abstract:
Land use changes are the main determinant of the current biodiversity crisis. The direct effects of land use on diversity, like a reduction in diversity with an increase in fertilization, are well known. However, the indirect effects of land use on diversity by shaping habitat heterogeneity are not yet clear, but are vital to obtain a comprehensive picture on impacts of land use changes.
It has been suggested that differences in diversity among differently managed grasslands could be mediated by small-scale habitat heterogeneity. This assumption was tested by assessing land use effects on α- and γ-diversity, as well as β-diversity across different scales.
I sampled the data at 20 grasslands with a clustered design distributed over 10 m by 10 m in Mai and June 2017 in Hainich-Dün, Germany (and in 2018 with the same design on the Swabian Alb, Germany, dataset 31140). For each plot I had 25 sampling units in the size of 20 cm x 20 cm, on which I took plant species abundance. 
The data collection was part of the project HEDGE II within the framework of the DFG-founded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Plant species diversity and habitat heterogeneity measures at grasslands of Swabian Alb 2018 - species data
abstract:

The data collection was part of the project HEDGE II within the framework of the DFG-founded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Hyperspectral reflection data for selected grassland EPs, 2020-2021
abstract:
Hyperspectral measurements were taken to predict forage quality (metabolizable energy), forage quantity, and biodiversity measures from hyperspectral reflection data above a grassland canopy.
We took data from all 3 Biodiversity Exploratory sites (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich, Schorfheide) in Germany. Data collection took place 4 times: in spring and autumn 2020 and spring and autumn 2021.  In total 40 sites (11 in Schwäbische Alb, 15 in Hainich, and 14 in Schorfheide) were visited in 2020 and 2021 at least once and a maximum of 4 times. 
At the 50 by 50m plots, the hyperspectral readings were taken at an edge of the plot, where ten 1 by 1m quadrates were located. The measurements contain the hyperspectral reflection of grassland canopy between 350 and 2485 nm at a spectral resolution of 3 nm in the visible and near-infrared (NIR) area and a resolution of 10 nm in the short-wave infrared (SWIR) area. 
The data collection was part of the project SeBAS within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Coordinates of all meteorological stations of all EP plots
abstract: The dataset provides the coordinates of the climate stations of the BE project. The coordinates were calculated automatically by the research area management module (plotcharts) of BExIS and are based on the coordinates of the plots (see dataset 20907) and the drawn subplots in the plotcharts. The polygon coordinates are provided as latitude and longitude coordinates in WGS84 spatial reference system. The data is provided in tabular format and as attachment in GEOJSON and Shapefile format.

title: Overview maps of all plots in the three regions of the Biodiversity Exploratories
abstract: The dataset contains maps for the three exploratory regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). For each region, overview maps are provided for all grassland and/or forest plots (including the joint multi-site experiment plots). The maps are available in color or black and white as *.pdf or *.png. The maps were created in 2021.

title: Morphometric Traits of Herbivorous and Saproxylic Beetles (Coleoptera)
abstract: Functional traits can be used to understand community assembly (response traits) as well as the relations between community composition and ecosystem functioning (effect traits). Morphometric traits, which are related to functions such as microhabitat use or dispersal, overcome some of the caveats of literature-based traits. Here, morphometric traits of specimens are assembled, which cover most herbivorous and/or saproxylic species that were collected in Biodiversity Exploratories grasslands (sweep netting) and forests (window traps, ground traps, deadwood eclectors of the BELongDead experiment).

title: DNA concentration of algal samples; selected plots Hainich-Dün; Oct 2020
abstract:
Tree bark provides a large variety of micro-niches constituting ideal habitats for microbial communities with different ecologies. We still have a very limited understanding of the diversity and biotic interactions that characterize the bark microbiome, as investigations have mainly focussed on agriculturally-relevant systems and on single components of these microbiomes. Here we implemented a multi-kingdom metabarcoding approach to analyse diversity and community structure of the algal, bacterial, and fungal components of the bark microbiome of beech, the most common broadleaved tree of Central European forests.

The 16 study sites are 20x20 m subplots of the EPs situated in the Hainich-Dün exploratory. Data was collected from the 13th to 15th of October 2020. 

The table contains the DNA concentration of the algal fraction of bark samples collected on selected plots in the Hainich-Dün exploratory in October 2020. The concentration and the information of the control samples is necessary for detection of potential contaminant ASVs with the decontam R package.

The data collection/analysis was part of the project SYMBIODRIVE within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de)

abstract:

This is a Sample x ASV table with read numbers obtained by Illumina MiSeq 2x300 bp after sample inference with DADA2, detection of potential contaminants with the decontam R package and curation of similar ASVs with LULU. 

The data collection/analysis was part of the project SYMBIODRIVE within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de)

title: Modules of algal ASV interaction networks; selected plots Hainich-Dün; Oct 2020
abstract:
Tree bark provides a large variety of micro-niches constituting ideal habitats for microbial communities with different ecologies. We still have a very limited understanding of the diversity and biotic interactions that characterize the bark microbiome, as investigations have mainly focussed on agriculturally-relevant systems and on single components of these microbiomes. Here we implemented a multi-kingdom metabarcoding approach to analyse diversity and community structure of the algal, bacterial, and fungal components of the bark microbiome of beech, the most common broadleaved tree of Central European forests. 

The 16 study sites are 20x20 m subplots of the EPs situated in the Hainich-Dün exploratory. data was collected from the 13th to 15th of October 2020. 

This is a table containing information on which ASV belongs to which module as derived from the interaction network in Gephi. It is necessary to extract taxonomic information of the modules members as seen in the analysis script at https://github.com/LukDrey/beech_micro_communities.

The data collection/analysis was part of the project SYMBIODRIVE within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de
