title: DBH and relative spatial orientation for selected trees, selected plots Hainich-Dün; Oct 2020
abstract:
Tree bark provides a large variety of micro-niches constituting ideal habitats for microbial communities with different ecologies. We still have a very limited understanding of the diversity and biotic interactions that characterize the bark microbiome, as investigations have mainly focussed on agriculturally-relevant systems and on single components of these microbiomes. Here we implemented a multi-kingdom metabarcoding approach to analyse diversity and community structure of the algal, bacterial, and fungal components of the bark microbiome of beech, the most common broadleaved tree of Central European forests.

The 16 study sites are 20x20 m subplots of the EPs situated in the Hainich-Dün exploratory. data was collected from the 13th to 15th of October 2020. 

This is the metadata table containing the spatial orientation of the trees to each other and within the plot, as well as measurements of diameter at breast height. 

The data collection/analysis was part of the project SYMBIODRIVE within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de)

title: Vegetation records for grassland SADE on 73 EPs, 2015 - 2019 and 2021
abstract:
A major challenge in ecological restoration is to effectively restore plant diversity in permanent grasslands. As species richness is often limited by seed dispersal, introducing locally absent species by seed addition is often crucial. We established a full-factorial experiment with high-diversity seeding and topsoil disturbance in 73 grasslands along land-use intensity and productivity gradients and evaluated the restoration success over 5 years (SADE is an abbreviation for "seed addition and disturbance experiment"). 
In May/June of the years 2015-2019 and 2021, we sampled in three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) all species in area of 2 m x 2 m and estimated the percentage cover of each species for each treatment separately. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Acari fertilizer experiment 2009 on 36 grassland EPs
abstract:
We applied experimental fertilization with an organic plant-sourced fertilizer on 12 grassland plots in each of the three regions of the DFG Biodiversity-Exploratories to study the immediate and long-term effects of fertilization on the taxonomic composition and feeding activity of soil mesofauna (Nematoda, Oribatida and Collembola). Sampling was conducted in spring and autumn 2009 on: Schwäbische Alb (AEG), Hainich-Dün (HEG) and Schorfheide-Chorin (SEG).
At each grassland site, two subplots with a size of 5 m × 5 m were established with a minimum distance from the grassland edge of 20 m and 2 m distance from each other. We randomly selected one subplot as control and the other as experimental fertilizer treatment subplot. The latter was fertilized with 2000 kg ha-1 of an organic plant-sourced commercial fertilizer (N = 6.67% (=133.4 kg N ha-1), P2O2 = 0.85%, K2O = 0.86%; AGROBIOSOL®, SW Düngesysteme, Wolfenbüttel, Germany) in spring and autumn 2009). The control subplots were not experimentally fertilized. In spring and autumn 2009 feeding activity of soil fauna was investigated by using a bait-lamina test.
The work has been funded by the DFG Priority Program 1374 "Biodiversity- Exploratories". Field work permits were issued by the responsible state environmental offices of Baden-Württemberg, Thüringen, and Brandenburg. Identification of oribatid mites and trait allocation was partially supported by RFBR project 18-29-25067.

title: Vegetation records 2020-2021 for new grassland experiment REX and LUX
abstract:
Land-use changes are major drivers of plant diversity in grasslands in all three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). However, how effective a reduction in land use intensity is in recovering plant diversity is unclear, and deliberate sowing of some plants may be necessary to restore grassland diversity. Furthermore, different components of land use, e.g. mowing, fertilizing, and grazing, are correlated with each other, and therefore assessing the effect of individual components of land use requires disentangling them experimentally.
In the new grassland experiments REX and LUX, we study the effect of reduced land use intensity and seed sowing on plant diversity. For this, we compare factorially combined plots with regular and reduced land use that were seeded or not-seeded with additional plants. Furthermore, we study the effect of individual components of land use. For this, we compare factorially combined plots with regular and reduced land use with or without fertilization.

Plant diversity is recorded on a 2 m x 2 m subplot by estimating the coverage of each species between May and early June in 2020 and 2021.
The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Vegetation records for 151 forest EPs, 2009 - 2021
abstract: Long-term monitoring of plants is an important element to assess the effect of forest management on the functioning of ecosystems. Plants and their diversity affect other trophic groups and the temporal stability of the plant community is an important indicator of ecosystem functioning. Therefore, we assess the diversity of vascular plants on 151 forest plots from three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) that differ in their management, ranging from unmanaged forests, to selection forests, where individual trees are felled individually, to age-class forest. For this, we estimate the abundance of each plant species on an area of 20 m x 20 m both in spring and in summer, separately in different layers (herb layer, shrub layer, tree layer < 10 m, and tree layer > 10 m and provide them in this dataset. From this data, we calculate plant diversity as well as trends and variability of individual plant species over time. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Collembola fertilizer experiment 2009 on 36 grassland plots
abstract:
We applied experimental fertilization with an organic plant-sourced fertilizer on 12 grassland plots in each of the three regions of the DFG Biodiversity-Exploratories to study the immediate and long-term effects of fertilization on the taxonomic composition and feeding activity of soil mesofauna (Nematoda, Oribatida and Collembola). Sampling was conducted in spring and autumn 2009 on: Schwäbische Alb (AEG), Hainich-Dün (HEG) and Schorfheide-Chorin (SEG).
At each grassland site, two subplots with a size of 5 m × 5 m were established with a minimum distance from the grassland edge of 20 m and 2 m distance from each other. We randomly selected one subplot as control and the other as experimental fertilizer treatment subplot. The latter was fertilized with 2000 kg ha-1 of an organic plant-sourced commercial fertilizer (N = 6.67% (=133.4 kg N ha-1), P2O2 = 0.85%, K2O = 0.86%; AGROBIOSOL®, SW Düngesysteme, Wolfenbüttel, Germany) in spring and autumn 2009). The control subplots were not experimentally fertilized. In spring and autumn 2009 feeding activity of soil fauna was investigated by using a bait-lamina test.
The work has been funded by the DFG Priority Program 1374 "Biodiversity- Exploratories". Field work permits were issued by the responsible state environmental offices of Baden-Württemberg, Thüringen, and Brandenburg. Identification of oribatid mites and trait allocation was partially supported by RFBR project 18-29-25067.

title: Vegetation records for grassland EPs, 2008 - 2021
abstract: Long-term monitoring of plants is an important element to assess the effect of land use in grasslands on the functioning of ecosystems. Plants and their diversity affect other trophic groups and the temporal stability of the plant community is an important indicator of ecosystem functioning. Therefore, we assess the diversity of vascular plants on 150 grassland plots in three German regions (Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) that differ in their management intensity. For this, we estimate the abundance of each plant species on an area of 4 m x 4 m in May/June from 2008 to 2021, which is given in this dataset. From this data, we calculate plant diversity as well as trends and variability of individual plant species over time. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Nematoda experiment 2009 on 36 grassland EPs
abstract:
We applied experimental fertilization with an organic plant-sourced fertilizer on 12 grassland plots in each of the three regions of the DFG Biodiversity-Exploratories to study the immediate and long-term effects of fertilization on the taxonomic composition and feeding activity of soil mesofauna (Nematoda, Oribatida and Collembola). Sampling was conducted in spring and autumn 2009 on: Schwäbische Alb (AEG), Hainich-Dün (HEG) and Schorfheide-Chorin (SEG).
At each grassland site, two subplots with a size of 5 m × 5 m were established with a minimum distance from the grassland edge of 20 m and 2 m distance from each other. We randomly selected one subplot as control and the other as experimental fertilizer treatment subplot. The latter was fertilized with 2000 kg ha-1 of an organic plant-sourced commercial fertilizer (N = 6.67% (=133.4 kg N ha-1), P2O2 = 0.85%, K2O = 0.86%; AGROBIOSOL®, SW Düngesysteme, Wolfenbüttel, Germany) in spring and autumn 2009). The control subplots were not experimentally fertilized. In spring and autumn 2009 feeding activity of soil fauna was investigated by using a bait-lamina test.
The work has been funded by the DFG Priority Program 1374 "Biodiversity- Exploratories". Field work permits were issued by the responsible state environmental offices of Baden-Württemberg, Thüringen, and Brandenburg. Identification of oribatid mites and trait allocation was partially supported by RFBR project 18-29-25067.

title: Vegetation records in the FOX-experiment in forests, 2020 - 2021
abstract: Open gaps in forest create important habitats for many forest species and offer opportunity for forest regeneration. However, in how far these gaps differ in their effect depending on the former forest management, remains unclear and is often tested in observational studies only. Moreover, the importance of deadwood, which may accumulate in such gaps, for the diversity of other taxa is poorly understood. Therefore, we established a factorially combined forest gap experiment called FOX  (forest gap experiment). On each of 29 forest forest experimental plot (EPs) (8 in the Schwäbische Alb, 9 in Hainich-Dün, 12 in Schorfheide-Chorin), four plots were created, two of which contained a gap of ca. 20 m diameter, in which all trees were felled, and two plots with non-felled forest. Into half of the plots, deadwood stems were added. Plant diversity was estimated on a subplot of 5 m x 5 m by estimating the abundance of each plant species, including the overhanging trees and shrubs and we provide them in this dataset. From this data, we calculate plant diversity and the changes in vegetation composition over time. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Suction sampling grasslands experiments (2021), pooled individual numbers
abstract: Arthropods are sensitive to land use. To test whether the reduction of land-use intensity influences arthropod abundances, a suction-sampler was used to quantitatively collect arthropods in the grassland experiments including the adjacent EPs (control). Per plot, arthropods were sucked out of two times 1 m². Specimens were separated from debris and counted. The dataset contains information on total arthropod individual numbers (excluding mites, springtails, ants) and associated vegetation parameters (cover and height).

title: Vegetation summary and biomass data for SADE experiment on 73 grassland EPs in 2021, without species identities
abstract:
A major challenge in ecological restoration is to effectively restore plant diversity in permanent grasslands. As species richness is often limited by seed dispersal, introducing locally absent species by seed addition is often crucial. We established a full-factorial experiment with high-diversity seeding and topsoil disturbance in 73 grasslands along land-use intensity and productivity gradients and evaluated the restoration success over 5 years (SADE is an abbreviation for "seed addition and disturbance experiment"). 
In May 2021, we did a vegetation survey in an area of 2 m x 2 m in all three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). This dataset contains data, like the date of survey, vegetation height, the cover of the 2 m x 2 m survey plot (shrubs, herbs, lichens, litter, deadwood, rocks, bare soil), vascular plant species richness, cumulative cover, and dry biomass. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Vegetation summary and biomass data for 150 grassland EPs in 2021 without species identities
abstract:
Long-term monitoring of plants is an important element to assess the effect of grassland land use on the functioning of ecosystems. Plants and their diversity affect other trophic groups and the temporal stability of the plant community is an important indicator of ecosystem functioning. Therefore, we assess the diversity of all vascular plants on all 150 grassland plots from the three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) that differ in land-use intensity, ranging from unfertilized pastures grazed once, to fertilized pastures and meadows grazed heavily or mown repeatedly. 

This dataset is containing general data on land use and vegetation from 2021. These data are the date of survey, vegetation height, the cover of the 4 m x 4 m survey plot (shrubs, herbs, lichens, litter, deadwood, rocks, bare soil), vascular plant species richness, cumulative cover, and dry biomass. 

This dataset doesn't contain individual species identity and cover.

The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Bait Lamina soil fauna feeding activity, fertilizer experiment 2009 on 36 grassland EPs
abstract:
We applied experimental fertilization with an organic plant-sourced fertilizer on 12 grassland plots in each of the three regions of the DFG Biodiversity-Exploratories to study the immediate and long-term effects of fertilization on the taxonomic composition and feeding activity of soil mesofauna (Nematoda, Oribatida and Collembola). Sampling was conducted in spring and autumn 2009 on: Schwäbische Alb (AEG), Hainich-Dün (HEG) and Schorfheide-Chorin (SEG).
At each grassland site, two subplots with a size of 5 m × 5 m were established with a minimum distance from the grassland edge of 20 m and 2 m distance from each other. We randomly selected one subplot as control and the other as experimental fertilizer treatment subplot. The latter was fertilized with 2000 kg ha-1 of an organic plant-sourced commercial fertilizer (N = 6.67% (=133.4 kg N ha-1), P2O2 = 0.85%, K2O = 0.86%; AGROBIOSOL®, SW Düngesysteme, Wolfenbüttel, Germany) in spring and autumn 2009). The control subplots were not experimentally fertilized. In spring and autumn 2009 feeding activity of soil fauna was investigated by using a bait-lamina test.
The work has been funded by the DFG Priority Program 1374 "Biodiversity- Exploratories". Field work permits were issued by the responsible state environmental offices of Baden-Württemberg, Thüringen, and Brandenburg. Identification of oribatid mites and trait allocation was partially supported by RFBR project 18-29-25067.

title: Arthropod (per year, 2008-2017) and environmental data (climate, land use, land cover) from grasslands used in "Unravelling insect declines: can space replace time?", Biology Letters
abstract: To compare trends in arthropod species numbers between space and time, arthropod data from the sweep net samples (2008-2017) in grasslands were used. We tested whether trends over time are also found within single years (i.e. in space). The dataset contains, pooled per sampling year, arthropod individual numbers (Araneae, Coleoptera, Hemiptera, Orthoptera) and associated environmental data (climate, land use, land cover). This data is only to complement the publication "Unravelling insect declines: can space replace time?" by Blüthgen et al. in Biology Letters. Data are a combination of the yearly grassland arthropod data in dataset 25786, the LUI input data in dataset 25086, climate data (19007), and land cover data (26007).

title: Taxonomy table of algal ASVs from bark samples; selected plots Hainich-Dün; Oct 2020
abstract:
Tree bark provides a large variety of micro-niches constituting ideal habitats for microbial communities with different ecologies. We still have a very limited understanding of the diversity and biotic interactions that characterize the bark microbiome, as investigations have mainly focussed on agriculturally-relevant systems and on single components of these microbiomes. Here we implemented a multi-kingdom metabarcoding approach to analyse diversity and community structure of the algal, bacterial, and fungal components of the bark microbiome of beech, the most common broadleaved tree of Central European forests.

The 16 study sites are 20x20 m subplots of the EPs situated in the Hainich-Dün exploratory. Data was collected from the 13th to 15th of October 2020. 

This is a taxonomy table of algal ASVs obtained by Illumina MiSeq 2x300 bp after sample inference with DADA2, detection of potential contaminants with the decontam R package and curation of similar ASVs with LULU. 

The data collection/analysis was part of the project SYMBIODRIVE within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de)

title: Taxonomy table of bacterial ASVs from bark samples; selected plots Hainich-Dün; Oct 2020
abstract:
Tree bark provides a large variety of micro-niches constituting ideal habitats for microbial communities with different ecologies. We still have a very limited understanding of the diversity and biotic interactions that characterize the bark microbiome, as investigations have mainly focussed on agriculturally-relevant systems and on single components of these microbiomes. Here we implemented a multi-kingdom metabarcoding approach to analyse diversity and community structure of the algal, bacterial, and fungal components of the bark microbiome of beech, the most common broadleaved tree of Central European forests.

The 16 study sites are 20x20 m subplots of the EPs situated in the Hainich-Dün exploratory. Data was collected from the 13th to 15th of October 2020. 

This is a taxonomy table of bacterial ASVs obtained by Illumina MiSeq 2x300 bp after sample inference with DADA2, detection of potential contaminants with the decontam R package and curation of similar ASVs with LULU. 

The data collection/analysis was part of the project SYMBIODRIVE within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de)

abstract:
Tree bark provides a large variety of micro-niches constituting ideal habitats for microbial communities with different ecologies. We still have a very limited understanding of the diversity and biotic interactions that characterize the bark microbiome, as investigations have mainly focussed on agriculturally-relevant systems and on single components of these microbiomes. Here we implemented a multi-kingdom metabarcoding approach to analyse diversity and community structure of the algal, bacterial, and fungal components of the bark microbiome of beech, the most common broadleaved tree of Central European forests.

The 16 study sites are 20x20 m subplots of the EPs situated in the Hainich-Dün exploratory. data was collected from the 13th to 15th of October 2020. 

This is a taxonomy table of fungal ASVs obtained by Illumina MiSeq 2x300 bp after sample inference with DADA2, detection of potential contaminants with the decontam R package and curation of similar ASVs with LULU.

title: Vegetation summary in 2021 without species identities for the new grassland experiment REX and LUX on 45 Grassland EPs
abstract:
Land-use changes are major drivers of plant diversity in grasslands in three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). However, how effective a reduction in land use intensity is in recovering plant diversity is unclear, and deliberate sowing of some plants may be necessary to restore grassland diversity. Furthermore, different components of land use, e.g. mowing, fertilizing and grazing, are correlated with each other, and therefore assessing the effect of individual components of land use requires disentangling them experimentally. I the new grassland experiments REX and LUX, we study the effect of reduced land use intensity and seed sowing on plant diversity. For this, we compare factorially combined plots with regular and reduced land use that were seeded or not-seeded with additional plants. Furthermore, we study the effect of individual components of land use. For this, we compare factorially combined plots with regular and reduced land use with or without fertilization.

This dataset is containing general data of the REX (Reduced Land-use Intensity experiment) and the LUX (Land-use experiment) surveys from 2021. These data are the date of survey, vegetation height, the cover of the 2 m x 2 m survey plot (shrubs, herbs, lichens, litter, deadwood, rocks, bare soil), vascular plant species richness, cumulative cover, and dry biomass. 

This dataset doesn't contain individual species identity and cover.

The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Intraspecific morphological traits in Geotrupidae (specimens sampled on several EPs in all three regions in 2014)
abstract: We investigated intraspecfic morphological trait variation in large dung beetle species from a species collection stored at the University of Darmstadt. Species were formerly collected in the field for the study of Frank et. al (2018). Specimens were collected in forest and grassland sites across all three regions in spring and summer 2014 and 2015. We measured five morphological traits (body length, pronotum length, elytra length, elytra width and hindfemur length) in Trypocopris vernalis, Anoplotrupes stercorosus and Typhaeus typhoeus.

title: Vegetation records in grassland plotwise sorted over 2008 - 2021 from all regions, biomass included. Document is compiled for farmers and stakeholders (in German)
abstract: To provide long-term trends of plant species on each of the 150 grassland plots from 2008 to 2021, we compiled data of plant cover, cover of functional groups, species richness, and biomass (from data sets 31180 & 31175). In addition, the data set indicates which plant species are regional characteristic species (Kennarten). This dataset is compiled for farmers and stakeholders and provided in three Excel files, one for each region. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Vegetation records in forest plotwise sorted over 2009 - 2021 from all regions. Document is compiled for foresters and stakeholders (in German)
abstract: To provide long-term trends of plant species on each of the 151 forest plots from 2009 to 2021, we compiled data of plant cover, cover of functional groups and species richness (from data sets 31173 & 31249). This dataset is compiled for foresters and stakeholders and provided in three Excel files, one for each region. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Intraspecific morphological traits in small dung beetles (specimens sampled on several EPs in all three regions in 2014 and 2015)
abstract: We investigated intraspecfic morphological trait variation in small dung beetle species from a species collection stored at the University of Darmstadt. Species were formerly collected in the field for the study of Frank et. al (2018) .We measured the abdomen and pronotum length, the femur and tibia length on the hind and midleg and the femur width on the hind and midleg in Aphodius ater, Aphodius depressus, Onthophagus fracticornis and Onthophagus similis.

title: Time series of biocrust chlorophyll-a content in Schorfheide FOX experiments suplots, 2020 to 2021
abstract: Chlorophyll-a is a proxy for the phototrophic biomass in soils. Biocrusts are communities of soil microorganisms that inhabit bare soils as the pioneer vegetation where vascular plants are not present (due to climate or disturbance). Therefore, a focus was laid on the forest experiments (FOX), which consist of 3 new subplots: 2 with clear-cut gaps and one intact in close proximity to the respective EP. In 2020, the Schorfheide FOX-plots were visited and biocrusts found and sampled monthly from May to October. In 2021, the same biocrusts (where possible) were sampled again in April, July and September. The chlorophyll-a content was measured per area. The analysis is part of the project CRUSTFUNCTION 3.

title: Intraspecific morphological traits in bee species (specimens sampled on several EPs in all three regions in 2008 and 2012)
abstract: We investigated intraspecfic morphological trait variation in bee species from a species collection stored at the University of Darmstadt. Species were formerly collected in the field for the study of Weiner et al. (2014).Morphological traits in Bombus lapidarius, Bombus sylvarum, and Lasioglossus calceatum were measured with a caliper on both sides of the individual if applicable: intersegmental width, wing length, wing width, hindfemur length, forefemur length, eye length and eye width.

title: Biocrust and bare soil cover estimation of all forest EPs, 2020 to 2021
abstract: Biocrusts are communities of soil microorganisms that are driven by their photosynthetic components (micro-algae, mosses, lichens) and are the pioneer vegetation on bare soils where vascular are not present (due to climate or disturbance). Therefore, a focus was laid on the forest experiments (FOX), which created a major disturbance with 2 clear-cut subplots in proximity to the original EPs. Due to Corona-restrictions in 2020, only Schorfheide FOX-plots could be visited and were visited monthly from April to October. In 2021, coverages were investigated in Schorfheide, Hainich and Alb FOX plots in April, and in Schorfheide and Alb in July and September. The coverages of biocrusts and non-vegetated soil were estimated as percent. The analysis is part of the project CRUSTFUNCTION 3.

title: Intraspecific morphological traits in grasshoppers (specimens sampled on several EPs in Hainich Dün and the Swabian Alb in 2014)
abstract: We investigated intraspecfic morphological trait variation in grasshopper species from a species collection stored at the University of Darmstadt. Species were formerly collected in the field for the study of Chisté et al. (2016) in 2014. Morphological traits of Chorthippus biguttulus, Chorthippus paralellus, Merioptera roeselii, and Stenobothrus lineatus were measured using a digital caliper by Pollin Electronic: pronotum length, pronotum width, hindfemur length and forewing length. All traits were measured twice per individual and on both sides of the body if applicable.

title: Vegetation records for all grassland EPs and new Experiments (REX, LUX), 2020-2021
abstract:
In each region (Alb, Hainich and Schorfheide), we aimed to study the reciprocal relationships between plant species richness and biomass production in an observational setting, and an experimental setting (within managed grasslands). 
Specifically, we aim to investigate how experimental reductions in land-use intensity as well as increases in the variation in plant species pool affect the relationship between species richness and biomass produced. Furthermore, we aim to study how different land-use components (fertilization, mowing and grazing) affect species richness. Finally, we plan to assess the relative strength of both PRR (productivity richness relationships) and BEF (biodiversity ecosystem functioning) relationships in managed grasslands.

In order to do so, we performed vegetation records in all grassland EPs and in the new experiments (LUX: UP_C, RP_F; REXI: RP_C, RP_SN; REXII: RP_SC), in the spring and summer season (April to May and July to August respectively) in 2020 and 2021. In each plot (7 x 7 m) we were assigned to a 1 x 1 m subplot, in which we estimated total vegetation cover (in percent) as well as vascular plant species specific cover. The data collection was part of the project BEF-Loops within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Biomass and environmental variables measured in all grassland EPs and new experiments (REX, LUX), 2020-2021
abstract:
In each region (Alb, Hainich and Schorfheide), we aimed to study the reciprocal relationships between plant species richness and biomass production in an observational setting, and an experimental setting (within managed grasslands). 
Specifically, we aim to investigate how experimental reductions in land-use intensity as well as increases in the variation in plant species pool affect the relationship between species richness and biomass produced. Furthermore, we aim to study how different land-use components (fertilization, mowing and grazing) affect species richness. Finally, we plan to assess the relative strength of both PRR (productivity richness relationships) and BEF (biodiversity ecosystem functioning) relationships in managed grasslands.

In order to do so, we non-destructively measured standing biomass and additional environmental variables (soil moisture, light availability) in all grassland EPs and in the new experiments (LUX: UP_C, RP_F; REXI: RP_C, RP_SN; REXII: RP_SC), in the spring and summer season (April to May and July to August respectively) in 2020 and 2021. All measurements were performed in an 1 x 1 m subplot. The data collection was part of the project BEF-Loops within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Phytometric assay to assess soil fertility in all grassland EPs and new experiments (REX, LUX) performed on soil samples collected in Spring 2021
abstract:
In each region (Alb, Hainich and Schorfheide), we aimed to study the reciprocal relationships between plant species richness and biomass production in an observational setting, and an experimental setting (within managed grasslands). 
Specifically, we aim to investigate how experimental reductions in land-use intensity as well as increases in the variation in plant species pool affect the relationship between species richness and biomass produced. Furthermore, we aim to study how different land-use components (fertilization, mowing and grazing) affect species richness. Finally, we plan to assess the relative strength of both PRR (productivity richness relationships) and BEF (biodiversity ecosystem functioning) relationships in managed grasslands.

We were further interested in how soil fertility mediates the relationship between species richness and biomass produced. Thus, we assessed aboveground potential productivity using a phytometer experiment. In order to do so, we performed a Phytometric Assay with Taraxacum officinale grown in a greenhouse on soil cores extracted from each subplot. After a month all aboveground biomass was harvested, dried and weighted. These abovground biomass values were then used as a proxy for soil fertility.

The data collection was part of the project BEF-Loops within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Assembled RAW diversity from forest EPs (2007-2020) for multidiversity synthesis -  January 2022
abstract:
A truly general understanding of ecological systems requires a broad perspective and thus the synthesis of knowledge across taxa, ecological processes, as well as spatial and temporal scales. This multi-disciplinary approach to ecosystems is at the very core of the Biodiversity Exploratories.

The aim of the synthesis core project is to ensure that these ecological syntheses are realised. This dataset provides occurrence information in forests at the species level for a maximum number of taxonomic groups at the Experimental Plot (EP) level (i.e. all 150 plots) in the three regions of the Exploratories.

To build this dataset we scanned in BExIS all datasets with information at the EP level and completed the search with discussions within the Biodiversity Exploratories. After discussions with each dataset owner, we then homogenised the datasets (which have all different data structures). We harmonised taxonomic names when needed. If necessary, values in subplots were averaged in order to obtain one unique value per species, plot and year. The full process is documented with R scripts (https://github.com/biodiversity-exploratories-synthesis/Synthesis_dataset_diversity_forest).

The final dataset contains species occurrences for each plot and year. Depending on the taxonomic group, values (in the column "value") correspond to abundance, presence-absence, numbers of OTUs/ASVs or cover. This information is provided in the column "type".

The dataset covers the period from 2007 to 2020 with some taxa covering the whole period (plants) or unique years (e.g. snails) or several non-consecutive years (e.g. bacteria, soil fungi). Not that not all taxa have information on all 150 plots.

This dataset is connected to dataset 31207 (taxonomic, trophic and functional information) by the "Species" column.

We also provide an R script (ID 22046) to help merging this dataset with dataset 31207 (species information) and calculate various metrics (richness, abundance, diversity and multidiversity).

The data collection/analysis was part of the project Synthesis within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de)

title: Assembled species information from forest EPs (2007-2020) for multidiversity synthesis - January 2022
abstract:
A truly general understanding of ecological systems requires a broad perspective and thus the synthesis of knowledge across taxa, ecological processes, as well as spatial and temporal scales. This multi-disciplinary approach to ecosystems is at the very core of the Biodiversity Exploratories.

The aim of the synthesis core project is to ensure that these ecological syntheses are realised. This dataset is complementary to a dataset on species occurrence (31206) in forests for a maximum number of taxonomic groups at the Experimental Plot (EP) level (i.e. all 150 plots) in the three regions of the Exploratories.

To build this dataset we scanned in BExIS all datasets with information at the EP level and completed the search with discussions within the Biodiversity Exploratories. After discussions with each dataset owner, we harmonised taxonomic names when needed. Using information provided by experts and data collectors in the Exploratories, we assigned each species (or OTU/ASV) to a trophic level, functional group and broad taxonomic group.The full process is documented with R scripts (https://github.com/biodiversity-exploratories-synthesis/Synthesis_dataset_diversity_forest).

The final dataset contains taxonomic classification, trophic level and functional role of each species in the grassland EPs. The information is given at a broad and a finer scale.

The dataset covers the period from 2007 to 2020 with some taxa covering the whole period (plants) or unique years (e.g. snails) or several non-consecutive years (e.g. bacteria, soil fungi). Note that not all taxa have information on all 150 plots.

This dataset is connected to dataset 31206 (species occurrences) by the "Species" column.

We also provide an R script (ID 22046) to help merging this dataset with dataset 31207 (species information) and calculate various metrics (richness, abundance, diversity and multidiversity).

The data collection/analysis was part of the project Synthesis within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de)

title: MinSoil 2021 Soil Sampling
abstract: The core project ‘Soils' provides essential information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all 300 Experimental Plots (EPs) of the Biodiversity Exploratories. Together with core projects 8, 1 and 2 (Microorganisms, BEO; LMTs), we organized the 4th coordinated soil sampling on all 300 Experimental Plots of the Exploratories in May 2021. The field data of the coordinated soil sampling are stored in this dataset.

title: List of biotic interactions between pairs of species in Biodiversity Exploratories
Soil carbon and nitrogen concentrations - soil sampling campaign 2021, all experimental plots (EPs), 0-10 cm
abstract:
The core project Soil provides essential information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all 301 Experimental Plots (EPs) of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the organic carbon (OC), inorganic carbon (IC) and nitrogen (TN) concentrations and carbon to nitrogen ratios (CN ratio) in 0-10 cm depth from all EPs in 2021. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil organic carbon and nitrogen concentrations are master variables in soil science. Soil organic carbon and nitrogen are the measureable components of soil organic matter (SOM). SOM exerts positive effects on numerous physical, chemical and biological soil properties. An increase in SOM generally results in an improved soil structure, soil moisture retention, soil buffering capacity, retention of pollutants, cycling and storage of plant nutrients and biodiversity. SOM also acts as a sink and source for atmospheric carbon dioxide.

The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-4, TR 1054/4-4, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Predicted plant species richness in grasslands 2017-2021
abstract: Spatially explicit information of biodiversity is necessary to achieve a mechanistic understanding of the interactions between land use and ecosystem services across environmental gradients. To that end, we have produced this georeferenced spatial dataset that represents species richness in all grasslands of the three Exploratories for 2017-2021 at 10 m resolution. It covers thus not only the grassland plots, but also all surrounding grasslands. Units in the raster file are number of species per 4x4 m. Created by the project SeBAS, grant code DU 632 1596/1-1.

title: Biomass, species richness and environmental data from all three regions of the Exploratories project, 2020-2021, used in: "Relationships between species richness and biomass production are context dependent in managed grasslands"
abstract:
In each region (Alb, Hainich and Schorfheide), we studied the effect of plant species richness on biomass production in an observational setting (within managed grasslands), by reducing land-use, as well as by manipulating species richness via seed addition of new species. Specifically, we aimed to distinguish between relationships of species richness and biomass production i) across grasslands varying in land-use intensity, ii) in settings where land-use intensity is experimentally reduced, and iii) in the latter settings, in which additionally, the variation in plant species pool size is experimentally enlarged through seed additions. In order to do so, we performed vegetation records and estimated standing biomass using a rising plate-meter in all grassland EPs and in the new experiments (REX: RP_C, RP_SN, RP_SC), in the spring and summer season (April to May and July to August respectively) in 2020 and 2021. In each plot (7 x 7 m) we were assigned to a 1 x 1 m subplot, in which we estimated the species specific cover of each plant species (in percent). Furthermore, we measured standing biomass using a rising plate meter with 4 replicates per subplot. The data collection was part of the project BEF-Loops within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

Important note!
This data set is a processed version for the paper "Relationships between species richness and biomass production are context dependent in managed grasslands (Andraczek et al.)". This data derived from other raw data sets (ID 31203, ID 31204 and ID 31205).

title: Planet satellite image time series
abstract:
The Planet satellite system collects satellite images with a spatial resolution of 3m. It consists of a large fleet of similar satellites and sensors and has thus a high temporal resolution which provides multiple coverages within one vegetation period. More Information on the image products is available on the Planet website: https://www.planet.com/

Satellite data was acquired for the years 2020 and 2021 for all three Exploratories. The data is provided as analytic surface reflectance products directly by Planet. For details, see the product specifications in the attached documents.

title: SMI annual dynamics - Silvicultural Management Intensity Dynamics on all forest EPs, 2008 - 2020
abstract:
The dynamics of the index of Silvicultural Management Intensity (SMI) between 2008 and 2020 can be used to assess changes in forest management intensity and associated effects on biodiversity.

The SMI consists of two components, the risk of stand loss SMIr, which is a function of tree species and stand age, and stand density SMId, which is a function of the silvicultural regime, stand age and tree species.  SMIr quantifies the age dependent probability of losing a stand before it reaches 180 years. SMId accounts for the deviation of the actual stocking from a fully stocked mature forest in terms of basal area, which has been modified by harvests and thinning.

title: FOX Initial forest inventory, single tree data and gap cutting, 2019 – 2020
abstract:
The initial forest inventory of the FOX plots was carried out in 2019 for the treatments G (gap cutting) and GD (gap cutting and deadwood enrichment) and in 2020 for treatment D (deadwood enrichment). Size of the plots is 71 m x 71 m for treatments G and GD and 50 m x 50 m for treatment D.

The dataset served to document the initial state of the plots and to plan the silvicultural intervention of gap cutting and deadwood enrichment.

This dataset comprises original data on species, diameter at breast height, tree heigth, wood volume and geographical location (caliper limit: dbh >= 7 cm).

title: Enzymatic capabilities of fungal isolates from grassland VIPs 2017
abstract: The functional significance of fungi in soil based ecosystem services, such as soil structure formation, nutrient cycling, and plant productivity, is widely acknowledged. However, a comprehensive link between individual fungal taxa and ecosystem services is currently impossible, due to a lack of knowledge of functional traits of these taxa. We currently engage in large scale, high throughput culturing of saprobic fungi from the very intensive grassland plots (VIP) of the Biodiversity Exploratories.

title: FOX Experiment design variables, 2019
abstract:
The FOX is a full factorial joint experiment of the biodiversity exploratories, in which canopy closure and deadwood availability were manipulated.
  
The design of the FOX experiment comprises the treatments G (gap cutting), GD (gap cutting and deadwood enrichment), D (deadwood enrichment) and C (control = EP). However, the size of the gap and the amount of deadwood enrichment depended on stand characteristics. These covariable are specified in this dataset.

title: BEXIS 2 module of the land-use intensity index (LUI) calculation tool of the Biodiversity Exploratories project for grassland survey data from three different regions in Germany since 2006
abstract: The land-use intensity (LUI) index summarizes three land-use components which are yearly surveyed by the LMTs (land management teams) for each grassland plot i: fertilization (Fi), mowing (Mi), and grazing (Gi). Here we provide the code of a tool that calculates the LUI index. The tool can be found on the BExIS website under the Tools menu entry (https://www.bexis.uni-jena.de/).

title: Long-term (1901-2017) phenology data of 20 forest understory herbs in Europe, collected from herbaria and GBIF, used in: "Forest wildflowers bloom earlier as Europe warms: Lessons from herbaria and spatial modeling", New Phytologist
abstract:
Today plants often flower earlier due to climate warming, and the collection dates of herbarium specimens can provide proof of this. 

To test for such fingerprints of climate change in Europe, we compiled a long-term (1901-2017) dataset from 6131 herbarium specimens of 20 early-flowering European forest understory herbs. The data were collected in the herbaria of Jena (JE), Stuttgart (STU) and Tübingen (TUB), and were complemented with herbarium data from the database GBIF. 

The final data file consisted of the collection dates (DOY) of each specimen, along with its year of collection, geographic coordinates, altitude and climate in the year of collection. The climate data was from gridded historical data from the Climate Research Unit, UK. 

We used the data to analyse long-term trends in plant phenology and to test for relationships between climate and phenology. We also carried out all analyses with and without taking spatial autocorrelation into account (spatial modeling with R-INLA). For the results of our analyses please see the article "Forest wildflowers bloom earlier as Europe warms: Lessons from herbaria and spatial modeling" in the New Phytologist.

The data collection and analysis was part of the project "PhenoDiv" within the framework of the DFG-funded Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de). Unlike most data in the BE, our data are not directly from the common study plots, but they are related as we conducted field surveys of the phenology of the same 20 plant species in the forest EPs of Alb and Hainich (data set 27746 "Phenology of forest herbs, from 2017 and 100 plots", used in "Spring understory herbs flower later in intensively managed forests", Ecological Applications.

title: Borders of all three regions of the Biodiversity Exploratories project
abstract: The datast contains the actual borders of the three exploratory regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). The file format is GeoPackage (GPKG).

title: Spatial species distribution of vascular plants in the FOX canopy gaps (G, GD) along a north-south transect in all regions, 2021
abstract: Various studies showed that plant diversity is not uniformly distributed across forest gaps. Here, we investigated diversity distribution patterns in the experimentally created stand clearances from the FOX experiment (forest gap experiment) in all three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). Vegetation surveys were conducted on the regeneration subplots which are arranged on a north-south transect and included presence/absence data of all plant species that rooted within the subplot. Within the regeneration subplots of 3 m x 4 m, we only sampled a one-meter-wide band closest to the north-south transect (3 m x 1 m). Data was collected between June and September 2021. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Tree and shrub cover in the FOX canopy gaps (G, GD) along a north-south transect in all three regions, 2021
abstract: Various studies showed that plant diversity is not uniformly distributed across forest gaps. Here, we investigated diversity distribution patterns in the experimentally created stand clearances from the FOX experiment (forest gap experiment) in all three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). Vegetation cover estimations of trees and shrubs were conducted on the regeneration subplots which are arranged on a north-south transect. Within the regeneration subplots of 3 m x 4 m, we only surveyed a one-meter-wide band closest to the north-south transect (3 m x 1 m). Tree and shrub cover serve as a proxy for light availability for herbs. Data was collected between June and September 2021. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Window traps on FOX, 2020 + 2021: Hemiptera and Coleoptera
abstract:
Arthropods in forests depend on the availability of light and deadwood, but the influence of both variables has not been assessed experimentally. The full-factorial FOX experiment manipulates light (via gaps) and deadwood, allowing to assess how gaps and deadwood relate to arthropod diversity in forests.

Arthropod have been sampled annually with window traps on all forest FOX plots and the corresponding EPs since 2020 to provide data for various analyses, for example effects of FOX treatments on arthropods.

Note: This dataset will be consecutively updated as species identifications become available. Currently, data on Hemiptera and Coleoptera for 2020 and 2021 are available. Further data will be appended once available.

title: Dung beetles collected in FOX in summer 2020
abstract:
Arthropods in forests depend on the availability of light and deadwood, but the influence of both variables has not been assessed experimentally. The full-factorial FOX experiment manipulates light (via gaps) and deadwood, allowing to assess how gaps and deadwood relate to arthropod diversity in forests.

We collected dung beetles in all FOX plots (including corresponding EP controls) for 48 h with dung baited pitfall traps. We wanted to test the influence of experimental creation of gaps and deadwood in forests on dung beetle diversity, abundance and biomass.

title: Vegetation records in the FOX-experiment in forests, header data without species identity, 2020
abstract: Open gaps in forest create important habitats for many forest species and offer opportunity for forest regeneration. However, in how far these gaps differ in their effect depending on the former forest management, remains unclear and is often tested in observational studies only. Moreover, the importance of deadwood, which may accumulate in such gaps, for the diversity of other taxa is poorly understood. Therefore, we established a factorially combined forest gap experiment called FOX. On each of 29 forest EPs (8 in the Schwäbische Alb, 9 in Hainich-Dün, 12 in Schorfheide-Chorin), four plots were created, two of which contained a gap of ca. 20 m diameter, in which all trees were felled, and two plots with non-felled forest. Into half of the plots, deadwood stems were added. For an area of 5 m x 5 m, on which plant abundances were estimated in summer. We estimated the cover of bryophytes, deadwood, rocks, and bare soil, when they exceeded 5 % of the plot area. In addition, the number of vascular plant species and the cumulative cover is calculated. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Vegetation summary data in the FOX-experiment in forests without species identity, 2021
abstract: Open gaps in forest create important habitats for many forest species and offer opportunity for forest regeneration. However, in how far these gaps differ in their effect depending on the former forest management, remains unclear and is often tested in observational studies only. Moreover, the importance of deadwood, which may accumulate in such gaps, for the diversity of other taxa is poorly understood. Therefore, we established a factorially combined forest gap experiment called FOX. On each of 29 forest experimental plots (EPs) (8 in the Schwäbische Alb, 9 in Hainich-Dün, 12 in Schorfheide-Chorin), four plots were created, two of which contained a gap of ca. 20 m diameter, in which all trees were felled, and two plots with non-felled forest. Into half of the plots, deadwood stems were added. For an area of 5 m x 5 m, on which plant abundances were estimated in summer. We estimated the cover of bryophytes, deadwood, rocks, and bare soil, when they exceeded 5 % of the plot area. In addition, the number of vascular plant species and the cumulative cover is calculated. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Vegetation summary data for 151 forest EPs without species identity, 2021
abstract: Long-term monitoring of plants is an important element to assess the effect of forest management on the functioning of ecosystems. Plants and their diversity affect other trophic groups and the temporal stability of the plant community is an important indicator of ecosystem functioning. Therefore, we assess the diversity of vascular plants on 151 forest plots from three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) that differ in their management, ranging from unmanaged forests, to selection forests, where individual trees are felled individually, to age-class forest. On an area of 20 m x 20 m, on which we estimate the abundance of each plant species, we estimated the cover of bryophytes, litter, rocks, bare soil and deadwood. Moreover, the total number of plant species and the cumulative cover of all plants is given. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Carbon and nitrogen concentrations in soil and mineral containers at 5cm depth for all forest and grassland EPs, 2020 (BEmins project)
abstract:
Soil organic carbon and nitrogen concentrations are master variables in soil science. Soil organic carbon and nitrogen are the measurable components of soil organic matter (SOM). SOM exerts positive effects on numerous physical, chemical and biological soil properties. An increase in SOM generally results in an improved soil structure, soil moisture retention, soil buffering capacity, retention of pollutants, cycling and storage of plant nutrients and biodiversity. SOM also acts as a sink and source for atmospheric carbon dioxide.

Mineral associated OM (MAOM) -i.e., OM bound to soil minerals - can account for as much as 90% of total SOM. Therefore, understanding the processes/factors controlling the formation of MAOM is key to understanding SOM dynamics. We buried mineral containers filled with mixtures of quartz sand and pristine minerals (either the iron oxyhydroxide, goethite, or the clay mineral, illite) at a 5 cm soil depth for five years in all 300 experimental plots (EPs) to study the interplay between mineral type, land use, and management intensity on the formation of MAOM. This dataset contains C and N concentrations in soil and mineral containers.

title: Standard deviation of diameter at breast height in all forests of the Exploratories
abstract: Spatially explicit information of biodiversity is necessary to achieve a mechanistic understanding of the interactions between land use and ecosystem services across environmental gradients. To that end, we have produced this georeferenced spatial dataset that represents the habitat heterogeneity in all forests of the three Exploratories. It covers thus not only forest plots, but also the surrounding forests. Specifically, it contains information on the variability of the diameter at breast height for all forest patches larger than 1 ha. The spatial resolution is 100 m. Created by the project SeBAS, grant code DU 632 1596/1-1.

title: Vegetation data in grasslands for upscaling 2020-2021
abstract: This dataset contains plant data collected from several grassland plots during SeBAS four campaigns (June & September 2020 and 2021). It was collected along with UAV flights, available at https://vhrz1078.hrz.uni-marburg.de:8201. All VIPs were covered every campaign, plus 62 EPs that were visited only once. The dataset contains biomass, leaf area index, percentage covers estimations (forbs, grasses and legumes), species richness and plant height and reflectance values from the UAV. SeBAS is funded by grant code DU 632 1596/1-1.

title: Intra-individual trait variation in Galium odoratum grown in a common garden and subjected to drought and shade treatments, 2021
abstract: In 2020, we collected clonal replicates from 71 genets of Galium odoratum originating from 21 forest plots from all three Exploratory regions (Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) and grew them in a common garden at Goethe University Frankfurt. In 2021 we applied a full-factorial design of drought and shade treatments and measured vegetative traits (plant height, leaf length and leaf width) to investigate intra-individual variation.

title: Microcosm experiment, plant species richness (2019), HEDGE II
abstract:
The focus of this project is to understand how (compositional and configurational) habitat heterogeneity influences species composition and biodiversity of grassland communities. Traditionally, it is believed that an increase in habitat heterogeneity has a positive effect on biodiversity (Hutchinson's niche concept); however, empirical data suggest that the effect of heterogeneity on biodiversity might as well be negative, neutral or unimodal Allouche et al. (2012). According to the Area-heterogeneity trade-off proposed by Kadmon and Allouche (2007) environmental heterogeneity has two opposite effects on species richness. On the one hand it increases opportunities for niche partitioning, at the other hand it reduces the amount of suitable area available for each species, thereby increasing the probability of stochastic extinction. To test the predictions of the AHTO model we set up a long term microcosm experiment simulating different combinations of habitat types and land use, resulting in different levels of habitat heterogeneity within a given area.

The experiment was conducted at a common garden site in Tübingen and comprised 248 Planting tubs (Polyethylene (PE)-boxes; 80 × 80 cm width, 40 cm depth) that were embedded into the ground and filled with a seedless sand/soil mixture. A grid of 4 × 4 subplots (20 x 20 cm each) was established within each planting tub. In a subset of plots subplots were separated by PE-walls, in all other plots subplots were not physically separated from each other. Each subplot received a species mix consisting of 40 species common to Germany (8 seeds per species). Four treatments (mowing, fertilization, trampling by livestock, soil depth) were applied to create different land management regimes on the subplot-level and in combination different levels of habitat heterogeneity on the plot level.

THE EXPERIMENTS WERE NOT CONDUCTED WITHIN THE EXPLORATORIES! THEY WERE CONDUCTED IN A COMMON GARDEN!

title: Vegetation analysis and trait data of plant communities originating from the Exploratories in the common garden in Marburg (2020-2021)
abstract:
Changes in land-use intensity along with land degradation have been identified as major causes of the decline in biodiversity and a loss of ecological functions. The application of fertilizer, mowing and grazing are land-use components that have been shown to affect plant species diversity and composition in grasslands in many ways. However, a strong environmental impact on the effects of land use can be inferred by the variation in strength as well as direction of these effects. Site-specific differences in regard to various environmental factors between but also within the three Exploratories impede a separation of environmental and land-use effects and therefore the identification of the actual effects of land use on communities. Thus, we established a controlled environment by using a common-garden approach to better illustrate the sole effects of various types of land use by reducing environmental heterogeneity to a minimum. 
To establish a common garden at the University Marburg in April-May 2020, grass sods (1x1m) harvested at n = 39 plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories that best represent a land-use gradient from all three regions have been partitioned into four equal parts. Each of the subplots (50x50cm) will be subjected to one of four land-use treatments. Additionally, one plot containing sterilized soil has been placed in each treatment block.
Treatments differed in mowing frequency and application of fertilizer in a full factorial design: ‘Control’ (= mowing once per year), ‘Mowing’ (= mowing twice per year), ‘Fertilizer’ (= mowing once per year and fertilizing once per year) and ‘Mowing & Fertilizer’ (= mowing twice per year and fertilizing once per year).
This dataset contains data on the taxonomic composition of the sods as well as manual measurements of plant traits (plant height [cm], leaf length [cm] and width [cm], leaf dry weight [g] and specific leaf area [mm2 mg-1]). Vegetation surveys were conducted in June/July 2020 and 2021 where all vascular plant species were identified and their cover was estimated with a resolution of 1% and trait values were recorded in 2020 for all plant species that covered >5% in a sod according to the vegetation survey.
The data collection and analysis was part of the project EXClAve within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Scan data from digital whole-community phenotyping of the common garden in Marburg
abstract:
Trait-based approaches are of great importance in ecological studies, particularly for integrating species-specific traits to community-wide indices, thus linking observable patterns in plant communities to ecosystem functions and processes and contributing to the derivation of general rules and predictions about responses to environmental gradients. Ecological field studies often use manual ‘low-throughput’ methods to assess plant phenotypes on species level. In greenhouse or lab-based studies, mostly in agriculture, ‘high-throughput phenotyping’ of plant individuals is used to track plant growth or fertilizer and water demand. We customized an automated plant phenotyping system for its mobile application in the field. By scanning whole plant communities, multispectral and physiological information together with the 3-dimensional structure of the vegetation is gathered within seconds and non-invasively. We tracked plant community responses to experimental land-use treatments by scanning the subplots of the common garden at the University Marburg (established 2020, for more information also see dataset id: 31267) multiple times over the course of the years 2020 and 2021.
This dataset contains 14 parameters from n=11 scan events where all plots of the common garden have been scanned. 
The data collection and analysis was part of the project EXClAvE within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Carbon, nitrogen and sulfur stocks - soil sampling campaign 2017, all forest experimental plots (EP), organic layer
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the soil bulk density and the soil organic carbon (OC), total nitrogen (TN) and total sulfur (TS) stocks in the organic layer from all experimental plots (EP) in 2017. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soils are important reservoirs for carbon, nitrogen and sulfur. The storage of organic carbon and nutrients is not only important for climate regulation and plant growth but also affects other soil functions. A multitude of natural factors (e.g. climate, parent material, landscape position) but also human-induced factors (e.g. land use type, management intensity) influence the potential of soils to store carbon and nutrients. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-3, TR 1054/4-3, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Soil pH - soil sampling campaign 2021, all forest gap exeriment (FOX) plots, 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the soil pH values in 0-10 cm depth from all forest gap experiment (FOX) plots in 2021. Soil pH is considered a master variable in soil science as it affects many chemical processes in soils. Most importantly, the plant nutrient availability is greatly affected by the soil pH as it controlls the chemical forms of the different nutrients and influences the chemical reactions they undergo. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-4, TR 1054/4-4, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Microcosm experiment, plant species cover (2019), HEDGE II
abstract:
The focus of this project is to understand how (compositional and configurational) habitat heterogeneity influences species composition and biodiversity of grassland communities. Traditionally, it is believed that an increase in habitat heterogeneity has a positive effect on biodiversity (Hutchinson's niche concept); however, empirical data suggest that the effect of heterogeneity on biodiversity might as well be negative, neutral or unimodal Allouche et al. (2012). According to the Area-heterogeneity trade-off proposed by Kadmon and Allouche (2007) environmental heterogeneity has two opposite effects on species richness. On the one hand it increases opportunities for niche partitioning, at the other hand it reduces the amount of suitable area available for each species, thereby increasing the probability of stochastic extinction. THE EXPERIMENTS WERE NOT CONDUCTED WITHIN THE EXPLORATORIES! THEY WERE CONDUCTED IN A COMMON GARDEN!

title: Potential nitrous oxide flux rates of all grassland EP Plots, Soil sampling campaign 2017
abstract: In the project BE_CH4 we want to investigate the effect of land use intensity on methane fluxes and methane cycling microorganisms. During these measurements also CO2 and N2O fluxes were determined at 20°C, at adjusted soil moisture and in recompacted soil colums of all 150 grassland EPs sampled during teh soil sampling campaign 2017.

title: EP Grassland Landuse Information ALB 2022
abstract:
Information about the land use on the EPs in 2022, based on information given by the farmers or on observations by members of the exploratories.
This file will be updated continuously.
It should be used only for fieldwork planning, NOT FOR ANALYSIS!.

title: Bat activity in urban sites in the Alb Exploratory region in summer 2021
abstract: We did a bat survey in 45 urban sites of the Schwäbische Alb Exploratory to assess differences in species composition and activity patterns in response to urbanization. Bats were assessed acoustically, using automated ultrasound recording devices (Batcorders 3.1, EcoObs). Recorders were placed at sites, differing in urban density and sampling was repeated in June, Juli/August, and September 2021. Identification of echolocation call sequences was conducted using an automated preclassification and additional manual inspection for species assignation, feeding activity, and social interactions. The data collection is part of the DFG-funded project birds & bats (project phase 2020-2023).

title: Wood-inhabiting archaeal community - primer comparison: Data set 'Prok'  (16S amplicon sequencing)
abstract:
In late 2008 the BELongDead (Biodiversity Exploratories Long term Deadwood) experiment for investigating deadwood decomposition was established. Freshly cut logs of 13 temperate tree species [nine broadleaved species: Acer sp., Betula sp., Carpinus sp., Fagus sylvatica, Fraxinus excelsior, Populus spp., Prunus avium, Quercus spp. and Tilia spp., and four conifers: Larix decidua, Picea abies, Pinus sylvestris and Pseudotsuga menziesii were placed on the forest floor. 

Here, we tried to improve archaeal detection by meainingful primer chioce for Illumina amplicon sequencing. We tested four primer sets and compared the ratio of archaeal sequences and archaeal diversity in deadwood. Samples have been taken in Schorfheide in 2017 as part of the BELongDead sampling campaign. Wood was collected after bark removal by driving an auger horizontally to the center of each of the selected logs. 10 Samples (4 Populus, 2 Carpinus, 2 Acer and Fagus) with higher pH value than five have been analysed. 
Here, we provide the abundances of observed prokaryotic ASVs (amplicon sequence variants) for the 'Prok' primer set (515f/806R). Data are not rarefied and need to be standardized according to the respective research question.

title: Wood-inhabiting archaeal community - primer comparison: Data set 'V34'  (16S amplicon sequencing)
abstract:
In late 2008 the BELongDead (Biodiversity Exploratories Long term Deadwood) experiment for investigating deadwood decomposition was established. Freshly cut logs of 13 temperate tree species [nine broadleaved species: Acer sp., Betula sp., Carpinus sp., Fagus sylvatica, Fraxinus excelsior, Populus spp., Prunus avium, Quercus spp. and Tilia spp., and four conifers: Larix decidua, Picea abies, Pinus sylvestris and Pseudotsuga menziesii were placed on the forest floor. 

Here, we tried to improve archaeal detection by meainingful primer chioce for Illumina amplicon sequencing. We tested four primer sets and compared the ratio of archaeal sequences and archaeal diversity in deadwood. Samples have been taken in Schorfheide in 2017 as part of the BELongDead sampling campaign. Wood was collected after bark removal by driving an auger horizontally to the center of each of the selected logs. 10 Samples (4 Populus, 2 Carpinus, 2 Acer and Fagus) with higher pH value than five have been analysed. 
Here, we provide the abundances of observed prokaryotic ASVs (amplicon sequence variants) for the 'V34' primer set (Arch-0349F/Arch-0806) (Takai and Horikoshi 2000). Data are not rarefied and need to be standardized according to the respective research question.

abstract:

Freshly cut logs of 13 temperate tree species [nine broadleaved species: Acer sp., Betula sp., Carpinus sp., Fagus sylvatica, Fraxinus excelsior, Populus spp., Prunus avium, Quercus spp. and Tilia spp., and four conifers: Larix decidua, Picea abies, Pinus sylvestris and Pseudotsuga menziesii were placed on the forest floor.

Here, we provide the abundances of observed prokaryotic ASVs (amplicon sequence variants) for the 'V46' primer set (Arch-0519/Arch-1041) (Ovreas et al. 1997, Baker et al. 2003). Data are not rarefied and need to be standardized according to the respective research question.

abstract:

Freshly cut logs of 13 temperate tree species [nine broadleaved species: Acer sp., Betula sp., Carpinus sp., Fagus sylvatica, Fraxinus excelsior, Populus spp., Prunus avium, Quercus spp. and Tilia spp., and four conifers: Larix decidua, Picea abies, Pinus sylvestris and Pseudotsuga menziesii were placed on the forest floor.
