We tested four primer sets and compared the ratio of archaeal sequences and archaeal diversity in deadwood. Samples have been taken in Schorfheide in 2017 as part of the BELongDead sampling campaign. Wood was collected after bark removal by driving an auger horizontally to the center of each of the selected logs. 10 Samples (4 Populus, 2 Carpinus, 2 Acer and Fagus) with higher pH value than five have been analysed. 
Here, we provide the abundances of observed prokaryotic ASVs (amplicon sequence variants) for the 'V56' primer set (Arch-0787F/Arch-1043) (Yu et al. 2005). Data are not rarefied and need to be standardized according to the respective research question.

title: Topographic Wetness Index for all plots of the BiodiversityExploratories
abstract:
The Topographic Wetness Index (TWI) is hydrological index to quantify the topographic control on hydrological processes. It uses the size of the catchment area above the point of interests as well as the slope.
We calculated the TWI for all three Exploratories based on a digital elevation model ALOS World 3D 30m (AW3D30). Details on the calculation can be found here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topographic_wetness_index.  Data is provided in GeoTIFF format. The data processing was part of the core project Instrumentation & Remote Sensing within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Basic information and coordinates of all grassland joint experiment plots
abstract:
In 2019 the joint multi-site experiment was installed to study the impact of changes in land-use management in grasslands in all three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). In the new grassland experiments REX and LUX, the effect of reduced land use intensity and seed sowing is studied. Furthermore, the effect of individual components of land use is investigated.
The dataset provides on overview of all plots and the applied experiemtents.

title: Nematode trophic groups from the forests of Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün and Schorfheide-Chorin (2014)
abstract: A key to forest performance are structure and function of the biotic communities in the soil microbiome. Soil nematodes are a dominant part of these assemblages, with an important role in the associated micro-food web. However, virtually nothing is known about how forest management and soil properties affect the nematode fauna. This data-sheet shows the nematode trophic composition and density in the organic layer and mineral soil of fifty forest stands each in the Schwäbische Alb (ALB), Hainch-Dün (HAI) and Schorfheide-Chorin (SCH), Germany. The dataset shows the distribution of nematodetrophic groups and densities in the soil of these three forests, including plots with different forest management intensities. The data collection and analysis was part of the project MicroWeb within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Metabolic quotient of soil microorganisms, grassland EPs, soil sampling campaign 2017
abstract: The metabolic quotient (= specific respiration) is the respiration (CO2 production, basal respiration) per unit of soil microbial biomass carbon (C). It is an indicator of the C-use efficiency of the soil microbial biomass. A high metabolic quotient indicates inefficient metabolism (nutrient-poor resources) and/or stress (e.g., triggered by grazing by protists or nematodes). It was determined for all grassland EPs using soil samples from the soil sampling campaign 2017 .

title: Enzyme activities in soil and mineral containers, 2020
abstract: The data analysis was part of the BEMins project, studying the co-formation of goethite- and illite-associated organic matter and microorganisms. To gain knowledge about microbial functionality on the mineral surfaces, we determined enzyme activities (beta-glucosidase, beta-xylosidase, n-acetylglucosaminidase and acid phosphatase) via MUF analysis in the mineral containers and surrounding soils derived from 5 cm soil depth. Thus, the dataset contains the enzyme activities of those four hydrolytic enzymes. Samples were taken in August 2020.

title: Phospholipid fatty acids (PLFAs) in soil and mineral containers (5 cm), 2020
abstract: The data analysis was part of the BEMins project, studying the co-formation of goethite- and illite-associated organic matter and microorganisms. To gain knowledge about microbial colonization of the mineral surfaces, we determined the composition of main microbial groups via phospholipid fatty acid (PLFA) analysis in the mineral containers and surrounding soils. These PLFA data are contained in this dataset. Samples were taken in August 2020.

title: Water-extractable organic matter in soils, Swabian Alb grasslands, 2020
abstract: The data analysis was part of a cooperation between the ShapeDOM and BEMins project, studying the co-formation of goethite- and illite-associated organic matter and microorganisms. To gain knowledge about potential transport of organic matter (OM) and nutrients through the soil solution to the buried mineral containers, we determined water-extractable organic C, N and P as well as total phosphorus, phosphate, total nitrogen, ammonium and nitrate in the soils (5cm soil depth) on the 50 grassland EPs of the ALB, which are contained in this dataset. Samples were taken in August 2020.

title: Landscape structure (composition and configuration) at multiple scales around 150 grassland experimental plots (2012/2015/2018)
abstract:
This dataset has information on landscape structure (i.e. composition and configuration) of different land uses surrounding grassland experimnetal plots. The metrics calculated here are the most often used metrics in ecological studies to test the effects of landscape structure on ecological processes.

Data are available for the years 2012, 2015, and 2018, at four spatial scales (500m, 1000m, 1500m, and 2000m) around grassland experimental plots.

title: Extractable phosphorus (Olsen-P) in mineral containers (5 cm) and soils, 2020
abstract: The data analysis was part of the BEMins project, studying the co-formation of goethite- and illite-associated organic matter and microorganisms. To gain knowledge about accumulation of phosphorus (P) on the mineral surfaces, we determined sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3)-extractable phosphorus, commonly termed Olsen-P, in mineral containers and soils. These Olsen-P data are contained in this dataset. Samples were taken in August 2020.

title: Biological nitrogen fixation and concentrations of nutrients and non-structural carbohydrates in deadwood of 13 different tree species
abstract:
Deadwood is an extremely nitrogen poor plant litter whose decomposition may rely on external nitrogen sources. Biological nitrogen fixation by free-living diazotrophs is a potential pathway of nitrogen acquisition in deadwood. Still, the control of this process by tree species specific traits is hardly known. 
We determined rates of biological nitrogen fixation, respiration rate, and concentrations of nutrients and non-structural carbohydrates in deadwood logs of the BELongDead project from 13 tree species in the Hainich-Dün region of the Biodiversity Exploratories in June 2020. 
The data collection and analysis was part of the project Woodstock within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Individual bumble bee worker identity for feeding experiments with treatment code
abstract: We conducted lab experiments to disentangle land-use effects and to validate potential effects of land-use on bumble bee health. Since high land-use intesity is associated with (high) pesticide use and decreasing plant diversity which is in turn the food source for pollinators, we performed feeding experiments with a common pollinator species, Bombus terrestris. Experiments were conducted in behavioral observation rooms at Ulm University between October 2021 and January 2022. In this fulfactorial experiment, bees were treated with either (1) a field realistic dose (5ng per g pollen/nectar) of the neonicotinoid acetamiprid, (2) low quality food (7:3 honeybee collected pollen and pollen exines) or (3) a combination of both. We assessed different health traits individually for each worker and development parameters at colony level. For each worker we recorded the age from hatching to the end, where the respective trait was measured.

title: Single compound data of chemical surface profile of Bombus terrestris in feeding experiments
abstract: We conducted lab experiments to disentangle land-use effects and to validate potential effects of land-use on bumble bee health. Since high land-use intensity is associated with (high) pesticide use and decreasing plant diversity which is in turn the food source for pollinators, we performed feeding experiments with a common pollinator species, Bombus terrestris. Experiments were conducted in behavioral observation rooms at Ulm University between October 2021 and January 2022. In this fulfactorial experiment, bees were treated with either (1) a field realistic dose (5ng per g pollen/nectar) of the neonicotinoid acetamiprid, (2) low quality food (7:3 honeybee collected pollen and pollen exines) or (3) a combination of both. We assessed different health traits individually for each worker and development parameters at colony level. For each worker we recorded the age from hatching to the end, where the respective trait was measured. Here, we analysed the chemical surface profile of 283 bumble bees individually, since chemical communication plays an important role in social insects. The absolute amount of each compound is presented in this dataset.

title: Health traits of Bombus terrestris in a feeding experiment
abstract:
We conducted lab experiments to disentangle land-use effects and to validate potential effects of land-use on bumble bee health. Since high land-use intensity is associated with (high) pesticide use and decreasing plant diversity which is in turn the food source for pollinators, we performed feeding experiments with a common pollinator species, Bombus terrestris. Experiments were conducted in behavioral observation rooms at Ulm University between October 2021 and January 2022. In this fulfactorial experiment, bees were treated with either (1) a field realistic dose (5ng per g pollen/nectar) of the neonicotinoid acetamiprid, (2) low quality food (7:3 honeybee collected pollen and pollen exines) or (3) a combination of both. We assessed different health traits individually for each worker and development parameters at colony level.
Here, we analysed 2 different health traits in Bombus terrestris. We measured ovary size and the relative fat body mass in the abdomen.

title: Encapsulation response of worker bumble bees in a feeding experiment
abstract:
We conducted lab experiments to disentangle land-use effects and to validate potential effects of land-use on bumble bee health. Since high land-use intensity is associated with (high) pesticide use and decreasing plant diversity which is in turn the food source for pollinators, we performed feeding experiments with a common pollinator species, Bombus terrestris. Experiments were conducted in behavioral observation rooms at Ulm University between October 2021 and January 2022. In this fulfactorial experiment, bees were treated with either (1) a field realistic dose (5ng per g pollen/nectar) of the neonicotinoid acetamiprid, (2) low quality food (7:3 honeybee collected pollen and pollen exines) or (3) a combination of both. We assessed different health traits individually for each worker and development parameters at colony level. 
Here, we analysed the encapsulation response of worker bumble bees which is a general immune response towards novel antigens.

title: Size data of bumble bees in a feeding experiment
abstract:
We conducted lab experiments to disentangle land-use effects and to validate potential effects of land-use on bumble bee health. Since high land-use intensity is associated with (high) pesticide use and decreasing plant diversity which is in turn the food source for pollinators, we performed feeding experiments with a common pollinator species, Bombus terrestris. Experiments were conducted in behavioral observation rooms at Ulm University between October 2021 and January 2022. In this fulfactorial experiment, bees were treated with either (1) a field realistic dose (5ng per g pollen/nectar) of the neonicotinoid acetamiprid, (2) low quality food (7:3 honeybee collected pollen and pollen exines) or (3) a combination of both. We assessed different health traits individually for each worker and development parameters at colony level. For each worker we recorded the age from hatching to the end, where the respective trait was measured.
Here, we analysed the body size of bumble bees using centroid size as a proxy for body size

title: Interaction data of bumble bee workers in a feeding experiment
abstract:
We conducted lab experiments to disentangle land-use effects and to validate potential effects of land-use on bumble bee health. Since high land-use intensity is associated with (high) pesticide use and decreasing plant diversity which is in turn the food source for pollinators, we performed feeding experiments with a common pollinator species, Bombus terrestris. Experiments were conducted in behavioral observation rooms at Ulm University between October 2021 and January 2022. In this fulfactorial experiment, bees were treated with either (1) a field realistic dose (5ng per g pollen/nectar) of the neonicotinoid acetamiprid, (2) low quality food (7:3 honeybee collected pollen and pollen exines) or (3) a combination of both. We assessed different health traits individually for each worker and development parameters at colony level. For each worker we recorded the age from hatching to the end, where the respective trait was measured.
Here, we analysed the social behavior of bumble bee workers in the colony at 3 different time points. We recorded three different interaction behaviors (nudging, backing and further interaction).

title: Food consumption and  development of bumble bees in a feeding experiment
abstract:
We conducted lab experiments to disentangle land-use effects and to validate potential effects of land-use on bumble bee health. Since high land-use intensity is associated with (high) pesticide use and decreasing plant diversity which is in turn the food source for pollinators, we performed feeding experiments with a common pollinator species, Bombus terrestris. Experiments were conducted in behavioral observation rooms at Ulm University between October 2021 and January 2022. In this fulfactorial experiment, bees were treated with either (1) a field realistic dose (5ng per g pollen/nectar) of the neonicotinoid acetamiprid, (2) low quality food (7:3 honeybee collected pollen and pollen exines) or (3) a combination of both. We assessed different health traits individually for each worker and development parameters at colony level. For each worker we recorded the age from hatching to the end, where the respective trait was measured. 
Here, we analysed food consumption and development of bumble bee colonies.

title: Biological nitrogen fixation, nutrient concentrations and isotopic signatures of mosses growing on deadwood logs
abstract:
Mosses rely on nitrogen from external sources, such as the symbiosis with diazotrophs. Diazotrophs fix atmospheric nitrogen and provide it to the moss host. However, research mainly focusses on boreal regions, and mosses from temperate forests are missing. 
We determined rates of biological nitrogen fixation, nutrient concentrations and isotopic signatures of two moss species (Brachythecium rutabulum, Hypnum cupressiforme) growing on top of deadwood logs from the BELongDead project from 3 tree species (Fagus, Quercus, Pinus) in the three exploratory regions (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün, and Schwäbische Alb) in September and October 2020. 
The data collection and analysis was part of the project Woodstock within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Biological nitrogen fixation, respiration rate and dissolved organic carbon and nitrogen in deadwood logs after 9 years of N addition
abstract:
Deadwood is an extremely nitrogen poor plant litter whose decomposition may rely on external nitrogen sources. Biological nitrogen fixation by free-living diazotrophs is a potential pathway of nitrogen acquisition in deadwood. Still, it is unknown how repeated addition of nitrogen and no soil contact influences the biological nitrogen fixation in deadwood.
We determined rates of biological nitrogen fixation, respiration rate, and concentrations of dissolved organic carbon and nitrogen in deadwood logs in a subproject of the BELongDead project from 13 tree species in the Hainich-Dün exploratory on 5 plots after 9 years of repeated N addition in autumn 2020. 
The data collection and analysis was part of the project Woodstock within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Biological nitrogen fixation in deadwood under laboratory manipulation
abstract:
Deadwood is an extremely nitrogen poor plant litter whose decomposition may rely on external nitrogen sources. Biological nitrogen fixation by free-living diazotrophs is a potential pathway of nitrogen acquisition in deadwood. Still, the control of this process by laboratory incubation conditions is hardly known. 
After sampling in September 2021, we determined rates of biological nitrogen fixation and respiration rate in deadwood of three tree species in an lab experiment under different methane and oxygen concentrations, temperatures, and after the addition of a mixed-nutrient, molybdenum and glucose solution.
The data collection and analysis was part of the project Woodstock within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de)."

title: Field moisture and density in three tree species
abstract:
Deadwood is an extremely nitrogen poor plant litter whose decomposition may rely on external nitrogen sources. Biological nitrogen fixation by free-living diazotrophs is a potential pathway of nitrogen acquisition in deadwood. Still, the control of this process by laboratory incubation conditions is hardly known. 
Before determining biological nitrogen fixation and respiration rate in deadwood of three tree species in an lab experiment, we determined the field moisture, maximum water holding capacity and density of the used deadwood. Sampling took place in September 2021.
The data collection and analysis was part of the project Woodstock within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Nutrient concentrations and isotopic signaturs of deadwood
abstract:
Deadwood is an extremely nitrogen poor plant litter whose decomposition may rely on external nitrogen sources. Biological nitrogen fixation by free-living diazotrophs is a potential pathway of nitrogen acquisition in deadwood. Still, the control of this process by laboratory incubation conditions is hardly known. 
Before determining biological nitrogen fixation and respiration rate in deadwood of three tree species in an lab experiment, we determined nutrient concentrations and isotopic signatures of the deadwood. Sampling took place in the Hainich-Dün exploratory in September 2021.
The data collection and analysis was part of the project Woodstock within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de)."

title: Olsen P - soil sampling campaign 2021, all experimental plots (EPs), 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project ‘Soil' provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3)-extractable inorganic phosphorus (P), commonly termed Olsen-P in 0-10 cm depth from all Experimental Plots (EPs) in 2021. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). The Olsen P analysis provides an estimate of the inorganic ortho-phosphate (PO4-P) that is accessible as “available” phosphorus for uptake by plants. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-4, TR 1054/4-4, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/)

title: Participatory social network analysis in the three Exploratories (social sciences approach)
abstract: We have organized three workshops in the Exploratories to conduct a participatory social network analysis (SNA). The central question of the workshop was "Who is demanding something from nature in the three regions?". Therefore, the aim was to identify  interest/stakeholder groups and their network. The selected method is called "net-map method" with several steps: Identification of stakeholders/interests groups; linking the groups (quality, intensity, type of link); building influence towers with Lego bricks; final discussion. Afterwards, the data was analysed with the software "Visual social networks" (Visone). Furthermore, the conduced data was validated and refined with information of the transcripted workshop discussion as well as qualitative interviews and quantitative survey data (see further BEF-up datasets). The data are available quantified in tabular form. The data set contains the perceived influence on the network per stakeholder group, as well as the network characteristics, such as node centrality (degree, betweeness and closeness).

title: Soil pH - soil sampling campaign 2021, all reduced land-use intensity experiment (REX) and land-use experiment (LUX) plots, 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the soil pH values in 0-10 cm depth from all reduced land-use intensity experiment (REX) and land-use experiment (LUX) plots in 2021. Soil pH is considered a master variable in soil science as it affects many chemical processes in soils. Most importantly, the plant nutrient availability is greatly affected by the soil pH as it controls the chemical forms of the different nutrients and influences the chemical reactions they undergo. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-4, TR 1054/4-4, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Plant species richness and biomass, and soil microbial properties data used in "Microbial drivers of plant richness and productivity in a grassland restoration experiment along a gradient of land-use intensity"
abstract:
Plant-soil feedbacks (PSFs) underlying grassland plant richness and productivity are typically coupled with nutrient availability; however, we lack understanding of how restoration measures to increase plant diversity might affect PSFs. We examined the roles of sward disturbance, seed addition and land-use intensity (LUI) on PSFs.
We conducted a seed addition and disturbance experiment (SADE) in ten grasslands along a LUI gradient and characterized plant above- and belowground biomass and richness, soil microbial biomass carbon and nitrogen (Cmic and Nmic); microbial community composition in terms of microbial groups determined from phospholipid fatty acid biomarkers (PLFAs); enzyme activities (Beta-D-Glucosidase, Xylosidase, N-Acetylglucosaminidase and Acid phosphatase); soil properties (pH, Olsen P, bulk density, extractable carbon and nitrogen, mineral nitrogen = nitrate + ammonium and the proportion of fungal OTUs assigned to saprotrophs, pathotrophs (putative plant pathogens) and symbiotrophs (mycorrhizal symbionts).

This dataset contains the data that was analysed on soil samples  and plant species richness and biomass of the years 2015, 2016, 2017 and 2018 on 10 selected SADE plots in the Schwäbische Alb, southwestern Germany.

title: Soil bacterial (16S) communities from 10 grassland plots in Germany (2015-2018; Illumina MiSeq) - OTU abundances (subset of dataset 25346)
abstract:
Cooperation between the BE projects SADE, Scalemic, Microorganisms (core): Plant-soil feedbacks (PSFs) underlying grassland plant richness and productivity are typically coupled with nutrient availability; however, we lack understanding of how restoration measures to increase plant diversity might affect PSFs. We examined the roles of sward disturbance, seed addition and land-use intensity (LUI) on PSFs. We conducted a disturbance and seed addition experiment in ten grasslands along a LUI gradient and characterized plant biomass and richness, soil microbial biomass, community composition and enzyme activities. This dataset contains OTU abundances  for bacterial community composition of the years 2015, 2016, 2017 and 2018 on 10 selected SADE plots in the Schwäbische Alb.

This is a subset of dataset 25346 made as accompanying data for the article "Microbial drivers of plant richness and productivity in a grassland restoration experiment along a gradient of land-use intensity" published in New Phytologist.

title: Soil bacterial (16S) communities from 10 grassland plots in Germany (2015-2018; Illumina MiSeq) - OTU taxonomic look-up table (subset of dataset 25466)
abstract:
Cooperation between the BE projects SADE, Scalemic, Microorganisms (core): Plant-soil feedbacks (PSFs) underlying grassland plant richness and productivity are typically coupled with nutrient availability; however, we lack understanding of how restoration measures to increase plant diversity might affect PSFs. We examined the roles of sward disturbance, seed addition and land-use intensity (LUI) on PSFs. We conducted a disturbance and seed addition experiment in ten grasslands along a LUI gradient and characterized plant biomass and richness, soil microbial biomass, community composition and enzyme activities. This dataset contains the taxonomic look up table for bacterial community composition of the years 2015, 2016, 2017 and 2018 on 10 selected SADE plots in the Schwäbische Alb.

This is a subset of dataset 25466 made as accompanying data for the article "Microbial drivers of plant richness and productivity in a grassland restoration experiment along a gradient of land-use intensity" published in New Phytologist.

title: Soil fungal (ITS) communities from 10 grassland plots in Germany (2015-2018; Illumina MiSeq) - OTU abundances (subset of dataset 25026)
abstract:

title: Soil fungal (ITS) communities from 10 grassland plots in Germany (2015-2018; Illumina MiSeq) - OTU taxonomic function look-up table (subset of dataset 25426)
abstract:
Cooperation between the BE projects SADE, Scalemic, Microorganisms (core): Plant-soil feedbacks (PSFs) underlying grassland plant richness and productivity are typically coupled with nutrient availability; however, we lack understanding of how restoration measures to increase plant diversity might affect PSFs. title: Check list for species names (including synonyms) for all Arthropods Core species data
abstract:
The nomenclature of species is in constant flux and the scientific names of species may change over time. For example, synonyms get resolved, morphologically cryptic species are split or species previously treated as separate are unified under one name. When referring to species names in publications, it is important to use the currently accepted nomenclature, not least to avoid confusion regarding species' identities.
We here provide a check list for all scientific binomials (genus, species) used in the monitoring data of Arthropods Core. The check list is valid for all species collected with pitfall traps, flight interception traps, sweep-netting and deadwood eclectors. We urge all explorers to consult the check list before uploading data originally collected by Arthropods Core, e.g. as part of a publication.
Species name data are valid as of May 2025 and will be updated regularly.

title: Abundances of denitrification and nitrate ammonification marker genes (soil sampling campain 2017)
abstract: In the project BE-Cult we want to identify the influence of land use intensity on the denitrifying and nitrate ammonifying bacterial community. Denitrification is the serial reduction of nitrate to nitrogen gas with nitrite, nitric oxide and nitrous oxide as intermediates. Nitrate ammonification is the reduction of nitrate to ammonium with nitrite as intermediate. We measured the abundance of marker genes of these reactions in all grassland experimental plots (EP) in all three regions of the Biodiversity Exploratories (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün, Schwäbische Alb).

title: Topographical Wetness Index (TWI) and soil depth data used in Neyret et al. Landscape strategies for multifunctionality and equity (300 EPs)
abstract: Topographical Wetness Index (TWI) and soil depth data for 300 forest and grassland EPs used as covariates in Neyret et al. Landscape strategies for multifunctionality and social equity.

title: Predicted grassland biomass 2020-2021
abstract: This is a georeferenced spatial dataset with the aboveground biomass in all grasslands of the three Exploratories (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb) at 10 m resolution. The temporal coverage is every 14 days from the end of March to the end of October of 2020 and 2021. It covers thus not only the grassland plots, but also all surrounding grasslands. Units: g/m2. The data collection was part of the project SeBAS within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de), grant code code DU 632 1596/1-1

title: Small mammal abundance in the Hainich region 2020-2021
abstract:
Rodents are important reservoirs for zoonotic pathogens that cause severe diseases in humans. Recent investigations revealed that factors like land-use and small mammal biodiversity have the potential to mitigate the underlying transmission processes on various levels. Biodiversity is hypothesized to be more closely related to pathogen prevalence on the population level, through direct mitigation of transmission rates while certain landscape features might also promote or hinder transmission. Although these factors are crucial to estimate potential future changes in human infection risk, they remain poorly understood. In this contribution we present the first results of an ongoing large-scale field experiment.
In Central Germany small mammals were trapped and analysed for various zoonotic pathogens in spring, summer and autumn 2020-2021. Trapping was conducted on forest and grassland sites and adjacent grassland that differed in the intensity of land use. First analysis revealed a strong impact of small mammal biodiversity on community composition and abundance. 
This study will generate a better understanding of natural pathogen-host dynamics, allowing public health recommendations and policy advice according to predicted future biodiversity scenarios.
The data available are relative abundance indices of all trapped small mammals within the study period. The index is standardized as individuals per 100 trap nights.

title: Vegetation records (neighboring species) around focal individuals of four common forb species collected for analyses of age and stem anatomical traits in the grassland EP`s (collected between 2017-2019)
abstract: Life span of plants is a key demographic trait important for the life history of plant species, the persistence and stability of plant populations and plant species` responses to environmental changes. However, information on the longevity of plant individuals (or ramets) and specifically its variation dependent on environmental conditions such as land use or regional differences in climatic conditions is not available for a large number of grassland species. Stem anatomical traits related to functions such as transport, storage and mechanical support are largely ignored in ecological studies of herbaceous species and therefore it is not known how sensitively these traits respond to variation in environmental conditions. Moreover, it is not known whether and/or how the diversity of plant species in the direct neighborhood of a plant individual are related to the age and expression of stem anatomical traits. We selected four common forb species (Achillea millefolium, Galium mollugo, Plantago lanceolata and Trifolium pratense), where we sampled 20 individuals in appr. 60 populations per species. We made thin cross sections of the oldest part of plant samples (root crown, or distal part of stolons or rhizoms) to count growth rings and measure the width of the stem anatomical tissues (dataset ID 31288). In the field, we also recorded the identity of all neighboring vascular plant species with a maximum distance of 10 cm around each focal individual. The data collection was part of the project ForbAge within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Nematode data from Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün and Schorfheide-Chorin, 2014 used in Forest Ecology and Management
abstract: A key to forest performance are structure and function of the biotic communities in the soil microbiome. Soil nematodes are a dominant part of these assemblages, with an important role in the associated micro-food web. However, virtually nothing is known about how forest management and soil properties affect the nematode fauna. This data-sheet shows the nematode communities in the organic layer and mineral soil of fifty forest stands each in the Schwäbische Alb (ALB), Hainch-Dün (HAI) and Schorfheide-Chorin (SCH), Germany. The dataset shows the distribution of nematode families in the soil of these three forests, including plots with different forest management intensities. The data collection and analysis was part of the project MicroWeb within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Bird traits for all species in the Exploratories experimental plots
abstract:
Traits allow us to compare patterns and processes across taxa,
regions, and time. They can help linking the responses of organisms to land-use intensity with their effects on ecosystem
functioning. Here we have assembled trait information for all bird species found in the Biodiversity Exploratories experimental plots between 2008 and 2018 in three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin).

title: R script used to calculate landscape structure (composition and configuration) at multiple scales around 150 grassland experimental plots (2012/2015/2018) (Bexis 31319)
abstract: This code can be used to reproduce the landscape metrics readily available on Bexis 31319 on landscape structure (i.e. composition and configuration) of different land uses surrounding 150 grassland experimental plots.

title: Biomass, species richness and environmental data from all three regions of the Biodiversity Exploratories, 2020-2021, used in: "Biomass removal promotes plant diversity after short-term extensification of managed grasslands"
abstract:
Here we test an hypothesis involving proposed effects of fertilization and biomass removal (by mowing/grazing) on plant biodiversity (here species richness and Shannon diversity). Specifically, we aim to distinguish between direct and indirect effects of fertilization on plant biodiversity, and how biomass removal due to mowing/grazing mediates these pathways. We thus aim to understand how different drivers of land-use extensification may, or may not, promote plant biodiversity. To address these questions, we used data from a full factorial experiment, replicated within managed grasslands in three regions in Germany. We compare the effects of land-use drivers crossing fertilization with a combined treatment of biomass removal (mowing/grazing treatment): (a) fertilized & biomass removal (in LUX: EP-C), (b) unfertilized & biomass removal (in LUX: UP-C), (c) unfertilized & reduced biomass removal (in LUX: RP-C) and (d) fertilized & reduced biomass removal (in LUX: RP-F). In particular, we tested the following hypotheses:
(1) Fertilization will cause plant species richness and Shannon diversity to decline, both directly and indirectly, by altering light competition due to increased biomass production and thereby increased standing biomass.
(2) Biomass removal partly compensates for the negative effects of fertilization on species richness and Shannon diversity, by decreasing levels of standing biomass and thereby reducing light competition or changing the competitive dominance of plant species. 
 
In order to do so, we performed vegetation records and estimated standing biomass using a rising plate-meter in all grassland EPs and in the new experiments (LUX: EP-C, RP-C, RP-F, UP-C), in the spring and summer season (April to May and July to August respectively) in 2020 and 2021. In each plot (7 x 7 m) we were assigned to a 1 x 1 m subplot, in which we estimated the species specific cover of each plant species (in percent). Furthermore, we measured standing biomass using a rising plate meter with 4 replicates per subplot. The data collection was part of the project BEF-Loops within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

Important note!
This data set is a processed version for the paper "Biomass removal promotes plant diversity after short-term extensification of managed grasslands (Andraczek et al.)". This data derived from other raw data sets (ID 31203, ID 31204 and data from LUI Tool based on ID 25086).

title: Topography of 300 forest and grassland EPs
abstract: This dataset contain information regarding topography attributes of 300 forest and grasslands EPs across the Exploratories, specifically slope, aspect, topographic wetness index (TWI) and elevation. Data were obtained using a 5m resolution DTM (BExIS 27729) available for the Exploratories regions.

title: R script to calculate road density at multiple spatial scales and distance to roads for the 300 forest and grassland EPs
abstract: The presence of roads can direct affect biodiversity reducing landscape permeability, leading to habitat loss, and increasing habitat fragmentation, or indirectly, via noise disturbance. This script was used to produce the BExIS 31375 dataset and it calculates the total length of roads (considering different road types; e.g., main roads, tracks, secondary and tertiary roads, etc) at multiple spatial scales (250, 500,1000,1500, 2000) and the distance from all EPs to the closest road (of different types as well).

title: Road density at multiple spatial scales and distance to roads for the 300 forest and grassland EPs
abstract: The presence of roads can direct affect biodiversity reducing landscape permeability, leading to habitat loss, and increasing habitat fragmentation, or indirectly, via noise disturbance. This dataset contains information regarding road density at multiple spatial scales (250, 500,1000,1500, 2000) around grasslands and forests EPs and the distance of EPs to different kinds of roads.

title: Arthropod mediated processes (dung and seed depletion) measured on VIPs (intensively studied plots), time series 2017-2024
abstract:
We investigated the arthropod mediated processes dung depletion and seed removal from 2017-2024 on all VIP (intensively studied plots) plots in all three (Alb, Hainich, Schorfheide) Exploratory regions. The data can be used to e.g. test (i) whether plot-level process rates and their spatial variation differ between forests and semi-natural grasslands, (ii) whether process rates are correlated among each other across sites and iii) whether the rates are affected by climate and land-use intensity at short and medium-term temporal scales.
The data contain the retrieval rates for seeds and dung after approximately 48 h. As potential covariates, vegetation cover, vegetation height and canopy cover are given. For matching with weather/climate data, the exact dates and times of process measurements are included.

title: 'Predation' marks on dummy caterpillars measured on VIPs (intensively studied plots), time series 2017-2024
abstract:
We investigated 'predation' of dummy caterpillars from 2017-2024 on all VIP (intensively studied plots) plots in all three (Alb, Hainich, Schorfheide) Exploratory regions. The data can be used to e.g. test (i) whether 'predation' rates and their spatial variation differ between forests and semi-natural grasslands, (ii) whether 'predation' rates are correlated among each other across sites and iii) whether the rates are affected by climate and land-use intensity at short and medium-term temporal scales.
The data contain the presence/absence of attack marks separated by arthropods, small mammals, birds and snails. As potential covariates, vegetation cover, vegetation height and canopy cover are given. For matching with weather/climate data, the exact dates and times of process measurements are included.

title: Deadwood decomposition under elevated nitrogen deposition
abstract: Elevated nitrogen (N) deposition due to anthropogenic activity is a global phenomeon especially influencing ecosystems that are naturally N limited. We exposed deadwood logs of thirteen temperate tree species to 40 kg ha-1 year-1 of elevated N deposition to investigate long term effects on the decomposition process. Measurements included mass loss (weighting all logs), wood-physicochemical properties (pH, Klason and acid soluble lignin content, dissolved organic C and N, C and N content) and activities of five enzymes involved in deadwood decomposition. The experiment was funded by the DFG priority program 1374.

title: Position of sampling quadrats in SeBAS 2020-2021
abstract: This shapefile contains the position of the 1x1 m quadrats sampled by the SeBAS project during the campaigns June and September 2020-2021. The 10 VIPs of each exploratory were covered each time, plus several EPs covered only once. The dataset can be linked to the field data (ID 31258) with the common field 'Qnum'. Field data was collected simultaneously with UAV flights accessible from the Remote Sensing Database (RSDB, ID 30840).

title: Vegetation summary and biomass data for 150 grassland EPs in 2022 without species identities
abstract:
Long-term monitoring of plants is an important element to assess the effect of grassland land use on the functioning of ecosystems. Plants and their diversity affect other trophic groups and the temporal stability of the plant community is an important indicator of ecosystem functioning. Therefore, we assess the diversity of all vascular plants on all 150 grassland plots from the three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) that differ in land-use intensity, ranging from unfertilized pastures grazed once, to fertilized pastures and meadows grazed heavily or mown repeatedly. 

This dataset is containing general data on land use and vegetation from 2022. These data are the date of survey, vegetation height, the cover of the 4 m x 4 m survey plot (shrubs, herbs, lichens, litter, deadwood, rocks, bare soil), vascular plant species richness, cumulative cover, and dry biomass. 

This dataset doesn't contain individual species identity and cover.

The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Vegetation records for grassland EPs, 2008 - 2022
abstract: Long-term monitoring of plants is an important element to assess the effect of land use in grasslands on the functioning of ecosystems. Plants and their diversity affect other trophic groups and the temporal stability of the plant community is an important indicator of ecosystem functioning. Therefore, we assess the diversity of vascular plants on 150 grassland plots in three German regions (Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) that differ in their management intensity. For this, we estimate the abundance of each plant species on an area of 4 m x 4 m in May/June from 2008 to 2022, which is given in this dataset. From this data, we calculate plant diversity as well as trends and variability of individual plant species over time. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Vegetation records in grassland plotwise sorted over 2008 - 2022 from all regions, biomass included. Document is compiled for farmers and stakeholders (in German)
abstract: To provide long-term trends of plant species on each of the 150 grassland plots from 2008 to 2022, we compiled data of plant cover, cover of functional groups, species richness, and biomass (from data sets 31180 & 31175). In addition, the data set indicates which plant species are regional characteristic species (Kennarten). This dataset is compiled for farmers and stakeholders and provided in three Excel files, one for each region. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Vegetation summary in 2022 without species identities for the new grassland experiment REX and LUX on 45 Grassland EPs
abstract:
Land-use changes are major drivers of plant diversity in grasslands in all three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). However, how effective a reduction in land use intensity is in recovering plant diversity is unclear, and deliberate sowing of some plants may be necessary to restore grassland diversity. Furthermore, different components of land use, e.g. mowing, fertilizing, and grazing, are correlated with each other, and therefore assessing the effect of individual components of land use requires disentangling them experimentally. In the new grassland experiments REX and LUX, we study the effect of reduced land use intensity and seed sowing on plant diversity. For this, we compare factorially combined plots with regular and reduced land use that were seeded or not-seeded with additional plants. Furthermore, we study the effect of individual components of land use. For this, we compare factorially combined plots with regular and reduced land use with or without fertilization.

This dataset is containing general data of the REX (Reduced Land-use Intensity experiment) and the LUX (Land-use experiment) surveys from 2022. These data are the date of survey, vegetation height, the cover of the 2 m x 2 m survey plot (shrubs, herbs, lichens, litter, deadwood, rocks, bare soil), vascular plant species richness, cumulative cover, and dry biomass. 

This dataset doesn't contain individual species identity and cover.

The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Vegetation summary data for 150 forest EPs without species identity, 2022
abstract: Long-term monitoring of plants is an important element to assess the effect of forest management on the functioning of ecosystems. Plants and their diversity affect other trophic groups and the temporal stability of the plant community is an important indicator of ecosystem functioning. Therefore, we assess the diversity of vascular plants on 150 forest plots from three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) that differ in their management, ranging from unmanaged forests, to selection forests, where individual trees are felled individually, to age-class forest. On an area of 20 m x 20 m, on which we estimate the abundance of each plant species, we estimated the cover of bryophytes, litter, rocks, bare soil and deadwood. Moreover, the total number of plant species and the cumulative cover of all plants is given. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Frankia sp. is governing the diazotrophic community composition in deadwood of 13 tree species (diazotrophic community in the active fraction)
abstract:
Deadwood is a nitrogen (N) poor environment and its decomposition rate is limited by N-bioavailability. Diazotrophs can reduce such N-limitations as they are capable to fix N2, which employ the functional gene nifH that encode for dinitrogenase reductase. The present study investigates the diazotrophic community composition and activity, and their relationship to environmental factors and wood parameters of 13 different tree species stored as logs in temperate forests. Directly after sampling, each deadwood sample was incubated with water (total fraction) or bromodeoxyuridine (BrdU), which labeled the metabolically active fraction. Thereafter, nucleic acids extract from both total and active fraction were used to assess the nifH gene-based diversity by amplicon sequencing.
Here, the dataset contain the diazotrophic community of the active fraction in deadwood logs of13 tree species in 9 temperate forest plots (Hainich-Dün exploratory).

The data collection and analysis was part of the project Woodstock (subproject of the BELongDead project) within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Frankia sp. is governing the diazotrophic community composition in deadwood of 13 tree species (raw sequences, total and active fraction)
abstract:
Deadwood is a nitrogen (N) poor environment and its decomposition rate is limited by N-bioavailability. Diazotrophs can reduce such N-limitations as they are capable to fix N2, which employ the functional gene nifH that encode for dinitrogenase reductase. The present study investigates the diazotrophic community composition and activity, and their relationship to environmental factors and wood parameters of 13 different tree species stored as logs in temperate forests. Directly after sampling, each deadwood sample was incubated with water (total fraction) or bromodeoxyuridine (BrdU), which labeled the metabolically active fraction. Thereafter, nucleic acids extract from both total and active fraction were used to assess the nifH gene-based diversity by amplicon sequencing.

Here, the dataset contain the Illumina generated demultiplexed paired-end raw fastq sequences (merged).The obtained combined sequences were initially undergone for quality filtering employing DADA2 algorithm. 

The data collection and analysis was part of the project Woodstock (subproject of the BELongDead project) within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Frankia sp. is governing the diazotrophic community composition in deadwood of 13 tree species (diazotrophic community in the total fraction)
abstract:
Deadwood is a nitrogen (N) poor environment and its decomposition rate is limited by N-bioavailability. Diazotrophs can reduce such N-limitations as they are capable to fix N2, which employ the functional gene nifH that encode for dinitrogenase reductase. The present study investigates the diazotrophic community composition and activity, and their relationship to environmental factors and wood parameters of 13 different tree species stored as logs in temperate forests. Directly after sampling, each deadwood sample was incubated with water (total fraction) or bromodeoxyuridine (BrdU), which labeled the metabolically active fraction. Thereafter, nucleic acids extract from both total and active fraction were used to assess the nifH gene-based diversity by amplicon sequencing. 
Here, the dataset contain the  diazotrophic community of the total fraction in deadwood logs of13 tree species in 9 temperate forest plots (Hainich-Dün exploratory).

The data collection and analysis was part of the project Woodstock (subproject of the BELongDead project) within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Vegetation records in the FOX-experiment in forests, 2020 - 2022
abstract: Open gaps in forest create important habitats for many forest species and offer opportunity for forest regeneration. However, in how far these gaps differ in their effect depending on the former forest management, remains unclear and is often tested in observational studies only. Moreover, the importance of deadwood, which may accumulate in such gaps, for the diversity of other taxa is poorly understood. Therefore, we established a factorially combined forest gap experiment called FOX  (forest gap experiment). On each of 29 forest experimental plot (EPs) (8 in the Schwäbische Alb, 9 in Hainich-Dün, 12 in Schorfheide-Chorin), four plots were created, two of which contained a gap of ca. 20 m diameter, in which all trees were felled, and two plots with non-felled forest. Into half of the plots, deadwood stems were added. Plant diversity was estimated on a subplot of 5 m x 5 m by estimating the abundance of each plant species, including the overhanging trees and shrubs and we provide them in this dataset. From this data, we calculate plant diversity and the changes in vegetation composition over time. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Vegetation records for 151 forest EPs, 2009 - 2022
abstract: Long-term monitoring of plants is an important element to assess the effect of forest management on the functioning of ecosystems. Plants and their diversity affect other trophic groups and the temporal stability of the plant community is an important indicator of ecosystem functioning. Therefore, we assess the diversity of vascular plants on 151 forest plots from three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) that differ in their management, ranging from unmanaged forests, to selection forests, where individual trees are felled individually, to age-class forest. For this, we estimate the abundance of each plant species on an area of 20 m x 20 m both in spring and in summer, separately in different layers (herb layer, shrub layer, tree layer < 10 m, and tree layer > 10 m and provide them in this dataset. From this data, we calculate plant diversity as well as trends and variability of individual plant species over time. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Vegetation summary data in the FOX-experiment in forests without species identity, 2022
abstract: Open gaps in forest create important habitats for many forest species and offer opportunity for forest regeneration. However, in how far these gaps differ in their effect depending on the former forest management, remains unclear and is often tested in observational studies only. Moreover, the importance of deadwood, which may accumulate in such gaps, for the diversity of other taxa is poorly understood. Therefore, we established a factorially combined forest gap experiment called FOX. On each of 29 forest experimental plots (EPs) (8 in the Schwäbische Alb, 9 in Hainich-Dün, 12 in Schorfheide-Chorin), four plots were created, two of which contained a gap of ca. 20 m diameter, in which all trees were felled, and two plots with non-felled forest. Into half of the plots, deadwood stems were added. For an area of 5 x 5 m, on which plant abundances were estimated in summer. We estimated the cover of bryophytes, deadwood, rocks, and bare soil, when they exceeded 5 % of the plot area. In addition, the number of vascular plant species and the cumulative cover is calculated. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Vegetation records in forest plotwise sorted over 2009 - 2022 from all regions. Document is compiled for foresters and stakeholders (in German)
abstract: To provide long-term trends of plant species on each of the 151 forest plots from 2009 to 2022, we compiled data of plant cover, cover of functional groups and species richness (from data sets 31404 and 31395). This dataset is compiled for foresters and stakeholders and provided in three Excel files, one for each region. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Vegetation records 2020-2022 for new grassland experiment REX and LUX
abstract:
Land-use changes are major drivers of plant diversity in grasslands in all three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). However, how effective a reduction in land use intensity is in recovering plant diversity is unclear, and deliberate sowing of some plants may be necessary to restore grassland diversity. Furthermore, different components of land use, e.g. mowing, fertilizing, and grazing, are correlated with each other, and therefore assessing the effect of individual components of land use requires disentangling them experimentally. In the new grassland experiments REX and LUX, we study the effect of reduced land use intensity and seed sowing on plant diversity. For this, we compare factorially combined plots with regular and reduced land use that were seeded or not-seeded with additional plants. Furthermore, we study the effect of individual components of land use. For this, we compare factorially combined plots with regular and reduced land use with or without fertilization.
Plant diversity is recorded on a 2 m x 2 m subplot by estimating the coverage of each species between May and early June from 2020 to 2022. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Plant community-level herbivory rates, plant, herbivore insect, and land-use metrics from the Exploratories, used in "Reductions of invertebrate herbivory due to land use are only partly explained by changes in plant and insect characteristics"
abstract: This is a collated dataset used for the analyses in "Reductions of invertebrate herbivory due to land use are only partly explained by changes in plant and insect characteristics". It contains data on the level of plant communities, i.e. at level of experimental plots (EPs), for both forests and grasslands in all regions of the Biodiversity Exploratories (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün, Schwäbische Alb). For each EP, an average herbivory rate, metrics for taxonomic and functional plant and herbivore insect composition, abundance and diversity are included along with data on land-use intensity (LUI and components in grasslands, ForMI and components in forests). Herbivory rates were measured in 2017–2018, other data come from different years (2008–2018). The data collection/analysis was part of the project FuncNet within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Plant species-level herbivory rates, plant, herbivore insect, and land-use metrics from the Exploratories, used in "Reductions of invertebrate herbivory due to land use are only partly explained by changes in plant and insect characteristics"
abstract: This is a collated dataset, which was used for the analyses in "Reductions of invertebrate herbivory due to land use are only partly explained by changes in plant and insect characteristics". It contains data on the level of plant species, i.e. at the level of 8-10 focal plant species at each experimental plot (EP), for both forests and grasslands in all regions of the Biodiversity Exploratories (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün, Schwäbische Alb). For each focal plant species, an average herbivory rate, metrics for taxonomic and functional plant and herbivore insect composition, abundance and diversity are included along with data on land-use intensity (LUI and components in grasslands, ForMI and components in forests). Herbivory rates were measured in 2017–2018, other data come from different years (2008–2018). The data collection/analysis was part of the project FuncNet within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Fungal communities of BELongDead logs in Hainich 2017(Metaproteomic)
abstract:
In late 2008, the BELongDead (Biodiversity Exploratories Long-term Deadwood) experiment, aimed at investigating the decomposition of deadwood, was initiated. Freshly cut logs from 13 temperate tree species  [eight broadleaved species: Acer sp., Betula sp., Fagus sylvatica, Fraxinus excelsior, Populus spp., Prunus avium, Quercus spp. and Tilia spp., and four conifers: Larix decidua, Picea abies, Pinus sylvestris and Pseudotsuga menziesii] were placed on the forest floor.

To comprehend the key fungal contributors and the specific extracellular lignocellulolytic enzymes they employ in their natural environment, samples were gathered in 2017 from 12 deadwood logs situated on all designated BELongDead "normal plots" after eight years of decomposition. Following the removal of bark, samples were obtained in the form of chips by horizontally driving an auger into the center of each selected log. Microbial communities were analyzed using metaproteomics.

Here, we present the abundances of the observed fungal protein groups. Quantification is based on the normalized spectral abundance factor (NSAF), calculated from peptide spectral matches (PSMs). The functional annotation focused on putative extracellular enzymes involved in lignocellulolysis, categorized according to their active substrate and the CAZy database.

title: Life-history traits of snail species
abstract: This data set contains life-history traits for snail species collected in the grassland and forest plots in all regions (Alb, Hainich, Schorfheide) of the Exploratories. Traits are mostly ordinal or categorical, have been collated from literature, and allow a coarse functional classification of snail assemblages. The following traits are included: Maximum shell size, Shell shape, Character of shell, Sexes, Reproduction, Oviposition, Number of offspring, Inundation tolerance, Humidity preference, Drought resistance and Light preference.

title: Active diazotrophic community in mosses growing on deadwood
abstract:
Mosses rely on nitrogen from external sources, such as the symbiosis with diazotrophs. Diazotrophs fix atmospheric nitrogen and provide it to the moss host. However, research mainly focusses on boreal regions, and mosses from temperate forests are missing.
We determined rates of biological nitrogen fixation, nutrient concentrations and isotopic signatures of two moss species (Brachythecium rutabulum, Hypnum cupressiforme) growing on top of deadwood logs from the BELongDead project from 3 tree species (Fagus, Quercus, Pinus) in the Exploratories (Schorfheide, Hainich-Dün, and Schwäbische Alb) in September and October 2020. 
The data collection and analysis was part of the project Woodstock within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).This dataset was analyzed from the Dataset 31422 and contains the active diazotrophic community (bacteria and archaea) in two mosses across three exploratories.

title: Total diazotrophic community in mosses growing on deadwood
abstract:
Mosses rely on nitrogen from external sources, such as the symbiosis with diazotrophs. Diazotrophs fix atmospheric nitrogen and provide it to the moss host. However, research mainly focusses on boreal regions, and mosses from temperate forests are missing.
We determined rates of biological nitrogen fixation, nutrient concentrations and isotopic signatures of two moss species (Brachythecium rutabulum, Hypnum cupressiforme) growing on top of deadwood logs from the BELongDead project from 3 tree species (Fagus, Quercus, Pinus) in the Exploratories (Schorfheide, Hainich-Dün, and Schwäbische Alb) in September and October 2020.
The data collection and analysis was part of the project Woodstock within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).This dataset was analyzed from the Dataset 31422 and contains the total (active and inactive) diazotrophic community (bacteria and archaea) in two mosses across three exploratories.

title: Raw sequences of total and active diazotrophic community in mosses growing on deadwood
abstract:
Mosses rely on nitrogen from external sources, such as the symbiosis with diazotrophs. Diazotrophs fix atmospheric nitrogen and provide it to the moss host. However, research mainly focusses on boreal regions, and mosses from temperate forests are missing.
We determined rates of biological nitrogen fixation, diazotrophic diversity, nutrient concentrations and isotopic signatures of two moss species (Brachythecium rutabulum, Hypnum cupressiforme) growing on top of deadwood logs from the BELongDead project from 3 tree species (Fagus, Quercus, Pinus) in the Exploratories (Schorfheide, Hainich-Dün, and Schwäbische Alb) in September and October 2020.
The data collection and analysis was part of the project Woodstock within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

This dataset contains the fastq files (forward and reverse after primer removal) which containing the sequence of   active (dataset 31419) and total (dataset 31420) diazotrophic community detected in two mosses across three exploratories.

title: Above- and below-ground trait data for Grasslands EPs plants at the individual level measured in controlled conditions 2017-2018
abstract:
To investigate how the traits of grassland species vary across environmental gradients we measured above- and below-ground traits on the species occurring in the grasslands EPs. Traits were measured on plants grown from seeds.

We conducted three traits screening, (1) on plant and particularly root morphology (2) on rooting depth (3) on nitrate and ammonium update.
For now (August 2020), data on (1) plant morphology and (2) rooting depth are available. Data on (3) Nitrate and ammonium uptake will be added when we receive and clean the data, estimated in Spring 2023

This is the dataset for the traits measured at the individual level (1 value per trait per plant species), by averaging the values of individual replicates for each species.

For the (aggregated) dataset at the species level please refer to dataset ID 26587: https://www.bexis.uni-jena.de/ddm/data/Showdata/26587

The root scans pictures upon which the root traits were calculated for the plant individuals are in dataset 31432	https://www.bexis.uni-jena.de/ddm/data/Showdata/31432	

This dataset contains the unique plant identifier to associate a root scan number to a species, experiment, block replicate and fertilizer treatment (e.g. root scan 228E corresponds to a Thymus pulegioides in high fertilization treatment level in the 2nd replication block).

The detailed description of the variables (header description) is provided in an excel file under "Attachment".

title: Tree and shrub cover in the FOX canopy gaps (G, GD) along a north-south transect in all three regions, 2022
abstract: Various studies showed that plant diversity is not uniformly distributed across forest gaps. Here, we investigated diversity distribution patterns in the experimentally created stand clearances from the FOX experiment (forest gap experiment) in all three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). Vegetation cover estimations of trees and shrubs were conducted on the regeneration subplots which are arranged on a north-south transect. Within the regeneration subplots of 3 m x 4 m, we only surveyed a one-meter-wide band closest to the north-south transect (3 m x 1 m). Tree and shrub cover serve as a proxy for light availability for herbs. Data was collected between June and September 2022. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Spatial species distribution of vascular plants in the FOX canopy gaps (G, GD) along a north-south transect in all regions, 2022
abstract: Various studies showed that plant diversity is not uniformly distributed across forest gaps. Here, we investigated diversity distribution patterns in the experimentally created stand clearances from the FOX experiment (forest gap experiment) in all three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). Vegetation surveys were conducted on the regeneration subplots which are arranged on a north-south transect and included presence/absence data of all plant species that rooted within the subplot. Within the regeneration subplots of 3 m x 4 m, we only sampled a one-meter-wide band closest to the north-south transect (3 m x 1 m). Data was collected between June and September 2022. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Animal mediated processes (seed and prey depletion) in a forest gap experiment (FOX) in 2021
abstract:
We investigated the animal mediated processes seed and prey depletion in July/August 2021 on the experimental plots of the FOX experiment (FOX = forest gap experiment) in all three Exploratories (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin - Germany). The data contain the retrieval rates for seeds (sunflower, beech, oak, pine, spruce) and prey (mealworms) after an exposure time of approximately 24 h.  We analyzed whether food depletion rates differed among food types, FOX experimental treatments , and the three study regions. 
The data collection and analysis were part of the project SMaTI within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Photographs for size data of bumble bees in a feeding experiment
abstract:
We conducted lab experiments to disentangle land-use effects and to validate potential effects of land-use on bumble bee health. Since high land-use intensity is associated with (high) pesticide use and decreasing plant diversity which is in turn the food source for pollinators, we performed feeding experiments with a common pollinator species, Bombus terrestris. Experiments were conducted in behavioral observation rooms at Ulm University between October 2021 and January 2022. In this fulfactorial experiment, bees were treated with either (1) a field realistic dose (5ng per g pollen/nectar) of the neonicotinoid acetamiprid, (2) low quality food (7:3 honeybee collected pollen and pollen exines) or (3) a combination of both. We assessed different health traits individually for each worker and development parameters at colony level. For each worker we recorded the age from hatching to the end, where the respective trait was measured.
Here, we present the photos from which we obtained the body size of bumble bees.

title: Root system scans for grassland species grown individually in pots in a greenhouse for morphological analysis
abstract:
These are the raw data images (root scans) used for the Morphological experiment of the RootFun project.

Note: See dataset ID 31432 for the plant-level root traits derived from these pictures.
-----
The objective was to obtain 2D pictures of young root system for a maximum of herbaceous species occuring in the grassland EPs (grown in controlled conditions from seeds)
-----
From 1 May to 6 October 2017, we performed a glasshouse experiment to measure root-system morphological traits of the study species.
We grew the plants for four weeks only to avoid roots becoming pot-bound, to be able to analyse the entire root systems and to ensure that all the belowground biomass was formed by roots, excluding rhizomes. After washing off the substrate, the root system was cut below the collar and stored for <1 week in a plastic tube filled with distilled water at 4°C.
Then, root systems were spread individually in a thin layer of water in transparent trays (11 × 11 cm) and scanned at 800 dpi with a flatbed scanner modified for root scanning (Epson Expression 10 000 XL and 11 000 XL).

title: Comparision of fungal communities in bark beetle affected and unaffected spruces on HEW51 - taxonomy look-up table
abstract:
In recent years, climate change let to mass infestations of bark beetles with tremendous economic and ecological consequences. Fungi as independent kingdom and as key players in nutrient cycles fulfill important roles in forest ecosystems.
The development of molecular methods like high throughput sequencing and maintained databases facilitate fungal analysis of environmental samples.The main aim of this study was in understanding the impact of bark beetle infection on fungal diversity and communities in soil, litter and wood of infested and not infested Norway spruce trees (Picea abies (L.) H.Karst., Pinaceae). 
In January, 2020, infested and not infested trees were sampled within one forest plot belonging to the Biodioversity Exploratories in Hainich-Dün in Central Germany. Using Illumina MiSeq, the fungal internal transcribed spacer region (ITS) was sequenced and subsequently bioinformatically processed. The complete dataset consists of the obtained fungal matrix and information on taxonomical and functional fungal assignments.

title: Assembled RAW diversity from grassland EPs (2008-2020) for multidiversity synthesis - January 2023
abstract:
A dataset including information on abundance for each single species for all trophic levels in grassland EPs. 

This is an updated and more complete version of datasets 21766, 24606, 25626 and 27707.
This dataset is connected to dataset 31435 (taxonomic, trophic and functional information) by the "Species" column.

The script used to update this dataset from the previous version is available at: https://github.com/biodiversity-exploratories-synthesis/Grassland_diversity_dataset (see scripts description there).
The first lines of the script describe the changes that have been made to the dataset.

Manual. We have prepared a document the describes how to handle the datasets, provides tips and outlines the common issues when analysing the data: https://github.com/biodiversity-exploratories-synthesis/Synthesis_dataset_manual/blob/main/Synthesis%20datasets%20%20How%20to%20use.md

Merge and use. We also provide an R script (ID 22046) to help merging this dataset with dataset 27706 (species information) and calculate various metrics (richness, abundance, diversity and multidiversity. Please consider this script as an example and use it carefully. Many decisions on how to calculate these metrics are dependent on the research question. Please refer to the manual for more information.

IMPORTANT - PLEASE READ CAREFULLY:
- Please read carefully the metadata of each single dataset included in the present dataset before use. Some groups were measured by different researchers with different protocols and different years.
- When aggregating by e.g. Trophic_level, make sure that the information from different groups was collected on the SAME plots. 
- When aggregating, in particular for abundance information, make sure that the methods are comparable.
- For soil bacteria, fungi and protists: we provide the number of OTUs for (e.g.) rarefaction purposes but do not use this as abundance information.
- For soil bacteria and fungi: missing combinations of plots X species are not NAs but zeros, they were not added to the dataset to limit its size (but note that bacteria miss plots AEG33 AEG34, these are NAs).
- For other groups plots with missing information (e.g. non measured plot) were removed from the dataset to reduce its size. For use in matrix format (plot x species) please fill missing information with NA's (and not zeros).
- Ant data is provided as presence/absence but abundance data is also available in BExIS.
- When using information on functional and trophic groups for snails, please cite: 
Falkner, G., Obrdlík, P., Castella, E., Speight, M. C. D. (2001). Shelled Gastropoda of Western Europe. Friedrich-Held-Gesellschaft, Munich.
- Single datasets may contain more information (e.g. birds were also measured at larger spatial scales)
- More detailed information can be found here: https://github.com/biodiversity-exploratories-synthesis/Synthesis-dataset-manual/blob/main/Synthesis%20datasets%20%20How%20to%20use.md

title: Assembled species information from grassland EPs (2008-2020) for multidiversity synthesis - January 2023
abstract:
A dataset including information on each species found in the in grassland EPs. It provides information on broad taxonomic classification, trophic level and functional role of each species.

This is an updated and more complete version of datasets 21726, 25646 and 27706. 
This dataset is connected to dataset 31434 (raw abundance/presence-absence) by the "Species" column.

The script used to update this dataset from the previous version is available at: https://github.com/biodiversity-exploratories-synthesis/Synthesis_dataset_diversity_grassland
The first lines of the script describe the changes that have been made to the dataset.

Manual. We have prepared a document the describes how to handle the datasets, provides tips and outlines the common issues when analysing the data: https://github.com/biodiversity-exploratories-synthesis/Synthesis_dataset_manual/blob/main/Synthesis%20datasets%20%20How%20to%20use.md

Merge and use. We also provide an R script (ID 22046) to help merging this dataset with dataset 31434 (raw abundance/presence-absence) and calculate various metrics (richness, abundance, diversity and multidiversity. Please consider this script as an example and use it carefully. Many decisions on how to calculate these metrics are dependent on the research question. Please refer to the manual for more information.

IMPORTANT - PLEASE READ CAREFULLY: 
- Please read carefully the metadata of each single dataset included in the present dataset before use. Some groups were measured by different researchers with different protocols and different years.
- When aggregating by e.g. Trophic_level, make sure that the information from different groups was collected on the SAME plots.
- When aggregating, in particular for abundance information, make sure that the methods are comparable.
- For soil bacteria, fungi and protists: we provide the number of OTUs for (e.g.) rarefaction purposes but do not use this as abundance information.
