- For soil bacteria and fungi: missing combinations of plots X species are not NAs but zeros, they were not added to the dataset to limit its size (but note that bacteria miss plots AEG33 AEG34, these are NAs).
- For other groups plots with missing information (e.g. non measured plot) were removed from the dataset to reduce its size. For use in matrix format (plot x species) please fill missing information with NA's (and not zeros).
- Ant data is provided as presence/absence but abundance data is also available in BExIS.
- When using information on functional and trophic groups for snails, please cite:
Falkner, G., Obrdlík, P., Castella, E., Speight, M. C. D. (2001). Shelled Gastropoda of Western Europe. Friedrich-Held-Gesellschaft, Munich.
- Single datasets may contain more information (e.g. birds were also measured at larger spatial scales)
- More detailed information can be found here: https://github.com/biodiversity-exploratories-synthesis/Synthesis_dataset_diversity_grassland

title: Landscape structure (composition and configuration) at multiple scales around 150 forest experimental plots (2012/2015/2018)
abstract:
This dataset has information on landscape structure (i.e. composition and configuration) of different land uses surrounding forest experimental plots. The metrics calculated here are the most often used metrics in ecological studies to test the effects of landscape structure on ecological processes.
Data is available for the years 2012, 2015, and 2018, at four spatial scales (500m, 1000m, 1500m, and 2000m) around forest experimental plots.

title: R script used to calculate landscape structure (composition and configuration) at multiple scales around 150 forest experimental plots (2012/2015/2018) (BExIS 31442)
abstract: This code can be used to reproduce the landscape metrics readily available on Bexis 31442 on landscape structure (i.e. composition and configuration) of different land uses surrounding 150 forest experimental plots. For details on metrics, land use classes, and source maps, please check BExIS 31442.

title: Land use intensity (LUI) at the landscape level around 150 grassland experimental plots (2017/2018)
abstract:
A dataset with information on landscape level LUI (i.e. composition and configuration) surrounding grassland EPs and encompassing three classes of LUI: low, high, and very-high. The metrics calculated here are the most used metrics in ecological studies when the goal is to test the effects of landscape structure in ecological processes. 

Data are available for the years 2017 and 2018, at four spatial scales (500m, 1000m, 1500m, and 2000m) around the plots, and the metrics were derived from remote sensed LUI (details in methods).

title: R script to calculate land use intensity (LUI) at the landscape level (composition and configuration) around 150 grassland experimental plots (2017/2018)
abstract: This code can be used to reproduce the landscape metrics readily available on Bexis 31444 on landscape structure (i.e. composition and configuration) of LUI surrounding 150 grassland experimental plots.

title: EP Grassland Landuse Information ALB 2023
abstract:
Information about the land use on the EPs in 2023, based on information given by the farmers or on observations by members of the exploratories.
This file will be updated continuously.
It should be used only for fieldwork planning, NOT FOR ANALYSIS!.

title: Biomass data for grassland EPs, 2009 - 2022
abstract:
To create a dataset of a large-scale long-term time series vegetation biomass, we weighed dry biomass annually from 2009 to 2022 on 150 plots in 3 different regions in Germany (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin).

The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Densities of different meso- and macrofauna taxa in the forest of Schorfheide-Chorin (2018)
abstract:
Here we investigated the taxonomic composition of the soil fauna in the organic layer of three temperate forests, a coniferous (pine) and two deciduous (mixed oak-beech, pure beech) forest stands in the Schorfheide-Chorin region, Germany . Performed was a taxonomic analysis (density, community structure) for different mesofauna (springtails, mites, enchytraeids) and macrofauna taxa (e.g. arachnids, insects, chilopods, diplopods, earthworms, slugs).
The data-sheet shows the distribution of meso- and macrofauna in the organic layer depending from forest type and management intensity. The data collection and analysis were part of the project MicroWeb within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Total lipid fatty acid pattern of different meso- and macrofauna taxa in the forests of Schorfheide-Chorin (2018)
abstract:
Organisms in terrestrial habitats are considered to be significantly less well supplied with omega-3 long-chain polyunsaturated fatty acids (w3 LC-PUFA) as nutritional important molecules. Recent studies report an increasing number of soil invertebrates to synthesize w3 LC-PUFA de novo. However, there are hardly any systematic and comprehensive comparative studies related to this. Here we investigated the community level lipid profiles (CLLP) of the soil fauna in the organic layer of three temperate forests, a coniferous (pine) and two deciduous (mixed oak-beech, pure beech) forest stands in the Schorfheide-Chorin region, Germany. Performed was a biochemical (total lipid fatty acids) analyses for different mesofauna (springtails, mites, enchytraeids) and macrofauna taxa (e.g. arachnids, insects, chilopods, diplopods, earthworms, slugs).
The data-sheet shows the total lipid fatty acid (TLFA) pattern of meso- and macrofauna taxa depending from forest type and management intensity. The data collection and analysis were part of the project MicroWeb within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Landcover in the surrounding of all experimental plots (2016-2018)
abstract: Information on the structure of the landscapes and the land use in the plot surroundings is of great importance for biodiversity research. The dataset provides information on the land cover and land use in the plot surroundings of all experimental plots (EPs) in three different regions in Germany (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). It is based on the ATKIS data and was updated by visual interpretation of high resolution aerial images.

title: Landscape elements in the surrounding of all experimental plots (2016-2018)
abstract: Information on the structure of the landscapes and the land use in the plot surroundings is of great importance for biodiversity research. The GIS dataset provides information on landscape elements such as single trees, tree groups and hedges in the plot surroundings of all experimental plots (EPs) in three different regions in Germany (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). It is based on visual interpretation of high resolution aerial images.

title: Vegetative and phenological traits for five forest understorey herb species grown in a common garden, 2022
abstract: In 2020, we collected individuals of five understorey herbs (Anemone nemorosa, Galium odoratum, Milium effusum, Oxalis acetosella, and Viola reichenbachiana) in all three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Häinich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) on all forest EPs whenever they were present. They were grown in a common garden (Frankfurt, Germany) in 2021 and 2022. The presented measurements (flowering start, plant height, proportion of flowering ramets) are from 2022. The data collection was part of the HerbAdapt project within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Fungal communities of BELongDead logs in Hainich 2017 (ITS amplicon sequencing)
abstract:
In late 2008 the BELongDead (Biodiversity Exploratories Long term Deadwood) experiment for investigating deadwood decomposition was established. Freshly cut logs of 13 temperate tree species [nine broadleaved species: Acer sp., Betula sp., Carpinus sp., Fagus sylvatica, Fraxinus excelsior, Populus spp., Prunus avium, Quercus spp. and Tilia spp., and four conifers: Larix decidua, Picea abies, Pinus sylvestris and Pseudotsuga menziesii] were placed on the forest floor. 

In order to serve as a database for proteomics analyses
wood sampling from these 13 deadwood logs was performed in 2017. After bark removal, samples were collected in the form of chips by driving an auger horizontally to the center of each of the selected logs. Fungal communities were analysed using DNA-amplicon sequencing of the ITS2 region.
 
Here, we provide the abundances of observed fungal ASVs (amplicon sequence variants) of 12 tree species (without Carpinus sp.) that have been used for database construction for proteomics. Data are not rarefied and need to be standardized according to the respective research question.

title: Description of the reduced land-use experiment (REX) and land-use experiment (LUX) in grasslands
abstract: The dataset contains a description of the joint multi-site experiments in grassland: REX (reduced land-use experiment) and LUX (land-use experiment). These experiments were established in all three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) in 2020.

title: Description of the forest gap experiment (FOX)
abstract: The dataset contains a description of the FOrest gap eXperiment (FOX). The experiment was established in all three Biodiversity Exploratories regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) in 2020.

title: Results of the survey "Knowledge Transfer between the Biodiversity Exploratories and Forestry and Nature Conservation Practice" - Part two: stakeholder
abstract:
The overall goal of the KnowledgeTransferProject of the Biodiversity Exploratories (BE) is to foster the bilateral transfer of results, knowledge, and experiences between the BE and forestry and nature conservation practice, and thereby increasing the effectiveness of biodiversity research for biodiversity conservation.

Main objectives of the project:
* to assess and improve the transfer of knowledge between the Biodiversity Exploratories (BE) and the local stakeholders of forestry and nature conservation,
* to identify gaps in current data collection and analyses that preclude comprehensive answers to practice-relevant questions until now,
* to identify new and most urgent practice-relevant research questions.

Methodological approach:
* Anonymous questionnaire with closed respondent groups,
* Specific questionnaire for scientists and stakeholders,
* Online questionnaire via LimeSurvey, 
* Duration: January to May 2018.

This dataset contains for example the anonymized stakeholder survey results, the questionnaire, and some statistics.

The data collection was part of the KnowledgeTransferProject within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Practice-relevant research questions as a result of workshops with scientists and stakeholders
abstract:
The overall goal of the KnowledgeTransferProject of the Biodiversity Exploratories (BE) is to foster the bilateral transfer of results, knowledge, and experiences between the BE and forestry and nature conservation practice, and thereby increasing the effectiveness of biodiversity research for biodiversity conservation.

Main objectives of the project:
* to assess and improve the transfer of knowledge between the Biodiversity Exploratories (BE) and the local stakeholders of forestry and nature conservation,
* to identify gaps in current data collection and analyses that preclude comprehensive answers to practice-relevant questions until now,
* to identify new and most urgent practice-relevant research questions.

This dataset contains the outcome of a workshop at the Waldinfotag Hainich in March 2018 and at the assembly of the BE in March 2019.

The data collection was part of the KnowledgeTransferProject within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Questions for interviews with local stakeholders
abstract:
The overall goal of the KnowledgeTransferProject of the Biodiversity Exploratories (BE) is to foster the bilateral transfer of results, knowledge, and experiences between the BE and forestry and nature conservation practice, and thereby increasing the effectiveness of biodiversity research for biodiversity conservation.

Main objectives of the project:
* to assess and improve the transfer of knowledge between the Biodiversity Exploratories (BE) and the local stakeholders of forestry and nature conservation,
* to identify gaps in current data collection and analyses that preclude comprehensive answers to practice-relevant questions until now,
* to identify new and most urgent practice-relevant research questions.

This dataset contains the question for the the interviews with local stakeholder.

The data collection was part of the KnowledgeTransferProject within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Vegetation summary and biomass data for 150 grassland EPs in 2017 without species identities
abstract:
Long-term monitoring of plants is an important element to assess the effect of grassland land use on the functioning of ecosystems. Plants and their diversity affect other trophic groups and the temporal stability of the plant community is an important indicator of ecosystem functioning. Therefore, we assess the diversity of all vascular plants on all 150 grassland plots from the three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) that differ in land-use intensity, ranging from unfertilized pastures grazed once, to fertilized pastures and meadows grazed heavily or mown repeatedly. 

This dataset is containing general data on land use and vegetation from 2017. These data are the date of survey, vegetation height, the cover of the 4 m x 4 m survey plot (shrubs, herbs, lichens, litter, deadwood, rocks, bare soil), vascular plant species richness, cumulative cover, and dry biomass. 

This dataset doesn't contain individual species identity and cover.

The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Drought responses of 13 common temperate grassland species under different nutrient conditions, common garden experiment in Bayreuth, 2018 /2019, used in: Nutrient effects on drought responses vary across common temperate grassland species
abstract:
We conducted a fully factorial drought-fertilization experiment to examine the effect of  nutrient addition on species' drought survival, and on drought resistance of growth as well as drought legacy effects. 

The experiment was conducted at the Ecological Botanical Garden of the University of Bayreuth, Germany  in 2017-2019 on 13 common temperate grassland species. The drought experiment was conducted 

We conducted a fully factorial drought-fertilization experiment in a common garden setting with four different nutrient conditions: nitrogen addition (N), phosphorus addition (P), combined NP addition and unfertilized control (c) combined with two moisture treatments: irrigated control and drought treatment (56 days drought period). For the drought treatment in half of the boxes, irrigation was discontinued under rainout shelters until most plants showed severe necrosis (56 days, June-August 2018). 

We assessed performance based on growth (during the drought phase) and in the next growing season (post-drought period) and whole-plant drought survival.

Then three different performance parameters were calculated based on growth rates and survival: Drought resistance for growth during the drought period, drought legacy for growth in the post-drought period and drought survival response. 

The data collection was part of the project BETol II  within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories  (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de)

title: Local adaptation of Anemone nemorosa and Milium effusum  in a reciprocal transplant along a forest management intensity gradient, 2021 and 2022
abstract: In 2020, we collected genets of Anemone nemorosa and Milium effusum, from a subset of forests plots along the silvicultural management intensity (SMI) gradient from all three Exploratory regions (Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). Each genet was propagated into four ramets, and reciprocally transplanted sympatrically, near allopatrically, far allopatrically and to a plot where the species did not naturally occur. In 2021 and 2022, the plots were revisited and measurements (number of ramets, proportion of flowering ramets, plant height, phenological sum) were taken. Additionally, in 2022 all above-ground biomass was collected. The data collection was part of the HerbAdapt project within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Root biomass of 150 forest plots, May 2021
abstract: Root biomass was determined in a composite sample, representative of each forest plot. All forest plots' dry fine root and coarse root biomass were measured in three regions in Germany (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) from 4th May to 20th May.

title: Soil water extractable organic carbon, -nitrogen, -phosphorus and specific UV absorption - forest and grassland plots
abstract: Dissolved organic matter plays an important role in the biogeochemical cycles of carbon and nutrients. The dataset contains water extractable organic carbon (WEOC), water extractable organic nitrogen (WEON), water extractable organic phosphorus (WEOP) quantities, as well as specific UV absorbance (SUVA) for 298 experimental plots (EP) topsoils (0-5 cm sampling depth) and 51 VIP subsoils (25 - 30 cm sampling depth).

title: Fine root biomass in the top soil of 150 grassland plots in 2021
abstract: Biomass of fine roots (< 2 mm) was measured within the upper 10 cm of the mineral soil in 150 grassland experimental plots (EP) in three regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin; Germany). Composite sample were mixed from soil taken from 14 single points within a plot. The samples were taken in May 2021. The total soil volume was 2747.5 cm³.

title: Dark carbondioxide fixation in temperate beech and pine forest soils
abstract: Soils are the largest terrestrial organic carbon pool and the largest terrestrial source of atmospheric carbondioxide (CO2). Non-phototrophic CO2 fixation by microbes re-fixes and recycles CO2 respired in soils. Our previous study showed that in temperate deciduous forest soil profiles, rates of dark CO2 fixation were proportional to microbial biomass, irrespective of soil depth. However, the amount and quality of organic matter entering different soil depths vary for different temperate forest types and these influence microbial communities with unknown consequences for CO2 fixation rates. To test whether differences in the amount and quality of SOC caused by tree species affect dark CO2 fixation rates with depth, we conducted a study using acidic soils from two forest plots from the Schorfheide-Chorin Exploratory, Germany. These soils, dominated by either beech (deciduous) or pine (coniferous) tree stands differ in their SOC content and quality. We traced the incorporation of 2% (v:v) 13C–CO2 label into microbial biomass and estimated the CO2 fixation rates relative to microbial biomass carbon content (in μg C g MBC−1 d−1) across the soil profiles. Data provided include CO2 fixation rates per unit soil dry weight and per unit of microbial biomass carbon.

title: Identification of microbial communities that dominate temperate beech and pine forest soil profiles
abstract: We aim to determine the bacterial community composition and their abundance across beech and pine dominated soil profiles of the Schorfheide-Chorin Exploratory forest area in December 2018. Data provided include phylum-level abundance of each bacteria community and their relative abundance in percent (%).

title: Quantification of bacterial abundance and metabolic potential for dark carbondioxide fixation in temperate beech and pine forest soils
abstract: We aim to determine differences in the abundance and metabolic potential for carbondioxide (CO2) fixation among bacterial communities between beech and pine-dominated soils in the Schorfheide-Chorin Exploratory forest region in December, 2018.  Gene abundances of bacterial 16S rRNA, RuBisCO and rTCA cycle genes were determined by quantitative PCR (qPCR). Additionally, PICRUSt2 predictions was used to predict genes for key enzymes involved in chemolithoautotrophic and non-autotrophic CO2 fixation or anaplerotic reactions for all 16S rRNA bacterial OTUs present in both the beech and pine-dominated forest plots in SEW 49 and SEW 17, respectively.  Data provided include Shannon diversity index, bacterial 16S rRNA gene abundance, and abundance of RuBisCO (cbbL IA, cbbL IC, cbbM genes), rTCA cycle (aclA gene), and PEPC/PC genes.

title: Collembola traits from all grassland plots 2018
abstract:
To assess assembly processes based on functional traits along land use gradients and the resilience of functional groups after disturbance morphological and life history traits were compiled. 

The data is based on the Collembola species list of the Fauna Inventory from  2018 of all grassland experimental plots from from three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) to understand soil fauna community assembly and resilience dependence on land use.

title: Full genome and 16S rRNA sequences for Baekduia alba 0141_2T
abstract:
Strain 0141_2T was isolated from a temperate grassland soil in Germany and was found to be affiliated with the order Solirubrobacterales. Both full genome and 16S rRNA sequences from this strain were ascertained and deposited at GeneBank.
The GenBank/EMBL/DDBJ accession numbers for the 16S rRNA gene sequence and draft genome sequence of Baekduia alba 0141_2T are ON980755 and CP114013, respectively.

title: 3rd forest inventory, single tree data, on all forest EPs, 2020 - 2023
abstract:
The “3rd forest inventory at the experimental plot level” was conducted 5 to 6 years after the 2nd inventory in all three Exploratories (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). It serves to quantify forest productivity, forest dynamcis, forest management interventions, and changes in forest structure and land use intensity. 
This dataset comprises original data on species, diameter at breast height, tree heigth, wood volume and geographical location (caliper limit: dbh >= 7 cm).

title: Arthropod abundances from grassland sweep net samples since 2008
abstract: Arthropods have been sampled on all 150 grassland EP plots from 2008 to provide data for various analysis, e.g. effects of land use on arthropods. The dataset contains data from 2008-2022. Further years will be added as soon as samples are getting processed. For identified taxa from the same samplings please see dataset 21969. The exact sampling dates are available in dataset 17018.

title: Behavioural observations of a bumblebee and syrphid fly species in the Schwäbische Alb, 2021
abstract: Behavioural observations of pollinators are commonly used as a proxy for pollinator foraging performance and the provision of pollination services. We observed Bombus lapidarius and Episyrphus balteatus individuals in the field to invistigate potential direct or indirect effects of land-use intensity on their foraging behaviour or plant choice. The study was conducted on 43 experimental grassland plots of the Schwäbische Alb region in June and July 2021. We recorded the behaviour of a total of 307 Bombus lapidarius workers on 27 plots and 325 Episyrphus balteatus individuals on 34 plots.

title: Recordings of relative plot flower cover in the Schwäbische Alb, 2021
abstract: We made surveys of total plot flower cover and relative cover of individual plant species on plots where we conducted behavioural observations of Bombus lapidarius and Episyrphus balteatus to discover possible indirect effects of land-use on pollinator behaviour via plant diversity and abundance. We recorded 91 different plant species on 43 experimental grassland plots of the Schwäbische Alb region between mid of June and end of July 2021.

title: Data and code for the manuscript Freitag et al. 'Increasing plant species richness by seeding has marginal effects on ecosystem functioning in agricultural grasslands'
abstract: This is the data and code to reproduce the analysis of the manuscript Freitag et al. 'Increasing plant species richness by seeding has marginal effects on ecosystem functioning in agricultural grasslands'. The data comes as a .zip folder of a RStudio project with data (in the data/ folder), R scripts  (in the R/ folder).

title: Fragaria vesca microbiome experiment 2021 - Main dataset including single plant and plant community scans and associated bacterial and fungal ASVs and taxonomy
abstract:
Land-use intensity affects the diversity and composition of communities, ecosystem functioning, and plant phenotypes. Furthermore, direct effects of land-use on the diversity of plant-associated bacteria have been demonstrated, which, in turn, may affect the plant phenotype. Previous correlational findings suggest that plant-associated bacteria may mediate the relationship between plant species diversity and ecosystem functions.
 
Using the framework of the common garden at the University of Marburg with plant communities from all three Exploratories, Fragaria vesca plants were grown for 3 months, serving as phytometers to test whether microbes mediate land use effects on plant phenotypes and performance as well as ecosystem functions.To test for a mediation of land-use effects on the phenotype via the microbiome, we assessed bacterial and fungal communities on the F. vesca plants (next-generation 16SrRNA gene amplicon sequencing of leaf and root samples) and captured the phenotype of the plants through single-plant phenotyping with a customized plant phenotyping system. Furthermore, a subsequent lab experiment where we inoculated seed-sterilized Fragaria vesca plants that have grown in a sterile environment with the ‘treatment-specific’ microbiome of the field Fragaria vesca plants was supposed to validate any correlative findings on the relationship of microbiome and plant phenotype through direct experimental results. These lab Fragaria vesca plants were also scanned with the digital phenotyping system after 3 months of growth after the inoculation.

This dataset contains 13 morphological and physiological parameters from digital phenotyping of plant communities, field Fragaria vesca plants and lab Fragaria vesca plants as well as manually measured performance proxies (herbivory, fruit set, vegetative reproduction) of the field Fragaria vesca plants.

Files in the attachment section of this dataset contain the counts and taxonomy of bacterial and fungal ASVs from leaf and root samples of Fragaria vesca plants.
Bacterial_ASVs.csv: Bacterial ASV counts from leaf and root samples.
Bacterial_ASVs_taxonomy.csv: Taxonomy of bacterial ASVs.
Fungal_ASVs.csv: Fungal ASV counts from leaf and root samples.
Fungal_ASVs_taxonomy.csv: Taxonomy of fungal ASVs.

The data collection and analysis was part of the project EXClAvE within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Topographical parameters (slope, aspect, elevation) for all forest and grassland experimental plots (EP)
abstract: This dataset provides topography data, namely slope, aspect, and elevation for all experimental plots (EP) in three regions of Germany (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). The dataset is a public version of dataset 11603. The original dataset 11603 contains the exact coordinates of the plots. These coordinates are considered as sensitive information; therefore, the original dataset is not publicly available. Furthermore, the present dataset contains, in contrast to dataset 11603, only the EPs (not the GPs) and the EP IDs were added. The original data have been derived from a digital terrain model which is provided in dataset 10022.

title: List of synthesis proposals in the Biodiversity Exploratories
abstract: The dataset contains an overall overview of all proposed synthesis ideas inside the Exploratories project. The status of the proposal is updated yearly by BEO. Please contact BEO with any needed additions, updates, questions, or remarks.

title: Taxonomy table of fungal ASVs from bark samples; 146 EPs, May 2022
abstract: Bark surfaces are large components of forest ecosystems, that through their longevity and seasonal stability, provide an ideal habitat suitable for microbial communities. Here we provide a comprehensive study of the bark surface microbiome of Central European forests and what drives its diversity and composition. We examine algal, fungal and bacterial communities and their interactions using metabarcoding. The data includes samples from 146 experimental plots (EPs) and was collected in May 2022. This is a taxonomy table of fungal ASVs obtained by Illumina MiSeq 2x300 bp after sample inference with DADA2, detection of potential contaminants with the decontam R package and curation of similar ASVs with LULU. The data collection/analysis was part of the project SYMBIODRIVE within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de)

title: Taxonomy table of algal ASVs from bark samples; 146 EPs, May 2022
abstract: Bark surfaces are large components of forest ecosystems, that through their longevity and seasonal stability, provide an ideal habitat suitable for microbial communities. We examine algal, fungal and bacterial communities and their interactions using metabarcoding. The data includes samples from 146 experimental plots (EPs) and was collected in May 2022. This is a taxonomy table of algal ASVs obtained by Illumina MiSeq 2x300 bp after sample inference with DADA2, detection of potential contaminants with the decontam R package and curation of similar ASVs with LULU. The data collection/analysis was part of the project SYMBIODRIVE within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de)

title: Land-use intensity index (LUI) calculation tool of the Biodiversity Exploratories project for grassland survey data from three different regions in Germany since 2006
abstract: The land-use intensity (LUI) index summarizes three land-use components which are yearly surveyed by the LMTs (land management teams) for each grassland plot i: fertilization (Fi), mowing (Mi), and grazing (Gi). Here we provide the link to the tool that calculates the LUI index.  The tool is publicly available on the BExIS website under the menu item "Tools" (https://www.bexis.uni-jena.de/). The data basis of this tool (dataset 25086) is updated annually.

title: The HAInich: A multidisciplinary vision data-set for a better understanding of the forest ecosystem
abstract: This is a multidisciplinary forest ecosystem 3D perception dataset. The dataset was collected in the Hainich-Dün region in central Germany, which includes two dedicated areas, which are part of the Biodiversity Exploratories - a long term research platform for comparative and experimental biodiversity and ecosystem research. The dataset combines several disciplines, including computer science and robotics, biology, bio-geochemistry, and forestry science. We present results for common 3D perception tasks, including classification, depth estimation, localization, and path planning. We combine the full suite of modern perception sensors, including high-resolution fisheye cameras, 3D dense LiDAR, differential GPS, and an inertial measurement unit, with ecological metadata of the area, including stand age, diameter, exact 3D position, and species. The dataset consists of three hand held measurement series taken from sensors mounted on a UAV during each of three seasons: winter, spring, and early summer. This enables new research opportunities and paves the way for testing forest environment 3D perception tasks and mission set automation. We do not focus on even more accurate and better forest data collection, our focus is automated forest inventory for robots.

title: BE fieldwork overview table - previous phases
abstract: During the year 2019 assembly, there was an increasing request for tables containing who does what on which plots and when. These tables were set up then in the context of the discussion and group meetings on the various topics. For a better overview, we compiled a table with all fieldwork done in the previous phases, if the data is available.

title: BE fieldwork overview table - 7th phase
abstract: In the course of the 18th BE-Assembly in 2021, there was an increasing request for tables containing who does what on which plots and when. For the 7th phase, all projects provided information about their planned fieldwork.

title: Bird survey and trait data on all grassland and forest EPs 2018
abstract:
Birds were surveyed during breeding time (March to June 2018) as count data. 

Birds heard or seen were assigned to various distance classes: 1 = 0-10 m, 2 = 10-25 m, 3 = 25-50 m, 4 = 50-100 m, 5 = 100-200 m, 6 = 200-500 m (only grassland). It was also assessed if the bird was within the EP or outside the EP.  

Birds flying over and migrating birds were excluded from the dataset.

title: Microbial communities in deadwood of 13 temperate tree species after nine years of elevated N deposition
abstract: Enhanced nitrogen (N) deposition due to anthropogenic combustion of fossil fuels and agricultural fertilization is a global phenomenon which has severely altered carbon (C) and N cycling in forest ecosystems in the northern hemisphere. Although deadwood holds a substantial amount of C in forest ecosystems and thus plays a crucial role in nutrient cycling, the effect of increased N deposition on microbial processes and communities, wood chemical traits and deadwood mass loss remains unclear. Here, we simulated high N deposition rates by adding reactive N in form of ammonium-nitrate (40 kg N ha-1 yr-1) to deadwood of 13 temperate tree species over nine years in a field experiment in Germany and sequenced the microbial and fungal communities to look for any shifts in community composition. Non-treated deadwood from the same logs served as control with background N deposition. The experiment was funded by the DFG priority program 1374.

title: Fungal communities in deadwood of 13 temperate tree species after nine years of elevated N deposition
abstract: Enhanced nitrogen (N) deposition due to anthropogenic combustion of fossil fuels and agricultural fertilization is a global phenomenon which has severely altered carbon (C) and N cycling in forest ecosystems in the northern hemisphere. Although deadwood holds a substantial amount of C in forest ecosystems and thus plays a crucial role in nutrient cycling, the effect of increased N deposition on microbial processes and communities, wood chemical traits and deadwood mass loss remains unclear. Here, we simulated high N deposition rates by adding reactive N in form of ammonium-nitrate (40 kg N ha-1 yr-1) to deadwood of 13 temperate tree species over nine years in a field experiment in Germany and sequenced the microbial and fungal communities to look for any shifts in community composition. Non-treated deadwood from the same logs served as control with background N deposition. The experiment was funded by the DFG priority program 1374.

title: Bryophyt, lichen, vascular plant inventory on dead-wood of the BELongDead in 2020
abstract: The BELongDead experiment was conceived in 2008 under the direction of Prof. E. D. Schulze (MPI Biogeochemistry Jena) with the intention to monitor the impact of habitats on the dead wood decomposition processes and to observe colonization patterns of various saproxylic organisms over long time. Here abundance data of vascular plants, bryophytes and lichens were sampled in August and September of 2020 on all dead-wood logs of the BELongDead Experiment on several forest experimental plots (VIPs) in three German Regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin.

title: ASV read numbers of fungal soil samples; selected EPs Schorfheide-Chorin and Swabian Alb, May 2022
abstract:
Trees interact with fungi in mutualistic, saprotrophic, and pathogenic relationships. With their extensive aboveground and belowground structures, trees provide diverse habitats for fungi. Thus, tree species identity is an important driver of fungal community composition in forests. Here we investigate how forest habitat (bark surface vs. soil) and tree species identity (deciduous vs. coniferous) affect fungal communities in two Central European forests. We assess differences and interactions between fungal communities associated with bark surfaces and soil, in forest plots dominated either by Fagus sylvatica, Picea abies, or Pinus sylvestris in two study regions in southwestern and northeastern Germany. Our study suggests that habitat (bark versus soil) and tree species identity are important factors structuring fungal communities in temperate European forests. The aboveground (bark-associated) fungal community is currently poorly known, including a high proportion of reads assigned to “unknown Ascomycota” or “unknown Dothideomycetes.” The role of bark as a habitat and reservoir of unique fungal diversity in forests has been underestimated.

The data includes fungal ASVs from soil samples of 89 experimental plots (EPs) and was collected in May 2022. The primary data contains a long format table of ASVs and their read count per sample. In the attachments is a Sample x ASV table with read numbers obtained by Illumina MiSeq 2x300 bp after sample inference with DADA2, detection of potential contaminants with the decontam R package and curation of similar ASVs with LULU.  The data collection/analysis was part of the project SYMBIODRIVE within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de)

title: Animal data from thesis and paper: "Opening up new niche dimensions: The stoichiometry of soil microarthropods in European beech and Norway spruce forests"
abstract: Data retrieved for studying the elemental composition of soil mite taxa in beech and spruce forests. Samples were taken in autumn 2021 on eight forest experimental plots in the Hainich Dün region (HEW 1, 3, 5, 6, 13, 17, 21, 51). The tables contain the measured element concentrations for the collected taxa. The motivation was to investigate niche differentiation in soil mites in different forest types to find possible explanations for the high number of species in a homogeneous habitat such as the soil.

title: Litter data from thesis and paper: "Opening up new niche dimensions: The stoichiometry of soil microarthropods in European beech and Norway spruce forests"
abstract: Data retrieved for studying the elemental composition of soil mite taxa in beech and spruce forests. Samples were taken in autumn 2021 on eight forest experimantal plots in the Hainich Dün region plots (HEW 1, 3, 5, 6, 13, 17, 21, 51). The tables contain the measured element concentrations for the collected litter. The general motivation was to investigate niche differentiation in soil mites in different forest types to find possible explanations for the high number of species in a homogeneous habitat such as the soil. In order to do this, litter data (this dataset) was needed to asses the stoichiometry of the resource the animals use.

title: Stable isotope data for thesis and paper: "Opening up new niche dimensions: The stoichiometry of soil microarthropods in European beech and Norway spruce forests"
abstract: Data retrieved for studying the elemental composition of soil mite taxa in beech and spruce forests. Samples were taken in autumn 2021 on eight Forest experimental plots in the Hainich Dün region (HEW 1, 3, 5, 6, 13, 17, 21, 51). The tables contain the measured stable isotope data. The motivation was to investigate niche differentiation in soil mites in different forest types to find possible explanations for the high number of species in a homogeneous habitat such as the soil. To investigate possible correlations between trophic height and stoichiometry of the animals, stable isotope ratios (this dataset) were measured.

title: Assembled ecosystem measures from forest EPs (2008-2021) for multifunctionality synthesis - revised in August 2023
abstract: The Synthesis Core team aims to facilitate synthesis with data from the Biodiversity Exploratories. One tool to achieve this is the generation and sharing of Biodiversity Exploratories Synthesis datasets, which combine information about different biodiversity and ecosystem functions components across plots. This dataset combines proxies of ecosystem functions measured by several different projects in forests, including both raw measurements and cross-year plot averages. The datasets used (primary data) were collected from 2010  to 2021 on all 150 forest experimental plots (EPs) across the Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün, and Schwäbische Alb regions, although some variables were measured in a subset of plots. The dataset is complemented with a detailed description of the source dataset, sampling procedure and coverage, synthesis calculations, variable units and ecological meaning of each forest function (“Synthesis_Forest_Function_Metadata.xlsx”) and an R script to transform the dataset from long to wide format - see attachments. The Synthesis Core team also provided a manual on how to use synthesis datasets (https://github.com/biodiversity-exploratories-synthesis/Synthesis_dataset_manual).

title: Age and stem anatomical traits of multiple forb species for all grassland EP`s (collected between 2017-2019)
abstract:
Life span of plants is a key demographic trait important for the life history of plant species, the persistence and stability of plant populations and plant species` responses to environmental changes. However, information on the longevity of plant individuals (or ramets) and specifically its variation dependent on environmental conditions such as land use or regional differences in climatic conditions is not available for a large number of grassland species. Stem anatomical traits related to functions such as transport, storage and mechanical support are largely ignored in ecological studies of herbaceous species and therefore it is not known how sensitively these traits respond to variation in environmental conditions. 
The data contain the age and stem anatomical traits of perennial dicotyledonous forb species collected on all grassland experimental plots  (EP) in the three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) between 2017 and 2019 (one visit per plot) by collecting five individuals of all forb species with a cover of at least 1% in the vegetation records of this particular grassland EP. The age was determined by counting growth rings at the oldest part of plant samples (root crown, or distal part of stolons or rhizoms) in thin cross sections made with a microtome; the width of the stem anatomical tissues (diameter of the pith, and width of phellem, cortex, phloem, xylem and individual growth rings) was also measured at the cross sections. The data collection was part of the project ForbAge within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Age and stem anatomical traits of Galium mollugo (collected between 2017-2019 in three regions of Germany)
abstract:
Life span of plants is a key demographic trait important for the life history of plant species, the persistence and stability of plant populations and plant species` responses to environmental changes. However, information on the longevity of plant individuals (or ramets) and specifically its variation dependent on environmental conditions such as land use or regional differences in climatic conditions is not available for a large number of grassland species. Stem anatomical traits related to functions such as transport, storage and mechanical support are largely ignored in ecological studies of herbaceous species and therefore it is not known how sensitively these traits respond to variation in environmental conditions. 
The data contain the age and stem anatomical traits of Galium mollugo, which was sampled with 20 individuals in 64 populations (in four cases with less individuals) located on grassland experimental plots (EP) in the three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) chosen to represent different land-use intensities in each region to get an estimate of age distribution within populations. The age was determined by counting growth rings at the oldest part of plant samples (root crown, or distal part of rhizoms) in thin cross sections made with a microtome; the width of the stem anatomical tissues (diameter of the pith, and width of phellem, cortex, phloem, xylem and individual growth rings) was also measured at the cross sections. The data collection was part of the project ForbAge within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Age and stem anatomical traits of three common forb species (collected between 2017-2019)
abstract:
Life span of plants is a key demographic trait important for the life history of plant species, the persistence and stability of plant populations and plant species` responses to environmental changes. However, information on the longevity of plant individuals (or ramets) and specifically its variation dependent on environmental conditions such as land use or regional differences in climatic conditions is not available for a large number of grassland species. Stem anatomical traits related to functions such as transport, storage and mechanical support are largely ignored in ecological studies of herbaceous species and therefore it is not known how sensitively these traits respond to variation in environmental conditions. 
The data contain the age and stem anatomical traits of three common grassland species (Achillea millefolium, Plantago lanceolata and Trifolium pratense), which were sampled with 20 individuals in appr. 60 populations per species located on grassland experimental plots (EP) in the three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) chosen to represent different land-use intensities in each region to get an estimate of age distribution within populations. The age was determined by counting growth rings at the oldest part of plant samples (root crown, or distal part of rhizoms) in thin cross sections made with a microtome; the width of the stem anatomical tissues (diameter of the pith, and width of phellem, cortex, phloem, xylem and individual growth rings) was also measured at the cross sections. The data collection was part of the project ForbAge within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: ITS2 DNA metabarcoding of wild bee pollen loads, collected in 2020 and 2021 across all three exploratories
abstract:
This dataset includes the results of wild bee pollen loads for 57 Plots across all three exploratories, with 19 plots in the Schwäbische Alb, 19 plots in Hainich-Dün and 19 plots in Schorfheide-Chorin. Wild bees were sampled in 2020 and 2021  (Based on Dataset id: 31131). Bees were caught in a transect walk along the edges of the 50 * 50 m plots, and once 50 m outside the plot, totalling to 250 m transect within one hour. In addition, we did a targeted sampling around the plots. Plots were chosen based on their land-use index, to have a range from low to high land-use intensity. 

Pollen loads were separated from each individual and later pooled per explo, plot and bee species, with a min of 3 and a maximum of 14 individuals per pool. Each pollen pool was then processed in a molecular lab, extracting DNA and amplifying the ITS2 gene region to gain relative read abundance for plant amplicon sequence variants (ASVs).

title: The interplay of landscape composition and configuration on social bee pollinators fitness
abstract: Insect-mediated pollination is critical for pollination ecosystem services to crops and wild plants, in which bees play a major role. Bee populations are declining as well as biodiversity in farmlands, largely due to land use change and habitat loss. Managing agricultural landscapes to support biodiversity and ecosystem services is a major topic in the research agenda of the 21st century. However, the interplay of landscape composition and configuration and its impact on population dynamics remains poorly explored for insects, particularly for bees. Here, we used mechanistic models to simulate population dynamics of four social bee species (Apis mellifera, Bombus spp.) along combined gradients of landscape composition (floral abundance) and configuration (fragmentation). Overall, all species were significantly? affected by both landscape metrics, with a higher importance of fragmentation and honey bees outperforming bumble bees. Interestingly, the effect of fragmentation on bee fitness was stronger under low floral abundance. These results suggest that in simple and flower-poor landscapes, increasing landscape fragmentation could represent a suitable recommendation for the conservation of social bee pollinators in farmlands.

title: Quadrant plant diversity 2021
abstract: We performed transect walks in the edges of plots using quadrants of 1m x 1m to count flowering plant species and with that be able to calculate plant diversity for each plot. The measurements where done approximately once a month when we visited plot for bee netting, during April-September 2021. The plants where identified with field guides and a minority of them were barcoded using ITS2 to identify them to species level. Yet several of them remain as NA when not identified.

title: Land classification in an area of 500 m2 around plots based on remote sensing data
abstract: We used existing image databases to quantify the area of each land use type and calculate a diversity index for land use heterogeneity. We have plots in Belgium as well as the Biodiversity Exploratories. The land cover data in Germany were classified into two schemes (geometric property and attribute property). The attribute property contained unique plot numbers and corresponding class descriptions, while three fields in the data represented feature descriptions using code numbers. To quantify the diversity in land use around the plot we extracted the percentage of area that each land use type occupies in 500 m around the center where our transects were placed, for each plot visited .

title: Fungal community composition at forest VIPs in mineral containers and soil samples - ASV taxonomic look-up table
abstract: This dataset is part of the BEMins project, studying the co-formation of goethite- and illite-associated organic matter and microorganisms. To gain knowledge about fungal colonization of the mineral surfaces, we applied amplicon sequencing to mineral containers and surrounding soils in all three regions, Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, and Schorfheide-Chorin. Samples were taken in August 2020. This dataset contains the look-up table for the ASV counts.

title: Fungal community composition at forest VIPs in mineral containers and soil samples - ASV reads
abstract: This dataset is part of the BEMins project, studying the co-formation of goethite- and illite-associated organic matter and microorganisms. To gain knowledge about fungal colonization of the mineral surfaces, we applied amplicon sequencing to mineral containers and surrounding soils in all three regions, Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, and Schorfheide-Chorin. Samples were taken in August 2020. This dataset contains the ASV reads.

title: Fungal community composition at forest VIPs in mineral containers and soil samples - Illumina MiSeq raw data external link
abstract: This external link is part of the BEMins project, studying the co-formation of goethite- and illite-associated organic matter and microorganisms. To gain knowledge about fungal colonization of the mineral surfaces, we applied amplicon sequencing to mineral containers and surrounding soils in all three regions, Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, and Schorfheide-Chorin. Samples were taken in August 2020. This dataset contains the external link to the raw sequencing data uploaded at NCBI.

title: Vegetation records 2020-2023 for new grassland experiment REX and LUX
abstract:
Land-use changes are major drivers of plant diversity in grasslands in all three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). However, how effective a reduction in land use intensity is in recovering plant diversity is unclear, and deliberate sowing of some plants may be necessary to restore grassland diversity. Furthermore, different components of land use, e.g. mowing, fertilizing, and grazing, are correlated with each other, and therefore assessing the effect of individual components of land use requires disentangling them experimentally. In the new grassland experiments REX and LUX, we study the effect of reduced land use intensity and seed sowing on plant diversity. For this, we compare factorially combined plots with regular and reduced land use that were seeded or not-seeded with additional plants. Furthermore, we study the effect of individual components of land use. For this, we compare factorially combined plots with regular and reduced land use with or without fertilization.
Plant diversity is recorded on a 2 m x 2 m subplot by estimating the coverage of each species between May and early June from 2020 to 2023. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Vegetation summary in 2023 without species identities for the new grassland experiment REX and LUX on 45 Grassland EPs
abstract:
Land-use changes are major drivers of plant diversity in grasslands in all three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). However, how effective a reduction in land use intensity is in recovering plant diversity is unclear, and deliberate sowing of some plants may be necessary to restore grassland diversity. Furthermore, different components of land use, e.g. mowing, fertilizing, and grazing, are correlated with each other, and therefore assessing the effect of individual components of land use requires disentangling them experimentally. In the new grassland experiments REX and LUX, we study the effect of reduced land use intensity and seed sowing on plant diversity. For this, we compare factorially combined plots with regular and reduced land use that were seeded or not-seeded with additional plants. Furthermore, we study the effect of individual components of land use. For this, we compare factorially combined plots with regular and reduced land use with or without fertilization.

This dataset is containing general data of the REX (Reduced Land-use Intensity experiment) and the LUX (Land-use experiment) surveys from 2023. These data are the date of survey, vegetation height, the cover of the 2 m x 2 m survey plot (shrubs, herbs, lichens, litter, deadwood, rocks, bare soil), vascular plant species richness, cumulative cover, and dry biomass. 

This dataset doesn't contain individual species identity and cover.

The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Vegetation records for grassland EPs, 2008 - 2023
abstract: Long-term monitoring of plants is an important element to assess the effect of land use in grasslands on the functioning of ecosystems. Plants and their diversity affect other trophic groups and the temporal stability of the plant community is an important indicator of ecosystem functioning. Therefore, we assess the diversity of vascular plants on 150 grassland plots in three German regions (Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) that differ in their management intensity. For this, we estimate the abundance of each plant species on an area of 4 m x 4 m in May/June from 2008 to 2023, which is given in this dataset. From this data, we calculate plant diversity as well as trends and variability of individual plant species over time. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Vegetation summary and biomass data for 150 grassland EPs in 2023 without species identities
abstract:
Long-term monitoring of plants is an important element to assess the effect of grassland land use on the functioning of ecosystems. Plants and their diversity affect other trophic groups and the temporal stability of the plant community is an important indicator of ecosystem functioning. Therefore, we assess the diversity of all vascular plants on all 150 grassland plots from the three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) that differ in land-use intensity, ranging from unfertilized pastures grazed once, to fertilized pastures and meadows grazed heavily or mown repeatedly. 

This dataset is containing general data on land use and vegetation from 2023. These data are the date of survey, vegetation height, the cover of the 4 m x 4 m survey plot (shrubs, herbs, lichens, litter, deadwood, rocks, bare soil), vascular plant species richness, cumulative cover, and dry biomass. 

This dataset doesn't contain individual species identity and cover.

The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Biomass data for grassland EPs, 2009 - 2023
abstract:
Long-term monitoring of plant biomass is an important element to assess the productivity of grasslands. To create a dataset of a large-scale long-term time series vegetation biomass, we weighed dry biomass annually from 2009 to 2023 on 150 grassland plots in 3 different regions in Germany (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). These grasslands differed in land-use intensity, ranging from unfertilized pastures grazed once to fertilized pastures and meadows grazed heavily or mown repeatedly.

The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Audio database of the Biodiversity Exploratories (AudioDB)
abstract: AudioDB provides an archive of audio recordings of the acoustic environment. One area of focus is on the sounds of animal activities, especially birds, bats and orthoptera. The audio archive covers three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). The database was developed in the core project Instrumentation & remote sensing within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Compiled trait data of saproxylic beetles
abstract:
Trait data used in “Effects of heterogeneity on the ecological diversity and redundancy of forest fauna”.

This study investigated the effects of different facets of heterogeneity in forest stands, i.e. deadwood, plant diversity, forest stand structure, and micro-scale topography, on the ecological (functional-phylogenetic) diversity and redundancy.

This dataset was used to calculate a functional-distance matrix and, together with the corresponding phylogenies, phylogenetic-functional-distance matrix for all saproxylic beetle species.

All information on trait data was compiled from literature.
It was available for 515 species.

The data collection/analysis was part of the project TreeScape within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Compiled trait data of phytophagous beetles
abstract:
Trait data used in “Effects of heterogeneity on the ecological diversity and redundancy of forest fauna”.

This study investigated the effects of different facets of heterogeneity in forest stands, i.e. deadwood, plant diversity, forest stand structure, and micro-scale topography, on the ecological (functional-phylogenetic) diversity and redundancy.

This dataset was used to calculate a functional-distance matrix and, together with the corresponding phylogenies, phylogenetic-functional-distance matrix for all phytophagous beetle species.

All information on trait data was compiled from literature.

It was available for 293 species.


The data collection/analysis was part of the project TreeScape within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Compiled trait data of necrophagous beetles
abstract:
Trait data used in “Effects of heterogeneity on the ecological diversity and redundancy of forest fauna”.

This study investigated the effects of different facets of heterogeneity in forest stands, i.e. deadwood, plant diversity, forest stand structure, and micro-scale topography, on the ecological (functional-phylogenetic) diversity and redundancy.

This dataset was used to calculate a functional-distance matrix and, together with the corresponding phylogenies, phylogenetic-functional-distance matrix for all necrophagous beetle species.

All information on trait data was compiled from literature.
It was available for 40 species.


The data collection/analysis was part of the project TreeScape within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

used in “Effects of heterogeneity on the ecological diversity and

title: Species data for oribatid mites from 48 forest plots sampled in three-year intervals from 2008 to 2020
abstract: Key belowground ecosystem services, such as litter decomposition and carbon and nitrogen cycling, are intrinsically linked to the functioning of aboveground systems (Bardgett and van der Putten, 2014) and are largely facilitated by microorganisms and microarthropods, such as oribatid mites (Oribatida: Acari) (Petersen and Luxton, 1982; Schaefer, 1991). Studies on the temporal dynamics of arthropods have reported alarming declines in the local biomass and diversity of European insects. Thus, there is an urgent need to determine whether belowground communities are following similar declines compared to those observed in aboveground communities, and to disentangle the drivers and potential threats that shape soil microarthropod communities (Geisen et al., 2019; Tibbett et al., 2020). Thus, we collected oribaitd mites in three-year intervals from 2008 to 2020 in 48 forest sites, with 16 sites in each of the three Exploratories (see study design for details). Species occurrences are given for each site and year. The data collection was part of the LitterLinks project within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Vegetation summary data for 150 forest EPs without species identity, 2023
abstract: Long-term monitoring of plants is an important element to assess the effect of forest management on the functioning of ecosystems. Plants and their diversity affect other trophic groups and the temporal stability of the plant community is an important indicator of ecosystem functioning. Therefore, we assess the diversity of vascular plants on 150 forest plots from three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) that differ in their management, ranging from unmanaged forests, to selection forests, where individual trees are felled individually, to age-class forest. On an area of 20 m x 20 m, on which we estimate the abundance of each plant species, we estimated the cover of bryophytes, litter, rocks, bare soil and deadwood. Moreover, the total number of plant species and the cumulative cover of all plants is given. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Vegetation records for 151 forest EPs, 2009 - 2023
abstract: Long-term monitoring of plants is an important element to assess the effect of forest management on the functioning of ecosystems. Plants and their diversity affect other trophic groups and the temporal stability of the plant community is an important indicator of ecosystem functioning. Therefore, we assess the diversity of vascular plants on 151 forest plots from three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) that differ in their management, ranging from unmanaged forests, to selection forests, where individual trees are felled individually, to age-class forest. For this, we estimate the abundance of each plant species on an area of 20 m x 20 m both in spring and in summer, separately in different layers (herb layer, shrub layer, tree layer < 10 m, and tree layer > 10 m and provide them in this dataset. From this data, we calculate plant diversity as well as trends and variability of individual plant species over time. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Vegetation records in grassland plotwise sorted over 2008 - 2023 from all regions, biomass included. Document is compiled for farmers and stakeholders (in German)
abstract: To provide long-term trends of plant species on each of the 150 grassland plots from 2008 to 2023, we compiled data of plant cover, cover of functional groups, species richness, and biomass (from data sets 31579 and 31580). In addition, the data set indicates which plant species are regional characteristic species (Kennarten). This dataset is compiled for farmers and stakeholders and provided in three Excel files, one for each region. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Vegetation records in forest plotwise sorted over 2009 - 2023 from all regions. Document is compiled for foresters and stakeholders (in German)
abstract: To provide long-term trends of plant species on each of the 151 forest plots from 2009 to 2023, we compiled data of plant cover, cover of functional groups and species richness (from data sets 31623 and 31614). This dataset is compiled for foresters and stakeholders and provided in three Excel files, one for each region. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: UAV LiDAR point clouds (leaf-off 2023) for all forest experiments and neighbouring EPs
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) or drones equipped with a LiDAR sensor provide highly dense pointclouds which can be used to analyze the 3D representation of forest. The flight campaign were conducted in Februray and March 2023 und leaf-off conditiona and covered all forest experiments and neighbouring EPs in the three Exploratories (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb; Germany).

title: Assembled ecosystem measures from grassland EPs (2008-2018) for multifunctionality synthesis - June 2020
abstract: The Synthesis Core team aims to facilitate synthesis with data from the Biodiversity Exploratories. One tool to achieve this is the generation and sharing of Biodiversity Exploratories Synthesis datasets, which combine information about different biodiversity and ecosystem functions components across plots. This dataset combines proxies of ecosystem functions measured by several different projects in grasslands, including both raw measurements and combined proxies as e.g. soil Nitrate fluxes. The synthesised datasets (primary data) were collected during 2008 to 2018, on all 150 grassland EPs. The dataset is complemented (attachments) with a detailed description of the source of each proxy (attached metadata), a R script to reshape the dataset from long to wide format and a README with detailed description of all attachments. Externally, we provide a manual of use (https://github.com/biodiversity-exploratories-synthesis/Synthesis_dataset_manual). We welcome any feedback via GitHub issues (https://github.com/biodiversity-exploratories-synthesis) or contact Email.

title: Fragaria vesca microbiome experiment 2021 - Bacterial ASVs
abstract:
It is known that land-use intensity affects the diversity and composition of communities as well as ecosystem functioning and also the plant phenotype. Furthermore, direct effects of land-use on the diversity of plant-associated bacteria have been demonstrated, which, in turn, may affect the plant phenotype. Previous correlational findings suggest that plant-associated bacteria may mediate the relationship between plant species diversity and ecosystem functions. 
Making use of the framework of the previously established common garden at the University of Marburg with plant communities from all three Exploratories (for more information also see dataset id: 31267), for this experiment Fragaria vesca plants were growing in the common garden for 3 months, serving as phytometers to test whether microbes mediate land use effects on plant phenotypes and performance as well as ecosystem functions.
To test for a mediation of land-use effects on the phenotype via the microbiome, we assessed bacterial and fungal communities on the F. vesca plants (next-generation 16SrRNA gene amplicon sequencing of leaf and root samples) and captured the phenotype of the plants through single-plant phenotyping with a customized plant phenotyping system (for more information see dataset id: 31269). Furthermore, a subsequent lab experiment where we inoculated seed-sterilized Fragaria vesca plants that have grown in a sterile environment with the ‘treatment-specific’ microbiome of the field Fragaria vesca plants was supposed to validate any correlative findings on the relationship of microbiome and plant phenotype through direct experimental results. These lab Fragaria vesca plants were also scanned with the digital phenotyping system after 3 months of growth after the inoculation.
This dataset contains bacterial ASVs from Fragaria vesca leaf and root samples, the same data as the attachment 'Bacterial_ASVs.csv' that can be found at the dataset # 31497: "Fragaria vesca microbiome experiment 2021/2022 - Main dataset containing single plant (field and lab) and whole plant community scans etc. + attached datasets with bacterial and fungal ASVs and associated taxonomy".
This dataset contains the counts of bacterial ASVs from leaf and root samples of Fragaria vesca plants that have been growing in plant communities in the common garden for 3 months and were subjected to different land-use treatments (no treatment, mowing, fertilization, mowing & fertilization). Microbial DNA was extracted using the ZymoBIOMICS DNA Miniprep Kit following the manufacturers’ instructions. We analyzed the microbiome samples by next-generation sequencing and microbiome profiling of isolated DNA was performed on the Qiita web platform, where bacterial ASVs were obtained using Deblur. Raw sequences can be found on the ENA (European Nucleotide Archive) under study accession ERP137704 (http://www.ebi.ac.uk/ena/data/view/ERP137704).
The data collection and analysis was part of the project EXClAvE within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

'Fungal_ASVs_taxonomy.csv' This dataset contains the taxonomy to fungal ASVs from Fragaria vesca leaf and root samples.
The data collection and analysis was part of the project EXClAvE within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Litter and fertilizer effects on seedling traits (two-leaf biomass, seedling height and specific leaf area) as obtained in a common garden experiment for 75 grassland species used in the seed addition plots of the REX experiment
abstract:
Agricultural grasslands play an important role in conserving the biodiversity of the European cultural landscape. Both, litter cover and soil nutrient availability are well-known factors that change with grassland management, but it is not well-studied how the germination and seedling growth of multiple grassland species are influenced by their single or combined effects. 
We studied the effects of fertilization (100 kg N per year and ha) and litter cover (250 gdw per m2) on seedling traits: time until two leaves developed, seedling height, SLA and biomass at the two-leaf stage. For this, we examined 75 temperate grassland species (16 grass species, 51 forb species, 8 legume species) which were sown as single species in a full factorial microcosm experiment. The microcosm experiment was part of the project SeedDiv within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Soil extractable organic carbon and extractable total nitrogen – soil sampling campaign 2021, all grassland experimental plots (EPs), 0-10 cm
abstract: The project SCALEMIC measured for all 150 grassland Experimental plots (EPs) the extractable organic carbon (EOC) and extractable total nitrogen (ETN). Soil samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). EOC and ETN represent the mobile C and N in soil and which is a fraction of the total soil organic C and total N (for these data please see data ID 31730). EOC and ETN are considered being the part of soil C and N which is available for soil microorganisms. EOC and ETN was extracted with 0.5 M K2SO4 from soils taken during the soil sampling campaign 2021 from 0-10 cm soil depth. This dataset contains the mass of EOC and ETN per gram dry soil. Sample and data collection was within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (MA4436/1-5, KA1590/8-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Soil mineral nitrogen (Nmin) of all grassland plots, Soil sampling campaign (SSC) 2021
abstract:
The SCALEMIC project measured for all 150 grassland Experimental plots (EPs)  extractable ammonium (NH4+) and nitrate (NO3-) of soil samples taken during the soil sampling campaign 2021 from 0-10 cm soil depth. These are important data for farmers, which need them for the calculation of the maximal allowed N fertilization amount at their grassland sites.
Soil samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb).
Sample and data collection was within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (MA4436/1-5, KA1590/8-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Single chemical compound data of cuticular surface of bumblebees at grassland plots in 2020
abstract: To analyse the effects of land-use intensity on the chemical surface profile of bumblebees, we analysed cuticular chemical surface extracts of Bombus lapidarius workers deriving from three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). We used chemical surface profiles as a proxy for fitness, since they play an important role in colony maintenance in bumblebees. Chemical communication is very important in bumblebees, because important behavioral patterns like mating, dominance and the fertility status of individuals are represented by their individual chemical profile. In total, we analysed 1023 surface extracts of Bombus lapidarius workers from 126 different plots. In the present dataset, relative amounts of each single scent compound is presented.

title: Genotyping by sequencing data of European beech populations of selected plots in the Biodiversity Exploratories (2021)
abstract: European beech is negatively affected by climate. Despite the importance of this species, knowledge of genetic adaptation and especially the genetic basis of tree physiological traits is scarce. We used genotyping by sequencing to identify Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms (SNPs) in 43 German European beech populations growing under different environmental conditions and to identify SNPs involved in adaptation. DNA was isolated from leaf material (collected in 2020) and Illumina sequencing was conducted. This data set comprises the raw sequencing reads, which are deposited in NCBI SRA. The project was funded by the German Federal Ministry of Food and Agriculture (BMEL) and the German Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation, Nuclear Safety, and Consumer Protection (BMUV) represented by the Fachagentur Nachwachsende Rohstoffe (FNR) within the framework of the Waldklimafonds (projects BEECHLIMITS (reference number: 22WC415001) and GenVarBuche (reference number: 2218WK34A4). Further,the work has been partly funded by the DFG Priority Program 1374 "Biodiversity-Exploratories" (GENEDIV, project number 433288081).

title: Soil mineral nitrogen (Nmin) of REX 1 and LUX grassland plots, Soil sampling campaign (SSC) 2021
abstract:
The SCALEMIC project measured for selected plots of the land-use intensity experiment (REX) and land-use experiment (LUX) extractable ammonium (NH4+) and nitrate (NO3-) of soil samples taken during the soil sampling campaign 2021 from 0-10 cm soil depth. These are important data for farmers, which need them for the calculation of the maximal allowed N fertilization amount at their grassland sites.
Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Sample and data collection was within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (MA4436/1-5, KA1590/8-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Soil extractable organic carbon and extractable total nitrogen of REX 1 and LUX grassland plots, Soil sampling campaign (SSC) 2021
abstract: The SCALEMIC project measured for selected plots of the the land-use intensity experiment (REX) and land-use experiment (LUX) the extractable organic carbon (EOC) and extractable total nitrogen (ETN) in 0.5 M K2SO4 extracts of soil samples taken during the soil sampling campaign 2021 from 0-10 cm soil depth. EOC and ETN represent the mobile C and N in soil and represent a fraction of the total soil organic C and total N (see data set 31730).
