EOC and ETN are considered being available for soil microorganisms. This dataset contains the EOC and ETN related on gram dry soil. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Sample and data collection was within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (MA4436/1-5, KA1590/8-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Microbial biomass C (Cmic) and N (Nmic) and soil microbial C to N ratio of all grassland plots, Soil sampling campaign (SSC) 2021
abstract: Data on soil microbial biomass carbon and nitrogen (Cmic, MBC and Nmic, MBN) measured by chloroform-fumigation extraction in soils from all grassland experimental plots (EPs) collected during the soil sampling campaign 2021.

title: Microbial biomass C (Cmic) and N (Nmic) and soil microbial C to N ratio of grassland experimental plots REX 1 and LUX, Soil sampling campaign (SSC) 2021
abstract: Data on soil microbial biomass carbon and nitrogen (Cmic, MBC and Nmic, MBN) measured by chloroform-fumigation extraction in soils from all REX (Reduced Land-use Intensity experiment) and LUX (Land-use experiment) plots collected during the soil sampling campaign 2021.

title: Fungal communities BEShortDead: ITS amplicon sequencing of wood blocks in forest and grassland experimental plots (EPs)
abstract:
In 2017, woodblocks (1 cm x 2.5 cm x 10 cm) of beech (Fagus sylvatica), pine (Pinus sylvestris) and spruce (Picea abies) were exposed on each experimental plot (EP) in Hainich, Swabian Alb and Schorfheide for ~1 year to follow mass loss and related wood-colonizers.
Fungal communities were analysed using DNA-amplicon sequencing of the ITS2 region. Here, we provide the abundances of observed fungal OTUs (operational taxomic units). Data is not rarefied and need to be standardized according to the respective research question.

title: Pesticides in soil and biomass of forest and grassland experimental plots in 2021
abstract: Pesticides are used in agriculture to control weeds, insect infestation and diseases. These substances can also get into the grassland and forest in the surrounding area. Together with the JKI (Julius Kühn-Institut, Bundesforschungsinstitut für Kulturpflanzen) we analyzed soil and biomass samples from all grassland and forest Experimental Plots (EP) of the three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) in 2021 for fungicides, insecticides, and herbicides.

title: Soil pH - soil sampling campaign 2023, all experimental plots (EPs), 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides essential information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the soil pH values in 0-10 cm depth from all Experimental Plots (EPs) in 2023. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil pH is considered a master variable in soil science as it affects many chemical processes in soils. Most importantly, the plant nutrient availability is greatly affected by the soil pH as it controls the chemical forms of the different nutrients and influences the chemical reactions they undergo. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-5, TR 1054/4-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Soil carbon, nitrogen and sulfur concentrations - soil sampling campaign 2023, all experimental plots (EPs), 0-10 cm
abstract:
The core project Soil provides essential information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all 300 Experimental Plots (EPs) of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the organic carbon (OC), inorganic carbon (IC), total nitrogen (TN) and total sulfur (TS) concentrations, and carbon to nitrogen ratios (CN ratio) as well as carbon to sulfur ratios (CS ratio)  in 0-10 cm depth from all EPs in 2023. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil organic carbon, nitrogen and sulfur concentrations are master variables in soil science. They are the measureable components of soil organic matter (SOM). SOM exerts positive effects on numerous physical, chemical and biological soil properties. An increase in SOM generally results in an improved soil structure, soil moisture retention, soil buffering capacity, retention of pollutants, cycling and storage of plant nutrients and biodiversity. SOM also acts as a sink and source for atmospheric carbon dioxide.

The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-5, TR 1054/4-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Sampling protocol - soil sampling campaign 2023, all experimental plots (EPs), organic layer + 0-10 cm
abstract:
The core project Soil provides essential information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all 300 Experimental Plots (EPs) of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the three sampling protocols of the coordindated soil sampling for the EPs, the REX-LUX experiment, and the FOX experiment. Together with core projects 8, 1 and 2 (Microorganisms, BEO; LMTs), we organized the 4th soil sampling campaign on all 300 Experimental Plots of the Exploratories in May 2023. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). At all plots composite samples from the mineral soil (0-10 cm depth) were sampled. At all forest plots additional samples from the organic layer were taken. We used the same sampling design as in 2011, 2014, 2017, 2021 to allow comparisons with previous soil samplings campaigns.
The soil sampling protocol considered the requirements of each of the 12 participating soil groups. Approximately 60 people from 4 core projects and 8 contributing projects were involved in the fieldwork.

The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-5, TR 1054/4-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Bacterial communities BEShortDead: 16S amplicon sequencing of wood blocks in forest and grassland experimental plots (EPs)
abstract:
In 2017, woodblocks (1 cm x 2.5 cm x 10 cm) of beech (Fagus sylvatica), pine (Pinus sylvestris) and spruce (Picea abies) were exposed on each experimental plot (EP) in Hainich, Swabian Alb and Schorfheide for ~1 year to follow mass loss and related wood-colonizers.
Wood-colonizing bacterial communities were analysed using DNA-amplicon sequencing of the 16S region. Here, we provide the abundances of observed bacterial OTUs (operational taxomic units). Data is not rarefied and need to be standardized according to the respective research question.

title: Gene abundances 16S Bacteria, nirK, nirS, nosZ clade I, II, soil sampling campaigns (SSC) 2011, 2014, 2017
abstract: We determined the abundances of functional genes of denitrifying bacteria in soils of all grassland EPs collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil samples of the top 10 cm were taken during the soil sampling campaigns 2011, 2014 and 2017. qPCR data on gene abundances of total bacteria (16S rRNA) and functional genes of soil denitrifying bacteria (nirK, nirS, nosZ clade I and nosZ clade II) measured for centrally extracted DNA from the soil sampling campaigns 2011, 2014 and 2017 (0-10 cm soil depth). Sample and data collection was within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (MA4436/1-2to4, KA1590/8-2to4, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Canopy openness of forest plots (2014, 2019, 2023)
abstract:
Canopy Openness describes the average light availability on the ground of a forest stand, with values ranging from 0 % (no sky visible) to 100 % (no plant material visible).
The data was collected on 151 forest plots in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hanich-Dün und Schwäbsiche Alb) and is available for the years 2014, 2019 and 2023 (leaf-on).

title: Stand Structural Complexity Index (SSCI) - Forest plots - 2014, 2019, 2023
abstract:
The Stand Structural Complexity Index (SSCI) is an approach based on fractal dimensions to quantify the structural complexity of forest stands. It is based on the three-dimensional spatial arrangement of all above-ground tree components and makes it possible to analyze relationships between management types, forest structure, biodiversity and ecosystem functions objectively and efficiently. The higher the value of the SSCI, the greater the complexity of the stand.
The data was collected on 151 forest plots in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hanich-Dün und Schwäbsiche Alb) and is available for the years 2014, 2019 and 2023 (leaf-on).

title: Effective Number of Layers (ENL) - Forest plots - 2014, 2019, 2023
abstract:
Based on terrestrial laser scanning data (TLS), the index quantifies vertical stand structure by applying the inverse Simpson-Index to the vertical distribution of points in 3D space. Index values increase with increasing stand height and a more even occupation of 3D space by foliage, branches and stems along the vertical axis. 
The data was collected on 151 forest plots in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hanich-Dün und Schwäbsiche Alb) and is available for the years 2014, 2019 and 2023 (leaf-on).

title: Data and RCode used in Andraczek et al. 2024: "Weak reciprocal relationships between productivity and plant biodiversity in managed grasslands"
abstract: To study the causal effects between biodiversity and productivity we collected seasonal data of both biodiversity and productivity and potential confounding variables (environmental and land-use related variables) in all 150 EP plots across the three regions of the Biodiversity Exploratories (i.e. Schorfheide-Chorin, Swabian Alb and Hainich-Dün) in both spring and summer of 2020 and 2021. This dataset comprises variables collected by the BEF-Loops project (funded by DFG: Nr. 433266560, Exploratories project phase Nr. PL 891/3-1) and other projects within the Biodiversity Exploratories.

title: Soil carbon, nitrogen and sulfur concentrations - soil sampling campaign 2021, all experimental plots (EPs), 0-10 cm
abstract:
The core project Soil provides essential information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all 300 Experimental Plots (EPs) of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the organic carbon (OC), inorganic carbon (IC), total nitrogen (TN) and total sulfur (TS) concentrations, and carbon to nitrogen ratios (CN ratio) as well as carbon to sulfur ratios (CS ratio)  in 0-10 cm depth from all EPs in 2021. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil organic carbon, nitrogen and sulfur concentrations are master variables in soil science. They are the measureable components of soil organic matter (SOM). SOM exerts positive effects on numerous physical, chemical and biological soil properties. An increase in SOM generally results in an improved soil structure, soil moisture retention, soil buffering capacity, retention of pollutants, cycling and storage of plant nutrients and biodiversity. SOM also acts as a sink and source for atmospheric carbon dioxide.

The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-4, TR 1054/4-4, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Gravimetric soil water content - soil sampling campaign 2023, all experimental plots (EP), 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides essential information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all 300 experimental plots (EPs) of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the gravimetric soil water contents and dry matter contents in 0-10 cm depth from all EPs in 2023. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil water content has a dominant influence on plant growth, soil temperature, transport of chemical compounds, ground water recharge and soil aeration. The gravimetric soil water content is the mass of water in the soil, measured as the weight difference between the moist and the oven-dry soil. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-5, TR 1054/4-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Input data of all grassland plots for Land-Use Intensity Index (LUI) calculation tool since 2006 - revised 2023
abstract: The data is derived from the land use survey. These are annual interviews with all grassland land owners/users in three regions of Germany: Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, and Schorfheide-Chorin (dataset 23746). This dataset contains the values for the land management components mowing, grazing, and fertilization, which are the input data for the LUI (land-use intensity) calculation Tool.

title: Soil enzyme activities - soil sampling campaign 2023, all forest experimental plots (EP), 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides essential information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all 300 experimental plots (EPs) of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the soil enzyme activities  in 0-10 cm depth from all forest EPs in 2023. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil enzymes play an important role in nutrient turnover in forest ecosystems as they are responsible for the conversion of organic matter into plant-available nutrients. We measured the activities of key enzymes involved in N, C, P, and S cycling. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-5, TR 1054/4-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Viral prevalence in Bombus lapidarius and Episyrphus balteatus in three regions of the Biodiversity Exploratories
abstract: In the HealthyPollination project, we wanted to know how land-use intensity in grasslands and land-use in the surrounding landscape affects pollinator health and pollination services in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Here, we analysed viral infections in two important pollinator species, Bombus lapidarius and Episyrphus balteatus, since viral infections are a good proxy for the health status of those pollinators. Based on sequencing of sample pools, we identified possible candidate viruses and screened for those in each sample. We focused on the two bumblebee-specific viruses Slow Bee Paralysis Virus (2 different strains) and Black Queen Cell Virus and three different syrphid fly viruses, namely a Jingmenvirus, a Birnavirus and a Alphamesonivirus. In total, we screened 1046 bumblebees and 998 syrphid flies from 139 individual plots, which were caught between May and July 2020. The following dataset presents presence-absence-data of viral infections for each species and each virus.

title: Body size and body surface pollen data of two pollinator species, Bombus lapidarius and Episyrphus balteatus, in three regions of the Biodiversity Exploratories
abstract: In the HealthyPollination project, we wanted to know how land-use intensity in grasslands and land-use in the surrounding landscape affects pollinator health and pollination services in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Here, we analysed body size of two important pollinator species, Bombus lapidarius and Episyrphus balteatus, since body size plays a crucial role in foraging and food provisioning in social insects. As a proxy for body size, wing measurements were taken of both forewing. Furthermore, we analyzed the body surface pollen, because it is relevant for pollination. To do so, we sampled pollen from the body surface of each individual using gelatine cubes. We analyzed the identity and frequency of pollen grains to the lowest possible identification level (species, genus, family or pollen class type) with an automated method for pollen identification. In total, we screened 1046 bumblebees and 998 syrphid flies from 141 individual plots, which were caught between May and July 2020. The following dataset presents data on body size (centroid size of right and left wings) and data on body surface pollen (amount of pollen grains, pollen species richness and its diversity).

title: Behavioural observations of bumblebees in a semi-field experiment
abstract:
We conducted semi-field experiments to disentangle links between land-use associated stressors, pollinator health and pollination services. Both the use of pesticides and the limitation of floral resources are main stressors causing pollinator declines in land-use intensive areas. Therefore, we treated two common pollinators species, the bumblebee Bombus terrestris and the syrphid fly Episyrphus balteatus with either (1) a field realistic dose (5ng per g pollen/nectar) of the neonicotinoid acetamiprid, (2) low quality food (7:3 honeybee collected pollen and pollen exines) or (3) a combination of both. Experiments were conducted in rearing chambers and insect flight cages in the Botanical Garden of Ulm University between March and July 2022. For both species, we assessed various  health traits and parameters associated with the provision of pollination services like foraging behaviour or pollen deposition.
Here, we conducted behavioural observations of the bumblebee B. terrestris foraging on potted plants in a flight cage.

title: Behavioural observations of syrphid flies in a semi-field experiment
abstract:
We conducted semi-field experiments to disentangle links between land-use associated stressors, pollinator health and pollination services. Both the use of pesticides and the limitation of floral resources are main stressors causing pollinator declines in land-use intensive areas. Therefore, we treated two common pollinators species, the bumblebee Bombus terrestris and the syrphid fly Episyrphus balteatus with either (1) a field realistic dose (5ng per g pollen/nectar) of the neonicotinoid acetamiprid, (2) low quality food (7:3 honeybee collected pollen and pollen exines) or (3) a combination of both. Experiments were conducted in rearing chambers and insect flight cages in the Botanical Garden of Ulm University between March and July 2022. For both species, we assessed various health traits and parameters associated with the provision of pollination services like foraging behaviour or pollen deposition.
Here, we conducted behavioural observations of the syrphid fly E. balteatus foraging on potted plants in a flight cage.

title: Colony development and food consumption of bumblebees in a semi-field experiment
abstract:
We conducted semi-field experiments to disentangle links between land-use associated stressors, pollinator health and pollination services. Both the use of pesticides and the limitation of floral resources are main stressors causing pollinator declines in land-use intensive areas. Therefore, we treated two common pollinators species, the bumblebee Bombus terrestris and the syrphid fly Episyrphus balteatus with either (1) a field realistic dose (5ng per g pollen/nectar) of the neonicotinoid acetamiprid, (2) low quality food (7:3 honeybee collected pollen and pollen exines) or (3) a combination of both. Experiments were conducted in rearing chambers and insect flight cages in the Botanical Garden of Ulm University between March and July 2022. For both species, we assessed various health traits and parameters associated with the provision of pollination services like foraging behaviour or pollen deposition.
Here, we analysed colony development (worker production) and food consumption of the bumblebee B. terrestris.

title: Health traits of bumblebees in a semi-field experiment
abstract:
We conducted semi-field experiments to disentangle links between land-use associated stressors, pollinator health and pollination services. Both the use of pesticides and the limitation of floral resources are main stressors causing pollinator declines in land-use intensive areas. Therefore, we treated two common pollinators species, the bumblebee Bombus terrestris and the syrphid fly Episyrphus balteatus with either (1) a field realistic dose (5ng per g pollen/nectar) of the neonicotinoid acetamiprid, (2) low quality food (7:3 honeybee collected pollen and pollen exines) or (3) a combination of both. Experiments were conducted in rearing chambers and insect flight cages in the Botanical Garden of Ulm University between March and July 2022. For both species, we assessed various health traits and parameters associated with the provision of pollination services like foraging behaviour or pollen deposition.
Here, we analysed various health traits of B. terrestris. workers, including body size, wing asymmetry and ovary development.

title: Pollen deposition of bumblebees on stigmata after a single floral visit in a semi-field experiment
abstract:
We conducted semi-field experiments to disentangle links between land-use associated stressors, pollinator health and pollination services. Both the use of pesticides and the limitation of floral resources are main stressors causing pollinator declines in land-use intensive areas. Therefore, we treated two common pollinators species, the bumblebee Bombus terrestris and the syrphid fly Episyrphus balteatus with either (1) a field realistic dose (5ng per g pollen/nectar) of the neonicotinoid acetamiprid, (2) low quality food (7:3 honeybee collected pollen and pollen exines) or (3) a combination of both. Experiments were conducted in rearing chambers and insect flight cages in the Botanical Garden of Ulm University between March and July 2022. For both species, we assessed various health traits and parameters associated with the provision of pollination services like foraging behaviour or pollen deposition.
Here, we analysed the amount of pollen transfered to stigmata by foraging bumblebee workers after a single floral visit.

title: Ovary development of syrphid flies in a sem-field experiment
abstract:
We conducted semi-field experiments to disentangle links between land-use associated stressors, pollinator health and pollination services. Both the use of pesticides and the limitation of floral resources are main stressors causing pollinator declines in land-use intensive areas. Therefore, we treated two common pollinators species, the bumblebee Bombus terrestris and the syrphid fly Episyrphus balteatus with either (1) a field realistic dose (5ng per g pollen/nectar) of the neonicotinoid acetamiprid, (2) low quality food (7:3 honeybee collected pollen and pollen exines) or (3) a combination of both. Experiments were conducted in rearing chambers and insect flight cages in the Botanical Garden of Ulm University between March and July 2022. For both species, we assessed various health traits and parameters associated with the provision of pollination services like foraging behaviour or pollen deposition.
Here, we dissected ovaries of the syrphid fly E. balteatus to analyse their reproductive state.

title: Survival probability of syrphid flies in a semi-field experiment
abstract:
We conducted semi-field experiments to disentangle links between land-use associated stressors, pollinator health and pollination services. Both the use of pesticides and the limitation of floral resources are main stressors causing pollinator declines in land-use intensive areas. Therefore, we treated two common pollinators species, the bumblebee Bombus terrestris and the syrphid fly Episyrphus balteatus with either (1) a field realistic dose (5ng per g pollen/nectar) of the neonicotinoid acetamiprid, (2) low quality food (7:3 honeybee collected pollen and pollen exines) or (3) a combination of both. Experiments were conducted in rearing chambers and insect flight cages in the Botanical Garden of Ulm University between March and July 2022. For both species, we assessed various health traits and parameters associated with the provision of pollination services like foraging behaviour or pollen deposition.
Here, we analysed the survival probabilty of the syrphid fly E. balteatus.

title: Vegetation records in the FOX-experiment in forests, 2020 - 2023
abstract: Open gaps in forest create important habitats for many forest species and offer opportunity for forest regeneration. However, in how far these gaps differ in their effect depending on the former forest management, remains unclear and is often tested in observational studies only. Moreover, the importance of deadwood, which may accumulate in such gaps, for the diversity of other taxa is poorly understood. Therefore, we established a factorially combined forest gap experiment called FOX  (forest gap experiment). On each of 29 forest experimental plot (EPs) (8 in the Schwäbische Alb, 9 in Hainich-Dün, 12 in Schorfheide-Chorin), four plots were created, two of which contained a gap of ca. 20 m diameter, in which all trees were felled, and two plots with non-felled forest. Into half of the plots, deadwood stems were added. Plant diversity was estimated on a subplot of 5 m x 5 m by estimating the abundance of each plant species, including the overhanging trees and shrubs and we provide them in this dataset. From this data, we calculate plant diversity and the changes in vegetation composition over time. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Vegetation summary data in the FOX-experiment in forests without species identity, 2023
abstract: Open gaps in forest create important habitats for many forest species and offer opportunity for forest regeneration. However, in how far these gaps differ in their effect depending on the former forest management, remains unclear and is often tested in observational studies only. Moreover, the importance of deadwood, which may accumulate in such gaps, for the diversity of other taxa is poorly understood. Therefore, we established a factorially combined forest gap experiment called FOX. On each of 29 forest experimental plots (EPs) (8 in the Schwäbische Alb, 9 in Hainich-Dün, 12 in Schorfheide-Chorin), four plots were created, two of which contained a gap of ca. 20 m diameter, in which all trees were felled, and two plots with non-felled forest. Into half of the plots, deadwood stems were added. For an area of 5 x 5 m, on which plant abundances were estimated in summer. We estimated the cover of bryophytes, deadwood, rocks, and bare soil, when they exceeded 5 % of the plot area. In addition, the number of vascular plant species and the cumulative cover is calculated. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Spatial species distribution of vascular plants in the FOX canopy gaps (G, GD) along a north-south transect in all regions, 2023
abstract: Various studies showed that plant diversity is not uniformly distributed across forest gaps. Here, we investigated diversity distribution patterns in the experimentally created stand clearances from the FOX experiment (forest gap experiment) in all three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). Vegetation surveys were conducted on the regeneration subplots which are arranged on a north-south transect and included presence/absence data of all plant species that rooted within the subplot. Within the regeneration subplots of 3 m x 4 m, we only sampled a one-meter-wide band closest to the north-south transect (3 m x 1 m). Data was collected between June and August 2023. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Tree and shrub cover in the FOX canopy gaps (G, GD) along a north-south transect in all three regions, 2023
abstract: Various studies showed that plant diversity is not uniformly distributed across forest gaps. Here, we investigated diversity distribution patterns in the experimentally created stand clearances from the FOX experiment (forest gap experiment) in all three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). Vegetation cover estimations of trees and shrubs were conducted on the regeneration subplots which are arranged on a north-south transect. Within the regeneration subplots of 3 m x 4 m, we only surveyed a one-meter-wide band closest to the north-south transect (3 m x 1 m). Tree and shrub cover serve as a proxy for light availability for herbs. Data was collected between June and August 2023. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Litter and fertilizer effects on final seedling biomass as obtained in a common garden experiment for 75 grassland species used in the seed addition plots of the REX experiment
abstract:
Agricultural grasslands play an important role in conserving the biodiversity of the European cultural landscape. Both, litter cover and soil nutrient availability are well-known factors that change with grassland management, but it is not well-studied how the germination and seedling growth of multiple grassland species are influenced by their single or combined effects. 
We studied the effects of fertilization (100 kg N per year and ha) and litter cover (250 gdw per m2) on seedling growth as final biomass which compares the biomass per species after the same time. For this, we examined 75 temperate grassland species (16 grass species, 51 forb species, 8 legume species) which were sown as single species in a full factorial microcosm experiment. The microcosm experiment was part of the project Seed Div within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Litter and fertilizer effects on the number of seedlings as obtained in a common garden experiment for 75 grassland species used in the seed addition plots of the REX experiment
abstract:
Agricultural grasslands play an important role in conserving the biodiversity of the European cultural landscape. Both, litter cover and soil nutrient availability are well-known factors that change with grassland management, but it is not well-studied how the germination and seedling growth of multiple grassland species are influenced by their single or combined effects. 
We studied the effects of fertilization (100 kg N per year and ha) and litter cover (250 gdw per m2) on germination measured as the number of seedlings germinated. For this, we examined 75 temperate grassland species (16 grass species, 51 forb species, 8 legume species) which were sown as single species in a full factorial microcosm experiment. The microcosm experiment was part of the project SeedDiv within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Seed mass and seed morphological traits for seed material used in the seed addition experiment in the land-use experiment (REX)
abstract: Morphological traits of seeds (or the dispersule) are important functional traits related to dispersal (seed morphology) and storage of reserves (seed mass). The data contain seed mass and measured morphological traits (projected area, straight length, curved length, straight width, curved width, curvature, width-to-length ratio and projected perimeter) for the seed material used in the seed addition plots of the land-use experiment (REX). The data collection was part of the project SeedDiv within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Activity of common voles (Microtus arvalis) in a reduced land use intensity experiment (REX and LUX) on 15 grassland plots in the Hainich region
abstract:
The common vole, Microtus arvalis, is a small herbivorous mammal that is highly abundant in Europe. Common voles can provide important ecosystem functions such as bioturbation and seed distribution and thereby enhance the biodiversity of grasslands. It is also a key prey species for many predators. However common voles can also cause great loss of biomass and plant cover leading to high economic losses. Populations of common voles respond to disturbances by grassland management practices. 

The activity of common voles was estimated by counting actively reopened burrow entrances in spring 2023 on 15 sites in Thuringia, Central Germany. Each site consisted of perennial grassland and was part of the reduced land use experiment called REX1 and LUX, where mowing and fertilization were reduced to a minimum.   
The activity of common voles was estimated using the burrow index (Lisická et al., 2007), in which the entrances to burrows on a defined area are sealed with soil and the number of reopened entrances is counted after 24 hours. This allows an assessment of the current activity of voles in contrast to signs of past activity such as the general presence of burrows.

In order to determine a potential correlation between vole activity and vegetation height, the vegetation height was measured on all subplots with a plate meter.

title: Soil enzyme activities - soil sampling campaign 2021, all forest experimental plots (EP), 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides essential information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all 300 experimental plots (EPs) of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the soil enzyme activities  in 0-10 cm depth from all forest EPs in 2021. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil enzymes play an important role in nutrient turnover in forest ecosystems as they are responsible for the conversion of organic matter into plant-available nutrients. We measured the activities of key enzymes involved in N, C, P, and S cycling. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-4, TR 1054/4-4, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Soil enzyme activities - soil sampling campaign 2017, all forest experimental plots (EPs), 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides essential information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all 300 experimental plots (EPs) of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the soil enzyme activities  in 0-10 cm depth from all forest EPs in 2017. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil enzymes play an important role in nutrient turnover in forest ecosystems as they are responsible for the conversion of organic matter into plant-available nutrients. We measured the activities of key enzymes involved in N, C, P, and S cycling. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-3, TR 1054/4-3, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: R Code for publication Birkenbach et al. 2024 in Ecology and Evolution
abstract:
This dataset contains a R-script to reproduce the results from Birkenbach, Straub, Kiesel, Ayasse, Wilfert, Kuppler (2024) Land-use affects pollinator-specific resource availability and pollinator foraging behaviour. Ecology and Evolution.

It requires the following datasets:
- 31495 version 5 (plant data)
- 31494 version 6 (behavioural data)
- 26487 version 64 (interview data)
- LUI data Alb 2021 (standardized, regional) from LUI tool
https://www.bexis.uni-jena.de/lui/LUICalculation/index
- Air temperature (Ta_200) from 14th June to 29th July 2021 on all EPs of the Alb in 1 hour intervals from Climate Data
https://www.bexis.uni-jena.de/tcd/PublicClimateData/Index

title: R-script to clean and calculate data and results used in 'Strengths of Fertilizer and Litter effects on seedling emergence and growth of grassland species differ depending on functional groups and seed size'
abstract:
This is the R script to reproduce the analysis of the manuscript Martin and Roscher 2024 'Strengths of fertilizer and litter effects on seedling recruitment and growth of grassland species differ depending on functional groups and seed size'. The data comes as an .R-file written in RStudio.
It requires the following datasets 31627, 31678, 31679, 31682 which are also available in the Biodiversity Exploratories Information System (https://www.bexis.uni-jena.de).

Further, the R Script cleans the data and calculates mixed effects models and the random structure of the model. It calculates the log-response ratio and the linear regression of the slopes from the mixed models against seed mass.

title: Food consumption of syrphid flies in a semi-field experiment
abstract:
We conducted semi-field experiments to disentangle links between land-use associated stressors, pollinator health and pollination services. Both the use of pesticides and the limitation of floral resources are main stressors causing pollinator declines in land-use intensive areas. Therefore, we treated two common pollinators species, the bumblebee Bombus terrestris and the syrphid fly Episyrphus balteatus with either (1) a field realistic dose (5ng per g pollen/nectar) of the neonicotinoid acetamiprid, (2) low quality food (7:3 honeybee collected pollen and pollen exines) or (3) a combination of both. Experiments were conducted in rearing chambers and insect flight cages in the Botanical Garden of Ulm University between March and July 2022. For both species, we assessed various health traits and parameters associated with the provision of pollination services like foraging behaviour or pollen deposition.
Here, we analysed pollen and nectar consumption of the syrphid flies E. balteatus.

title: Multi-taxa Community Weighted Mean (CWM) traits in grassland plots used in Neyret et al. 2024 Nature Communications
abstract:
The dataset contains Community Weighted mean data in grassland plots of the Exploratories (ALB, SCH, HAI) for a range of functional guilds: Lepidoptera, other above-ground arthropods (primary consumers and predators), birds, bats, bacteria & fungi, plant pathogen protists, bacterivore protists, secondary consumer protists, Oribatid mites, Collembola, other below-ground arthropods (primary and secondary consumers). CWM were calculated using Exploratories abundance data and trait data from a range of sources.
CWM for plant traits are replicated from dataset 27608.

Dataset used in Neyret et al. 2024. A slow-fast trait continuum at the whole community level in relation to land-use intensification. Nature Communications. https://doi.org/10.1038/s41467-024-45113-5.

Additionnal traits than those used in the paper are also included.

If using the data for other purposes than replicating the results of the manuscript, please carefully read the methods below, as well as those in the corresponding manuscript. Multiple decisions had to be made for CWM calculations, and there are limitation specific to each guild, which might not fit the requirements of your project. A link to an example R script to match trait and abundance data and calculate CWM for each guild is also provided to re-run the analyses if not.

title: Soil, rhizosphere, and root data on gap plots, including edge and stand trees
abstract:
We sampled bulk soil, rhizosphere soil and roots of even aged beech trees (Fagus sylvatica) on gap plots without deadwood. In each three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb), three plots were sampled (AEW22, AEW39, AEW42, SEW35, SEW36, SEW49, HEW05, HEW06, HEW32). Five samples were taken on three areas per plot (Undisturbed standing trees surrounding the gap (Stand), cut-down trees within gap (Gap), trees at northern edge of gap (Edge). 

We sampled twice, first sampling campaign was from 25.09.2020 to 05.10.2020, second sampling campaing was from 25.09.2022 - 05.10.2022, corresponding one and three growth phases after creation of gaps, which took place in Winter 2019/2020.

During the first sampling campaign we additionally exposed three roots per sampled tree/stump to 15N labeled NH4NO3 solutions for four hours.

Data is presented for roots (15NH4 and 15NO3 contents, morphology, element concentrations, non-structural carbohydrate concentrations, moisture), rhizopshere soil (soluble P, C and N concentrations, enzyme activities, fungi and bacteria+archaea community analysis, ergosterol concentrations (fungal biomass proxy), bacterial DNA abundance (bacterial biomass proxy), moisture and bulk soil (NH4, NO2 and NO3 concentrations, pH, moisture).

title: Dataset used in "Trophic shift of soil animal species with forest type as indicated by stable isotope analysis" (publication)
abstract: Anthropogenic land use shapes the dynamics and composition of central European forests and changes the quality and availability of resources of the decomposer system. These changes likely alter the structure and functioning of soil animal food webs. Using stable isotope analysis (13C, 15N) we investigated the trophic position and resource use of soil animal species in each of four forest types (coniferous, young managed beech, old managed beech and unmanaged beech forests) across three regions in Germany (Alb, Hainich, Schorfheide) in 2008.

title: Density and composition of the soil seed bank in the reduced land-use intensity experiment (REX) and the land-use experiment (LUX) 2021
abstract: The ability of seeds to persist in the soil until dormancy is broken or germination requirements are met may buffer populations against the failure of seed production or seedling recruitment under unfavorable environmental conditions and may support the recovery of plant communities. We collected data on the density and species composition of the viable soil seed bank (0-10 cm depth) in plots of the reduced land-use intensity experiment (EP-C, RP-C) and the land-use experiment (EP-C, RP-C, RP-F, UP-C) in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb) by taking soil samples in early spring 2021. The data collection was part of the project SeedDiv within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Seed mass, seed morphological and chemical traits for seeds used in the seed predation experiment of the project SPRINT
abstract: Morphological and chemical seed traits could be important characteristics to explain seed predation preferences of animals. The data contain seed mass, morphological traits (projected area, straight length, curved length, straight width, curved width, curvature, width-to-length ratio and projected perimeter) and chemical traits (concentrations of total carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium, sulphur, magnesium, iron, copper, manganesum, boron, zinc) for the seed material used in the seed predation experiment of the project SPRINT. The data were collected in the project SeedDiv within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Seed chemical traits for seed material used in the seed addition experiment in the land-use experiment (REX)
abstract: Chemical traits of seeds (or the dispersule) are important functional traits related to storage of reserves. The data contain seed chemical traits (concentrations of total carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium, sulphur, magnesium, iron, copper, manganesum, boron, zinc) for the seed material used in the seed addition plots of the land-use experiment (REX). The data collection was part of the project SeedDiv within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Sulfur fractions, isotopes and arylsulfatase activity - sampling 2020, all grassland VIPs, 0-10 cm depth
abstract: The BESoilS project analyzed sulfur contents and sulfur cycling in response to land use intensity across the plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains total element concentration and the respective isotope ratios for C, N, and S, as well as sulfur concentrations in different extractable fractions and arylsulfatase activity. Analyses are based on a set of soil cores collected in May and June 2020 from all grassland VIP plots.

title: Sulfur isotopes and arylsulfatase activity - sampling 2020, all forest VIPs, 0-10 cm depth
abstract: The BESoilS project analyzed sulfur contents and sulfur cycling in response to land use intensity across the plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains S isotope ratios, sulfur concentrations in extractable fractions and arylsulfatase activity. Analyses are based on a set of soil cores collected in May and June 2020 from all forest VIP plots.

title: Sulfur fractions in forest soil profiles - sampling 2020, all forest VIPs
abstract: The BESoilS project analyzed sulfur contents and sulfur cycling in response to land use intensity across the plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains total element concentration for C, N, and S, as well as sulfur concentrations in different extractable fractions. Analyses are based on a set of soil cores collected in May and June 2020 from all forest VIP plots up to a maximum depth of 40 cm.

title: Threatened fungi on deadwood sampled via metabarcoding or fruitbody 2012 - 2018
abstract:
This is a dataset on threatened deadwood-inhabiting fungal species from the BELongDead experiment, containing data from fruit body surveys  and metabarcoded eDNA samples.
The BELongDead experiment was conceived in 2008 under the direction of Prof. E. D. Schulze (MPI Biogeochemistry Jena) with the intention to monitor the impact of habitats on the dead wood decomposition processes and to observe colonization patterns of various saproxylic organisms over long time. Here presence/absence data of threatened fungi sampled via metabarcoding and as fruit body in 2012, 2015, 2017 and 2018 on dead-wood logs of the BELongDead Experiment is presented.

title: hTLS point clouds of all FOX plots in leaf-off condition, 2023
abstract: The dataset contains high-resolution LiDAR point clouds of the FOX gaps of Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb collected using a terrestrial laser scanner on a extendable tripod at a height of 8 m during leaf-off season. The gaps were scanned using a multi-scan approach of five positions. After co-registration of the single scanner positions, cloud-to-cloud matching was used to add georeferencing information (EPSG:32632 for ALB and HAI, EPSG:32633 for SCH) using the RTK-grade ULS point cloud data set (ID:31617).

title: Gravimetric soil water content - subsoil sampling 2023, all medium intensity research plots (MIP), 0-100 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the gravimetric soil water contents and dry matter contents in 0-100 cm depth from all medium intensity plots (MIPs) in 2023. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil water content has a dominant influence on plant growth, soil temperature, transport of chemical compounds, ground water recharge and soil aeration. The gravimetric soil water content is the mass of water in the soil, measured as the weight difference between the moist and the oven-dry soil. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-5, TR 1054/4-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: BEpipeR: a user-friendly, flexible, scalable, and easily expanded pipeline for a streamlined processing of biotic and abiotic data in R
abstract:
This is a versatile R-based pipeline for aggregating biotic and abiotic Biodiversity Exploratories data on EP-level. No coding is required to use this framework. More features will be implemented in future releases. Hence, for the most up-to-date information, see here: https://github.com/marcelglueck/BEpipeR

The pipeline's main features are (so far): 
- Easy to use: Simply parse the required aggregation information through the provided parameters files. No coding required.
- Flexibility: Biological data comes in many different shapes. We tried to implement as many aggregation/processing approaches as possible in this pipeline. Future releases will feature even more ways of aggregating your data ...
- Easy to deploy: You will be able to deploy this pipeline on many systems without modifications, as this pipeline adheres to best practice approaches on reproducibility and interoperability.
- Easy to debug and feature-expand: Compressed code, the processing through a few major loops, and consistent variables naming facilitate debugging and future feature implementations. In particular in the light of current high-paced discussions about good practice in data processing, a flexible framework that can accommodate novel insights with little effort is more than timely.
- Transparent and tractable: The main parameters file is updated on-the-fly to reflect the current state of processing, allowing the user to monitor the pipeline’s progress. Also, all derived variables in the composite data sets produced feature data set IDs. So, you will always be able to track information back to their original data sets.

title: Pollen numbers and pollen type classes on the surface of Bombus lapidarius and Episyrphus balteatus sampled in the three regions of the Exploratories in 2020
abstract: In the HealthyPollination project, we analyzed how land-use intensity in grasslands and land-use in the surrounding landscape affects pollinator health and pollination services in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Here, we analysed pollen from the surface of two pollinator species, Bombus lapidarius and Episyrphus balteatus. To do so, we sampled pollen from the body surface of each individual using gelatine cubes. We analyzed the identity and frequency of pollen grains to the lowest possible identification level (species, genus, family or pollen class type) using an automated method for pollen identification. In total, we screened 1046 bumblebees and 1009 syrphid flies from 140 individual plots, which were caught between May and July 2020.

title: EP Grassland Landuse Information ALB 2024
abstract:
Information about the land use on the EPs in 2024, based on information given by the farmers or on observations by members of the exploratories.
This file will be updated continuously.
It should be used only for fieldwork planning, NOT FOR ANALYSIS!.

title: Fine earth, roots and stones - subsoil sampling 2023, all medium intensity research plots (MIP), 0-100 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the fine earth, roots and stones from all medium intensity plots (MIPs) in 2023. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-5, TR 1054/4-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Grassland management parameter as input data for a computer model based on interview data of the Biodiversity Exploratories project
abstract:
The data is used to generate the land use input for the grassland model GrasslandTraitSim.jl.

This is a subset of the following dataset: "Land use in grasslands: raw data of yearly owner interviews (26487)". This subset includes specific information on when and how intensively the grassland sites were grazed, and when and to what height they were mown.

Description from the original dataset:
The present dataset summarises management information collected from 2006 ongoing for 150 grassland plots in three exploratories. Data are based on annual interviews of the respective farmers, land owners or tenants involved in land management activity, using a standardised questionnaire (DS ID 26006 - in German).

title: Species data for oribatid mites from 29 forest plots and four forest treatments of the FOX-Experiment sampled in 2021
abstract: Most forests in Central Europe are subject to human management, especially timber harvesting, which alters soil conditions by creating gaps in the forest canopy and reduces the availability of deadwood. However, consequences of these management practices, in particular the combined effect of gap formation and deadwood removal, have been largely neglected. Here, we sampled oribatid mites (Acari: Oribatida) by taking soil cores in forests where deadwood availability and gap formation were manipulated in a full factorial design (Control, Gap, Deadwood, Gap + Deadwood). Forest gaps of about 30 m in diameter were established by felling trees, which were subsequently removed (Gap) or left on site as deadwood (Gap + Deadwood). Nearby forest sites without gaps were enriched with the equal amount of felled trees (Deadwood) or left untreated (Control). Experimental treatments were established in spring 2020 at 29 forest sites including deciduous and coniferous stands in three regions of Germany, i.e. the Swabian Alb, Hanich-Dün and Schorfheide-Chorin in the south, center and north, respectively.

title: Revised 1st forest inventory on all forest EPs, single tree data, 2008 - 2014
abstract: The 1st tree inventory took place from 2008 to 2014 on 150 forest plots from three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) that differ in their management, ranging from unmanaged forests, to selection forests, where individual trees are felled individually, to age-class forest. Tree species, height, breast height diameter, volume and the exact position of all trees on the 100 x 100 m plots were recorded.

title: Gravimetric soil water content - soil sampling campaign 2023, all reduced land-use intensity experiment (REX) and land-use experiment (LUX) plots, 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the gravimetric soil water contents and dry matter contents in 0-10 cm depth from all reduced land-use intensity experiment (REX) and land-use experiment (LUX) plots in 2023. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil water content has a dominant influence on plant growth, soil temperature, transport of chemical compounds, ground water recharge and soil aeration. The gravimetric soil water content is the mass of water in the soil, measured as the weight difference between the moist and the oven-dry soil. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-5, TR 1054/4-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Gravimetric soil water content - soil sampling campaign 2021, all reduced land-use intensity experiment (REX) and land-use experiment (LUX) plots, 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the gravimetric soil water contents and dry matter contents in 0-10 cm depth from all reduced land-use intensity experiment (REX) and land-use experiment (LUX) plots in 2021. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil water content has a dominant influence on plant growth, soil temperature, transport of chemical compounds, ground water recharge and soil aeration. The gravimetric soil water content is the mass of water in the soil, measured as the weight difference between the moist and the oven-dry soil. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-4, TR 1054/4-4, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Gravimetric soil water content - soil sampling campaign 2021, all forest gap exeriment (FOX) plots, 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the gravimetric soil water contents and dry matter contents in 0-10 cm depth from all forest gap experiment (FOX) plots in 2021. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil water content has a dominant influence on plant growth, soil temperature, transport of chemical compounds, ground water recharge and soil aeration. The gravimetric soil water content is the mass of water in the soil, measured as the weight difference between the moist and the oven-dry soil. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-4, TR 1054/4-4, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Gravimetric soil water content - soil sampling campaign 2023, all forest gap exeriment (FOX) plots, 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the gravimetric soil water contents and dry matter contents in 0-10 cm depth from all forest gap experiment (FOX) plots in 2023. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil water content has a dominant influence on plant growth, soil temperature, transport of chemical compounds, ground water recharge and soil aeration. The gravimetric soil water content is the mass of water in the soil, measured as the weight difference between the moist and the oven-dry soil. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-5, TR 1054/4-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Soil pH - soil sampling campaign 2023, all forest gap exeriment (FOX) plots, 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the soil pH values in 0-10 cm depth from all forest gap experiment (FOX) plots in 2023. Soil pH is considered a master variable in soil science as it affects many chemical processes in soils. Most importantly, the plant nutrient availability is greatly affected by the soil pH as it controlls the chemical forms of the different nutrients and influences the chemical reactions they undergo. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-5, TR 1054/4-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Soil carbon, nitrogen and sulfur concentrations - soil sampling campaign 2021, all forest gap exeriment (FOX) plots, 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the organic carbon (OC), inorganic carbon (IC), total nitrogen (TN) and total sulfur (TS) concentrations, and carbon to nitrogen ratios (CN ratio) as well as carbon to sulfur ratios (CS ratio)  in 0-10 cm depth from all forest gap exeriment (FOX) plots in 2021. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil organic carbon, nitrogen and sulfur concentrations are master variables in soil science. They are the measureable components of soil organic matter (SOM). SOM exerts positive effects on numerous physical, chemical and biological soil properties. An increase in SOM generally results in an improved soil structure, soil moisture retention, soil buffering capacity, retention of pollutants, cycling and storage of plant nutrients and biodiversity. SOM also acts as a sink and source for atmospheric carbon dioxide. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-4, TR 1054/4-4, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Soil carbon, nitrogen and sulfur concentrations - soil sampling campaign 2021, all reduced land-use intensity experiment (REX) and land-use experiment (LUX) plots, 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the organic carbon (OC), inorganic carbon (IC), total nitrogen (TN) and total sulfur (TS) concentrations, and carbon to nitrogen ratios (CN ratio) as well as carbon to sulfur ratios (CS ratio)  in 0-10 cm depth from all reduced land-use intensity experiment (REX) and land-use experiment (LUX) plots in 2021. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil organic carbon, nitrogen and sulfur concentrations are master variables in soil science. They are the measureable components of soil organic matter (SOM). SOM exerts positive effects on numerous physical, chemical and biological soil properties. An increase in SOM generally results in an improved soil structure, soil moisture retention, soil buffering capacity, retention of pollutants, cycling and storage of plant nutrients and biodiversity. SOM also acts as a sink and source for atmospheric carbon dioxide. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-4, TR 1054/4-4, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Traits of wild bees from the literature
abstract: We use traits to calculate functional diversity from wild bees collected in the exploratories. In this dataset we collected information from the literature on sociality, specialization, size, nesting type, conservation classification and others, based on the dataset from a collaborator (Stuart) which is not yet published.

title: Taxonomy table of plants and day-active butterfly species; selected grassland experimental plots, Schorfheide-Chorin and Swabian Alb, 2008
abstract: We gathered all important taxonomic information of all plants and day-active butterfly species sampled during 2008 in the grasslands experimental plots (EPs) of Schorfheide-Chorin (SCH) and Swabian Alb (ALB) exploratories that were present in the datasets ID 12526 (butterflies) and ID 23586 (plants 2008–2017). This dataset serves as a supplement for analyses with the original data and provides taxonomic harmonisation of species names which have been modified since the time of data collection.

title: Literature-based, long-term interaction database for grasslands vascular plants and day-active (adult) Lepidoptera, region Baden-Württemberg including Schwäbische Alb, 1975 to 2005
abstract: We compiled butterfly and plant species interaction data (flower visitations) from periodic surveys published in the literature for the whole Baden-Württemberg state, covering a period from 1975 to 2005. We used this datasets to compare the accuracy of co-occurrence methods to predict species interactions in permanent grasslands, but its use is not limited to that. For example, it could be used to infer plot-based interaction networks, which can then be analysed along land-use intensity gradients.

title: Literature-based, long-term interaction database for grasslands vascular plants and Lepidoptera larvae, region Baden-Württemberg including Schwäbische Alb, 1975 to 2005
abstract: We compiled butterfly larva and plant species interaction data (herbivory) from periodic surveys published in the literature for the whole Baden-Württemberg region, covering a period from 1975 to 2005.

title: Literature-based, long-term interaction database for grasslands  vascular plants and day-active (adult) Lepidoptera, region Brandenburg including Schorfheide-Chorin, 1960 to 2018
abstract: We compiled butterfly and plant species interaction data (flower visitations) from periodic surveys published in the literature for the whole Brandenburg region, covering a period from (mainly) 1960 to 2018. We used this datasets to compare the accuracy of co-occurrence methods to predict species interactions in permanent grasslands, but its use is not limited to that. For example, it could be used to infer plot-based interaction networks, which can then be analysed along land-use intensity gradients.

title: Literature-based, long-term interaction database for grasslands vascular plants and Lepidoptera larvae, region Brandenburg including Schorfheide-Chorin, 1960 to 2018
abstract: We compiled butterfly larva and plant species interaction data (herbivory) from periodic surveys published in the literature for the whole Brandenburg region, covering a period from (mainly) 1960 to 2018.

title: Species interactions and predictions of co-occurrence methods for plant and butterfly species in 2008, used in "Co-occurrence patterns do not predict mutualistic interactions between plant and butterfly species"
abstract: Biotic interactions are crucial for determining the structure and dynamics of communities, but direct measurement of these interactions can be time- and resource-intensive, especially when numerous species are involved. Inferring species interactions from species co-occurrence patterns is increasingly being used; however, recent studies have highlighted some limitations. This is an assembled dataset that contains species-level interaction data for pairs of vascular plants and day-active (adult) Lepidoptera species and the prediction results of three different co-occurrence methods. Additionally, flower availability and flower visitation data was included. It considers, 51 and 21 lepidopteran and 135 and 51 plant species, for the regions Schwäbische Alb (ALB) and Schorfheide-Chorin (SCH) respectively, that simultaneously occurred in the field observations (abundance data) and showed  species interaction in the literature. Co-occurrences were calculated by including 89 sites (EPs) in total, 46 in ALB and 43 in SCH, for which we found overlapping field and literature data. We also include other measures like the number of sites that a plant or butterfly species occurred at. The data collection/analysis was part of the project TrophCost within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Fine root and soil mineral elemental concentrations - Soil Sampling Campaign 2021, all forest plots (EPs), 0-10cm
abstract:
In May 2021, we joined SSC 2021 to get the fine root (Diameter < 2 mm) and soil samples to measure the mineral elemental concentrations.
The core project Soil provides essential information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all 150 forest Experimental Plots (EPs) of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the fine root C, N, Na, K, Ca, Mg, Mn, Fe, Al, S, P, Glucose, Fructose, Starch and soil pH, C, N, NH4-N, NO3-N, Na, K, Ca, Mg, Mn, Fe, Al, S, P, Avail_P, moisture in 0-10 cm depth from all forest EPs in 2021. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb).

title: Arthropod abundances from grassland sweep netting before and after mowing in Hainich 2016, LegacyNet, Campus Freising and Egenried
abstract:
Arthropods face a global decline attributed to habitat loss, climate change, pesticide use, and an intensification of land-use practices such as mowing. Studies on the effects of mowing on arthropod abundance showed conflicting results potentially due to multiple factors, including study design, grassland management, sampling method, and arthropod taxon studied.
We conducted four studies in different grasslands, including intensively and extensively used agricultural and urban grasslands, utilising sweep netting, suction sampling, and pitfall traps in Freising, in the Hainich expploratory and in Egenried (south bavaria). We compared the mowing responses of arthropod taxa between those studies at three different taxonomic resolutions (first-level overall arthropods, second-level orders, and third-level families and suborders). The data frame contains the raw data of the abundance of the different first and second taxonomical levels.

title: Field data - soil sampling campaign 2023, all forest gap experiment (FOX) plots, organic layer + 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides essential information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the field data from the forest gap experiment (FOX) plots during the soil sampling campaign 2023. At all plots composite samples from the mineral soil (0-10 cm depth) were sampled. At all forest plots additional samples from the organic layer were taken. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-5, TR 1054/4-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Field data - soil sampling campaign 2023, all reduced land-use intensity experiment (REX) and land-use experiment (LUX) plots, 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides essential information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the field data from the reduced land-use intensity experiment (REX) and land-use experiment (LUX) during the soil sampling campaign in 2023. At all plots composite samples from the mineral soil (0-10 cm depth) were sampled. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-5, TR 1054/4-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Field data - soil sampling campaign 2023, all experimental plots (EP), organic layer + 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides essential information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the field data from the experimental plots (EPs) during the soil sampling campaign 2023. At all plots composite samples from the mineral soil (0-10 cm depth) were sampled. At all forest plots additional samples from the organic layer were taken. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-5, TR 1054/4-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Soil metagenomes from all grassland 150 experimental plots (EP), SSC 2023
abstract: Here we provide the metadata and link to an external repository with the raw metagenome sequencing data. The metagenome  are from 150 EP soil samples of all grassland in three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). The samples  were taken during the soil sampling campaign (SSC) 2023.

title: Intra-individual floral trait variation in Galium odoratum grown in a common garden and subjected to drought and shade treatments, 2022
abstract: In 2020, we collected clonal replicates from 71 genets of Galium odoratum originating from 21 forest plots from all three Exploratory regions (Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) and grew them in a common garden at Goethe University Frankfurt. In 2021 and in 2022 we applied a full-factorial design of drought and shade treatments and measured floral traits (number of flowers, flower size, petal size, flowering start, flowering end, and flower longevity) to investigate intra-individual variation.

title: Seed removal numbers by invertebrates in the joint-multisite experiments in Hainich Exploratory 2021
abstract:
Data collecting was conducted two weeks in summer (21.06. to 02.07.) and late summer (23.08. to 03.09.) of 2021 in the Hainich Exploratory. We followed recent approaches that conducted cafeteria-style experiments to disentangle the dispersal/removal of plant seeds by different invertebrates among the seed predator/remover community (Dudenhöffer et al. 2016; Pufal & Klein 2013). The construction of the seed cafeterias was based on Dudenhöffer et al. (2016).
60 seeds of six common grassland plant species (Lolium perenne L., Pastinaca sativa L., Phleum pratense L., Poa pratensis L., Taraxacum sect. Ruderalia and Trifolium pretense L.) were placed for 72 hours on a petri dish. The seed-cafeteria with five seed predator exclusion treatments manipulated the access to offered plant seeds for different invertebrate groups.

title: Intra-individual vegetative trait variation in Galium odoratum grown in a common garden and subjected to drought and shade treatments, 2022
abstract: In 2020, we collected clonal replicates from 71 genets of Galium odoratum originating from 21 forest plots from all three Exploratory regions (Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) and grew them in a common garden at Goethe University Frankfurt. In 2022 we applied a full-factorial design of drought and shade treatments and measured vegetative traits (plant height, leaf length and leaf width) to investigate intra-individual variation.

title: Land use in grasslands: raw data from annual landowner interviews - revised in 05/2024
abstract:
The present dataset summarises management information collected from 2006 ongoing for 150 grassland plots in three exploratories (three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin)). Data are based on annual interviews of the respective farmers, land owners or tenants involved in land management activity, using a standardised questionnaire (dataset ID 26006 - in German). The dataset provides information on land use in grasslands, in particular on mowing, grazing, fertilization and maintenance measures, as well as drainage and management history. Out of this dataset, the LUI components, used in the LUI-Tool in BExIS, are calculated. LUI (Land Use Index) is a quantitative index that is calculated out of intermediate values for grazing, mowing and fertilization. Thereby, different land-use intensities of the grassland plots can be described. 

The dataset was revised in 2024 since problems occurred with the calculation of TotalFertilization in the LUI-Tool. Some values for fertilization were missing or incorrect having impact on the resulting LUI-component.

title: Mineral-associated organic carbon mineralization for 68 experimental plots, 2020
abstract:
Organic matter (OM) is the substrate from which heterotrophic soil microorganisms obtained their energy to carry out their biological functions.  Under aerobic conditions, CO2 is released as a result of mineralization of OM by soil microbes. Hence, the production of CO2 from soil samples incubated in the laboratory under controlled conditions has been widely used as an indicator of the bioavailability of OM in soils. While the conditions under which these incubations are done do not reflect field conditions, they are a useful tool for comparative studies of soil OM dynamics. Here we carry out short-term incubations on pristine minerals (the iron oxyhydroxide, goethite, and the phyllosilicate clay, illite) buried for c.a. five years (from November 2015 to August 2020) in differently managed forest and grassland plots across Germany to study the interplay between mineral type and land use on the bioavailability of mineral-associated organic matter (MAOM). Because of the relative low concentration of carbon that accumulated on the minerals, we opted to incubate them in 20 mL vials to ensure detectable concentrations of CO2 in the headscape of the incubation vessels.

This dataset contains information on the release of CO2 from the mineral samples during pre(incubation) under laboratory conditions, and the mineralizability of the mineral-bound organic carbon.

title: Mineral-associated organic carbon desorbability for 68 experimental plots, 2020
abstract:
The association of organic compounds with soils minerals is a key mechanism facilitating the long-term stabilization of organic carbon (OC) in soils. Quantification of extractability of mineral-bound OC  can give an indication of the strength of the bonds in the organo-mineral complex. Here organic C on minerals was extracted with CaCl2 in a 1:5 ratio as an indicator of ‘easily desorable’, bioavailable, OC. The samples analysed are from a five year experiment (from November 2015 to August 2020) where pristine minerals were exposed in  top soils at  68 study sites in three pedo-geologically distinct regions in Germany (i.e., Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, and Schorfheide-Chorin).

This dataset contains information on the quanity of mineral-bound organic carbon (OC) that is extractable with CaCl2.

title: Mineral-associated total phosphorus for 68 experimental, 2020
abstract:
Phosphorus (P) is an essential element for plants and microgranisms in the soil.  Here we measure total P on pristine minerals (the iron oxyhydroxide, goethite, and the phyllosilicate clay, illite) buried for five years (November 2015 to August 2020)  in differently managed forest and grassland plots across three regions in Germany (i.e., Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün and Schorfheide-Chorin).

Herein, are data on the total P concentration of the field-exposed mineral samples.

title: Estimated clay content - soil sampling campaign 2023, all experimental plots (EP), 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the residual water content of air-dried soil in 0-10 cm depth from all experimental plots (EPs) in 2023 and the estimated clay content derived from this. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil texture is one of the main factors controlling soil organic carbon (SOC) storage.
