The water content of air-dried soil samples can be used as a good proxy of clay contents since a significant linear relationship was found between clay contents and water contents of air dry soil samples.The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-5, TR 1054/4-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Literature-based list of ecological attributes per species for plants and butterflies from selected sites in the Schwäbische Alb and Schorfheide-Chorin, 2008
abstract: To improve Agri-Environment Schemes (AES), we must consider ecosystem complexity, encompassing multiple species and various ecological aspects beyond simple species counts. By adapting an existing model, we developed a simulation procedure for cost-effective grassland AES allocation (e.g. reduced fertiliser input, reduced number of hay cut, etc) based on the ecological value of specific single and joint conservation goals for the conservation of butterfly and plant species in two regions: Schwäbische Alb (ALB) and Schorfheide-Chorin (SCH). To allow the calculation of conservation goals, we first calculated 7 ecological attributes per species for posterior analyses. This dataset contains the 7 ecological attributes per species and summarises the procedure to obtain them.

title: Estimated clay content - soil sampling campaign 2023, all reduced land-use intensity experiment (REX) and land-use experiment (LUX) plots, 0-10 cm

This dataset contains the residual water content of air-dried soil in 0-10 cm depth from all reduced land-use intensity experiment (REX) and land-use experiment (LUX) plots in 2023 and the estimated clay content derived from this. title: Bacterial and fungal microbiome of Myodes glareolus and Microtus arvalis on grassland and forest plots
abstract:
We did amplicon sequencing on feces from dissected gut of bank voles caught on 15 forest plots and common voles caught on 15 grassland plots (experimental plots (EP)) in the region Hainich-Dün (Germany) 2020. We sequenced the V45 and the ITS2 region to analyze the bacterial and fungal microbiome.
This dataset does not contain data since these are stored in the NCBI repository, see below.
This dataset is connected to the publication 31823 "Seasonal shifts and land-use impact: Unveiling the gut microbiomes of bank voles (Myodes glareolus) and common voles (Microtus arvalis)".

title: List of ecological attributes per site for plant and butterfly communities from selected sites in Schwäbische Alb and Schorfheide-Chorin, 2008
abstract: To improve Agri-Environment Schemes (AES), we must consider ecosystem complexity, encompassing multiple species and various ecological aspects beyond simple species counts. By adapting an existing model, we developed a simulation procedure for cost-effective grassland AES allocation based on the ecological value of specific single and joint conservation goals for the conservation of butterfly and plant species in two regions: Schwäbische Alb (ALB) and Schorfheide-Chorin (SCH). To allow the calculation of conservation goals, we first calculated 7 ecological attributes per species (e.g., red list status, threat category, regional distribution, etc) and used them together with richness/abundance data from the Biodiversity Exploratories (BE) to calculate different attributes per site (number of red list species per site, average threat category of red list species, average regional distribution range of butterfly species per site, etc). This dataset contains a list of ecological attributes per site and summarises the procedure to obtain them.

title: Scan data from digital whole-community phenotyping in land-use experiment subplots in Hainich and Schorfheide 2023
abstract:
In the era of global and climate change, alterations of ecosystems, their functioning and biodiversity have been linked to agriculture and land use intensity. Those findings have also led to rapid changes in politics in terms of nature conservation ending up in a timely mismatch among the urgency of making meaningful regulations for the conservation of biodiversity and the time needed to investigate the facets of the effects of agriculture on our ecosystems, their functioning and services. Here, the exchange of "low-throughput" methods widely established in ecology by "high-throughput phenotyping" known from modern agriculture and lab works demonstrated in EXClAvE Phase 1 delivered a promising method ("Digital Whole Community Phenotyping") to quickly gather data for the effects of and responses to land use intensity and type on community level (He et al. 2023, Zieschank & Junker 2023). 
In May 2023, we used a field customized, automated plant phenotyping system (PlantEye F500) to derive multispectral and physiological information together with the 3-dimensional structure of the vegetation of the multi site experimental plot (reduced land-use & land-use experiments) in all three Exploratories (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün and Schorfheide-Chorin in Germany). To increase heterogeneity, we scanned three times in each subplot.
This dataset contains 14 parameters from two scanning weeks in which all subplots of the LUX experiments have been scanned except for those mentioned in important notes. 
The data collection and analysis was part of the project EXClAvE II within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: List of potential extensification/conservation measures in Schwäbische Alb (2008) and their assignment to soil productivity classes
abstract: To improve Agri-Environment Schemes (AES), we must consider ecosystem complexity, encompassing multiple species and various ecological aspects beyond simple species counts. By adapting an existing spatio-temporal explicit model for cost-effective optimization of AES, we developed a simulation procedure for cost-effective grassland AES allocation based on the ecological value of specific single and joint conservation goals and the cost of management measures. To do so, and based on the grassland management practices in the region Schwäbische Alb (ALB) in 2008 and the calculation of ecological attributes such as plant and butterfly richness on the experimental plots, we selected some potentially effective management measures for conservation and extensification. Not all measures would be suitable on all plots, therefore assumptions were made for the potential assignment of measures to soil productivity classes. A short description of the measures is also included.

title: Ecological and cost-effective optimization results of multiple conservation goals for plant and butterfly communities in selected grasslands sites in Schwäbische Alb
abstract: To improve Agri-Environment Schemes (AES), we must consider ecosystem complexity, encompassing multiple species and various ecological aspects beyond simple species counts. By adapting an existing spatio-temporal explicit model for cost-effective optimization of AES, we developed a simulation procedure for cost-effective grassland AES allocation based on the ecological value of specific single and joint conservation goals and the cost of management measures. We selected 12 attributes per site (single conservation goals) and assigned them into one of five major categories of joint conservation goals: 1) traditional species conservation (TSC), 2) regional distribution range (RDR), 3) trophic interactions (TIN), 4) ecosystem services (ESS), and 5) ecosystem resilience (ESR), plus different combinations of these groups. Based on actual grassland management data from the Schwäbische Alb region (ALB), we derived potential management measures for AES to be included in the different regional optimizations. Additionally, we calculated costs for each single goal by using the yield (based on soil productivity), variable costs, and labor costs. Here we present the optimization results for each of 12 single, and 19 joint conservation goals for grassland sites in Swabian Alb (ALB) using three budgets: one unconstrained (only ecological optimisation), one minimum and one mid budget for cost-effective (i.e. ecological-economic) optimizations.

title: 16S rRNA gene (V3 region) DNA-based analysis of microbial soil communities at sequence variant level in 150 grassland plots, using QIIME2-based bioinformatics, 2021
abstract:
We determine the microbial community composition of 300 experimental plots (EP) from grassland and woodlands in three regions of Germany (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). Here, we isolated DNA from soil sampled in 2021 and sequenced V3 16S rRNA gene amplicons. 

Note that via extraction of DNA the entire bacterial community is captured. This includes also dormant or inactive cells, even including dead cells. 

The results indicate substantial difference between grassland and woodland soils. Moreover, bacterial communities can be additionally distinguished by their soil type.

Here, the data are provided as quality-checked but non-rarefied read counts of distinct exact sequence variants (Callahan et al 2017). A bacterial sequence variant in this data set is defined by a specific nucleotide sequence of the V3 16S rRNA gene region of 165 base pair length. That means, bacterial sequence variants are distinguished at the level of single nucleotide differences.

This dataset contains the data from DNA extractions of the grassland plots.

title: 16S rRNA gene (V3 region) DNA-based analysis of microbial soil communities at sequence variant level in 150 forest plots, using QIIME2-based bioinformatics, 2021
abstract:
We determine the microbial community composition of 300 experimental plots (EP) from grassland and woodlands in three regions of Germany (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). Here, we isolated DNA from soil sampled in 2021 and sequenced V3 16S rRNA gene amplicons. 

Note that via extraction of DNA the entire bacterial community is captured. This includes also dormant or inactive cells, even including dead cells. 

The results indicate substantial difference between grassland and woodland soils. Moreover, bacterial communities can be additionally distinguished by their soil type.

Here, the data are provided as quality-checked but non-rarefied read counts of distinct exact sequence variants (Callahan et al. 2017). A bacterial sequence variant in this data set is defined by a specific nucleotide sequence of the V3 16S rRNA gene region of 165 base pair length. That means, bacterial sequence variants are distinguished at the level of single nucleotide differences.

This dataset contains the data from DNA extractions of the forest plots.

title: 16S rRNA gene (V3 region) RNA-based analysis of bacterial soil communities at sequence variant level in 150 grassland plots, using QIIME2-based bioinformatics, 2021
abstract:
We determine the microbial community composition in 300 experimental plots (EP) from grassland and woodlands in three regions of Germany (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). Most bacteria in soil are dormant or inactive. A substantial fraction might even be dead. Hence, in order to quantify the living and active bacteria, we isolated RNA from soil and sequenced V3 16S rRNA amplicons.

The presence and amount of ribosomes in a cell can be taken as a rough proxy for activity. The results indicate substantial difference between grassland and woodland soils. Moreover, bacterial communities can be additionally distinguished by their soil type.

Here, the data are provided as quality-checked but non-rarefied read counts of distinct exact sequence variants (Callahan et al 2017). A bacterial sequence variant in this data set is defined by a specific nucleotide sequence of the V3 16S rRNA gene region of 165 base pair length. That means, bacterial sequence variants are distinguished at the level of single nucleotide differences.

This dataset contains the data from RNA extractions of the grassland plots.

title: R script for merging and splitting optimization results files (or any other files), TrophCost project
abstract:
This script can be used to split the single file with all ecological and cost-effective optimization results for single and joint conservation goals for butterfly and plant communities in selected sites in the Biodiversity Exploratories. It can also be used to merge the individual files back into a single file.

The datasets necessary to run the analysis are also detailed in the script (dataset IDs 31798 and 31816).

This file can also be adapted for merging/splitting any (large amount of) other files.

title: List of potential extensification/conservation measures assigned in Schwäbische Alb (2008) per site with cost of the measure and value of the attributes per measure and site
abstract: In this compiled dataset the ecological effects of a measure which is directly linked to a plot in Schwäbische Alb (ALB) are assigned to other plots in the region where the measure can potentially be implemented and is expected to lead to similar ecological effects. The costs of the measures for ALB are also included. This dataset has been used for optimisations of the ecological effects per ecological goal and for cost-effective allocation/optimisation of measures based on the cost-benefit ration of measures for region ALB (see dataset ID 31798)

title: 16S rRNA gene (V1-V3 region) DNA-based analysis of archaeal soil communities at sequence variant level in 150 grassland plots, using QIIME2-based bioinformatics, 2021
abstract:
We determined the archaeal soil community composition in 300 experimental plots (EP) from grassland and forests in three regions of Germany (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) in 2021. This dataset pertains to grasslands only.
Here, we isolated DNA from soil and sequenced V1-V3 16S rRNA gene amplicons. Note that via extraction of DNA the entire bacterial community is captured. This includes also dormant or inactive cells, even including dead cells. 
Here, the data are provided as quality-checked but non-rarefied read counts of distinct exact sequence variants (Callahan et al 2017). 
An archaeal sequence variant in this dataset is defined by a specific nucleotide sequence of the V1-V3 16S rRNA gene region of 490 base pair length. That means, bacterial sequence variants are distinguished at the level of single nucleotide differences.The dataset contains only the data of the grassland plots.

title: 16S rRNA gene (V1-V3 region) DNA-based analysis of archaeal soil communities at sequence variant level in 150 forest plots, using QIIME2-based bioinformatics, 2021
abstract:
We determined the archaeal soil community composition in 300 experimental plots (EP) from grassland and forests in three regions of Germany (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) in 2021. This dataset pertains to forests only.
Here, we isolated DNA from soil and sequenced V1-V3 16S rRNA gene amplicons. Note that via extraction of DNA the entire bacterial community is captured. This includes also dormant or inactive cells, even including dead cells. 
Here, the data are provided as quality-checked but non-rarefied read counts of distinct exact sequence variants (Callahan et al 2017). 
An archaeal sequence variant in this data set is defined by a specific nucleotide sequence of the V1-V3 16S rRNA gene region of 490 base pair length. That means, bacterial sequence variants are distinguished at the level of single nucleotide differences. The dataset contains only the data of the forest plots.

title: 16S rRNA gene (V1-V3 region) RNA-based analysis of archaeal soil communities at sequence variant level in 150 grassland plots, using QIIME2-based bioinformatics, 2021
abstract:
We determined the archaeal soil community composition in 300 experimental plots (EP) from grassland and forests in three regions of Germany (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) in 2021. This dataset pertains to grasslands only.
Here, we isolated RNA from soil and sequenced V1-V3 16S rRNA gene amplicons.The presence and amount of ribosomes in a cell can be taken as a rough proxy for activity. 
Here, the data are provided as quality-checked but non-rarefied read counts of distinct exact sequence variants (Callahan et al 2017). An archaeal sequence variant in this data set is defined by a specific nucleotide sequence of the V1-V3 16S rRNA gene region of 490 base pair length. That means, bacterial sequence variants are distinguished at the level of single nucleotide differences. The dataset contains only the data of the grassland plots.

title: 16S rRNA gene (V1-V3 region) RNA-based analysis of archaeal soil communities at sequence variant level in 150 forest plots, using QIIME2-based bioinformatics, 2021
abstract:
We determined the archaeal soil community composition in 300 experimental plots (EP) from grassland and forests in three regions of Germany (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) in 2021. This dataset pertains to forests only.
Here, we isolated RNA from soil and sequenced V1-V3 16S rRNA gene amplicons.The presence and amount of ribosomes in a cell can be taken as a rough proxy for activity. 
Here, the data are provided as quality-checked but non-rarefied read counts of distinct exact sequence variants (Callahan et al 2017). An archaeal sequence variant in this data set is defined by a specific nucleotide sequence of the V1-V3 16S rRNA gene region of 490 base pair length. That means, bacterial sequence variants are distinguished at the level of single nucleotide differences. The dataset contains only the data of the forest plots.

title: Raster maps of German agricultural land use (2017-2021)
abstract: Maps of the agricultural land use in Germany. The maps contain the most dominant crop types, grassland and small woody features and were derived from different sources of satellite data and processed as a rasterlayer with a resolution of 10m x 10m for five consecutive years (2017-2021). The data cover entire Germany but can be cropped to the regions of the three exploratories on demand.

title: Raster maps of mowing events (2017-2021)
abstract:
The dataset contains area-wide assessments of mowing events (date, frequency). Data were generated from dense time series of satellite data for five consecutive year (2017 to 2021).
The maps cover all grassland areas in Germany but can be cropped for the regions of the three exploratories on demand.

title: Vector maps of German agricultural land use (2017-2021)
abstract: Maps of the agricultural land use in Germany. The maps contain the most dominant crop types, grassland and small woody features and were derived from different sources of satellite data and processed as a vectorlayer (homogeneous objects, fields) for five consecutive years (2017-2021). The data cover entire Germany but can be subsetted to the regions of the three exploratories on demand.

title: Ecological and cost-effective optimization results of multiple conservation goals for plant and butterfly communities in selected grasslands sites in Schorfheide-Chorin
abstract: To improve Agri-Environment Schemes (AES), we must consider ecosystem complexity, encompassing multiple species and various ecological aspects beyond simple species counts. By adapting an existing spatio-temporal explicit model for cost-effective optimization of AES, we developed a simulation procedure for cost-effective grassland AES allocation based on the ecological value of specific single and joint conservation goals and the cost of management measures. We selected 12 attributes per site (single conservation goals) and assigned them into one of five major categories of joint conservation goals: 1) traditional species conservation (TSC), 2) regional distribution range (RDR), 3) trophic interactions (TIN), 4) ecosystem services (ESS), and 5) ecosystem resilience (ESR), plus different combinations of these groups. Based on actual grassland management data from the Schorfheide-Chorin region (SCH), we derived potential management measures for AES to be included in the different regional optimizations. Additionally, we calculated costs for each single goal by using the yield (based on soil productivity), variable costs, and labor costs. Here we present the optimization results for each of 12 single, and 19 joint conservation goals for grassland sites in SCH using three budgets: one unconstrained (only ecological optimisation), one minimum and one mid budget for cost-effective (i.e. ecological-economic) optimizations.

title: R script for calculating the original ecological values reached for each goal at each optimization (i.e. undo min-max scaling and reciprocal), TrophCost project
abstract: This R script let you undo the min-max scaling and the reciprocal calculation done in the selected goals for optimization, allowing you to obtain the original values of the goals per site. Takes as input the selected list of original scale attributes per site from ID 31791 and the already transformed values from ID 31798 (ALB) or 31816 (SCH).

title: Social Network Analysis data on the co-production of nature's contributions to people in forests
abstract: To identify relevant actors for the governance of co-produced forest nature's contributions to people (NCP) we conducted a social-network analysis based on 39 semi-structured interviews with foresters and conservation managers between May and November 2021. These interviews were conducted across three case study sites in Germany: Schorfheide-Chorin in the Northeast, Hainich-Dün in the Centre, and Schwäbische Alb in the Southwest. All three case study sites belong to the large-scale and long-term research platform Biodiversity Exploratories.

title: Data used in: Intrinsic, instrumental and relational values behind nature’s contributions to people preferences of nature visitors in Germany
abstract: Protected areas not only provide biodiversity conservation but also offer a multitude of nature’s contributions to people (NCP), such as recreational opportunities. Visitors to these areas value nature and NCP for various reasons, potentially leading to different arguments for conservation planning. So far, research has neglected the heterogeneity of reasons why visitors value nature and NCP in natural areas. In this study, we identified NCP preferences and elicited diverse values underpinning those preferences, i.e. intrinsic, instrumental and relational values. We analysed 127 semi-structured interviews with nature visitors of three regions encompassing protected areas across Germany including Schorfheide-Chorin (North East), Hainich-Dün (Central), and Schwäbische Alb (South West). This data set contains the full responses of the surveys conducted to visitors, including preference for NCP/ecosystem services, values associated to these NCP, and socio-demographic information.

title: Root trait data including mycorrhizal colonization and root hair measurements
abstract: The project HAIRphae focusses on the trade-off between arbuscular mycorrhizal fungal structures in plant roots and root hair traits. This dataset contains root trait data (SRL, AD, RTD, root hair measurements) and mycorrhizal colonization data (arbuscules, vesicles, hyphae, coils), aggregated at the plant individual level. Samples were collected in spring 2021, on all grassland VIP plots (3 x 9 grassland VIP plots = 27 plots, however plot SEG06 was unavailable for sample collection, we sampled on SEG25 instead.) Root trait data (SRL, AD, RTD) was analyzed through scanning and WinRhizo software. Root hair length, root hair incidence as well as all mycorrhizal colonization parameters were scored under the microscope. The ten most abundant plant species per plot were sampled in three replicates each. This yields 81 grassland species in total in this dataset.

title: Utilised agricultural area of commercial field crops, fruit trees, fruit shrubs, vegetables, and vineyards of Baden-Württemberg and Brandenburg for years 2008, 2019, and 2015-2020
abstract: Using annual reports of the statistics offices of Germany, we assembled the utilised agricultural area (UAA) in hectares of (all) commercially relevant crops for the whole states of Baden-Württemberg (BW) and Brandenburg (BB) for years 2008, 2019, and the mean from 2015 to 2020. We include the scientific name of each crop, together with the common names in English and German. We also included the proportion of each crop's UAA relative to both the total area of the state and the total UAA of the state.

title: 16S rRNA gene (V3 region) DNA-based analysis of bacterial soil communities at sequence variant level in all forest gap experiment (FOX) plots, using QIIME2-based bioinformatics, 2020-2021
abstract:
We determined the bacterial community composition in all treatments of all forest gap experiment (FOX) plots. This dataset compiles the results of 3 timepoints: January 2020 (immediately before or just at the time of the establishment of the gaps), November 2020 (since the first sampling and start of experiment was done in winter, we had a second sampling on the next winter season), May 2021 (alongside the general soil sampling campaign).
Here, we isolated DNA from soil and sequenced V3 16S rRNA gene amplicons. Note that via extraction of DNA the entire bacterial community is captured, which includes also dormant, inactive cells or even dead cells. The data are provided as quality-checked but non-rarefied read counts of distinct exact sequence variants (Callahan et al 2017). A bacterial sequence variant in this data set is defined by a specific nucleotide sequence of the V3 16S rRNA gene region of 165 base pair length. That means, bacterial sequence variants are distinguished at the level of single nucleotide differences.

title: Seedling traits as obtained in a microcosm experiment under ambient light and temperature conditions for 229 grassland species common in the experimental grassland plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories
abstract:
During the last two decades, the research on plant functional traits has advanced rapidly. However, so far, research has focused on traits of adult plants, while research on seedling traits is scarce. Seedling traits, however, could play an important role during plant establishment from seeds and they are essential to understand the full plant life cycle. We studied seedling traits related to the timing of germination and seedling development (number of days until germination, time until two leaves developed), above- and belowground morphological seedling traits (seedling height, specific leaf area (SLA), root tissue density, specific root length), relative growth rate as well as seedling above- and belowground biomass in the stage, when seedlings had developed the first two true leaves. For this, we examined ca 229 temperate grassland species in a microcosm experiment under ambient light and temperature conditions in an open greenhouse (at the UFZ Field Station Bad Lauchstädt, Saxony-Anhalt, Germany) between November 2020 and July 2022. 
The microcosm experiment was part of the project SeedDiv within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Utilised agricultural area of 24 agricultural land cover classes around all grasslands sites in Schwäbische Alb and Schorfheide-Chorin in 2019
abstract: We compiled a dataset with the Utilized Agricultural Area (UAA) of 24 agricultural land cover classes around all grassland sites in the Schwäbische Alb (ALB) and Schorfheide-Chorin (SCH) in 2019. The data come from combined time series of Sentinel-1, Sentinel-2 and Landsat 8 data for all of Germany and were originally published by Blickensdörfer et al. 2021 and 2022. We extracted the UAA of each class at two buffers (3 and 5 km) from the centroid of each grassland plot in both Exploratories.

title: Seedling traits as obtained in a climate chamber experiment for 195 grassland species common in the experimental grassland plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories
abstract:
During the last two decades, the research on plant functional traits has advanced rapidly. However, so far, research has focused on traits of adult plants, while research on seedling traits is scarce. Seedling traits, however, could play an important role during plant establishment from seeds and they are essential to understand the full plant life cycle. We studied  seedling traits related to the timing of germination and seedling development (number of days until germination, time until two leaves developed), above- and belowground morphological seedling traits (seedling height, specific leaf area (SLA), root tissue density, specific root length), relative growth rate as well as seedling above- and belowground biomass in the stage, when seedlings had developed the first two true leaves. For this, we sow 229 temperate grassland species in a microcosm experiment under controlled light and temperature conditions in a climate chamber (at the German Centre for Integrative Biodiversity Research (iDiv) Halle-Jena-Leipzig, Leipzig, Germany) in 2021 and measured seedling traits for 195 successfully germinated species.
The climate chamber experiment was part of the project SeedDiv within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: The number of seedlings germinated as obtained in a common garden experiment under ambient light and temperature conditions for 219 grassland species common in the experimental grassland plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories
abstract:
During the last two decades, the research on plant functional traits has advanced rapidly. However, so far, research has focused on traits of adult plants, while research on seedling traits is scarce. Seedling traits, however, could play an important role during plant establishment from seeds and they are essential to understand the full plant life cycle. 
We studied the seedling traits: the number of seeds that germinated, the number of weeks until 50% of seeds had germinated (= T50), the date when the first seeds had germinated, and the number of weeks until the first seed had germinated. For this, we examined 219 temperate grassland species which were sown as single species in a microcosm experiment. The experiment was conducted in an open greenhouse with ambient light and temperature conditions (UFZ Field Station Bad Lauchstädt, Saxony-Anhalt, Germany) between November 2020 and July 2021. We obtained data for 213 species, which germinated successfully.
The microcosm experiment was part of the project SeedDiv within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Microbiome composition of Lotus corniculatus from 7 grassland plots in the Swabian Alb, 2018-2021
abstract:
Like all eukaryotes, plants are colonized by a wide range of microbes which collectively form the plant microbiome. The beneficial effects of this colonization for the host, which range from increased growth, nutrient uptake and stress tolerance to protection against pathogens, became better understood in the last years, but we still have a poor understanding of which factors shape such complex communities during the life of a plant. In this study we examine the influence different biotic and abiotic factors such as environmental conditions, host age and genotype and plant organ, on the microbiome composition of Lotus corniculates. 

Therefore, we sampled L. corniculates plants of four consecutive years from 2018-2021 in the Swabian Alb (ALB) research plots AEG3, AEG8, AEG10, AEG17, AEG22, AEG40, AEG43 of the Biodiversity Exploratories project. We divided each plant in roots, shoots, flowers, and seeds and analysed the microbiome (bacteria, fungi and eukaryotes) for each organ separately. In addition, we genotyped each plant using ddRADSeq and determine the plant age by counting the annual ring in the hypocotyl.

title: DNA metabarcoding data of Ranunculus stigma samples for grassland plots in Hainich-Dün and the Schwäbische Alb, 2022
abstract: DNA metabarcoding is a fast and reliable method for analyzing mixed pollen samples, traditionally focusing on the pollinator's perspective, such as dietary patterns or preferences. However, this study shifts the focus to the plant's perspective, examining heterospecific pollen transfer and its potential insights into pollination for plants in semi-natural and agricultural landscapes along a land-use intensity gradient. This dataset includes processed ITS2 DNA metabarcoding data of heterospecific pollen samples of three Ranunculus species. In total 94 samples were collected on 20 grassland plots in Hainich-Dün and the Schwäbische Alb, Germany. Data was collected at the beginning of May (Schwäbische Alb) and end of May 2022 (Hainich-Dün). Data comprises of relative read abundances of plant species found on Ranunculus stigma. The data collection was part of the project MacroBEEs within the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://biodiversity-exploratories.de)

title: Forest Gap Experiment (FOX): DNA-based analysis of soil fungal communities (Illumina MiSeq) - ASV abundances
abstract:
Forests are the largest terrestrial biome on Earth and have many important functions like the provision of habitats for wildlife and the storage of carbon, which can help to mitigate climate change. In the recent years, forest disturbances by natural forces or by anthropogenic activities have increased within Europe resulting in tree gaps in the forests. Forest gaps would naturally still contain surviving trees and the wood of the dead trees. Such biological legacies are missing in salvage-logged or clear-cut logged forest gaps. The forest soil microbiome plays an important role in maintaining the structure and functions of forests. Fungi, which form a major proportion of the forest microbiome, are strongly affected by forest disturbances. To understand the impact of forest disturbances on the overall biodiversity and to develop appropriate measurements to promote forest regeneration, it is important to also understand how the forest soil mycobiome is affected by forest disturbances.
In the frame of the forest gap experiment (FOX), we aim to understand the impact of forest gaps and the retention of deadwood on the composition and diversity of soil fungi was investigated in a such controlled field experiment. Therefore, we determined the fungal community composition in all FOX treatments. 
Please note: This dataset compiles currently the results of three time points: December2019/January 2020 (t0 - immediately before or just at the time of the establishment of the gaps), November 2020 (t1 - since the first sampling and start of experiment was done in winter, we had a second sampling on the next winter season), May 2021 (t2 - alongside the SSC).

title: Forest Gap Experiment (FOX): DNA-based analysis of soil fungal communities (Illumina MiSeq) - ASV taxonomic look-up table
abstract:
Forests are the largest terrestrial biome on Earth and have many important functions like the provision of habitats for wildlife and the storage of carbon, which can help to mitigate climate change. In the recent years, forest disturbances by natural forces or by anthropogenic activities have increased within Europe resulting in tree gaps in the forests. Forest gaps would naturally still contain surviving trees and the wood of the dead trees. Such biological legacies are missing in salvage-logged or clear-cut logged forest gaps. The forest soil microbiome plays an important role in maintaining the structure and functions of forests. Fungi, which form a major proportion of the forest microbiome, are strongly affected by forest disturbances. To understand the impact of forest disturbances on the overall biodiversity and to develop appropriate measurements to promote forest regeneration, it is important to also understand how the forest soil mycobiome is affected by forest disturbances.
In the frame of the forest gap experiment (FOX), we aim to understand the impact of forest gaps and the retention of deadwood on the composition and diversity of soil fungi was investigated in a such controlled field experiment. Therefore, we determined the fungal community composition in all FOX treatments. 
Please note: This dataset compiles currently the results of three time points: December2019/January 2020 (t0 - immediately before or just at the time of the establishment of the gaps), November 2020 (t1 - since the first sampling and start of experiment was done in winter, we had a second sampling on the next winter season), May 2021 (t2 - alongside the SSC).

title: Codebook on the relationships of forester’s nature values and land management
abstract: This codebook entails the meta-data as well as coding sheets for our coding of foresters' nature values in relationship to their management approaches. Between May and November 2021 we interviewed 15 foresters in Schorfheide-Chorin to better understand how their nature values, preferences for nature's contributions to people, and management approaches are interconnected. The interviews were transcribed using NVIVO (2022) software, checked manually, and coded using in MAXQDA (2022). Due to anonymity reasons this dataset contains the coding set used to analysed the interview transcripts as well as the binary code derived from these.

title: Compiled larval trait data and RScript used in "Influence of temperature and light on the development of moth larvae: different response in the sister species Orthosia gothica and Orthosia cerasi"
abstract:
This dataset contains the larval trait data used in "Influence of temperature and light on the development of moth larvae: different response in the sister species Orthosia gothica and Orthosia cerasi". The pupation data used in this study is linked, ID 31868.
This study, conducted between April 2022 and June 2022 at the Biocentre of the University of Würzburg, investigated the effects of different temperature and light cycle treatments on the larval development and pupation of the moths O. gothica and O. cerasi. The development time and the life history traits body size in mm and body weight in g were recorded. 
The data collection/analysis was part of the project GapResin within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories.
Attached is also the RScript to reproduce the statistical analyses and figures used in the manuscript "Influence of temperature and light on the development of moth larvae: different response in the sister species Orthosia gothica and Orthosia cerasi".

title: Air and soil temperature, relative humidity, and light intensity during a common garden experiment under ambient light and temperature conditions for 230 grassland species common in the experimental grassland plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories
abstract:
During the last two decades, the research on plant functional traits has advanced rapidly. However, so far, research has focused on traits of adult plants, while research on seedling traits is scarce. Seedling traits, however, could play an important role during plant establishment from seeds and they are essential to understand the full plant life cycle. However, environmental conditions like climate (light, temperature, relative humidity) and light intensity further influence this stage and are an important additional asset.
We measured the soil temperature (at 5 cm depth) and air temperature, relative humidity (both at 5 cm above the soil surface), and light intensity. All values resemble daily means during the time period of the microcosm common garden experiment in Bad Lauchstädt (near Halle), Germany.
The microcosm experiment was part of the project SeedDiv within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Soil pH - soil sampling campaign 2024, all arable plots, 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the soil pH values in 0-10 cm depth from all arable plots in 2024. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil pH is considered a master variable in soil science as it affects many chemical processes in soils. Most importantly, the plant nutrient availability is greatly affected by the soil pH as it controls the chemical forms of the different nutrients and influences the chemical reactions they undergo. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-5, TR 1054/4-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Seed mass and seed morphological traits for 293 grassland species occurring in the grassland experimental plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories
abstract: Morphological traits of seeds (or the dispersule) are important functional traits related to dispersal (seed morphology) and storage of reserves (seed mass). The data contain seed mass and measured morphological traits (projected area, straight length, curved length, straight width, curved width, curvature, width-to-length ratio and projected perimeter) for 293 species occurring in the grassland experimental plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. The data collection was part of the project SeedDiv within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Seed chemical traits for 291 grassland species occurring in the grassland experimental plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories
abstract: Chemical traits of seeds (or the dispersule) are important functional traits related to storage of reserves. The data contain seed chemical traits (concentrations of total carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium, sulphur, magnesium, iron, copper, manganesum, boron, zinc) for 291 species occurring in the grassland experimental plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. The data collection was part of the project SeedDiv within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Nitrogen and carbon concentrations in aboveground biomass of seedlings as obtained in a microcosm experiment under ambient light and temperature conditions for 227 species occurring on the grassland EPs of the Biodiversity Exploratories
abstract: During the last two decades, the research on plant functional traits has advanced rapidly. However, so far, research has focused on traits of adult plants, while research on seedling traits is scarce. Seedling traits, however, could play an important role during plant establishment from seeds and they are essential to understand the full plant life cycle. We analyzed the nitrogen and carbon concentrations of the aboveground biomass of seedling in the stage when they had developed the first two true leaves. For this, we examined 227 temperate grassland species in a microcosm experiment under ambient light and temperature conditions in an open greenhouse at the Experimental Field Station Bad Lauchstädt (UFZ, Helmholtz Centre for Environmental Research) between 2020 and 2022. The microcosm experiment was part of the project SeedDiv within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: ForMIX index quantifying land use for all forest plots
abstract: A quantitative measure of land use in forests should be biologically meaningful, comparable among forest types, and most importantly, derivable from standard inventory data and easy to understand and interpret. This dataset contains the new forest index, named "ForMIX" (Forest Management Index), that advances the already available SMI (Silvicultural management intensity index) and ForMI (Forest management intensity index). The new ForMIX index blends data on tree species composition, deficit in deadwood (i.e. inverse of deadwood availability), tree removal and stand maturity to derive a quantitative measure, which can be used to analyse the influence of forest land use. Index calculations are available for all 150 forest plots in the Biodiversity Exploratories (3 different regions in Germany: Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). At present, the index is based on the data from the first (mainly conducted between 2009-2012) and second forest inventory (conducted between 2015-2018).

title: Gravimetric soil water content - soil sampling campaign 2024, all arable plots, 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the gravimetric soil water contents and dry matter contents in 0-10 cm depth from all arable plots in 2024. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil water content has a dominant influence on plant growth, soil temperature, transport of chemical compounds, ground water recharge and soil aeration. The gravimetric soil water content is the mass of water in the soil, measured as the weight difference between the moist and the oven-dry soil. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-5, TR 1054/4-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Soil carbon, nitrogen and sulfur concentrations - soil sampling campaign 2024, all arable plots, 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the organic carbon (OC), inorganic carbon (IC), total nitrogen (TN) and total sulfur (TS) concentrations, and carbon to nitrogen ratios (CN ratio) as well as carbon to sulfur ratios (CS ratio)  in 0-10 cm depth from all arable soils in 2024. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil organic carbon, nitrogen and sulfur concentrations are master variables in soil science. They are the measureable components of soil organic matter (SOM). SOM exerts positive effects on numerous physical, chemical and biological soil properties. An increase in SOM generally results in an improved soil structure, soil moisture retention, soil buffering capacity, retention of pollutants, cycling and storage of plant nutrients and biodiversity. SOM also acts as a sink and source for atmospheric carbon dioxide. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-5, TR 1054/4-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Soil enzyme activities - soil sampling campaign 2024, all arable soils, 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the soil enzyme activities in 0-10 cm depth from all arable soils in 2024. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil enzymes play an important role in nutrient turnover in forest ecosystems as they are responsible for the conversion of organic matter into plant-available nutrients. We measured the activities of key enzymes involved in N, C, P, and S cycling. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-5, TR 1054/4-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Soil pH - subsoil sampling 2023, all medium intensity research plots (MIPs), 0-100 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the soil pH values in 0-100 cm depth from all medium intensity research plots (MIPs) in 2023/2024. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil pH is considered a master variable in soil science as it affects many chemical processes in soils. Most importantly, the plant nutrient availability is greatly affected by the soil pH as it controls the chemical forms of the different nutrients and influences the chemical reactions they undergo. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-5, TR 1054/4-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Olsen P - soil sampling campaign 2023, all experimental plots (EP), 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3)-extractable inorganic phosphorus (P), commonly termed Olsen-P in 0-10 cm depth from all experimental plots (EPs) in 2023. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). The Olsen P analysis provides an estimate of the inorganic ortho-phosphate (PO4-P) that is accessible as “available” phosphorus for uptake by plants. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-5, TR 1054/4-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/)

title: 16S rRNA gene (V3 region) RNA-based analysis of microbial soil communities at sequence variant level in 150 forest plots, using QIIME2-based bioinformatics, 2021
abstract:
We determine the microbial community composition in 300 EP plots from grassland and woodlands in three regions of Germany (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). Most bacteria in soil are dormant or inactive. A substantial fraction might even be dead. Hence, in order to quantify the living and active bacteria, we isolated RNA from soil in 2021 and sequenced V3 16S rRNA amplicons.

The presence and amount of ribosomes in a cell can be taken as a rough proxy for activity. The results indicate substantial difference between grassland and woodland soils. Moreover, bacterial communities can be additionally distinguished by their soil type.

Here, the data are provided as quality-checked but non-rarefied read counts of distinct exact sequence variants (Callahan et al. 2017). A bacterial sequence variant in this data set is defined by a specific nucleotide sequence of the V3 16S rRNA gene region of 165 base pair length. That means, bacterial sequence variants are distinguished at the level of single nucleotide differences.

This dataset contains the data from RNA extractions of the forest plots.

title: Macromoths collected in all forest gap experiment (FOX) plots in 2020 and 2021
abstract: We collected nightflying macromoths in all forest gap experiment (FOX) plots once per month in June and July in 2020 and 2021 with autonomous light traps. We wanted to test the influence of canopy structure and the FOX experimental setup of gaps and deadwood on moth diversity.

title: Olsen P - soil sampling campaign 2021, all reduced land-use intensity experiment (REX) and land-use experiment (LUX) plots, 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset dataset contains the sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3)-extractable inorganic phosphorus (P), commonly termed Olsen-P in 0-10 cm depth from all reduced land-use intensity experiment (REX) and land-use experiment (LUX) plots in 2021. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). The Olsen P analysis provides an estimate of the inorganic ortho-phosphate (PO4-P) that is accessible as “available” phosphorus for uptake by plants. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-4, TR 1054/4-4, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Compiled pupation data used in "Influence of temperature and light on the development of moth larvae: different response in the sister species Orthosia gothica and Orthosia cerasi"
abstract:
This dataset contains the pupation data used in "Influence of temperature and light on the development of moth larvae: different response in the sister species Orthosia gothica and Orthosia cerasi". The larval trait data and RScript used for the statistical analyses in this study is linked, ID 31841.
This study, conducted between April 2022 and June 2022 at the Biocentre of the University of Würzburg, investigated the effects of different temperature and light cycle treatments on the larval development and pupation of the moths O. gothica and O. cerasi. The number of larvae which had gone into pupation since the previous day has been recorded. Each row represents another larva that has gone into pupation.
The data collection/analysis was part of the project GapResin within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories.

title: Soil enzyme activities and microbial biomass; Forest HEW11, HEW12, HEW40; 0 – 10 cm; 2022 - 2023
abstract:
The cooperation project MykCZyk studies the influence of mycorrhizal type and tree diversity on carbon and nitrogen cycling. For this, 12 plots in the Hainich are studied, of which three are exploratory plots (HEW11, HEW12, HEW40). This dataset contains the microbial biomass and soil enzyme activity in those three exploratory plots.
Most tree species form symbiosis with ectomycorrhizal (ECM) or arbuscular mycorrhizal (AM) fungi to acquire mineral nutrients in exchange for carbon (C). Extracellular enzymes are produced by microorganisms to obtain nutrients and are involved in the decomposition of different organic compounds. We studied β-1,4-N-acetylglucosaminidase (NAG) for the depolymerisation of organic nitrogen (N), β-1,4-glucosidase (Glu) for relatively labile C constituents and phenol oxidase (Phenox) and peroxidase (Perox) for recalcitrant C constituents. We analysed if monoculture ECM forest stands have lower microbial biomass, faster recalcitrant C and N cycling, and slower labile C cycling than pure AM forest stands.

title: Olsen P - soil sampling campaign 2024, all arable plots, 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3)-extractable inorganic phosphorus (P), commonly termed Olsen-P in 0-10 cm depth from all arable plots in 2024. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). The Olsen P analysis provides an estimate of the inorganic ortho-phosphate (PO4-P) that is accessible as “available” phosphorus for uptake by plants. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-5, TR 1054/4-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/)

title: Olsen P - soil sampling campaign 2023, all reduced land-use intensity experiment (REX) and land-use experiment (LUX) plots, 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset dataset contains the sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3)-extractable inorganic phosphorus (P), commonly termed Olsen-P in 0-10 cm depth from all reduced land-use intensity experiment (REX) and land-use experiment (LUX) plots in 2023. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). The Olsen P analysis provides an estimate of the inorganic ortho-phosphate (PO4-P) that is accessible as “available” phosphorus for uptake by plants. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-5, TR 1054/4-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Soil bulk density and organic carbon, total nitrogen and total sulfur stocks - soil sampling campaign 2021, all experimental plots (EP), 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the soil bulk density and the soil organic carbon (OC), total nitrogen (TN) and total sulfur (TS) stocks in 0-10 cm depth from all experimental plots (EP) in 2021. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soils are important reservoirs for carbon, nitrogen and sulfur. The storage of organic carbon and nutrients is not only important for climate regulation and plant growth but also affects other soil functions. A multitude of natural factors (e.g. climate, parent material, landscape position) but also human-induced factors (e.g. land use type, management intensity) influence the potential of soils to store carbon and nutrients. Bulk density is used to calculate elemental stocks but at same time it is also an important indicator of the degree of soil compaction. It therefore greatly affects the water and solute movement in soils and the soil aeration.The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-4, TR 1054/4-4, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: IBP Score (Index of Biodiversity Potential) of all forest plots
abstract: To identify management effects on biodiversity, an estimation of biodiversity using forest structural attributes may be a reasonable approach. Forest structure can - compared to conventional species-based monitoring - easily be captured during forest inventories and does not require specific taxonomic expertise. The IBP (Index of Biodiversity Potential) developed by Larrieu and Gonin (2008) is a composite index aiming to provide practitioners with an efficient tool for estimating biodiversity at the local level. The IBP protocol consists of 10 factors considered among the most common structural drivers of forest biodiversity. They are easy and quick to record in the field, and do not require additional equipment or special taxonomic expertise to get the IBP score. The IBP was assessed in August 2020 on 147 EPs in all three biodiversity exploratories (the reamaining three plots had been heavily affected by storm events and were excluded).

title: Soil bulk density and organic carbon, total nitrogen and total sulfur stocks - soil sampling campaign 2017, all experimental plots (EP), 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the soil bulk density and the soil organic carbon (OC), total nitrogen (TN) and total sulfur (TS) stocks in 0-10 cm depth from all experimental plots (EP) in 2017. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soils are important reservoirs for carbon, nitrogen and sulfur. The storage of organic carbon and nutrients is not only important for climate regulation and plant growth but also affects other soil functions. A multitude of natural factors (e.g. climate, parent material, landscape position) but also human-induced factors (e.g. land use type, management intensity) influence the potential of soils to store carbon and nutrients. Bulk density is used to calculate elemental stocks but at same time it is also an important indicator of the degree of soil compaction. It therefore greatly affects the water and solute movement in soils and the soil aeration.The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-3, TR 1054/4-3, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Microbial biomass (Cmic) of leaf litter in 48 forest plots in the Hainich-Dün, Schwäbische Alb and Schorfheide-Chorin measured in three-year intervals from 2008-2020
abstract: Fungi and bacteria contribute significantly to the diet of soil detritivores.  We measured the microbial biomass (bacteria and fungi) in leaf litter of different forest types, i.e., near-natural beech forests, managed beech forests and coniferous forests across the three exploratories (Hainich-Dün, Schwäbische Alb, Schorfheide-Chorin) in three-year intervals from 2008-2020 as a potential driving factor for the community dynamics of soil invertebrates. Microbial biomass in litter was determined using substrate-induced respiration (SIR), i.e. the respiratory response of microorganisms after glucose addition. Leaf litter was aggregated from three soil cores (5 cm in diameter) on each sampling site and homogenized prior to measurement.

title: Soil bulk density and organic carbon, total nitrogen and total sulfur stocks - soil sampling campaign 2023, all experimental plots (EP), 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the soil bulk density and the soil organic carbon (OC), total nitrogen (TN) and total sulfur (TS) stocks in 0-10 cm depth from all experimental plots (EP) in 2023. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soils are important reservoirs for carbon, nitrogen and sulfur. The storage of organic carbon and nutrients is not only important for climate regulation and plant growth but also affects other soil functions. A multitude of natural factors (e.g. climate, parent material, landscape position) but also human-induced factors (e.g. land use type, management intensity) influence the potential of soils to store carbon and nutrients. Bulk density is used to calculate elemental stocks but at same time it is also an important indicator of the degree of soil compaction. It therefore greatly affects the water and solute movement in soils and the soil aeration.The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-5, TR 1054/4-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) / drone images from all Exploratory forest regions
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) or drones provide remote sensing images with a very high spatial resolution which can be used to analyze the small scale variation / spatial heterogeneity of forest at three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). Such data can also be used to support the field work or as training data for the development of classification models

title: Microbial biomass (Cmic) in sites of the forest gap experiment sampled in 2020 and 2021
abstract: Fungi and bacteria are a major part of the diet of soil detritivores. We measured the microbial biomass (bacteria and fungi) in leaf litter and soil of forests where deadwood availability and gap formation were manipulated in a full factorial design (Control, Gap, Deadwood, Gap + Deadwood). Forest gaps of about 30 m in diameter were established by felling trees, which were subsequently removed (Gap) or left on site as deadwood (Gap + Deadwood). Nearby forest sites without gaps were enriched with the equal amount of felled trees (Deadwood) or left untreated (Control). Experimental treatments were established in spring 2020 at 29 forest sites including deciduous and coniferous stands in three regions of Germany, i.e. the Swabian Alb, Hanich-Dün and Schorfheide-Chorin in the south, center and north, respectively. Treatment-induced changes in soil and litter properties may alter the microbial biomass, which has been determined as a potential driver for forest soil animal communities.

title: pH value of woodblocks from Fagus sylvatica, Pinus sylvestris, and Picea abies in forest and grassland experimental plots (EPs)
abstract:
Analysis of the deadwood pH value of woodblocks from beech (Fagus sylvatica), pine (Pinus sylvestris) and spruce (Picea abies). The study sites were 50 forest research plots and 50 grassland research plots each located in Germany (Hainich, Swabian Alb and Schorfheide - overall 300 research plots). The woodblocks were exposed to the environment from 2017 to 2018. Afterwards, pH value was measured. 
This project was part of the FunWood IV core project and funded by the German Research Foundation (DFG).

title: Metatranscriptomic dataset (Small Subunit ribosomal ribonucleic acids (SSU rRNA)) of grassland soils from all experimental plots (sampling campaign May 2021)
abstract: This CSV file contains fully processed metatranscriptome data (taxonomy and counts based on SSU rRNA) of grassland topsoils from all experimental plots (EP) in three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) (except SEG2). The samples were collected as part of the sampling campaign in May 2021, the RNA was extracted using phenol-chloroform extraction (Core project Microorganisms), metatranscriptome libraries were prepared (NEB Next Ultra II Library Prep Kit for Illumina) at the University Greifswald and sequenced using Illumnia NovaSeq 6000 (Cologne Center for Genomics). The sequence data were submitted to an internal PhyloFLASH processing pipeline (University Greifswald), SSU sequences were identified and blasted against Silva 138.1, eukaryotic sequences were filtered out and reclassified using CREST4.

title: Vegetation summary in arable lands 2024 incl. biomass
abstract: Long-term monitoring of plants is an important element to assess the effect of land use on the functioning of ecosystems on the landscape level. Plants and their diversity affect other trophic groups and the temporal stability of the plant community is an important indicator of ecosystem functioning. Therefore, we assess the diversity and biomass of vascular plants on 30 arable land plots in three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) that differ in their agricultural intensity. For this, we estimate the cover of seeded crop and weed (without individual species abundances) on an area of 4 m x 4 m in summer 2024, which is given in this dataset. In addition, we measure biomass of crops and weeds in summer. From this data, we can calculate productivity. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Vegetation records in arable lands 2024
abstract: Long-term monitoring of plants is an important element to assess the effect of land use on the functioning of ecosystems on the landscape level. Plants and their diversity affect other trophic groups and the temporal stability of the plant community is an important indicator of ecosystem functioning. Therefore, we assess the diversity of vascular plants on 30 arable land plots in three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) that differ in their agricultural intensity. For this, we estimate the abundance of each plant species (seeded crop and weed) on an area of 4 m x 4 m in summer 2024, which is given in this dataset. From this data, we can calculate plant diversity. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Abundance data of Bombus lapidarius and Episyrphus balteatus in the three regions of Biodiversity Exploratories in 2008, 2012 and 2020
abstract: We conducted a temporal analysis to investigate whether the effects of land-use intensity on pollinator health and pollinator abundance are stable over time. For this, we used conserved pollinator specimen of two abundant pollinator species, Bombus lapidarius and Episyrphus balteatus, sampled in the years 2008, 2012 and 2020 in all three Exploratories (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). Abundance data was calculated based on observed pollinator-plant interactions and number of specimen caught.

title: Olsen P fractions - soil sampling campaign 2023, all forest experimental plots (EP), 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3)-extractable total, inorganic and organic phosphorus (TP, Pi, Po) in 0-10 cm depth from all experimental plots (EPs) in 2023. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-5, TR 1054/4-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/)

title: Olsen P  fractions - soil sampling campaign 2023, all forest gap exeriment (FOX) plots, 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3)-extractable inorganic phosphorus (P), commonly termed Olsen-P in 0-10 cm depth from all forest gap experiment (FOX) plots in 2023. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-5, TR 1054/4-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/)

title: Olsen P - soil sampling campaign 2023, all forest gap exeriment (FOX) plots, 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories.
