title: Olsen P - soil sampling campaign 2021, all forest gap exeriment (FOX) plots, 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3)-extractable inorganic phosphorus (P), commonly termed Olsen-P in 0-10 cm depth from all forest gap experiment (FOX) plots in 2021. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). The Olsen P analysis provides an estimate of the inorganic ortho-phosphate (PO4-P) that is accessible as “available” phosphorus for uptake by plants. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-4, TR 1054/4-4, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/)

title: Aggregated pixel values of grassland fields and farms, 2020-2021
abstract:
A dataset composed of aggregated pixel values on alpha plant species richness, aboveground biomass, land use intensity index (LUI), spectral heterogeneity (Rao's Q based on NDVI) and topographic wetness index (TWI) at the three spatial scales of (1) virtual plots (not the grassland EPs, but also 50x50 m), (2) fields and (3) farms in 2020 and 2021. 

All variables originate from remote sensing and pixel values were extracted within polygons of grassland fields and farms in the regions Schorfheide-Chorin and Hainich-Dün based on data of agricultural subsidy requests (see methods).

title: Biomass data for grassland EPs, 2009 - 2024
abstract:
Long-term monitoring of plant biomass is an important element to assess the productivity of grasslands. To create a dataset of a large-scale long-term time series vegetation biomass, we weighed dry biomass annually from 2009 to 2024 on 150 grassland plots in 3 different regions in Germany (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). These grasslands differed in land-use intensity, ranging from unfertilized pastures grazed once to fertilized pastures and meadows grazed heavily or mown repeatedly.

The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Vegetation records for grassland EPs, 2008 - 2024
abstract: Long-term monitoring of plants is an important element to assess the effect of land use in grasslands on the functioning of ecosystems. Plants and their diversity affect other trophic groups and the temporal stability of the plant community is an important indicator of ecosystem functioning. Therefore, we assess the diversity of vascular plants on 150 grassland plots in three German regions (Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) that differ in their management intensity. For this, we estimate the abundance of each plant species on an area of 4 m x 4 m in May/June from 2008 to 2024, which is given in this dataset. From this data, we calculate plant diversity as well as trends and variability of individual plant species over time. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Data on morphological traits of Bombus lapidarius and Episyrphus balteatus in the three regions of the Biodiversity Exploratories in 2008, 2012 and 2020
abstract: We conducted a temporal analysis to investigate whether the effects of land-use intensity on pollinator health and pollinator abundance are stable over time. For this, we used conserved pollinator specimen of two abundant pollinator species, Bombus lapidarius and Episyrphus balteatus, sampled in the years 2008, 2012 and 2020 in all three Exploratories (ALB, HAI & SCH). We measured wing centroid sizes, which was used as a proxy for body size and to calculate fluctuating asymmetry.

title: Predicted and measured biomass and plant species richness at plot scale, 2020-2021
abstract: This dataset is used to compare the biodiversity - ecosystem functioning (BEF) relationship between plant species richness and aboveground biomass production (and its spatial variability) of measured field data and predicted raster data at the scale of grassland EPs. Within the scope of the SeBAS project, field data was measured in 2020 and 2021 and pixel values of prediction maps were aggregated within borders of grassland experimental plots (EPs).

title: Vegetation analysis and trait data of plant communities originating from the Exploratories in the common garden in Marburg (2020-2022)
abstract:
Changes in land-use intensity along with land degradation have been identified as major causes of the decline in biodiversity and a loss of ecological functions. The application of fertilizer, mowing and grazing are land-use components that have been shown to affect plant species diversity and composition in grasslands in many ways. However, a strong environmental impact on the effects of land use can be inferred by the variation in strength as well as direction of these effects. Site-specific differences in regard to various environmental factors between but also within the three Exploratories impede a separation of environmental and land-use effects and therefore the identification of the actual effects of land use on communities. Thus, we established a controlled environment by using a common-garden approach to better illustrate the sole effects of various types of land use by reducing environmental heterogeneity to a minimum.
To establish a common garden at the University Marburg in April-May 2020, grass sods (1x1m) harvested at n = 39 plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories that best represent a land-use gradient from all three regions have been partitioned into four equal parts. Each of the subplots (50x50cm) will be subjected to one of four land-use treatments. Additionally, one plot containing sterilized soil has been placed in each treatment block.
Treatments differed in mowing frequency and application of fertilizer in a full factorial design: ‘Control’ (= mowing once per year), ‘Mowing’ (= mowing twice per year), ‘Fertilizer’ (= mowing once per year and fertilizing once per year) and ‘Mowing & Fertilizer’ (= mowing twice per year and fertilizing once per year).
This dataset contains data on the taxonomic composition of the sods as well as manual measurements of plant traits (plant height [cm], leaf length [cm] and width [cm], leaf dry weight [g] and specific leaf area [mm2 mg-1]). Vegetation surveys were conducted in June/July 2020,2021 and 2022 where all vascular plant species were identified and their cover was estimated with a resolution of 1% and trait values were recorded in 2020 for all plant species that covered >5% in a sod according to the vegetation survey.
The data collection and analysis was part of the project EXClAve within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Forest gap experiment (FOX) deadwood volume and gap size, 2020
abstract:
The Forest gap experiment (FOX) is a full factorial joint experiment of the biodiversity exploratories, in which canopy closure and deadwood availability were manipulated. It was installed from January to April 2020.
  
The FOX experiment comprises the treatments G (gap cutting), GD (gap cutting and deadwood enrichment), D (deadwood enrichment) and C (control = EP). However, the size of the gap and the amount of deadwood enrichment depended on stand characteristics. 

This data set summarizes the added deadwood volume and the gap size within the FOX experiment after establishment.

title: Composition of mineral-associated organic carbon as revealed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, for 53 very intensive plots at various soil depths, 2020
abstract: The composition of soil organic matter links to its accumulation and stability. Here we determine carbon species on the surface of pristine minerals (the iron oxyhydroxide, goethite, and the phyllosilicate clay, illite) buried for five years (November 2015 to August 2020) at different soil depths in differently managed forest and grassland plots across three regions in Germany (i.e., Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün and Schorfheide-Chorin).

title: Stable isotope ratios of mineral-associated organic carbon, for 53 very intensive plots at various soil depths, 2020
abstract: The composition of soil organic matter links to its accumulation and stability. Here we determined the stable isotope ratio of organic carbon accumulated on pristine minerals (the iron oxyhydroxide, goethite, and the phyllosilicate clay, illite) buried for five years (November 2015 to August 2020) at different soil depths in differently managed forest and grassland plots across three regions in Germany (i.e., Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün and Schorfheide-Chorin).

title: Vegetation summary and biomass data for 150 grassland EPs in 2024 without species identities
abstract:
Long-term monitoring of plants is an important element to assess the effect of grassland land use on the functioning of ecosystems. Plants and their diversity affect other trophic groups and the temporal stability of the plant community is an important indicator of ecosystem functioning. Therefore, we assess the diversity of all vascular plants on all 150 grassland plots from the three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) that differ in land-use intensity, ranging from unfertilized pastures grazed once, to fertilized pastures and meadows grazed heavily or mown repeatedly. 

This dataset is containing general data on land use and vegetation from 2024. These data are the date of survey, vegetation height, the cover of the 4 m x 4 m survey plot (shrubs, herbs, lichens, litter, deadwood, rocks, bare soil), vascular plant species richness, cumulative cover, and dry biomass. 

This dataset doesn't contain individual species identity and cover.

The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Species data, abundance and biomass of Chilopoda in the forest experiment plots 2021 - 2023
abstract: Most forests in Central Europe are subject to human management, especially timber harvesting, altering soil conditions by creating gaps in the forest canopy and reducing the availability of deadwood. However, consequences of these management practices, in particular the combined effects of gap formation and deadwood removal, on soil arthropod predators have been largely neglected. Here, we sampled centipedes (Myriapoda: Chilopoda) by taking soil cores in forests where deadwood availability and gap formation were manipulated in a full factorial design (Control, Gap, Deadwood, Gap + Deadwood). Forest gaps of about 30 m in diameter were established by felling trees, which were subsequently removed (Gap) or left on site as deadwood (Gap + Deadwood). Nearby forest sites without gaps were enriched with the equal amount of felled trees (Deadwood) or left untreated (Control). Experimental treatments were established in spring 2020 at 29 forest sites including deciduous and coniferous stands in three regions of Germany, i.e. the Swabian Alb, Hanich-Dün and Schorfheide-Chorin in the south, center and north, respectively. Centipedes were counted, identified to species and biomass was estimated using length and witdth for all individuals.

title: Tire wear particle effects on soils from Schwäbische-Alb and Hainich-Dün research plots of the Exploratories project, 2023-2024 used in "Soil properties explain the variability in tire wear particle effects in soil in a test with 59 soils"
abstract:
The data showed the effects of tire wear particles (TWPs) on the soil properties such as water-stable aggregates (WSA), pH, respiration, and decomposition rate, which varied with the sampling plots.
Soils (0-10 cm) were collected from grassland plots in two regions of Germany (Schwäbische Alb and Hainich-Dün) in 2021.

title: Mesofauna abundances at grouplevel in forest experiment plots 2021 and 2023
abstract: Most forests in Central Europe are subject to human management, especially timber harvesting, which alters soil conditions by creating gaps in the forest canopy and reduces the availability of deadwood. However, consequences of these management practices, in particular the combined effect of gap formation and deadwood removal, have been largely neglected. Here, we sampled three major soil mesofauna groups (Collembola, Oribatida, Mesostigmata) by taking soil cores in forests where deadwood availability and gap formation were manipulated in a full factorial design (Control, Gap, Deadwood, Gap + Deadwood). Forest gaps of about 30 m in diameter were established by felling trees, which were subsequently removed (Gap) or left on site as deadwood (Gap + Deadwood). Nearby forest sites without gaps were enriched with the equal amount of felled trees (Deadwood) or left untreated (Control). Experimental treatments were established in spring 2020 at 29 forest sites including deciduous and coniferous stands in three regions of Germany, i.e. the Swabian Alb, Hanich-Dün and Schorfheide-Chorin in the south, center and north, respectively.

title: Species data, abundance and biomass of Isopoda and Diplopoda in the forest experiment plots 2021
abstract: Most forests in Central Europe are subject to timber harvesting, altering soil conditions by creating gaps in the forest canopy and reducing the availability of deadwood. However, consequences of these management practices, in particular the combined effects of gap formation and deadwood removal, on soil arthropod detritivores have been largely neglected. Here, we sampled millipedes (Myriapoda: Diplopoda) and woodlice (Crustacea: Isopoda) by taking soil cores in forests where deadwood availability and gap formation were manipulated in a full factorial design (Control, Gap, Deadwood, Gap + Deadwood). Forest gaps of about 30 m in diameter were established by felling trees, which were subsequently removed (Gap) or left on site as deadwood (Gap + Deadwood). Nearby forest sites without gaps were enriched with the equal amount of felled trees (Deadwood) or left untreated (Control). Experimental treatments were established in spring 2020 at 29 forest sites including deciduous and coniferous stands in three regions of Germany, i.e. the Swabian Alb, Hanich-Dün and Schorfheide-Chorin in the south, center and north, respectively. Millipedes and woodlice were counted, identified to species and biomass was estimated using bodymass regressions based on length and witdth for all individuals.

title: Species data, abundance and biomass of Lumbricidae in the forest experiment plots 2021
abstract: Most forests in Central Europe are subject to timber harvesting, altering soil conditions by creating gaps in the forest canopy and reducing the availability of deadwood. However, consequences of these management practices, in particular the combined effects of gap formation and deadwood removal, on soil arthropod detritivores have been largely neglected. Here, we sampled earthworms (Oligochaeta, Lumbricidae) by taking soil cores in forests where deadwood availability and gap formation were manipulated in a full factorial design (Control, Gap, Deadwood, Gap + Deadwood). Forest gaps of about 30 m in diameter were established by felling trees, which were subsequently removed (Gap) or left on site as deadwood (Gap + Deadwood). Nearby forest sites without gaps were enriched with the equal amount of felled trees (Deadwood) or left untreated (Control). Experimental treatments were established in spring 2020 at 29 forest sites including deciduous and coniferous stands in three regions of Germany, i.e. the Swabian Alb, Hanich-Dün and Schorfheide-Chorin in the south, center and north, respectively. Earthworms were counted, identified to species and biomass was estimated using length and witdth for all individuals.

title: Temporal pair-wise comparisons of plant-community and land-use data (all experimental plots 2008-2018)
abstract: Land-use intensification is considered a major driver of biodiversity loss. However, most evidence for land use effects come from space-for-time substitutions, comparing biodiversity in areas differing in current land use intensity. Despite their frequent use, the robustness of space-for-time substitutions in capturing temporal changes in biodiversity remains unclear. We compared spatial and temporal responses of plant and arthropod communities to changes in land-use intensity, using 150, ten-year time series from grasslands in three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) (this dataset, 31924, 31925, 31926). This data set comprises the data used to calculate temporal diversity responses of  plant communities to land-use changes (all experimental plots 2008-2018).

title: Full genome sequence of Paraconexibacter strain AEG42_29
abstract:
Strain AEG42_29 was isolated from a temperate grassland soil near Gomadingen, Germany and was found to be affiliated with the order Solirubrobacterales. The soil sample from where it originated was taken in May 2014, as part of the general soil sampling campaign. The full genome from this strain was assembled and deposited at GeneBank.
The genome sequence was deposited at DDBJ/ENA/GenBank under the accession number CP114014. Raw reads are available in the European Nucleotide Archive (ENA) under the accession number ERR13866265.

title: Vegetation records 2020-2024 for new grassland experiment REX and LUX
abstract:
Land-use changes are major drivers of plant diversity in grasslands in all three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). However, how effective a reduction in land use intensity is in recovering plant diversity is unclear, and deliberate sowing of some plants may be necessary to restore grassland diversity. Furthermore, different components of land use, e.g. mowing, fertilizing, and grazing, are correlated with each other, and therefore assessing the effect of individual components of land use requires disentangling them experimentally. In the new grassland experiments REX and LUX, we study the effect of reduced land use intensity and seed sowing on plant diversity. For this, we compare factorially combined plots with regular and reduced land use that were seeded or not-seeded with additional plants. Furthermore, we study the effect of individual components of land use. For this, we compare factorially combined plots with regular and reduced land use with or without fertilization.
Plant diversity is recorded on a 2 m x 2 m subplot by estimating the coverage of each species between May and early June from 2020 to 2024. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Spatial pair-wise comparisons of plant-community and land-use data (all experimental plots 2008-2018)
abstract: Land-use intensification is considered a major driver of biodiversity loss. However, most evidence for land use effects come from space-for-time substitutions, comparing biodiversity in areas differing in current land use intensity. Despite their frequent use, the robustness of space-for-time substitutions in capturing temporal changes in biodiversity remains unclear. We compared spatial and temporal responses of plant and arthropod communities to changes in land-use intensity, using 150, ten-year time series from grasslands in three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin)  (this dataset, 31921, 31925, 31926). This data set comprises the data used to calculate spatial diversity responses of plant-communities to land-use changes (all experimental plots 2008-2018).

title: Temporal pair-wise comparisons of arthropod-community and land-use data (all experimental plots 2008-2017)
abstract: Land-use intensification is considered a major driver of biodiversity loss. However, most evidence for land use effects come from space-for-time substitutions, comparing biodiversity in areas differing in current land use intensity. Despite their frequent use, the robustness of space-for-time substitutions in capturing temporal changes in biodiversity remains unclear. We compared spatial and temporal responses of plant and arthropod communities to changes in land-use intensity, using 150, ten-year time series from grasslands in three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) from sampling years 2008-2018 (this dataset, 31921, 31924, 31926). This data set comprises the data used to calculate temporal diversity responses of arthropod-communities to land-use changes (all experimental plots 2008-2017).

title: Spatial pair-wise comparisons of arthropod-community and land-use data (all experimental plots 2008-2017)
abstract: Land-use intensification is considered a major driver of biodiversity loss. However, most evidence for land use effects come from space-for-time substitutions, comparing biodiversity in areas differing in current land use intensity. Despite their frequent use, the robustness of space-for-time substitutions in capturing temporal changes in biodiversity remains unclear. We compared spatial and temporal responses of plant and arthropod communities to changes in land-use intensity, using 150, ten-year time series from grasslands in three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) from sampling years 2008-2018 (this dataset, 31921, 31924, 31925). This data set comprises the data used to calculate spatial diversity responses of arthropod-communities to land-use changes (all experimental plots 2008-2017).

title: Information on the sources of seeds used in the study of seed and seedling traits of grassland species occurring in the grassland experimental plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories
abstract: Seed and seedling traits are important functional traits related to dispersal (seed morphology), storage of reserves (seed mass and chemistry) and species establishment (seedling traits), which were studied for as many species as possible occurring in the grassland experimental plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. Here, we provide information on the sources (suppliers and regional provenances) of seeds used for the study of seed and seedling traits. This work was part of the project SeedDiv within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Acoustic indices on forest experiment (FOX) 2023
abstract: Soundscpaes can be described by a multitude of acoustic indices. These indices are a measure of the structure (temporal and/or spectral) of the soundscape. Often, these indices are correlating with e.g. vocalizing species diversity. A diversity of acoustic indices, was calculated on recordings made at the Forest Experiment (FOX) sites at three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). Recordings were made in spring (24.04. - 18.06.2023), summer (22.07. - 30.08.2023) and winter (10.12.2023 - 20.01.2024).

title: Predictions of anthropophony, biophony, geophony, or silence on audio recordings from forest xperiment (FOX) plots
abstract: Soundscapes are composed of 3 major components: biophony (sounds of the biotic environment), geophony (sounds of the abiotic environment) and anthopophony (anthropogenic sounds). We prepared predictions of major soundscape components on audio recordings. We trained a deep neural network (DNN) using the CNN-10 architecture, a pre-trained audio neural network (PANN) developed by Kong et al. (2020), subsequently fine-tuned by us on the publicly available EDANSA2019 dataset. This dataset contains the predictions for anthropophony, biophony, geophony, or silence on audio recordings from forest experiment three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). Audio recordings were made in spring (24.04. - 18.06.2023), summer (22.07. - 30.08.2023) and winter (10.12.2023 - 20.01.2024).

title: List of potential extensification/conservation measures in Schorfheide Chorin (2008) and their assignment to soil productivity classes
abstract: To improve Agri-Environment Schemes (AES), we must consider ecosystem complexity, encompassing multiple species and various ecological aspects beyond simple species counts. By adapting an existing spatio-temporal explicit model for cost-effective optimization of AES, we developed a simulation procedure for cost-effective grassland AES allocation based on the ecological value of specific single and joint conservation goals and the cost of management measures. To do so, and based on the grassland management practices in the region Schorfheide Chorin (SCH) in 2008 and the calculation of ecological attributes such as plant and butterfly richness on the experimental plots, we selected some potentially effective management measures for conservation and extensification. Not all measures would be suitable on all plots, therefore assumptions were made for the potential assignment of measures to soil productivity classes. A short description of the measures is also included.

title: List of potential extensification/conservation measures assigned in Schorfheide Chorin (2008) per site with cost of the measure and value of the attributes per measure and site
abstract: In this compiled dataset the ecological effects of a measure which is directly linked to a plot in Schorfheide Chorin (SCH) are assigned to other plots in the region where the measure can potentially be implemented and is expected to lead to similar ecological effects. The costs of the measures for SCH are also included. This dataset has been used for optimisations of the ecological effects per ecological goal and for cost-effective allocation/optimisation of measures based on the cost-benefit ratio of measures for region SCH (see dataset ID 31816).

title: Main cost parameters used in cost calculations for grassland measures in Swäbische Alb and Schorfheide-Chorin
abstract: Grassland extensification results in forgone yield and thus forgone income for farmers. Therefore, to motivate more farmers for such measures, economic policy instruments such as agri-environmental payments offer a financial incentive to compensate for the income forgone. To estimnate these costs of grassland measures we consider the forgone yields and also changes in variable costs (including changes in labor costs) when implementing a measure different from the reference profit-maximizing reference land use. For tthe cost calculations the land use data from BEXIS was combined with cost parameters and reference grassland uses from available regional data bases. Here the main cost parameters and their sources used for calculating the costs are presented.

title: Hyphobox experiment, Heidfeldhof Hohenheim, 2020
abstract: How the availability of different organic substrates influences the assembly and functionality of hyphosphere microbial communities is still poorly understood, particularly under natural field conditions. To address this, we constructed so-called ‘hyphoboxes’ separating a rhizosphere, hyphosphere, and substrate compartment, with the hyphosphere and substrate compartments accessible only to microbes but not to roots using a 50-µm mesh. The substrate compartment was amended with 13C-15N-labeled organic substrates of different complexity, i.e., the amino acid arginine and root litter. The hyphoboxes were buried in a temperate grassland soil at the Heidfeldhof (University of Hohenheim) for 20 weeks (between January and June 2020), allowing us to investigate the effects of the substrates on the assembly of hyphosphere microbial communities and the transfer of substrate-derived 15N via hyphosphere microbes into plant roots.

title: 16S microbiome data from grassland sites on Schwäbische Alb
abstract: From May to August 2022, samples of microbial communities associated to different hosts across the trophic chain were sampled on grassland plots on the Schwäbische Alb (22 plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories + 6 independent plots subjected to pig slurry fertilization) to assess the impact of fertilization on the microbiome of different hosts. Trophic compartments under study were soil, rhizosphere, root endosphere and flowers of Trifolium pratense, earthworms, bumblebees (Bombus lapidarius) and voles. Samples were taken on two time points, before fertilization and after fertilization. This dataset only contains before fertilization samples (R1). These samples were subjected to illumina sequencing of the V4 region of the 16s rRNA gene and stored as raw fastq files in the NCBI database.

title: Vegetation summary in 2024 without species identities for the new grassland experiment REX and LUX on 45 Grassland EPs
abstract:
Land-use changes are major drivers of plant diversity in grasslands in all three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). However, how effective a reduction in land use intensity is in recovering plant diversity is unclear, and deliberate sowing of some plants may be necessary to restore grassland diversity. Furthermore, different components of land use, e.g. mowing, fertilizing, and grazing, are correlated with each other, and therefore assessing the effect of individual components of land use requires disentangling them experimentally. In the new grassland experiments REX and LUX, we study the effect of reduced land use intensity and seed sowing on plant diversity. For this, we compare factorially combined plots with regular and reduced land use that were seeded or not-seeded with additional plants. Furthermore, we study the effect of individual components of land use. For this, we compare factorially combined plots with regular and reduced land use with or without fertilization.

This dataset is containing general data of the REX (Reduced Land-use Intensity experiment) and the LUX (Land-use experiment) surveys from 2024. These data are the date of survey, vegetation height, the cover of the 2 m x 2 m survey plot (shrubs, herbs, lichens, litter, deadwood, rocks, bare soil), vascular plant species richness, cumulative cover, and dry biomass. 

This dataset doesn't contain individual species identity and cover.

The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: 16S rRNA gene (V3 region) DNA-based analysis of bacterial soil communities at sequence variant level in all reduced land-use intensity experiment (REX) and land-use experiment (LUX) plots, using QIIME2-based bioinformatics, 2021
abstract: We determined the bacterial community composition in all treatments of all reduced land-use intensity experiment (REX) and land-use experiment (LUX) plots. Here, we isolated DNA from soil and sequenced V3 16S rRNA gene amplicons. Note that via extraction of DNA the entire bacterial community is captured, which includes also dormant, inactive cells or even dead cells. The data are provided as quality-checked but non-rarefied read counts of distinct exact sequence variants (Callahan et al 2017). A bacterial sequence variant in this data set is defined by a specific nucleotide sequence of the V3 16S rRNA gene region of 165 base pair length. That means, bacterial sequence variants are distinguished at the level of single nucleotide differences.

title: Soil nutrient content of grassland plots on the Schwäbische Alb in 2022
abstract: From May to August 2022, soil samples  were taken on 17 selected grassland plots on the Schwäbische Alb exploratories (plus 6 plots located on the Schwäbische Alb, but not within the biodiversity exploratories framework) to analyze the impact of fertilization on soil microbial communities. To assess the impact of soil nutrient content, we analyzed the soil samples for their nutrient content in macronutrients (NO3, Norg, P, K, Ca, Mg, B, S) and micronutrients (Mn, Fe, Cu, Zn) as well as Sodium content (Na). Samples were taken before fertilization (R1) or after fertilization (R2) and 4 individual samples were taken from each plot. For nutrient analysis, these 4 samples were pooled to one sample per plot and time point.

title: Codebook on the relationships of farmers' nature values and land management
abstract: This codebook entails the meta-data as well as coding sheets for our coding of foresters' nature values in relationship to their management approaches. Between May and November 2021 we interviewed 14 farmers in Schwäbische Alb to better understand how their nature values, preferences for nature's contributions to people, and management approaches are interconnected. The interviews were transcribed using NVIVO (2022) software, checked manually, and coded using in MAXQDA (2022). Due to anonymity reasons this dataset contains the coding set used to analysed the interview transcripts as well as the binary code derived from these.

title: R Script for Project "Spatial pair-wise comparisons of plant- and arthropod-community and land-use data (all experimental plots 2008-2017/18)"
abstract: Land-use intensification is considered a major driver of biodiversity loss. However, most evidence for land use effects come from space-for-time substitutions, comparing biodiversity in areas differing in current land use intensity. Despite their frequent use, the robustness of space-for-time substitutions in capturing temporal changes in biodiversity remains unclear. We compared spatial and temporal responses of plant and arthropod communities to changes in land-use intensity, using 150, ten-year time series from grasslands in three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) from sampling years 2008-2018. This dataset provides the link to the R sciript stored in GitHub/Zenodo linked to the datatset assembly and analysis of spatial pair-wise comparisons of plant- and arthropod-community and land-use data (all experimental plots 2008-2017/18). First this script provides the source couls that assembles the data used in the analyses and is provided in its assembled form already in BEXIS (31921, 31924, 31925, 31926). Second, this script provides the analytical steps for analysing spatial and temporal diversity responses of plant- and arthropod-communities to land-use changes (all experimental plots 2008-2018).

title: Collembola communities as corrected metagenomic read abundances from soil samples for all 150 grassland plots (2021)
abstract:
Collembola are a diverse group of globally occurring terrestrial microarthropods. Many thousands of individuals may occur in a single squaremeter of soil. Collembola feed on a wide variety of different resources, including leaf litter, fungi, bacteria, roots and algae. Thus, they are important regulators of microbial biomass and influence soil nutrient cycling as well as the soil structure. 

We generated this Collembola species inventory to investigate  effects of land-use types and other biotic and abiotic factors on soil Collembola communities and interactions among them.
The samples were taken in April 2021 on all 150 grassland plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories.

title: Vegetation records in the FOX-experiment in forests, 2020 - 2024
abstract: Open gaps in forest create important habitats for many forest species and offer opportunity for forest regeneration. However, in how far these gaps differ in their effect depending on the former forest management, remains unclear and is often tested in observational studies only. Moreover, the importance of deadwood, which may accumulate in such gaps, for the diversity of other taxa is poorly understood. Therefore, we established a factorially combined forest gap experiment called FOX  (forest gap experiment). On each of 29 forest experimental plot (EPs) (8 in the Schwäbische Alb, 9 in Hainich-Dün, 12 in Schorfheide-Chorin), four plots were created, two of which contained a gap of ca. 20 m diameter, in which all trees were felled, and two plots with non-felled forest. Into half of the plots, deadwood stems were added. Plant diversity was estimated on a subplot of 5 m x 5 m by estimating the abundance of each plant species, including the overhanging trees and shrubs and we provide them in this dataset. From this data, we calculate plant diversity and the changes in vegetation composition over time. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Vegetation summary data in the FOX-experiment in forests without species identity, 2024
abstract: Open gaps in forest create important habitats for many forest species and offer opportunity for forest regeneration. However, in how far these gaps differ in their effect depending on the former forest management, remains unclear and is often tested in observational studies only. Moreover, the importance of deadwood, which may accumulate in such gaps, for the diversity of other taxa is poorly understood. Therefore, we established a factorially combined forest gap experiment called FOX. On each of 29 forest experimental plots (EPs) (8 in the Schwäbische Alb, 9 in Hainich-Dün, 12 in Schorfheide-Chorin), four plots were created, two of which contained a gap of ca. 20 m diameter, in which all trees were felled, and two plots with non-felled forest. Into half of the plots, deadwood stems were added. For an area of 5 x 5 m, on which plant abundances were estimated in summer. We estimated the cover of bryophytes, deadwood, rocks, and bare soil, when they exceeded 5 % of the plot area. In addition, the number of vascular plant species and the cumulative cover is calculated. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Vegetation records for 151 forest EPs, 2009 - 2024
abstract: Long-term monitoring of plants is an important element to assess the effect of forest management on the functioning of ecosystems. Plants and their diversity affect other trophic groups and the temporal stability of the plant community is an important indicator of ecosystem functioning. Therefore, we assess the diversity of vascular plants on 151 forest plots from three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) that differ in their management, ranging from unmanaged forests, to selection forests, where individual trees are felled individually, to age-class forest. For this, we estimate the abundance of each plant species on an area of 20 m x 20 m both in spring and in summer, separately in different layers (herb layer, shrub layer, tree layer < 10 m, and tree layer > 10 m and provide them in this dataset. From this data, we calculate plant diversity as well as trends and variability of individual plant species over time. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Vegetation summary data for 150 forest EPs without species identity, 2024
abstract: Long-term monitoring of plants is an important element to assess the effect of forest management on the functioning of ecosystems. Plants and their diversity affect other trophic groups and the temporal stability of the plant community is an important indicator of ecosystem functioning. Therefore, we assess the diversity of vascular plants on 150 forest plots from three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) that differ in their management, ranging from unmanaged forests, to selection forests, where individual trees are felled individually, to age-class forest. On an area of 20 m x 20 m, on which we estimate the abundance of each plant species, we estimated the cover of bryophytes, litter, rocks, bare soil and deadwood. Moreover, the total number of plant species and the cumulative cover of all plants is given. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi on all 150 forest plots (from Soil Sampling Campain 2011; Illumina MiSeq) - AMF abundances
abstract: Arbuscular mycorrhiza represents one of the oldest symbiosis. The mutualism between plant roots and fungi of the subphylum Glomeromycotina is beneficial for both partners. Due to the extraradial mycelium the fungus is able to assess and provide limited nutrients such as phosphorus. Moreover, arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (AMF) enhance the plant’s tolerance against biotic and abiotic stressors. In return, the plant supplies photoassimilated carbon to the heterotroph fungal partner. Though the estimated richness of AMF is relatively low with 350-1000 species, they associate with more than 70% of all plants, including almost all economical relevant plant groups (with exception of Brassicaceae). Accordingly, AMF are of high ecological and economical value. Though the symbiosis is obligate for the fungal partner, the dispersal can be uncoupled from the plant. Still, current literature claims a low endemism of AMF globally. Nevertheless, local AMF communities are shaped by edaphic factors and anthropogenic effects like management and land-use intensity. Within the Core Project 8 "Microbiology", our task is to regularly monitor the AMF diversity and community composition within soils of all Experimental Plots (EPs) in three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). We here provide the AMF data from the soil sampling campaign 2011 accessed on all forest EPs.

title: Arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi on all 150 grassland plots (from Soil Sampling Campain 2014; Illumina MiSeq) - AMF abundances
abstract: Arbuscular mycorrhiza represents one of the oldest symbiosis. The mutualism between plant roots and fungi of the subphylum Glomeromycotina is beneficial for both partners. Due to the extraradial mycelium the fungus is able to assess and provide limited nutrients such as phosphorus. Moreover, arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (AMF) enhance the plant’s tolerance against biotic and abiotic stressors. In return, the plant supplies photoassimilated carbon to the heterotroph fungal partner. Though the estimated richness of AMF is relatively low with 350-1000 species, they associate with more than 70% of all plants, including almost all economical relevant plant groups (with exception of Brassicaceae). Accordingly, AMF are of high ecological and economical value. Though the symbiosis is obligate for the fungal partner, the dispersal can be uncoupled from the plant. Still, current literature claims a low endemism of AMF globally. Nevertheless, local AMF communities are shaped by edaphic factors and anthropogenic effects like management and land-use intensity. Within the Core Project 8 "Microbiology", our task is to regularly monitor the AMF diversity and community composition within soils of all Experimental Plots (EPs) in three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). We here provide the AMF data from the soil sampling campaign 2014 on all grassland EPs.

title: General soil fungi on agricultural plots (from soil pilot sampling April 2024; Illumina MiSeq) - OTU abundances
abstract:
In terms of biomass, activity and interactions, fungi are one of the key groups of soil living organisms. Recent advances in next generation sequencing and investigation of fungal diversity within soil habitats led to re-evaluate the estimated fungal species richness from 1.5 to 5 Mio taxa. Fungi are heterotrophs and behave as saprotrophs, pathogens or symbionts. They exist in multiple and tight interactions to living or dead plants. Consequently, the diversity and functioning of terrestrial ecosystems largely depend on soil fungal communities that dictate not only the primary mobilization and cycling of major nutrients but also influence the competition and co-existence of plant communities. However, the biodiversity and biogeographic patterns of soil fungi are decoupled from those of plants at the global scale, which reflects that not only plants but also climatic, edaphic, and spatial variables operating at smaller scales and anthropogenic effects like management and land-use intensity are predictors of fungal diversity and community composition. 
Within the Core Project 8 “Microorganisms”, our task is to regularly monitor the fungal diversity and community composition within soils of all Experimental Plots (EPs) in three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). We here provide the general fungal data retrieved from the pilot sampling of the newly established agricultural plots, taken in April 2024.
