title: Bat activity on forest experimental (FOX) plots in 2023
abstract:
Managed forest ecosystems are a fundamental pillar to the conservation of biodiversity. However, whether and how stand-scale management interventions can support biodiversity and associated ecosystem functions is yet unclear. Here we focused on the group of European insectivore bats, which are important top-down predators of herbivorous insects and guard forests against insect pests.
Using a full factorial experimental design, which included canopy gap creation and deadwood enrichment, we assessed weather and how species richness, relative abundance and behavior of bats and their functional groups, as well as species composition differ due to experimental treatment. Bat activity at all forest experiment (FOX) sites was assessed using acoustic monitoring. Recordings were conducted in summer 2023 (mid-June - mid-September).

title: Model to predict anthropophony, biophony, geophony, or silence in audio data
abstract: This dataset contains a model for predicting major soundscape components on audio recordings. We trained a deep neural network (DNN) using the CNN-10 architecture, a pre-trained audio neural network (PANN) developed by Kong et al. (2020), subsequently fine-tuned by us on the publicly available EDANSA2019 dataset. This dataset contains the corresponding model files. The motivation behind this it to enable biologists or interested researchers to automatically obtain information about the soundscape composition in audio recordings, and thus, recording sights, such that the info can be used for further analyses.

title: Arthropod suction sampling in agricultural plots, counted individuals per higher taxonomic group (2024)
abstract: Arthropods were sampled in the agricultural plot to compare arthropod densities between grassland and agriculture. A biocoenometer (i.e. "suction sampler") was used quantitatively collect arthropods. Per plot, arthropods were sucked out of two times 1 m². Specimens were separated from debris and counted. The dataset contains counted individual numbers per higher taxonomic group (mostly order). This dataset contains data for the 2024 sampling. Further years may be added later. Metadata (e.g. sampling dates, vegetation cover) for the sampling are available in dataset 31965.

title: Metadata for arthropod suction sampling in agricultural plots
abstract: Arthropods were sampled with a biocoenometer (i.e. "suction sampler") in the agricultural plot to compare arthropod densities between grassland and agriculture. This dataset contains the metadata (date, time, vegetation parameters) for the arthropod data in dataset 31964. This dataset contains metadata for the 2024 sampling. Further years may be added later.

title: Metadata for arthropod suction sampling in grassland experiments
abstract: Arthropods were sampled with a biocoenometer (i.e. "suction sampler") in the grassland experiments to test if reduction of land use influences atrhropod communities. This dataset contains the metadata (date, time, vegetation parameters) for the arthropod data in dataset 31967. This dataset contains metadata for the 2021 and 2023 sampling. Further years may be added later.

title: Arthropod suction sampling in grassland experiment, counted individuals per higher taxonomic group (2021, 2023)
abstract: Arthropods are sensitive to land use. To test whether the reduction of land-use intensity influences arthropod abundances and composition, a suction-sampler was used to quantitatively collect arthropods in the grassland experiments including the adjacent EPs (Experimental Plots, i.e. control). Per plot (RP: reduced land use plot; UP: unfertilized plot, EP), arthropods were sucked out of two times 1 m². Specimens were separated from debris and counted. The dataset contains counted individual numbers per higher taxonomic group (mostly order). This dataset contains data for the 2021 and 2023 samplings. Further years may be added later. Metadata (e.g. sampling dates, vegetation cover) for the samplings are available in dataset 31966.

title: Supplementary material: A trait-based model to describe plant community dynamics in managed grasslands (GrasslandTraitSim.jl v1.0.0)
abstract:
The supplementary material consists of five directories:

The model code and files for creating the documentation/tutorials are stored in Model_code_GrasslandTraitSim_v1/, the model is licensed under GNU General Public Licence v3.0

The data preparation script to process the raw data to the input and calibration/validation datasets and calibration/validation scripts are stored in Calibration_GrasslandTraitSim_v1/

The raw data for creating inputs and calibration/validation data is stored in Raw_data/

The input data is stored in Input_data/

The calibration/validation data is stored in Calibration_data/

title: M(i) - mowing intensity index for all grassland plots since 2006
abstract:
All 150 grassland plots of all regions have been investigated since 2006. Using these extensive data, we propose a new compound index for estimating the site-specific mowing intensity in order to facilitate assessment of the impact of mowing intensity on biodiversity and ecosystem processes. Our index integrates the various qualitative components of mowing machine type, mowing height and use of a conditioner, with the annual number of cuts.
The newly proposed index achieves a much finer gradation of mowing intensity compared to the previous quantification based on the number of cuts only. The proposed mowing intensity index offers enhanced precision in calculations and can easily be integrated into calculations with the LUI.

title: Plant trait measurements in experimental plots (not all) of grasslands
abstract: Plant trait measurements on species sampled in field campaigns of the SeBAS project from 2020, 2021 and 2023 in experimental plots (EPs) of grasslands. Plant species with at least one percent cover in quadrats of 1m² were sampled for trait measurements. In total, species inventories were done for three quadrats of each 1m² per plot and therefore traits of up to three individuals per plant species were measured. The following aboveground plant traits were measured or calculated: vegetative height, reproductive height, chlorophyll content measured as SPAD, leaf area (LA), leaf succulence index (LSI), leaf water content (LWC), leaf mass per area (LMA), leaf dry matter content (LDMC) and specific leaf area (SLA).

title: Vegetation records in forest plotwise sorted over 2009 - 2024 from all regions. Document is compiled for foresters and stakeholders (in German)
abstract: To provide long-term trends of plant species on each of the 151 forest plots from 2009 to 2024, we compiled data of plant cover, cover of functional groups and species richness (from data sets 31945 and 31946). This dataset is compiled for foresters and stakeholders and provided in three Excel files, one for each region. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Vegetation records in grassland plotwise sorted over 2008 - 2024 from all regions, biomass included. Document is compiled for farmers and stakeholders (in German)
abstract: To provide long-term trends of plant species on each of the 150 grassland plots from 2008 to 2023, we compiled data of plant cover, cover of functional groups, species richness, and biomass (from data sets 31893 and 31909). In addition, the data set indicates which plant species are regional characteristic species (Kennarten). This dataset is compiled for farmers and stakeholders and provided in three Excel files, one for each region. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Spatial species distribution of vascular plants in the FOX canopy gaps (G, GD) along a north-south transect in all regions, 2024
abstract: Various studies showed that plant diversity is not uniformly distributed across forest gaps. Here, we investigated diversity distribution patterns in the experimentally created stand clearances from the FOX experiment (forest gap experiment) in all three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). Vegetation surveys were conducted on the regeneration subplots which are arranged on a north-south transect and included presence/absence data of all plant species that rooted within the subplot. Within the regeneration subplots of 3 m x 4 m, we only sampled a one-meter-wide band closest to the north-south transect (3 m x 1 m). Data was collected between June and August 2024. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Tree and shrub cover in the FOX canopy gaps (G, GD) along a north-south transect in all three regions, 2024
abstract: Various studies showed that plant diversity is not uniformly distributed across forest gaps. Here, we investigated diversity distribution patterns in the experimentally created stand clearances from the FOX experiment (forest gap experiment) in all three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). Vegetation cover estimations of trees and shrubs were conducted on the regeneration subplots which are arranged on a north-south transect. Within the regeneration subplots of 3 m x 4 m, we only surveyed a one-meter-wide band closest to the north-south transect (3 m x 1 m). Tree and shrub cover serve as a proxy for light availability for herbs. Data was collected between June and August 2024. The data collection was part of the core project Botany within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: Plant species inventories in experimental plots (not all) of grasslands for trait measurements
abstract: Plant species inventories were conducted in grassland experimental plots (EPs) within the scope of the SeBAS project for the years 2020, 2021 and 2023. Two field campaigns (spring and autumn) took place in each of the years. The abundance of all plant species occurring in three separate quadrats of each 1m² along the eastern or western plot margin was estimated in percentage.

title: Rao's Q based on NDVI of Sentinel-2 images for grasslands in Schorfheide-Chorin and Hainich-Dün
abstract: The dataset contains four raster files on the Rao's Q dissimilarity index (Rocchini et al. 2017) for grasslands of the regions Schorfheide-Chorin and Hainich-Dün, each for the years 2020 and 2021. It was calculated based on the normalised vegetation index (NDVI) of Sentinel-2 satellite images (Magdon et al. 2024, ID 30969) of the time slices 24.05.2020 and 23.05.2021. The R package rasterdiv (Rocchini et al. 2021) was used for the calculation. The R script is attached to this dataset (see attachments). The raster files have the coordinate reference system (CRS) EPSG 3044 and a spatial resolution of 10x10m.

title: Red List Germany status of arthropods
abstract: Many species are in decline and threatened, for example, due to intensive land use. The status of species in Germany is assessed in the German Red List (Rote Liste Deutschland). This dataset is a compilation of the various taxa-specific Red Lists (downloaded and processed September and October 2023, using the most actual list for each taxon) and contains information on threat, temporal trends and other aspects covered in the German Red Lists. Information is available for all higher level taxa that are (or have been) assessed in the monitoring data of project Arthropods Core. Taxonomies between Arthropod Core data and Red List data has been harmonized to facilitate merging of data.

title: Red List Germany data for synthesis data sets
abstract: Many species are in decline and threatened, for example, due to intensive land use. The status of species in Germany is assessed in the German Red List (Rote Liste Deutschland). This dataset is a compilation of the various taxa-specific Red Lists (downloaded and processed September and October 2023, using the most actual list for each taxon) and contains information on threat, temporal trends and other aspects covered in the German Red Lists. Information is available for all higher level taxa that are (or have been) included in the synthesis data for forest and grassland. Taxonomy between synthesis data and Red List data has been harmonized to facilitate merging of data.

title: Meta-data including soil parameters, RNA content and calculated LUI for the evaluation of the metatranscriptome dataset (31880) - Soil sampling campaign 2021, all experimental plots (EP), 0-10 cm
abstract: This CSV file is a summary of the soil parameters, RNA content and calculated LUI for simplified evaluation of the metatranscriptome dataset (31880). The samples were taken from all grassland EPs (0-10 cm) in May 2021 as part of the soil sampling campaign. Soil parameters include gravimetric water content (Dataset 31075), soil pH (Dataset 31074), and bulk density and content of organic carbon, total nitrogen and total sulfur (Dataset 31872). To determine the RNA content, the RNA was extracted using phenol-chloroform extraction (core project microorganisms). The calculated LUI contains the following parameters: Standard components set, standardized, global, all years.

title: High Terestrial Laserscanning (hTLS) derived digital elevation models for all Forest Experiment (FOX) plots
abstract: Terrestrial laser scanning (TLS) was utilised to derive high-resolution digital elevation models (DGMs). The Forest Experiment (FOX) plots of Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb were scanned using a terrestrial laser scanner mounted on an extendable tripod at an altitude of 8 m during the leaf-off season. The gaps were scanned using a multi-scan approach of five positions. The resulting digital elevation model (DGM) provides a high level of detail regarding the microtopographic structure of the area.

title: BE-Publications
abstract: Die Daten der BExIS Publikationen wurden mit weiteren Informationen angereichert, um später

title: EP Grassland Landuse Information ALB 2025
abstract:
Information about the land use on the EPs in 2025, based on information given by the farmers or on observations by members of the exploratories.
This file will be updated continuously.
It should be used only for fieldwork planning, NOT FOR ANALYSIS!.

title: Metabarcoding of arthropods from suction sampling in grassland experiments 2021
abstract: Arthropods were sampled in May 2021 with a biocoenometer (i.e. "suction sampler") in the grassland experiments to test if reduction of land use influences arthropod communities. This dataset contains the results of metabarcoding of specimens. Data on relative reads are given. Metadata (date, time, vegetation parameters) for the same samples is available in dataset 31966. Counts of specimens per higher taxonomic group are available in dataset 31967.

title: processed 16S microbiome data from grassland sites on Schwäbische Alb
abstract: From May to August 2022, samples of microbial communities associated to different hosts across the trophic chain were sampled on grassland plots on the Schwäbische Alb (22 plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories + 6 independent plots subjected to pig slurry fertilization) to assess the impact of fertilization on the microbiome of different hosts. Trophic compartments under study were soil, rhizosphere, root endosphere and flowers of Trifolium pratense, earthworms, bumblebees (Bombus lapidarius) and voles. Samples were taken on two time points, before fertilization and after fertilization. This dataset only contains before fertilization samples (R1). These samples were subjected to illumina sequencing of the V4 region of the 16s rRNA gene and are available as a metadata-text file, taxonomy.biom file and a tree file to be combined for further use as aphyloseq object in R

title: R Script and data for "Functional and phylogenetic beta diversity response of nocturnal moth assemblages to land-use intensity in grasslands and forests"
abstract:
Land-use intensification causes homogenization of landscapes and filtering of species with specific traits, ultimately leading to functionally and phylogenetically simplified communities. In Central Europe, the two major steps of land-use intensification are the conversion of forests to agriculture, and the intensification of land-use practices within both habitats. Moths, a diverse taxon in these habitats, exhibit various morphological traits and lineages making them ideal for studying yet unknown effects on functional and phylogenetic homogenization. Using light-trap data from three regions in Germany, each representing land-use gradients in forests and grasslands, we tested the hypothesis of decreasing beta diversity with increasing land-use intensity. 

This dataset encompasses the figshare link to the R Script and raw data of the manuscript, which ich currently under peer review.

title: Raw Collembola metagenomes from 150 grassland plots (2021)
abstract:
Collembola are a diverse group of globally occurring terrestrial microarthropods. Many thousands of individuals may occur in a single squaremeter of soil. Collembola feed on a wide variety of different resources, including leaf litter, fungi, bacteria, roots and algae. Thus, they are important regulators of microbial biomass and influence soil nutrient cycling as well as the soil structure.

We generated Collembola metagenomes from all 150 grassland plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories, in the regions Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin in Germany, to investigate effects of land-use types and other biotic and abiotic factors on soil Collembola communities and interactions among them.

The data will be available on NCBI (date of release: 31.12.2025 or upon publication).

title: Deadwood-associated invertebrates, 9 forest plots Schorfheide, BELongDead, 2011- 2017
abstract: The BELongDead Experiment was initiated to study effects of tree species identity and forest stand attributes on saproxylic communities and wood decomposition. Freshly cut logs of 13 different tree species were placed on 30 forest plots in 2009/2010. Invertebrate samples (without beetles and true bugs) from closed emergence traps taken 2011, 2013, 2015 and 2017 from the nine Schorfheide plots were analyzed using metabarcoding.

title: Camera trapping of vertebrate scavengers on FOX plots
abstract: Observations of removal of small carrion by vertebrate scavengers using camera traps in summer 2023 (21.05.-02.08.) and summer 2024 (30.04.-31.07.)

title: Potential nitrification, microbial biomass C and N (Cmic, Nmic), soil mineral nitrogen (Nmin), soil sampling campaign (SSC) 2023, all grassland experimental plots (EPs)
abstract: This dataset derives from soil samples of the SSC2023 for 0-10 cm depth in three regions of Germany: Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide Chorin. It includes measurements on potential nitirication, Cmic, Nmic, Nmin of all 150 grassland EPs plots. This dataset is part of a study relating soil organic matter pools with complete and canonical nitrifiers.

title: Potential nitrification, soil sampling campaign (SSC) 2021, all experimental plots (EPs)
abstract: Potential nitrification activity was measured for all forest and grassland experimental plots (EPs), with soil samples of 0-10 cm depth from the soil sampling campaign (SSC) 2021 in the three german regions Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, and Schorfheide-Chorin. This dataset together with other years can serve to have a detailed understand the N cycle in all forest and grassland plots for further synthesis.

title: Gene abundance nitrification, AOA, AOB, nxrA NB, 16S NS, comammox, 16S bacteria, 16S archaea, soil sampling campaign (SSC) 2023, all grassland experimental plots (EPs)
abstract: This dataset derives from soil samples of SSC2023 for 0-10 cm depth for three regions in Germany: Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide Chorin. It contains absolute gene abundance of nitrification functional genes: ammonia oxidizing archaea (amoA AOA), ammonia oxidizing bacteria (amoA AOB), nitrospira nitrite oxidizers (16S rRNA NS), nitrobacter nitrite oxidizers (nxrA NB), complete ammonia oxidizers (amoA comammox), bacteria (16S rRNA bacteria), archaea (16S rRNA archaea) from qPCR. Soil samples correspond to 0-10 cm depth. This dataset is part of a study relating soil organic matter pools with complete and canonical nitrifiers.

title: Gene abundance nitrification comammox, 16S archaea, soil sampling campaign (SSC) 2014, all grassland experimental plots (EPs)
abstract: This dataset derives from soil samples of soil sampling campaign (SSC) in 2014 from 0-10 cm depth for three regions in Germany: Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide Chorin. It contains absolute gene abundance of nitrification functional genes: comammox, 16S archaea from qPCR.  This dataset is part of a study relating soil organic matter pools with complete and canonical nitrifiers.

title: Small mammal camera trap raw data on Schwäbische Alb forest gap experiment (FOX) plots 2024
abstract: The aim of this study was to investigate the influence of abiotic factors, more specific gaps in the canopy, and biotic changes caused by deadwood accumulation on small mammals. Using customized wildlife cameras, small mammals were recorded and data on relative abundance, diversity and species richness were collected on forest gap experiment plots (FOX) of the Schwäbische Alb Biodiversity Exploratory. This dataset contains tabuladed species-identified observations per plot and subplot with date and time.

title: Methane potential and soil respiration of reduced land-use intensity experiment (REX1) 2023
abstract:
On all 45 reduced land-use intensity experiment (REX1) plots and 15 additional grassland experimental plots (EPs) with historically low land-use intensity, we analyzed soil from Schorfheide-Corin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb taken from two depths (0-10 and 20-30 cm) in the soil sampling campaign in May 2023. We incubated the soil in mesocosms in duplicate and measured potential methane oxidation rates (PMOR) and carbon dioxide (CO2) production with gas chromatography under atmospheric conditions. Moreover, we measured the production potential for methane (CH4) and CO2 production under anoxic conditions. 
Additionally, we measured functional gene abundance from the field samples in qPCR. We quantified 3 different types of pmoA genes encoding the particulate methane monoxygenase to quantify the abundance of methanotrophic bacteria. Upland soil cluster (USC) y and α representing two groups involved in atmospheric methane oxidation and general pmoA representing a broad range of different methanotrophs. We quantified the abundance of mcrA which is used as a biomarker for methane producing Archaea (methanogens).

title: Seedling trait data of 180 grassland species used in the publication: Different from the start: key dimensions of seedling traits of temperate grassland species
abstract:
During the last two decades, the research on plant functional traits has advanced rapidly. However, so far, research has focused on traits of adult plants, while research on seedling traits is scarce. Seedling traits, however, could play an important role during plant establishment from seeds and they are essential to understand the full plant life cycle. We studied seedling traits related to the timing of germination and seedling development (number of days until germination, time until two leaves developed), above- and belowground morphological seedling traits (seedling height, specific leaf area (SLA), root tissue density, specific root length), relative growth rate as well as seedling above- and belowground biomass in the stage, when seedlings had developed the first two true leaves. For this, we examined ca 229 temperate grassland species in a microcosm experiment under ambient light and temperature conditions in an open greenhouse (at the UFZ Field Station Bad Lauchstädt, Saxony-Anhalt, Germany) between November 2020 and July 2022. 
The microcosm experiment was part of the project SeedDiv within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de).

title: BELongDead fungi sporocarp inventory 2020
abstract: The BELongDead experiment was conceived in 2008 under the direction of Prof. E. D. Schulze (MPI Biogeochemistry Jena) with the intention to monitor the impact of habitats on the dead wood decomposition processes and to observe colonization patterns of various saproxylic organisms over long time. Its central questions are I) how does the surrounding ecosystem influence wood decomposition, II) how does succession of the substrates proceed and III) how do microorganisms mediate wood decay and subsequently impact ecosystem processes like element turnover and storage. This enables us now to investigate the direct influence of different forest management regimes on a sizeable set of 12 (+1 less frequent) different dead wood tree species each homogenous in their initial wood properties (decay stage, volume, water content) and evenly distributed in replicates across plots, landscapes and management types.

title: Soil animal group-level data from a recolonization experiment across 48 forest plots in 2017
abstract: Soil animals play a critical role in ecosystem services, including the decomposition of organic matter, maintenance of soil structure, and regulation of biological populations. These functions are significantly impacted by disturbances from climate change and human activities, which alter soil microbial and animal community compositions. Drought, in particular, negatively affects forest soil animal communities, reducing both abundance and diversity. This study examines the recolonization of defaunated soil plots by macro- and mesofauna across various forest types and regions in Germany. 48 experimental plots within the Biodiversity Exploratories in Schorfheide, Hainich, and the Swabian Alb were utilized. Defaunated mesocosms were reintroduced to their original plots, with recovery assessed after six months and sampled in May 2017.

title: Data and code for the manuscript 'Schreiner et al. (2025). The potential of land-use extensification as grassland restoration tool.'
abstract:
This is supporting information for the manuscript ‘Schreiner et al. (2025). The potential of land-use extensification as grassland restoration tool.’ 

The data and the code are made available in a folder structure that allows the statistical analyses, the figures and the tables of the manuscript to be reproduced: 

The ‘scripts’ folder contains an R markdown script and the corresponding HTML document. 

The ‘data’ folder contains a csv file with the data and an xlsx file with the corresponding metadata. 

Figures generated by the script can be found in the html document in the ‘scripts’ folder. Tables generated by the script can either be found in the ‘output’ folder (static tables) or in the html document or in the ‘scripts’ folder (interactive tables).

title: Bat activity on Experimental Plots (EP) in the National Park Hainich 2021
abstract: Bat monitoring across all Exploratories and Plots was conducted to evaluate the effect of land use intensity and management applications in forests and grasslands and to assess potential changes in abundance patterns to previous monitoring campaigns. This is a subset of the overall dataset for the National Park Hainich-Dün to provided bat species observations data on experimental plots (EP) within the National Park. Bat species activity was determined by acoustic recordings using Batcorders (EcoObs). Recordings were conducted in summer 2021. Each EP was visited for one night per month (June, July, August).

title: BE-Publications
abstract: Die Daten der BExIS Publikationen wurden mit weiteren Informationen angereichert, um später

title: BE-Publications
abstract: Die Daten der BExIS Publikationen wurden mit weiteren Informationen angereichert, um später

title: Soil parameters of reduced land-use intensity experiment (REX1) 2023
abstract:
On all 45 reduced land-use intensity experiment (REX1) plots and 15 additional grassland experimental plots (EPs) with historically low land-use intensity, we analyzed soil taken from two depths (0-10 and 20-30 cm) from Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün, and Schwäbische Alb in the soil sampling campaign in May 2023.  
We measured soil parameters to analyze how they affect gas fluxes in soil incubations and functional genes from methane cycling (pmoA and mcrA) in qPCR (32025). Parameters measured are bulk density, gravimetric soil water content (SWC), pH, Nmin, Ammonia, Nitrate, microbial biomass nitrogen (Nmic), extractable organic carbon (EOC), and extractable total nitrogen (ETN).

title: Germany-wide single tree LiDAR data set
abstract: The data set contains 7033 automatically segmented High Terrestrial Laser Scanning (hTLS) and  Unmanned Aerial Laser Scanning (ULS) point clouds. Additionally, for a a selection of decidiuous trees Quantitative Strutcture Models (QSMs) are provided.

title: LiDAR derived single tree metrics
abstract: Single tree metrics and crown polygons derived from High Terrestrial Laser Scanning (hTLS) and Unmanned Aerial Laser Scanning (ULS).

title: Land cover assessment of trees and grass 200 m around the centroid of plots with wild bee trap nests
abstract: Using land cover maps from the European Land Monitoring Service, with a resolution of 10 m², within a 300 m radius of each plot’s centroid (where the weather station is located) we classified was based on three categories – trees, grasses, and built-up areas – each expressed as a percentage of the total area within the 300 m radius .

title: Stoichiometric composition of bees in wild bee trap nests
abstract: In 2020 we placed wild bee trap nests in several plots across the three exploratories. We collected filled reeds and froze the bees for analysis of their composition as well as pollen, using stoichiometrical analyses of elements.

title: Wild bee nest occupation and identification through barcoding 2020-2022
abstract: In 2020 we placed wild bee trap nests in plots in the three exploratories. We filled them with bamboo reeds in February and collected filled reeds from April-September, refilling them after removal of reeds. We used the collected larvae to answer different questions, mostly related to understanding bee diversity and composition in relation to pollen diversity and composition, under the influence of land use and landscape elements (e.g., soil type, vegetation cover).

title: Stoichiometry of pollen composition of wild bee nests
abstract: In 2020 we used pollen from our wild bee nests to analyze the elemental composition of pollen stored by Osmia sp. in filled cells. We had wild bee nests in several plots across the exploratories and placed bamboo reeds in February, later to be collected when filled by solitary bees on regular periods between April and July. We extracted pollen from those reeds per cell and performed metabarcoding and stoichiometrical analysis to assess the plant diversity of origin and the elemental composition of the pollen loads that are fed to larvae.

title: Fungal community composition at forest plots (VIP) in nutrient hotspots and soil samples -  Illumina MiSeq raw data external link
abstract: This external link is part of the ECTOMYC project: the organic and inorganic nitrogen (N) and phosphorus (P) utilization and fungal community variation. To explain the fungal colonization of the nutrient container surfaces, we applied amplicon sequencing to nutrient containers and closed soils in all regions, Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, and Schorfheide-Chorin. Samples were taken in October 2022 and 2023. The fungal dataset contains the external link to the raw sequencing data upload at NCBI.

title: Soil metagenomes from 55 grassland plots, soil sampling campaign (SSC) 2017
abstract:
We determined the genetic potential and in parallel their taxonomy of microbes in grassland soils to investigate changes in the community due to LUI (and-use-intensity index). Here we provide raw metagenome sequencing data from a subset of soil samples of grassland experimental plots in three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). The samples correspond were taken during the soil sampling campaign (SSC) 2017.
Raw sequencing data have been deposited in the NCBI Sequence Read Archive (SRA) under accession number PRJNA1240958 and will be available after publication (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sra/PRJNA1240958).

title: Biocrust metagenomes from 59 forest plots of biocrust and bulk soil samples, 2018
abstract:
We determined the genetic potential and in parallel the taxonomy of microbes in forest biocrusts and bulk soils to investigate changes in the community due to the formation of this hotspot. Here we provide raw metagenome sequencing data from biocrust and bulk soil samples of forest experimental plots in three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). The samples correspond were taken in Spring 2018.
Raw sequencing data will be deposited in the NCBI Sequence Read Archive (SRA) and will be available after publication (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sra/).

title: Diazotrophic communities in deadwood of 13 temperate tree species after nine years of elevated N deposition
abstract: Biological nitrogen fixation (BNF) by diazotrophic microorganisms contributes to increasing nitrogen (N) availability in nutrient-poor deadwood. Chronically elevated atmospheric N deposition may also increase N availability in deadwood and thereby reshape the diazotrophic community and decrease BNF rate in deadwood. Here, we simulated high N deposition by repeated addition of ammonium-nitrate to deadwood of 13 tree species in a field experiment over 9 years (N treatment) and investigated shifts in the diazotrophic community structure and BNF rates in deadwood compared to non-fertilized controls. The N treatment reduced overall BNF rates by 43%, increased total N concentration by 60% in deadwood, and increased diazotrophic richness in coniferous than in broadleaved deadwood. Furthermore, N treatment altered the diazotrophic community structure, by increasing the relative abundance of Bradyrhizobium and by reducing Methylocapsa across all tree species. BNF was positively correlated with nifH gene abundance in broadleaved deadwood under N treatment but showed a negative correlation in coniferous deadwood. Co-occurrence network analysis revealed more interconnected and modular networks in the N treatment, with diazotrophs (i.e. Azospirillum) occupying central roles in broadleaved deadwood and fungi (i.e. Meliniomyces, Athelia) in coniferous deadwood. Additionally, tree clade influenced the richness, and the response of diazotrophic communities to N treatment, with coniferous and broadleaved trees showing distinct patterns in diazotrophic richness and community composition under N treatment. These findings indicate that diazotrophs in deadwood sustain BNF under high N deposition through adjustments in their community composition.

title: Denitrification genes nirK, nirS, soil sampling campaign (SSC) 2023, all grassland EPs
abstract: This dataset derives from soil samples of SSC2023 for 0-10 cm depth for three regions in Germany: Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide Chorin. It contains absolute gene abundance of denitrification functional genes: nirK and nirS from qPCR. This dataset is part of a study relating soil organic matter pools with complete and canonical nitrifiers.

title: EnMAP hyperspectral satellite images for exploratory regions
abstract:
EnMAP, short for Environmental Mapping and Analysis Program, is a German hyperspectral satellite mission designed to provide high-resolution, hyperspectral imagery of Earth's surface with spatial resolution of 30m. EnMAP is equipped with a hyperspectral imager capable of capturing data across 230 spectral bands, covering the visible to near-infrared (VNIR: 420–1000 nm) and shortwave infrared (SWIR: 900–2450 nm) ranges.

Satellite data was acquired for the years 2022 to 2024 for all three Exploratories (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün, and Schwäbische Alb). The data is provided as surface reflectance products directly by EnMAP.

title: Soil animal species-level data from a recolonization experiment across 48 forest plots in 2017
abstract: Soil animals play a critical role in ecosystem services, including the decomposition of organic matter, maintenance of soil structure, and regulation of biological populations. These functions are significantly impacted by disturbances from climate change and human activities, which alter soil microbial and animal community compositions. Drought, in particular, negatively affects forest soil animal communities, reducing both abundance and diversity. This study examines the recolonization of defaunated soil plots by macro- and mesofauna across various forest types and regions in Germany. Experimental plots within the Biodiversity Exploratories in Schorfheide, Hainich, and the Swabian Alb were utilized. Defaunated mesocosms were reintroduced to their original plots, with recovery assessed after six months in spring 2017. This dataset contains data on species level of Oribatida, Collembola, Isopoda, Diplopoda and Chilopoda.

title: Losers and winners: Responses of grassland arthropods to land-use components - for all grassland plots from 2008-2018
abstract:
Intensified land-use in grasslands reduces biodiversity, particularly affecting arthropod populations. However, responses of individual species vary depending on their ecological traits and habitat requirements. Some species may tolerate or even benefit from intensive land-use, while others, particularly specialists or those with narrow niches, are likely to be negatively affected.
We used a quantitative niche model to evaluate species-specific responses to land-use intensity in four arthropod orders common in grasslands: Araneae, Coleoptera, Hemiptera, and Orthoptera. From 2008 to 2018, a total of 214,416 individuals across 1352 species were collected on 150 grassland plots across three regions of Germany. The effects of mowing, fertilizing, and grazing on species occurrence and abundance were evaluated with their niche optima to identify winners, losers, and neutrals.
Mowing showed the fewest winners (10.6%) and fertilizing the most losers (37.4%), both being the most detrimental land-use components. Nevertheless, most species showed neutral responses (63.5%). The niche optimum of grazing favored smaller species, whereas mowing and fertilizing favored larger species. Herbivores were particularly sensitive to fertilizing. Comparison with the Red List revealed that species under mowing exhibited lower niche optima with higher-risk categories, which also was reflected with declining population trends.

title: Carbon, nitrogen, d15N, d13C, and bulk density of grassland plots - soil sampling campaign 2023
abstract: This dataset contains data for the top 10cm of soil obtained during the deep soil sampling of the SSC2023. Deeper layers will be part of a separate dataset. It includes soil organic carbon and soil total nitrogen concentration and stocks, C/N ratio, bulk density, and d15N and d13C isotopic signatures. Samples were taken to determine difference in concentrations of C, N and the natural abundance of d15N and d13C across the land use gradient present within the three exploratories (Schorfheide-Chorin, Haunich-Dün, and Schwäbische Alb).

title: General soil fungi on all forest plots (from Soil Sampling Campaign 2011; Illumina MiSeq) - OTU abundances
abstract:
In terms of biomass, activity and interactions, fungi are one of the key groups of soil living organisms. Recent advances in next generation sequencing and investigation of fungal diversity within soil habitats led to the estimated fungal species richness of 1.5 to 5 Mio taxa. Fungi are heterotrophs and behave as saprotrophs, parasites or symbionts. They exist in multiple and tight interactions to living or dead plants. Consequently, the diversity and functioning of terrestrial ecosystems largely depend on soil fungal communities that dictate not only the primary mobilization and cycling of major nutrients but also influence the competition and co-existence of plant communities. However, the biodiversity and biogeographic patterns of soil fungi are decoupled from those of plants at the global scale, which reflects that not only plants but also climatic, edaphic, and spatial variables operating at smaller scales and anthropogenic effects like management and land-use intensity are predictors of fungal diversity and community composition. 

Within the Core Project 8 (Microorganisms), our task is to regularly monitor the fungal diversity and community composition within soils of all Experimental Plots (EPs) in three German regions (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin). We here provide the abundance of the general soil fungal operational taxonomic units (OTU = species equivalent) from the soil sampling campaign 2011 on all forest EPs.

title: General soil fungi on all 300 experimental plots (from Soil Sampling Campaign 2011, 2014, 2017, 2021 and 2023; Illumina MiSeq) - fungal OTU taxonomic look-up table
abstract:

Recent advances in next generation sequencing and investigation of fungal diversity within soil habitats led to the estimated fungal species richness of 1.5 to 5 Mio taxa. We here provide the abundance, taxonomy and functional guild of the general soil fungal operational taxonomic units (OTU = species equivalent) from the soil sampling campaigns 2011, 2014, 2017, 2021 and 2023 on all EPs.

title: 3rd dead wood inventory of all forest plots, item volumes, 2022 - 2024
abstract:
Deadwood is a critical resource for many decomposers, which is emphasised by the fact that about a quarter of all forest species depend on it. In contrast to other resources, the amount and diversity of deadwood is subject to forest management. We therefore monitor deadwood dynamics in the various forest types in the exploratories. 

On all forest experimental plots (EP) in the three Exploratories (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün and Schorfheide-Chorin) downed and standing deadwood and stumps is inventoried every six years using a stratified sampling design.

title: Land use in grasslands: raw data of mowing activities on new experimental plots
abstract: The present dataset summarises and compares management information about all mowing activities collected from 2020 ongoing for the 45 new experimental RP plots and their related EP plots. Data are based on annual interviews of the respective farmers, land owners or tenants involved in land management acticity, using a standardised questionnaire (DS ID 26006 - in German) and information by the local management teams.

title: Metagenomic analysis of Bos taurus, Ovis aries and Microtus arvalis fecal pool samples
abstract:
We aimed to analyse the composition of the bacterial, antimicrobial resistnace genes (ARG) and virulence factor (VF) community of livestock and wildlife inhabiting the same plots at the same time in order to determine possible transmission of agents between livestock and wildlife. Also one reference plot without grazing of livestock was analyzed.
Samples were taken in September 2020 on three plots (HEG7, HEG20, HEG26) in the Hainich-Dün exploratory. Link to the following data (raw sequence reads, metagenome-assembled genomies, Interactive iTOL) are provided here.
This dataset is connected to the publication 32137 "Insights into microbial composition, antimicrobial resistance and virulence factor gene dynamics in grassland ecosystems".

title: BTE 2014 Fungal community composition at roots of young beech – Illumina sequencing raw data external link
abstract: This external link is part of the ECTOMYC project: BTE (Beech Transplantation Experiment). Fungal bar coding was conducted with roots of beech, which had been outplanted in the BTE experiment. In this experiments, young beech plants were grown from beech nuts, which had been collected in in Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, and Schorfheide-Chorin. Bare-rooted seedlings were planted in 2012 and harvested in 2014 as described in data sets 20028 and 20029. Here, we applied amplicon sequencing to fine roots from seedlings harvested in Schwäbische Alb (ALB), Hainich-Dün (HAI), and Schorfheide-Chorin (SCH). This dataset contains the external link to the raw sequencing data upload at NCBI

title: Effective Number of Layers (ENL), Stand Structural Complexity Index (SSCI), and Canopy Openness next to the climate station on all forest plots in summer 2023 and winter 2024
abstract:
Based on terrestrial laser scanning data (TLS), the effective number of layers (ENL) quantifies vertical stand structure by applying the inverse Simpson-Index to the vertical distribution of points in 3D space. Index values increase with increasing stand height and a more even occupation of 3D space by foliage, branches and stems along the vertical axis. 

The Stand Structural Complexity Index (SSCI) is an approach based on fractal dimensions to quantify the structural complexity of forest stands. It is based on the three-dimensional spatial arrangement of all above-ground tree components and makes it possible to analyze relationships between management types, forest structure, biodiversity and ecosystem functions objectively and efficiently. The higher the value of the SSCI, the greater the complexity of the stand.

Canopy Openness describes the average light availability on the ground of a forest stand, with values ranging from 0 % (no sky visible) to 100 % (no plant material visible).

The data was collected on 150 forest plots in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hanich-Dün, and Schwäbsiche Alb). To capture the seasonal changes in three-dimensional forest structure, we conducted a single terrestrial laser scan next to the climate station on each forest plot in leaf-on conditions between June and August 2023 as well as in leaf-off conditions (only deciduous wood) between January and March 2024.

title: Effective Number of Layers (ENL), Stand Structural Complexity Index (SSCI), and Canopy Openness for all forest EPs in leaf-off conditions
abstract:
Based on terrestrial laser scanning data (TLS), the effective number of layers (ENL) quantifies vertical stand structure by applying the inverse Simpson-Index to the vertical distribution of points in 3D space. Index values increase with increasing stand height and a more even occupation of 3D space by foliage, branches and stems along the vertical axis. 

The Stand Structural Complexity Index (SSCI) is an approach based on fractal dimensions to quantify the structural complexity of forest stands. It is based on the three-dimensional spatial arrangement of all above-ground tree components and makes it possible to analyze relationships between management types, forest structure, biodiversity and ecosystem functions objectively and efficiently. The higher the value of the SSCI, the greater the complexity of the stand.

Canopy Openness describes the average light availability on the ground of a forest stand, with values ranging from 0 % (no sky visible) to 100 % (no plant material visible).

The data was collected on 150 forest plots in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hanich-Dün, and Schwäbsiche Alb). We made five systematically distributed single-scans with a terrestrial laser scanner (in the center, north-east, north-west, south-west, and south-east) on each of the deciduous forest plots in leaf-off conditions between January and March 2024. For the coniferous forest plots, we used data from existing datasets (terrestrial laser scanning during summer 2023; ID: 31651, 31652, 31653) and adapted it to our sampling design.

title: Nutrient concentrations and fibre contents in plant biomass at all grassland experimental plots, 2020-2024
abstract: The increase in agricultural management intensity has influenced vegetation patterns, composition and dynamics through increased vegetation disturbance (mowing, grazing) and altered soil fertility (fertilization). The chemical composition of the aboveground plant biomass- used as an indicator for plant nutrition and productivity- and fibre fractions of grassland biomass- used as measure of the quality and nutritive value of herbage fodder- both integrate spatial and temporal variation on soil resources during the growing season (Klaus et al, 2011). We used the material of the annual biomass sampling across the 150 grassland experimental plots taken by the botany core project in May/June 2020 - 2024 before management took place. Biomass nutrients (N, P, K, Ca, Mg) and fibre contents were determined with Near Infrared Reflectance spectroscopy (NIRS).

title: Soil bulk density and organic carbon, total nitrogen and total sulfur stocks - soil sampling campaign 2023, all reduced land-use intensity experiment (REX) and land-use experiment (LUX) plots, 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the soil bulk density and the soil organic carbon (OC), total nitrogen (TN) and total sulfur (TS) stocks in 0-10 cm depth from all reduced land-use intensity experiment (REX) and land-use experiment (LUX) plots in 2023. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soils are important reservoirs for carbon, nitrogen and sulfur. The storage of organic carbon and nutrients is not only important for climate regulation and plant growth but also affects other soil functions. A multitude of natural factors (e.g. climate, parent material, landscape position) but also human-induced factors (e.g. land use type, management intensity) influence the potential of soils to store carbon and nutrients. Bulk density is used to calculate elemental stocks but at same time it is also an important indicator of the degree of soil compaction. It therefore greatly affects the water and solute movement in soils and the soil aeration.The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-5, TR 1054/4-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Soil bulk density and organic carbon, total nitrogen and total sulfur stocks - soil sampling campaign 2023, all forest gap exeriment (FOX) plots, 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the soil bulk density and the soil organic carbon (OC), total nitrogen (TN) and total sulfur (TS) stocks in 0-10 cm depth from all forest gap experiment (FOX) plots in 2023. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soils are important reservoirs for carbon, nitrogen and sulfur. The storage of organic carbon and nutrients is not only important for climate regulation and plant growth but also affects other soil functions. A multitude of natural factors (e.g. climate, parent material, landscape position) but also human-induced factors (e.g. land use type, management intensity) influence the potential of soils to store carbon and nutrients. Bulk density is used to calculate elemental stocks but at same time it is also an important indicator of the degree of soil compaction. It therefore greatly affects the water and solute movement in soils and the soil aeration.The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-5, TR 1054/4-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Soil pH - soil sampling campaign 2023, all reduced land-use intensity experiment (REX) and land-use experiment (LUX) plots, 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides essential information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the soil pH values in 0-10 cm depthfrom all reduced land-use intensity experiment (REX) and land-use experiment (LUX) plots in 2023. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil pH is considered a master variable in soil science as it affects many chemical processes in soils. Most importantly, the plant nutrient availability is greatly affected by the soil pH as it controls the chemical forms of the different nutrients and influences the chemical reactions they undergo. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-5, TR 1054/4-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Mass of aboveground litter, all forest gap exeriment (FOX) plots
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the mass of aboveground litter (total weight, weight of leaves+rest, fruits, branches, and twigs)carbon (C) of from all forest gap experiment (FOX) plots in from 2019 until today. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-3, SCHR 1181/2-4, SCHR 1181/2-5, TR 1054/4-3, TR 1054/4-4 TR 1054/4-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Carbon, nitrogen and sulfur concentrations in aboveground litter, all forest gap exeriment (FOX) plots
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the carbon (C), nitrogen (N) and sulfur (TS) concentrations in the aboveground litter (leaves+rest, fruits, branches, and twigs) in all forest gap experiment (FOX) plots from 2019 until today. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-4, SCHR 1181/2-5, TR 1054/4-3, TR 1054/4-4  TR 1054/4-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Soil carbon, nitrogen and sulfur concentrations - subsoil sampling 2023, all medium intensity research plots (MIP), 0-100 cm
abstract:
The core project Soil provides essential information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all 300 Experimental Plots (EPs) of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the organic carbon (OC), inorganic carbon (IC), total nitrogen (TN) and total sulfur (TS) concentrations, and carbon to nitrogen ratios (CN ratio) as well as carbon to sulfur ratios (CS ratio)  in 0-10 cm depth from all EPs in 2023. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil organic carbon, nitrogen and sulfur concentrations are master variables in soil science. They are the measureable components of soil organic matter (SOM). SOM exerts positive effects on numerous physical, chemical and biological soil properties. An increase in SOM generally results in an improved soil structure, soil moisture retention, soil buffering capacity, retention of pollutants, cycling and storage of plant nutrients and biodiversity. SOM also acts as a sink and source for atmospheric carbon dioxide.

The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-5, TR 1054/4-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Sampling protocol - soil sampling campaign 2024, all arable plots, 0-10 cm
abstract:
The core project Soil provides essential information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all 300 Experimental Plots (EPs) of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the three sampling protocols of the coordindated soil sampling for the EPs, the REX-LUX experiment, and the FOX experiment. Together with core projects 8, 1 and 2 (Microorganisms, BEO; LMTs), we organized the 4th soil sampling campaign on all 300 Experimental Plots of the Exploratories in May 2023. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). At all plots composite samples from the mineral soil (0-10 cm depth) were sampled. At all forest plots additional samples from the organic layer were taken. We used the same sampling design as in 2011, 2014, 2017, 2021 to allow comparisons with previous soil samplings campaigns.
The soil sampling protocol considered the requirements of each of the 12 participating soil groups. Approximately 90 people from 2 core projects and 10 contributing projects were involved in the fieldwork.

The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-5, TR 1054/4-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).
