title: Sampling protocol - soil sampling campaign 2023, all reduced land-use intensity experiment (REX) and land-use experiment (LUX) plots, 0-10 cm
abstract:
The core project Soil provides essential information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all 300 Experimental Plots (EPs). This dataset contains the sampling protocol of the coordindated soil sampling of the REX-LUX experiment. In 2023, together with core projects 8, 1 and 2 (Microorganisms, BEO; LMTs), we organized the 5th soil sampling campaign. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). At all plots composite samples from the mineral soil (0-10 cm depth) were sampled. We used the same sampling design as in 2021 to allow comparisons with the previous soil samplings campaign. The soil sampling protocol considered the requirements of each of the participating soil groups. Approximately 90 people from 4 core projects and 8 contributing projects were involved in the fieldwork.

The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-5, TR 1054/4-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: Large mammal camera trap raw data on Schwäbische Alb forest gap experiment (FOX) plots 2024
abstract: The aim of this study was to investigate the influence of abiotic factors, more specific gaps in the canopy, and biotic changes caused by deadwood accumulation on large mammals. Using a classic camera trap design large mammals were recorded and data on relative abundance, diversity and species richness were collected on forest experiment plots (FOX) of the Schwäbische Alb Biodiversity Exploratory. This dataset contains tabuladed species-identified observations per plot and subplot with date and time.

title: Tick collection on 25 Schwäbische Alb forest plots 2023 - 2024
abstract:
Ticks, particularly Ixodes ricinus, and the associated Lyme borreliosis risk are of great importance in the One Health sector, prompting extensive research in this field. However, comprehensive studies including all potential influencing factors – such as landscape characteristics, local forest structure and management, climate, and host community composition – alongside tick density measures and Borrelia spp. infection status are scarce.

This study aimed to investigate I. ricinus tick density and Borrelia prevalence as a function of a wide range of habitat variables, as well as the abundance and diversity of the mammal community. For this purpose, ticks were collected using the flagging method, and mammals were monitored using an innovative camera-trapping approach on 25 experimental plots within the Biodiversity Exploratory “Schwäbische Alb” in Baden-Württemberg, Germany, in spring, summer, and autumn 2023 as well as in spring 2024.

The raw camera-trap data used to calculate mammal metrics are available in a separate dataset (Dataset ID: 32111 (large mammals) and 32113 (small mammals)). The tick dataset includes the number of flagged ticks per sampling event, their developmental stage (larva, nymph, male or female), the plot on which they were collected, as well as the season and year of collection.

title: Large mammal camera trap raw data on 25 Schwäbische Alb forest experiment plots (MIPs) 2021-2024
abstract: The aim of this study was to monitor large mammals as a function of forest management intensity. Using a classic camera trap design large mammals were recorded and data on relative abundance, diversity and species richness were collected on 25 forest experiment plots (MIPs) of the Schwäbische Alb Biodiversity Exploratory between December 2021 and August 2024. This dataset contains tabulated species-identified observations per plot and subplot with date and time.

title: Soil carbon and nitrogen content, soil moisture and pH value (0-10cm) in three quadrats along N-S grassland plot margin in spring and autumn 2023
abstract: Soil was sampled in grassland experimental plots (EPs) of all three regions within the scope of the SeBAS project in two field campaigns (spring and autumn) in the year 2023. Soil samples were collected in three 1m² quadrats situated along the eastern or western plot margin, where biomass had been previously cut in areas measuring 60 x 60 cm. Soil carbon and nitrogen content as well as soil moisture and pH value were measured. These soil measurements were carried out in the same quadrats in which the species inventories and plant traits were measured for the SeBAS project in order to capture the small-scale heterogeneity of soil conditions. Furthermore, aliquots of soil samples were analysed by the SpaceMic project in terms of microbial communities.

title: Small mammal camera trap raw data on 25 Schwäbische Alb forest experiment plots (MIPs) 2021-2024
abstract: The aim of this study was to investigate the influence of forest management intensity on small mammals. Using customized wildlife cameras, small mammals were recorded and data on relative abundance, diversity and species richness were collected on 25 forest experiment plots (MIPs) of the Schwäbische Alb Biodiversity Exploratory in summer and autumn 2023 and in spring 2024. This dataset contains tabulated species-identified observations per plot and subplot with date and time.

title: List of synthesis proposals in the Biodiversity Exploratories
abstract: The dataset contains an overall overview of all proposed synthesis ideas inside the Exploratories project. The status of the proposal is updated yearly by BEO. Please contact BEO with any needed additions, updates, questions, or remarks.

title: Microsatellite data of Myodes glareolus and Microtus arvalis
abstract:
This dataset is part of the publication :
Kauer, L., Imholt, C., Jacob, J. et al. Assessing the effects of land-use intensity on small mammal community composition and genetic variation in Myodes glareolus and Microtus arvalis across grassland and forest habitats. Landsc Ecol 40, 1 (2025). https://doi.org/10.1007/s10980-024-02021-9
https://rdcu.be/ejDIK
Dataset: 31789
Metadata, R-scripts and raw datat are found on DataDryad (Link below).

This study aimed to evaluate the effects of land-use intensity on small mammal diversity in grassland and forest habitats, as well as on genetic variation patterns driven by geographic (isolation by distance) and environmental distance (isolation by resistance) factors.

Methods
Genetic analyses were conducted on Myodes glareolus and Microtus arvalis populations from each habitat, using microsatellites. Maximum Likelihood Population Effects models were employed to elucidate gene flow patterns and significant differences in genetic structure based on land-use intensity.
Analysis was conducted on rodent samples taken in september 2020 in the Hanich-Dün region on 15 grassland and 15 forest plots.

title: Thyreophagus corticalis on Ixodes ricinus, Schwäbische Alb
abstract: Phoretic deutonymphs of Thyreophagus coticalis were found associated with a male and nymphs of Ixodes ricinus during a sampling conducted in May 2024 in the district of Reutlingen, Baden-Württemberg, Germany, using the flagging method. A total of six deutonymphs were detected on four of the 652 ticks collected, indicating a low incidence. Therefore, we consider that the phoretic association of T. corticalis with I. ricinus reported here for the first time is likely to be coincidental, possibly resulting from the ticks coming into contact with organic or decaying material where T. corticalis populations occurred.

title: Spider (Araneae) in pitfall traps in grassland EPs 2020
Compiled data used in "Rules of size and colour: Responses of forest insect communities to temperature and solar radiation"
abstract:
This dataset contains all data and RScript used in "Rules of size and colour: Responses of forest insect communities to temperature and solar radiation". This study investigates the responses of body size and colour lightness of predominantly diurnal Coleoptera and Heteroptera and nocturnal Lepidoptera to the environmental variables temperature and solar radiation at different climatic scales. We used linear mixed effect models to test the response of mean community values to macro-, meso-, and micro-climatic variables. The data analysis was part of the project GapResin within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories.
This work is based on data inter alia elaborated by the Arthropods and TreeScape projects of the Biodiversity Exploratories program (DFG Priority Program 1374). All datasets are publicly available and listed in the Reference section. Annotated R code, including the data needed to reproduce the statistical analyses and figures, will be publicly available from Zenodo (DOI to be added upon acceptance). During peer review, all information is available from figshare using the following link: https://figshare.com/s/4908138a894fd28b2351

title: Large mammal camera trap data on 25 Hainich- Dün forest experiment plots (MIPs) 2020-2021
abstract: The aim of this study was to monitor large mammals as a function of forest management intensity. Using a classic camera trap design large mammals were recorded and data on relative abundance, diversity and species richness were collected on 25 forest experiment plots (MIPs) of the Hainich-Dün exploratory between spring 2020 and autumn 2021.

title: Pathogen content from bees
abstract: We collected bees and recorded plant-bee visitations in May and June 2020 and in April, May, June and August 2021 on three sites in Germany and one site in Belgium. The sites in Germany contained plots that were part of the Biodiversity Exploratories: the Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb Exploratory (Fisher et al., 2010), while the site in Belgium contained plots in the province of Flemish Brabant that were managed by the nature conservation organization Natuurpunt vzw. Bees that were to be screened for pathogens were collected in 58 German and 9 Belgian plots. Within each sampling site, plots were on average 13.280 km apart from each other (minimum 0.220 km, maximum 35.910 km). Samples from a subset of 26 plots were used in network analyses (see below).

title: Corresponding R-Script for the paper "Local and landscape factors differently influence health and pollination services in two important pollinator groups" (Straub et. al, 2025, id=31709)
abstract: The R-Script contains all relevant information for the analysis of the data relevant in the paper. In the paper, we investigated links between local and landscape-level land-use, health and pollination services in common pollinators, the bumblebee Bombus lapidarius and the syrphid fly Episyrphus balteatus, by measuring various traits as proxies for pollinator health and pollination services.

title: Vegetation records for grasslands in the landscape Schwäbische Alb (2023)
abstract: Predicting and understanding spatial patterns of grassland plant diversity at the landscape scale is a major challenge in ecological research. To reliably assess the accuracy of these spatial prediction maps, independent validation data is required. This dataset contains 50 4x4 m vegetation plots randomly sampled in the landscape Schwäbische Alb. In these plots, we estimated the abundance of each plant species during May and June 2023. The data collection was part of the project "BEyond" within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories.

title: Vegetation records for grasslands in the landscape Thüringer Becken (2024)
abstract: Predicting and understanding spatial patterns of grassland plant diversity at the landscape scale is a major challenge in ecological research. To reliably assess the accuracy of these spatial prediction maps, independent validation data is required. This dataset contains 50 4x4 m vegetation plots randomly sampled in the landscape Thüringer Becken. In these plots, we estimated the abundance of each plant species during June 2024. The data collection was part of the project "BEyond" within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories.

title: δ13C values of soil animal groups derived from compound-specific isotope analysis of essential amino acids (CSIA-AA)
abstract: Specifically, stable isotope ratios of 13C/12C (δ13C) in essential amino acids (eAAs) synthesised by bacteria, fungi and plants can be distinguished, due to lineage-specific enzymatic pathways. Most animals cannot synthesise eAAs de novo at sufficient rates and must obtain them from dietary proteins, resulting in little to no isotopic fractionation of eAAs across trophic levels. This allows tracing of δ13C values in eAAs of consumers back to their basal resource and thus to quantify the relative importance of bacteria, fungi and plants for channelling carbon in soil animal food webs

title: Accounting for spatial interactions in the upscaling of ecosystem services
abstract: Maps of ecosystem service (ES) supply are frequently used to guide spatial planning, policy making, and ecosystem management. However, these are typically based upon coarse land-cover proxies. This approach lacks a strong mechanistic basis, and neglects spatial biodiversity dynamics and interactions among landscape properties that can modify ES provision. We present an analytical framework for ES upscaling that incorporates spatial interactions between landscape properties to determine ES supply. The resulting models can be viewed as a spatially informed ES production function. The framework advances existing approaches by assisting in identifying variables that represent the true drivers of change, by including spatial interactions in the upscaling model, and by incorporating expert’s feedback on the process. We demonstrate the approach using two example ES from German grasslands: biodiversity conservation and water supply. We show that the inclusion of spatial interactions in the upscaling model improved model predictions from 15% to 33% depending on the ES evaluated. In addition, inclusion of spatial interactions led to reduced error associated with the upscaled estimates.  By overcoming several shortcomings of existing, upscaling approaches we generate resulting maps of ES supply that can more reliably inform spatial planning Further, the underlying models allow for simulation of changes in the drivers of ES supply and estimation of respective outcomes. These advantages have the potential to better link detailed local-scale ecological understanding and land management with large-scale ES supply mapping, and thus better inform decision making and spatial planning.

title: Land use intensity has an impact on Borrelia burgdorferi s.l. prevalence and genodiversity in ticks from Central Germany
abstract:
Background Ticks are important vectors for zoonotic pathogens with Ixodes ricinus being the most abundant species and main vector of Borrelia burgdorferi sensu lato (s.l.), the causative agent of Lyme borreliosis. Both vector and reservoir hosts are dependent on their habitat structure which in turn is anthropogenically influenced by land use intensity. This study aimed to analyse the prevalence of B. burgdorferi s.l. and their genodiversity in ticks along a land use gradient in grassland and forest in Central Germany.
Methods Ticks were collected from 25 grassland and 25 forest sites using the flagging method, tested for Borrelia burgdorferi s.l. using real-time PCR, and positive samples were further analysed using Multi-Locus-Sequence-Typing (MLST) to identify the exact genospecies and Sequence Types. To analyse the prevalence of Borrelia and the density of I. ricinus, confidence intervals, GLMMs, LMs, GLMs (Tweedie distribution), model selection (ΔAICc < 2), Relative Abundance Index (RAI) and Shannon Index were used. 
Results In total, 210 of 1896 ticks collected tested positive for B. burgdorferi s.l. (11.08%). The prevalence in I. ricinus ticks was identical in females (48/156; 30.77%) and males (44/143; 30.77%) and lower in nymphs (118/1152; 10.24%). Ixodes ricinus collected from grassland were significantly more frequently infected (29.36%) than from woodland (6.43%). A positive correlation between land use intensity and the infection rate of ticks with Borrelia burgdorferi sensu lato has been demonstrated in both grasslands and woodlands. Further the Relative Abundance Index of predatory and small mammals showed a positive effect on Borrelia spp. prevalence in I. ricinus nymphs. For 184 samples multilocus sequence typing was performed. The most frequently found genospecies was B. afzelii (65.76%), followed by B. garinii (17.93%), B. valaisiana (13.59%), and B. burgdorferi s.s. (2.72%). Further, 59 known and 41 new different sequence types (STs) were detected. 
Conclusions Borrelia burgdorferi s.l. genotypes with zoonotic potential show variable host adaptation, which seems to promote high intraspecific pathogen diversity. Our study supports the dilution hypothesis that conserving native forests and species diversity may support Borrelia spp. biodiversity while reducing their overall prevalence.

title: Documentation of landuse and landuse change (since 2006, all exploratories)
abstract: The dataset contains the documentation of landuse and results of conducted surveys with farmers and landusers. The dataset lists the landuse type (e.g. mown pasture, pasture, meadow) of each plot in exploratory Swabian Alb, Hainich and Schorfheide for the specific year - and contains information about fertilization within the specific year (fertilised, unfertilised).

title: Untersuchung des Einflusses von Klima und Konkurrenz auf das Wachstum der  Buche (Fagus sylvatica) in  Nord-Ost-Deutschland - RWL Daten
abstract:
Am ausgewählten Baum wurde mittels eines Umfang-Maßbandes der Brusthöhendurch-messer (BHD) des Baumes in Zentimetern erfasst. Mit einer Bussole wurde für jeden be-probten Baum der Winkel gegen Nord in Gon gemessen. Sofern möglich, wurden Störfak-toren in Form von metallenen Kleidungs- und Ausrüstungsgegenständen während des Messvorganges ferngehalten. Mit dem Messgerät Vertex der Firma Haglöf wurde die Dis-tanz des Baumes zum Plot-Mittelpunkt bestimmt. Entsprechend der Hersteller-Empfehlung wurde das Gerät vor Arbeitsbeginn auf einer Referenz-Strecke von 10 m kalibriert (Bedi-enanleitung für Vertex IV und Transponder T3, 2007). Später erfolgte anhand des Winkels und der Distanz zum Plot-Mittelpunkt die eindeutige Identifikation der Probebäume auf den Stammfußkarten der FOX-Flächen und die Zuordnung der Baum-Identifikationsnummer (FOXTree-ID).

Die Bohrkernentnahme erfolgte mit dem „Haglöf Zuwachsbohrer Mora-Cortex“. Dieser wurde senkrecht zur Stammachse in den Stamm getrieben. Pro Baum wurden zwei Bohr-kerne  senkrecht zueinander auf Brusthöhe entnommen. Standardmäßig wurde von in Süd-Nord- und in West-Ost-Richtung gebohrt. Verletzungen dieser Norm erfolgten, wenn Versuchsaufbauten das Anbohren des Stammes aus der vorgesehenen Richtung verhin-derten. Die Entnahmerichtung der Bohrkerne wurde in diesen Fällen korrigiert, sodass die Versuchsaufbauten weder betreten noch beeinträchtigt, gleichzeitig die Verletzungen des Aufnahmeprotokolls aber so gering wie möglich gehalten wurden. 

Die Einbohrtiefe des Zuwachsbohrers wurde so gewählt, dass entweder die Hälfte des Baumdurchmessers deutlich überschritten wurde oder keine weiteren Umdrehungen des Bohrers mehr möglich waren. Anschließend wurde der Kern mittels des dazugehörigen Löffels aus dem Inneren des Bohrers gelöst und für den Transport zur Aufbewahrung in einen langen Strohhalm eingeführt. Im Fall eines Kernbruches wurden die Bruchstücke in der richtigen Reihenfolge sortiert und die Bruchflächen im Strohhalm möglichst bündig an-einandergefügt. Jeder Bohrkern erhielt eine fortlaufende Nummer, um diesen vorrüberge-hend einem Probebaum zuzuordnen und als weitere Nummer eins oder zwei, um die Ker-ne eines Baumes zu unterscheiden.

Während des Transportes waren die Enden der Strohhalme verschlossen. Um das Faulen der Kerne zu verhindern, wurden die Kerne zum Trocknen in Zeitungspapier eingewickelt. Die getrockneten Kerne wurden in selbstklebenden Kabelkanälen arretiert und auf einer Platte fixiert. Anschließend wurde mit einem Schwingschleifer die Oberseite der Kerne ab-geschliffen und poliert. Mit einer Lupe wurde im Laufe des Schleif-Prozesses optisch kon-trolliert, ab wann die Jahrringgrenzen des Kerns optimal zu erkennen waren (vgl. Maxwell & Larsson, 2021).

Mit dem Bildaufnahmesystem „Skippy“ (Version 1.2, Swiss Federal Institute for Forest, Snow and Landscape Research) inklusive des gleichnamigen Computerprogrammes wur-de für jeden Kern eine hoch aufgelöste Bilderserie erstellt. Der für die Aufnahme vorgese-hene Kern wurde mit seiner Platte auf den Aufnahmetisch gelegt und in das Zentrum des Kamera-Sichtfeldes bewegt. Während des Aufnahmevorganges der Bilderserie bewegte das System den Auflagetisch entgegen der Wuchsrichtung des Kernes gerade durch das Aufnahmefeld. Für jeden Kern wurde zu Anfang der Kamera-Fokus so justiert, dass dieser während der gesamten Aufnahme der Bilderserie möglichst optimal die Mitte des Kernes erfasst. 
Im darauffolgenden Arbeitsschritt wurde die Bilderserie mit dem Bildverarbeitungspro-gramm „PTGui“ zu einem einzigen Bild zusammengefügt. Das Zusammenfügen der über-lappenden Bilddateien zu einem Panoramafoto des einzelnen Bohrkernes erfolgte hierbei automatisch durch den Algorithmus des Programmes. Jedes Panorama-Bild wurde optisch auf die Bildqualität Bildschärfe kontrolliert. Bei mangelhafter Qualität des Panoramabildes wurde eine neue Bilderserie des Kernes erstellt.
 
Die Vermessung der Jahrringbreiten erfolgte unter Verwendung des Computerprogram-mes „CooRecorder“ (Cybis Elektronik & Data AB, Sweden) bis auf einen Tausendstel Mil-limeter [µm]. Zunächst erfolgte eine Primärmessung der Jahrringbreiten. Dazu wurden die einzelnen Panorama-Bilder in das Programm „CooRecorder“ geladen. Per Mausklick konnten die jeweiligen Jahrringgrenzen festgelegt werden. Um die Wuchsrichtung des Baumes abzubilden und die tatsächliche Jahrringbreite zu erfassen, erfolgte die Positionie-rung der Punkte entlang gut sichtbarer Holzstrahlen

title: Land use intensity has an impact on Borrelia burgdorferi s.l. prevalence and genodiversity in ticks from Central Germany
abstract: Ticks are important vectors for zoonotic pathogens with Ixodes ricinus being the most abundant species and main vector of Borrelia burgdorferi sensu lato (s.l.), the causative agent of Lyme borreliosis. Both vector and reservoir hosts are dependent on their habitat structure which in turn is anthropogenically influenced by land use intensity. This study aimed to analyse the prevalence of B. burgdorferi s.l. and their genodiversity in ticks along a land use gradient in grassland and forest in Central Germany. Ticks were collected from 25 grassland and 25 forest sites using the flagging method, tested for Borrelia burgdorferi s.l. using real-time PCR, and positive samples were further analysed using Multi-Locus-Sequence-Typing (MLST) to identify the exact genospecies and Sequence Types. Borrelia burgdorferi s.l. genotypes with zoonotic potential show variable host adaptation, which seems to promote high intraspecific pathogen diversity. Our study supports the dilution hypothesis that conserving native forests and species diversity may support Borrelia spp. biodiversity while reducing their overall prevalence.

title: Sweep net samples from grasslands 2020-2022: Araneae, Coleoptera, Hemiptera, Orthoptera
abstract: Arthropod diversity has been studied on all 150 grassland EP plots to provide data for various analysis, e.g. effects of land use on arthropods. The dataset contains data for 2020-2022. Note that these are preliminary data and that Heteroptera not yet included for 2021 and 2022. The full time series from 2008-2019 is available in dataset 21969. The present dataset will be merged with 21969 once data are final and complete.

title: Amplicon sequence variants, their taxonomic clasification, and relative abundace per sample in grassland experimental plots (not all) from SeBAS project of June 2023
abstract:
This dataset originates from a study investigating the drivers of soil bacterial community assembly in managed grassland ecosystems. The project focuses on understanding how spatial distance, environmental variation, and plant communities influence soil microbial diversity and distribution patterns—specifically the distance-decay relationship (DDR) of soil bacteria at local (meter) to regional (kilometer) scales. Sampling took place in June 2023 in two Biodiversity Exploratories regions in Germany: Hainich-Dün in Thuringia and Schorfheide-Chorin in Brandenburg. In total, 18 grassland plots were surveyed, each containing three 1 m² subplots arranged along a 50-meter south–north transect.

This dataset includes amplicon sequence variants (ASVs) derived from 16S rRNA gene sequencing targeting the V4 region. ASVs were inferred using the DADA2 pipeline and taxonomically classified using the SILVA reference database (v138.1). The dataset provides the relative abundance of each ASV per subplot. Raw sequences are publicly available in NCBI’s Sequence Read Archives under accession number PRJNA1284051

title: Geographic location, soil physicochemical properties, plant community composition and vegetation characteristic in grassland experimental plots (not all) from SeBAS project of June 2023
abstract:
This dataset originates from a study investigating the drivers of soil bacterial community assembly in managed grassland ecosystems. The project focuses on understanding how spatial distance, environmental variation, and plant communities influence soil microbial diversity and distribution patterns—specifically the distance-decay relationship (DDR) of soil bacteria at local (meter) to regional (kilometer) scales. Sampling took place in June 2023 in two Biodiversity Exploratories regions in Germany: Hainich-Dün in Thuringia and Schorfheide-Chorin in Brandenburg. In total, 18 grassland plots were surveyed, each containing three 1 m² subplots arranged along a 50-meter south–north transect.

The dataset includes a range of biotic and abiotic variables relevant to soil microbial ecology and plant community structure. Soil data include measurements of moisture, pH, and total carbon and nitrogen content. Vegetation data capture plant species composition, ground cover types such as bare ground, litter, green and senescent vegetation, and moss. Vegetation characteristics were also recorded, including specific leaf area (SLA) and aboveground biomass.

title: Soil carbon, nitrogen and sulfur concentrations - soil sampling campaign 2023, all reduced land-use intensity experiment (REX) and land-use experiment (LUX) plots, 0-10 cm
abstract: The core project Soil provides information on soil properties and ecosystem functions across all plots of the Biodiversity Exploratories. This dataset contains the organic carbon (OC), inorganic carbon (IC), total nitrogen (TN) and total sulfur (TS) concentrations, and carbon to nitrogen ratios (CN ratio) as well as carbon to sulfur ratios (CS ratio)  in 0-10 cm depth from all reduced land-use intensity experiment (REX) and land-use experiment (LUX) plots in 2023. Samples were collected in three regions in Germany (Schorfheide-Chorin, Hainich-Dün and Schwäbische Alb). Soil organic carbon, nitrogen and sulfur concentrations are master variables in soil science. They are the measureable components of soil organic matter (SOM). SOM exerts positive effects on numerous physical, chemical and biological soil properties. An increase in SOM generally results in an improved soil structure, soil moisture retention, soil buffering capacity, retention of pollutants, cycling and storage of plant nutrients and biodiversity. SOM also acts as a sink and source for atmospheric carbon dioxide. The data collection was part of the core project Soil within the framework of the DFG-funded joint project Biodiversity Exploratories (SCHR 1181/2-5, TR 1054/4-5, https://www.biodiversity-exploratories.de/).

title: 16S rRNA gene (V1-V3 region) RNA-based analysis of archaeal soil communities at sequence variant level in 150 forest plots, using QIIME2-based bioinformatics, 2023
abstract:
We determined the archaeal soil community composition in 300 experimental plots (EP) from grassland and forests in three regions of Germany (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) in 2023. This dataset pertains to forests only.
Here, we isolated RNA from soil and sequenced V1-V3 16S rRNA gene amplicons.The presence and amount of ribosomes in a cell can be taken as a rough proxy for activity. 
Here, the data are provided as quality-checked but non-rarefied read counts of distinct exact sequence variants (Callahan et al 2017). An archaeal sequence variant in this data set is defined by a specific nucleotide sequence of the V1-V3 16S rRNA gene region of 490 base pair length. That means, bacterial sequence variants are distinguished at the level of single nucleotide differences. The dataset contains only the data of the forest plots.

title: 16S rRNA gene (V1-V3 region) DNA-based analysis of archaeal soil communities at sequence variant level in 150 forest plots, using QIIME2-based bioinformatics, 2023
abstract:
We determined the archaeal soil community composition in 300 experimental plots (EP) from grassland and forests in three regions of Germany (Schwäbische Alb, Hainich-Dün, Schorfheide-Chorin) in 2023. This dataset pertains to forests only.
Here, we isolated DNA from soil and sequenced V1-V3 16S rRNA gene amplicons. Note that via extraction of DNA the entire bacterial community is captured. This includes also dormant or inactive cells, even including dead cells. 
Here, the data are provided as quality-checked but non-rarefied read counts of distinct exact sequence variants (Callahan et al 2017). 
An archaeal sequence variant in this data set is defined by a specific nucleotide sequence of the V1-V3 16S rRNA gene region of 490 base pair length. That means, bacterial sequence variants are distinguished at the level of single nucleotide differences. The dataset contains only the data of the forest plots.

title: 16S rRNA gene (V3-V4 region) RNA-based analysis of bacterial soil communities at sequence variant level in 150 forest plots, using QIIME2-based bioinformatics, 2021
